<question from>

Total points: 180 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is up with my whippet? =[?



Hey, I have a 1 yr old whippet and over the past year, he has been getting ill an awful lot. he must have been ill about 4 times in the past year, which I don't think is normal. He just lays there, wont eat, and goes really shaky. We always take him to the vet, and come back with the same answer - being told he has a high temerature and being sent home with some antibiotics. The only problem is that it is costing a fortune for my mum - to get him checked out is £40.00 and the antibiotics cost £20.00! We have insurance, but we have to pay an exccess of £70.00. It's getting rediculous. Does anyone know what could be up with him? Could it be an underlying problem? thank you x



</question>



<answer from>



Julien Poublon, vet
Member since: 30 July 2007



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Recurrent fever episodes surely can be secondary to a more profound illness.



Especially if your dog is insured, I recommend to try to get down to the bottom of the issue.



Basic testing includes blood and urine testing. If no answer come from those, survey chest x-rays and abdominal ultra-sound would be the next step. Joint and spinal fluid tap are also part of a more advanced investigation.



The list of potential trigger for a fever is very long. It includes local infections (kidney and Bladder, Liver abscess, Chest infection, Dental abscess, joint infection, meningitis ...) or predisposition to infections (immature immune system, porto-systemic shunt, auto-immune condition).



Best wishes, julien



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you so so much!!! Im so glad I got an answer from a proper vet! We are insured, and we took him back to the vet and he has had some blood tests and we should get the results soon. Your a life saver! :)



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



CJ

</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not a vet, but regular illness like that most likely has an underlying cause. You should discuss this with the vet and see about getting some tests done.



The other thing that you may want to consider is if your dog is regularly on anti-biotics, then he will have a low immune system and will therefore be more vulnerable to bugs and the like. Ask your vet about pro-biotics. They will help build up the good bacteria in his gut and help him fight off illness.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



It could be literally anything... have they ever done full blood-work on him? Tested everything that needs to be tested? Sounds a little like how my dog acted when she had a liver problem, which she ended up dying from (although she was quite old, so it was her time), but there are probably 100 different health issues with those same symptoms.



Have you thought about going to a different vet the next time this happens? We switched vets a few years ago, and it was honestly like night and day! We can't believe we wasted all those years going to our old vet (we call it the "bad vet"). All vets are not created equal, and a new vet might find a problem your old vet didn't. It's worth thinking about. If this were my dog, and he was getting sick over and over - which isn't normal by any means - I wouldn't be satisfied with just some antibiotics and NO solid answers, and it sounds like you aren't either. Not only is it costing you a fortune, but your dog may have a serious issue that is going untreated. A new vet definitely might be the way to go in this case!



I can only imagine how frustrated and worried you must be. I hope you get all of this figured out! Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



MamaB

</answer from>



<answer>



One of my neighbour's whippets suffers from ongoing colitis.  This affects, obviously, his bowels and he's generally not a well boy when this flares up.  I wonder if this is what's going on here?



However I'd say you need to take him back for a full blood workup/urinalysis now.  If he's showing a fever something is going on and it needs proper diagnosis (impossible on the Internet) before this becomes chronic.



If you don't get the answers you are looking for, get a second opinion/try another vet.  You are paying the bills here - I've been led by the nose recently by a vet's practice and ended up paying well over £1K, only to lose my b itch in the end.  She was terminal, but it took them 6 months to get to the bottom of what was wrong.  Every time I took her in she was given a new set of medication which I thought was going to work.  Never again will I let this happen.



Hope you get your Whippet back to full health



</answer>



<answer from>



dorothy s
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 9915 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Collect some sachets of electrolytes from the vets, they are cheap and they will help to bring your dogs temperature down. The fact that he may drink when he is poorly will not compensate if his temperature is high and he will dehydrate. Dehydration could be why he shakes. Even if he is well at present you should always have electrolytes available.
Don't tempt him to eat until he wants to, when he wants to eat,  give him  a light diet and feed him several small meals a day. Cook chicken or fish, (remove the bones and skin and discard this) and mix this with soggy rice. Or scramble eggs in water, no milk or butter and he will love this. NEVER EVER GIVE A DOG COWS MILK.
Does the problem start after he has had worming tablets or flea treatment?.



If he is on a food which contains grain change to a grain free diet. If you change, do it slowly over about three weeks.
Consider the above and it it happens again, he may have a poorly tummy. Put a pinch of bicarbonate of soda in a tablespoon of GOATS yogurt and try him with this.



Source(s):



Dorothy S



</answer>

ok, i have a 10 month old black labrador...he constantly goes outside and tries to dig to other dogs in yards that attach to ours! he's just so friendly and wants to play....he's a very smart dog so we have laid down the law and he pretty much knows not to dig but he stares at the other dogs through the fence and whines for them...most times he'd rather cry for the dog on the other side of the fence then to play with me and my little girl out the back! we had alot of trouble getting through the little puppy stage....i didn't know how much was in raising a puppy..especially a lab but now he seems a bit more mature and smart and were considering getting him a female friend (desexed of course lol) im just not sure if it would be a big mistakes seen as kodah isn't completely matured and obedient yet....some people say a friend would settle him down and some say its asking for double trouble..this is the first dog we have ever owned and i'd love your opinion..please make it kind as im a loving and caring and sensible pet owner!!):) thanks!



</question>

<answer from>



suzie
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 1196 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



ahh you won my heart when you said Lab.  I am a show person of Labradors.  I have 2.  Both black.



Yes they keep each other company and are the best, best of friends, cause Labs love company, they thrive on it.



But...and a big but.  They all start out as puppies and if you want to get another puppy you will go through exactly what you went through with Kodah.  In fact Kodah will teach the new puppy the ropes, Labs are mega intelligent and they copy ++++  I have had them most of my life I am nearly 50.  Then I could not stop at owning 1.  2 are much better.  When I am away from home I know they have each other for company.  They totally adore each other, If I take one in the car the other will cry till I come fetch that one into the car.  They play tug-o-war together, they share their bones, they compete for ball games and are great fun.  Neither dig now, in fact over the years I have had up to 5 Labs together and none digged.  Digging is a natural instinct in dogs but is mostly bought from boredom.



I say if you have the time to train them, give them what they need then go for it.  I have both mine in my bedroom now, one is on the pet bed snoring his head off and the other is on the floor sleeping peacefully.



Yes when it comes to Labs, their own company is a great distraction from boredom so long as they are from good quality stock of the kind that is not over exuberant.  Laid back, easy going typical Labs are what I have and I hope you get the same.  Research your breeder carefully first.  If you are in Australia I can give you good breeder contacts.  I just titled my male, the breeders were at the show I did this at, they were estatic as was I.



*****Bad breeding and or bad training or lack of is the cause of most exuberant Lab problems.



</answer>



<answer from>



MokaBear
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 412 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on your situation/motivations. Dogs are sociable creatures and they  naturally crave the company of other dogs. If you think your dog would benefit from getting a friend to play with, it could be a good option. however you have to wait the possible consequences: it might or might not calm him down, they could run around the house and bark at each other in a playful way... It all depends of your values.  I do believe dogs are happier when regularly in contact with other dogs. If you don't want to take the chance of having 2 crazy dogs in the house, go to the dog park more often or arrange doggy meeting with some friendly neighborhood dogs.



Source(s):



I run my own doggy day care and dog & biscuits business



</answer>

Mr. P's Person

<answer>



It's going to vary from place to place. If there are several Quality breeders where you are it will probably be a little less if there is say only one in a very large radius.



The best thing to do is contact the breed club in your area. Ask for a list of breeders in your area. Call them all as to prices. Research them all. When you find one that fits your bill recontact them to ask yo be put on their waiting list.



Unfortunately it's impossible for anyone here to tell you the price as it can vary so much.



Good luck in finding the perfect pup for you.



</answer>

<question>



Re-homing a rottweiler?



I have got to re-home one of my rottweilers , she is 12 months old , she is just like a fluffy bear (the reason been due to work commitments and moving into a smaller house ), i live in staffordshire, uk , does anyone know any where that find good caring people who love rottweilers , the one thing i am really scared of is someone having her and using her as a guard dog



</question>



<answer from>



Uggle
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 2189 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Rottweiler rescue trust should be able to help



http://www.rottweilerrescuetrust.co.uk/



Is there no way you can keep her?  There are so many homeless dogs out there - I have never known it so bad.  Rottys, staffies and other "desirable" breeds seem to be the ones most likely to end up in a rescue centre and, sadly, many of these never find a home.



If you could try and rehome her yourself, it would probably be better for her, provided that you check out whoever you give her to well.



I know that most rescues are full at the moment with beautiful, friandly dogs, but there just aren't the homes for them at the moment.  i would have thought that the above would be your best bet though, as they will do all they can to find a rescue with a place for your dog.



</answer>



<answer from>



Karens BCS
Member since: 24 October 2006
Total points: 6467 (Level 5)



</answer from>

<question>



Dog has green discharge while being pregnant?



ok so I know my dog is pregnant but she seems to be having discharge thats green looking ..sort of resembles snot is this normal when she is right about to have her pups ...like is it a mucus plug? if so how long till she has her puppies when the mucus plug has dropped should I try to stay awake tonight?



</question>



<answer from>



LanyFann...
Member since: 08 May 2008
Total points: 513 (Level 2)



</answer from>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Dobetazt...
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 194 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends, my females always have some kind of goop coming out of that area.
But right before they whole litter is born if there's a still born (usually, sometimes a breech) on the way they have a green plug type thing. Or it could be a sign of infection. Better take her to the vet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Pam
Member since: 31 October 2006
Total points: 15149 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If the discharge is green, it COULD mean a placenta (or more) have separated from the pup(s) in which case could mean trouble for the
pup(s). Call an after hours emergency vet.



A mucus plug is generally clean and whitish "mucus". Anything other than that is NOT good.



</answer>



<answer from>



moondog
Member since: 17 December 2006
Total points: 779 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Green discharge means your dog has an infection.  If you don't get her to the vet immediately you will lose her as well as the puppies.
If she survives this, have her desexed.



</answer>

Green is a sign of infection. I'd be heading to the vets.

<question from>



Your Highness
Member since: 01 August 2006
Total points: 4821 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Would getting another dog help my dog chill out?



My dog is very playful and very friendly. We take her to the dog park every other weekend and she absolutely loves playing with the other dogs there. The problem is when we aren't at the dog park, she gets way too excited when she sees another dog. Like, I think it's because she associates other dogs with playtime. But, I dunno. Do dogs even do that?



Anyway, I was thinking maybe if she had another dog around constantly, she wouldn't get canine ADD when she comes across other dogs because she'd be like "meh, i've already got one at home, you aren't that interesting"



Or would that plan totally not work? If it won't, what else can I do to help her mellow out around other dogs?



</question>



<additional details>



She does get walked daily, by the way



The dog park is 45-60 minutes away...so I can't take her there all the time.



</additional details>



<answer from>



karate hottie
Member since: 23 January 2007
Total points: 3666 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Getting another dog will not fix the problem. I have two dogs and my female still gets excited when she sees other dogs. If you get another dog you may just have two problems on your hands.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thats what I was worried about =|



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



alias boxer
Member since: 18 September 2007
Total points: 6391 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



She's not associating other dogs with "playtime;" she gets excited because she ONLY sees other dogs every other weekend.  You need to be socializing her much more often, and exercise her daily.  She's got too much pent up excitement and energy once she finally see the other dogs.



When dealing with training/behavior issues, getting a second dog is NEVER the answer.  You have to actually work with your dog.  There is no shortcut.  If you got another one.... well, then you'd have TWO untrained dogs.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris B
Member since: 06 April 2007
Total points: 714 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No. The key is to increase the excercise and make the sessions of play and walks longer.
Not ure how his training is but, it is best to get some obedience training for him in addition to help curb hi bhavior and energy level.
Adding another dog that also will need training, etc will only double the trouble right now.



</answer>



<answer from>



bds
Member since: 09 June 2008

</answer>

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Stacy E
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



No getting another dog will not help. If you don't have obedience on the one you have and don't get time to take her to the dog park as much as you would like as it is. Having another dog will give 4 times the reasons not to make time to go to the park or do other socializing activities with your dog.



Practice the "leave it" command. If your dog is food driven a good way to practice is to set a piece of food on the floor.  Tell her to "leave it" and don't let her have!  Once she tries to avoid the food, by not looking at it, then reward her with a piece from your pocket and then let her have the other piece.  It helps to use a leash.



The leave it command is used when ever the dog is paying attention to something other than you.  When you take her for a walk and she's sniffing pooh, tell her to "leave it", and give her a correction with the leash.  There are several opportunity to practice the "leave it" command.  So if she pays attention to the another dog and it's not play time tell her to "leave it", if she doesn't give her a correction that redirects her attention back to you.  As light as possible and as firm as necessary.  Hope this helps you out.



</answer>

<question from>



veebeede...
Member since: 15 June 2007
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How long do you leave your dogs daily and where do they stay while you're gone?



Does anyone leave their dogs in the garage all day? We have a nice place in our garage for our puppies while we're gone. (If they stay in the house they tear everything up and poo in the house) So we have blankets, food, water, toys in the garage for them. They can run and play and even go to the bathroom while we're gone.(We just clean it up, it's concrete) Does this seem like an ok place for dogs to stay while we're gone? There is nothing they can get into or get hurt, we already puppy proofed it.  If not, then we'd have to put them in a cage all day.

</answer from>



<answer>



My adult dog stays in the house with access to the kitchen, and hallway (blocked off with an extra tall doggie gate)



He is alone for approximatly 9.5hrs a day (work time and commute)  However as a puppy we had someone come and let him out during the day.



Leaving the puppies in the garage all day like that and you are never going to get them housebroken.  Once they learn that it is ok for them to go inside (even in the garage) it is going to be very hard to unteach that behavior.



The best thing you can do is crate train and have someone come by every few hours to let them out.



</answer>



<answer from>



Heidi Ho
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 212 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's a tough questions that needs some more information.  How old are the puppies?



You don't want to create a bad habit of going the the bathroom anywhere in the house/garage.



How long are you leaving them for?  While you are at work? Or a weekend vacation?



</answer>



<answer from>



gemma r
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 189 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the garage - does it have heat and natural light?  If not, then it's not suitable.  If so, then it's fine.  I know dogs that are kept in garages but they're probably nicer than my house!



And no wonder your dogs are going to the toilet if they are let inside the house - you let them go in the garage, how are they supposed to know the difference between the two places?  Sounds like you need to go back to basics with toilet training.



No dog should be left longer than 4 hours max (less if they are pups) so if you are out for longer than that then make sure you have somebody to come in.



Ask yourself how you want the dogs to behave in the future - do you want them housetrained and able to spend weekends with you in your home without chewing it and destroying it?  If so then you have to get them used to that environment and train them in it.  If you keep them in the garage several days a week then they will never learn how to behave in a house.  Could you not put them in a utility room or kitchen etc?  And start toilet training again, out every hour and out a couple of times a night, lots of praise, etc, etc.



Good luck.



Source(s):



Lots of doggy experience!



</answer>

unknown

<answer>



Australia wide there are more reported dog bites by Blue Heelers than Staffordshire Bull Terriers, according to Dogs Life magazine, about 6 months ago. I dont know what is going on in NSW!



Staffies were about 7th (from memory) on the list. The dogs  recorded as giving the most amount of dog bites (to humans) are not considered *dangerous* breeds, like the Blue Heeler, which was first on the list.



Go figure!



Add; It is interesting that SBT's are one of the most popular breeds. Here in W.A every second person owns one and yet there are more dog bites by Blue Heelers.



They NEVER report dog bites by a Blue Heeler and yet if a  Staffy or a Rottie so much as looks at someone the wrong way it is all over the news!

<answer>



Doh. I just asked almost the exact same question!! Sorry! :(



Well my thoughts on this is that from hospital/medical records, these statistics show that Staffies and Rotties have been the cause of 69 attacks.



I think we all can agree that many small breed dogs can be quite savage, and most of the larger breeds tend to be more mellow. The only problem is that when a Jack Russell attacks you it is usually pretty minor, and there is no way it is going to get a hold of your head or neck! Unfortunately the big dogs have size and strength behind them, so when they attack the injuries can be far worse.



I too have not known a bad Rottie, and I have owned a couple of Staffies, both of which you could literally eat out of their mouths. That is not to say that there are not bad dogs or bad owners amongst these breeds. Any dog has the potential to attack, they are animals after all.
I wouldn't not buy a Rottie simply because of these statistics though.



</answer>



<answer from>



antoinet...
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 974 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Rotties have a natural instinct to protect their families and can be ferocious in their defense.



Rottweilers exhibit a "wait-and-see" attitude when confronted with new people and situations. When these characteristics come together as they should, the Rottweiler is a natural guard dog with a mellow disposition who is successful not only in police, military, and customs work, but also as a family friend and protector.



http://dogtime.com/rottweiler.html



</answer>

<question>



My dog is bleeding, is this normal?



my dog is 11 months, just had a litter a pups there, 9 days ago, and to be honest, i never went threw wat i am going threw now, like ive never had a dog who had babies........but my dog kaci is bleedin, obviously not her cycle, its afterbirth yeah???? is this normal??



and wat do i keep her babies on?? blanket ?? (which there on now)
paper??
carboard??
etc, any idea??? and there is one pup who is always on its own, n cryin, but the 6 pups she had are all alive n strong n healthy!!



why is this pup always on its own, n crying???



i need these questions answered, i need helpful answers,
thanks pple x



</question>



<additional details>



i have to say for her first litter a pups she is great with them, cleans them alot, feeds them everyday around the same times, mostly morning / evening / night, she let us touch the pups n all, n trust us completley we toched them after a week, i will get beddin paper / towels for them like i jus wanted to know was it normal, shes not bleedin 24/7, wew'd jus notice blood her n dr, looks a bit gooy like, discharge, i dunno??? n wen i brought her the vet the vet told me SHE WASNT PREGNANT, even tho all the signs were dr, n wen i brought her to another vet, she told me she is, and they were fully formed, n the other vet jus told me she wasnt so i could termanaite her babies, but i couldnt do that, :( cuz she new she was and wen she sitted on the bed or anythin, she'd sit like she was protectin sumthin, n shes not stupid, no animal is, even tho sum pple think they are! i was told 2 days BEFORE she had the pups she was pregnant, n i was told maybe 2 weeks she'd have pups but was 2days!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Crimson&...
Member since: 23 February 2008
Total points: 1272 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes it is normal for your dog to be bleeding still after having her pups, and yes she can get pregnant again as soon after they give birth. They not only bleed after giving birth because of the after birth, but the do go back into season again after giving birth. So when you go outside with her to do her business you will have to make sure that she is not left around any other males again during this time as well.



You should make sure that the mother is nursing this little puppy that you say keeps being by itself. For the first two weeks of their lives is very crucial for them to be warm,especially now that it is getting cold. Se if the mother may possibly be rejecting this little puppy. How is the mother doing with her pups? I am asking this because she is quite young to be a mother already, and she may not take care of them like she is suppose to, She may not even produce the milk that she is suppose to have either?



When I have puppies for the first two weeks I have a red heat lamp to keep my puppies warm, but you do not want to keep it to close to them because it can get to hot for them as well as the mother getting to hot. Use red lights and not white, because white is harmful to their eyes when they first open them. That will not be for at least two weeks though. Use some old towels that you are willing to part with, or some old sheets for their bedding. When they get bigger you can use news paper instead. Just make sure that you keep their enviroment clean. At about two to three weeks old they need to start being dewormed, as well as the mother. Get something like Nemex or Dwormer. It will also tell you on the bottle how many times you should deworm them, and how much.They should get their first set of shots at 5-6 weeks. Then again at 8 weeks.
I hope this helps alot.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

Call first, don't just rush off. your vet has your pets history and knows more about what is likely going on with her than we do, but definitely call, you may need to take her in tonight depending on what he/she says.

<answer>



I am disgusted that you allowed an 11month old to breed in the first place.. Have you taken her temperature regularly since she whelped the puppies??  More than likely she is having complications from the birth and may have a puppy left inside her..



Take her to the vet immediately (take the puppies with you so that they are still with the mother or nearby) and get the vet to check the pups out too.



The mum & pups should have a covered dark area away from all the hectic household goings on covered with flat paper and some shredded so that you can change it a couple of times a day to keep it clean for mum & pups.  You could use a cardboard box that is in a warm area for them all.



Are you a puppy mill/farm?  Why did you let her breed at that age?



Why didn't you have her desexed at 6 months?



So many questions - all asked too late!



</answer>

trapt_is...
Member since: 28 October 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



Well, first off....an 11 month old PUPPY should not have had puppies!  If this is your first dog, you should have known what you were getting yourself into.  You should have done some research on breeding and puppies and taking care of them after they're born.  You want the puppies to be on blankets or towels, and in a warm area.  If the puppy away from all the others is smaller than the others, it's probably the runt of the litter, and if the mom isn't taking care of it, there might be something wrong with it.  As with your dog bleeding, I'm not sure.  I've never had a dog have puppies, but I know how to take care of them.  I would call a vet, and if they say to bring the dog in, take the puppy that's by it's self too, just to have it checked out.  Also, as soon as you can, get your dog fixed so you don't have any more puppies, since you don't know what you're doing.



</answer>

<question from>



♥Dr. Holly Girlfriend™♥

<question>



GEtting Akita to back off while eating.?



I've finally got my 5 month old Akita to pee on her paper or ask to go out, to stop pulling on walks, and almost stopped knawing.



I knew this was going to be an issue when her owner said "oh she eats anything. She cleans my kids plates off". Now she thinks she is entitled to anything and everything we eat. I have told her no sent her away put her in another room... She ignores every command and comes back. She'll do ANYTHING to get at the food. She tries to sit nicely as if she should get a treat for this.



I was feeding her 3x a day because when I got her she was very skinny. You could not only feel her bones but see them threw her fur. I'm guessing her previous owners couldn't afford to feed her properly. Since then she's put on about 5lbs and her bones are no longer jutting out. I stopped feeding her 3x and went down to 2x because she wasn't coming close to finishing her food.



I basically went down to working part time just to have the time to fully train her so she is getting 3 20-30 minute walks a day along with going to a tennis court and running after the ball.



I'm not sure what to do about the food issue. I've never had a dog that didn't get the point, and believe me I fostered about 60 dogs. Even my husband who she obeys completely she will not leave him alone.



</question>



<additional details>



I NEVER give her food while I'm eating. I only give her a treat pretty much every other day after a really good walk but it's always after we've eaten.



</additional details>

Zoe

<answer>



Ignore her, ignore her, ignore her!!! No eye contact, don't even say no, no pushing her away if she tries to get something...just move the plate. It's hard but it will pay off in the end. Here is some more details...



Most pet owners find it annoying when their dogs pester or beg for food at the table. Dogs develop this behavior for one reason – when owners offer them food while a meal at the table is in progress. Even occasional treating from the table can result in begging, because intermittent reinforcement on a random schedule is like being rewarded from a slot machine – every now and then the payoff is big enough to make persistence worthwhile. Curing a begging problem is not complicated, but it does require a strong commitment from all family members. It means that from now on, the dog is never, ever fed from the table. All family members must consistently follow this rule. At first, expect the dog to respond by showing other annoying behaviors. Hard-core beggars will become frustrated, and likely start pawing or barking at family members.



These behaviors must be ignored. If owners give in, the dog has then learned to be even more obnoxious. The dog may also do other things to get the owner’s attention, such as chewing on forbidden objects, stealing clothes, getting into the trash, etc. These behaviors can either be prevented (don’t allow the dog access to these rooms), or give the dog another, acceptable behavior to perform. For example, the dog can be taught to lay down in a particular location during meals, by giving him a special chew toy and treats at that location, and for a while even leashing him to the spot. Once the dog seems to have stopped begging, he may all of a sudden start doing it again. This is a normal part of treatment, and it is extremely important to continue to ignore the behavior. It will usually go away much sooner than it did the first time. Slipping up and feeding the dog from the table will almost surely cause a rec



Source(s):



http://www.petfriendlyhouse.com/informat...



</answer>



<answer from>



ainawgsd
Member since: 28 March 2007
Total points: 11525 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



If she's just staring and not physically trying to get at your food, I would simply "pretend she doesn't exist" while you're eating.  Don't look at her, don't talk to her, don't acknowledge her presence in any way until after you have finished eating and put the plates in the sink.



If you just can't ignore her or if she is being pushy and getting in your face while you are eating, then your best option is to physically restrain her either in a crate or with a tether in another area.  It could be in the same room, or in a different room.  If you use a tether it may be helpful for her to also give her a mat to clearly differentiate that that is her place where she should stay when you are eating.  It would also be helpful to give her something to do while you are eating.  You could fill a kong with her own dry food and top it with peanut butter or some other treat that she likes (you could even freeze it to make it harder for her to get to) to keep her busy while you eat.  The point here is not to "punish" her or put her in a "time out" but rather to change her behavior...and giving her a dog-appropriate chew is a good way to keep her out of your face while you are eating.



</answer>

<question from>



thebanne...

</question from>



<question>



My Lab is afraid of water? How do I help him with this problem?



We picked up a Lab puppy at the shelter about 3 1/2 months ago, and we've found that he is terrified of water. The first time we gave him a bath, he freaked out so bad he was in convulsions and was desperately trying to escape.



Since then, he's gotten 3 baths and he gets a little better each time, but he won't go anywhere near a pool or a sprinkler and refuses to go outside when it's raining.



I'm beginning to think that he was trained with water as a form of discipline, like it was his form of punishment.



This is very sad to see, since Labs are truly water dogs and I would like to see him be able to enjoy one of his true callings. I hate for him to miss out on one of a Lab's major life pleasures.



What steps can I take to get him to be comfortable around water, and maybe even jump in the pool with me one day?



</question>



<answer from>



CaseyJo
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 3802 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not all dogs, even water dogs, like water. YOu can't make the statement that they all will love it.



Baths, sprinklers, and rain aren't things dogs typically like even if they are water dogs. SO don't expect him to like those and try to minimize his encounters with them. Labs shouldn't be getting many baths - it ruins the natural oil in their coats.



I would suggest taking him to the beach where the water is shallow and he can walk into at his own pace. Work slowly and get him to walk out to you are different depths - not making him swim right off the bat just walk in the water. Give him treat - don\t physically touch him in the water this may send him into a panic mode like you are going to hold him in their.
After a while if that is working try tossing the cokkie into the water and you stay on shore. Milkbones folat for a little while 5-10 minutes. Make sure the water is calm where you take him as well.
Never drag your dog into the water or throw him in, this will only make things worse.



He may never be a water dog and that is something you always have to keep in mind.



Source(s):



Vet Tech



Lab Owner



</answer>



<answer from>



kelsy&lt;...
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 672 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not all labs like the water..so he could be afraid of it.. maybe one day he willl turn around and go on in it on its own.

<question from>



Emmalyz

</question from>



<question>



We over walked out puppy on her first day of walks, and now Skylar refuses to go at all!?



About a week ago, we took SLyar for her first walk. She loved it and flew through it. (3/5 mile) The next day, we took her for two more 3/5 mile walks. Skylar is a siberian husky mix, so she can handle that. Well, that same night, we tried a third walk.



Big mistake.



She totally refused. I can understand her being tired, so I turn around. Immediately, she goes into full pulling mode when she realizes we change the direction. I became a "tree" and made her walk beside me, even though she was still pulling.
Well, I give her a day to rest; I thought Skylar was just tuckered out. Same thing happens the next day. We can't even make it 1/4 the way around. The thing is, off leash, she easily follows you. When I say," Follow me!", she looks up and trots to me. Also, I try just walking her around the house, but she pulls there, too.



I know Skylar has had a bad experience. How can I change this to a positive walking time? Please help.



</question>



<additional details>



I'm sorry I forgot her age. Skylar is seven and a half weeks old.



</additional details>



<answer from>



puplovet...
Member since: 27 August 2007
Total points: 3244 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't mention her age but she just might be going through another fear period.  If she is the best thing to do is encourage her to take the walk (or explore feared things) but don't force it.  Instead you can temporarily use her energy through obedience lessons and playing games, especially training games that use her mind such as doggy versions of follow the leader, and hide 'n seek.



</answer>



<answer from>



Frosted Flakes
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 264 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not from a "bad experience".  Your dog is attempting to be the dominant dog.  She doesn't want to walk on leash.  She wants control.  If this is in fact a leash pulling problem, it can be relatively easily fixed by teaching your dog the 3 stages of the Heel command as outlined in SitStayFetch. I have copied in the text from Stage 1 of the process below; even this stage should give you good results regardless of whether you have a dog or fully grown dog!



Stage 1
The first stage of teaching your dog to heel is to prevent him from pulling on the leash at all.
1. You will need to have the collar and leash on your dog.
2. Stand next to and to the right of your dog so that you are both facing in the same direction and the dog is sitting on your left.
3. Start walking forward slowly in a straight line, leading with your left leg. As soon as your dog takes off and starts pulling on the leash, stand still and pull the leash back towards you. Do not drag the dog back towards you. All you need to do is halt its progress.
4. Wait until the dog stops, praise it and then continue walking. No command needs to be given at this stage as you are just trying to teach your dog good manners so that it can more easily understand the Heel command when the time comes to teach it fully.
5. If you apply this method for ten minutes at a time and for three or four times per day then within four or five days you should be ready to move on to the next phase.
6. It is quite likely that you will get good results within a few minutes, at least enough that your dog will stop pulling you all over the place. It may take longer for some older dogs that have been given a free rein, so to speak, throughout their lives to change their leash-pulling behavior.



When the SitStay Technique isn't Enough
1. You have to modify the way that you are training your dog slightly. When your dog starts to pull, you need to:
2. Stop and give your dogs lead a few tugs, and growl the guttural growl, ("AAHH!" rather then "NO") then bring the dog back beside you.
3. Start walking away again and hold a treat by your side (so that your dog knows it is there).
4. Your dog should be following along side you, if it tries to jump for the treat ignore it (do not let your dog bite at your hand though).
5. When your dog tires of that, and simply walks along beside you say "HEEL!" then reward your dog for walking beside you.
6. Repeat this over and over, then you should start to see the results. If you praise your dog as it comes towards you then your dog is being rewarded only for backing up (the very last action it performed). You need to reward your dog for walking freely beside you as you move off from the stand still.



Whether your dog is pulling on the leash, lagging behind or not moving at all, the heal command still remains the same. The meaning of the command is that your dog remains by your side. This means that your dog shouldn’t be charging ahead of you, however it also means that he should be dragging behind you either. It will take time to train him to walk beside you and you will need to try various things..



The basis of training is getting your dog to heal, which may take some work by the sounds of things. It sounds as though you may have already started this training. If you devote two or three 5 – 10 minute training sessions every day with your dog, you should notice a difference with a month or so.



The reasons for this behavior are possibly four fold:
1. Your dog has a health related problem and it isn’t comfortable walking at the speed you would like it to
2. Your dog becomes interested and distracted by other things on a walk and thus doesn’t heel
3. Your dog doesn’t like going on walks (I doubt this would be the cause! I don’t know of any dogs that don’t like walking – unless of course it hurts them, but that does us back to point number 1)
4. Finally - you’re dog may just be lazy!!



By depriving your dog of walks for a while, you may be able to notice whether his interest in the walk itself rather than the surroundings picks up. This should help him pick up his excitement and interest in going for walks and you may hopefully find that he stops dragging behind you.



If your dog is simply disinterested in walks, you will need to think of ways to make them more exciting. Take him to the beach if you’re near one, or a dog park where you can let him off the lead and roam around. This may also rekindle a love for walking and the outdoors again. It will also show him that although he may not like the lead, it is worth the trip to behave properly with it on in order to get the reward of being let off the lead.



This will in fact be the basis of your training. For starters, I would like you to (at home) train your dog 2 – 3 times per day for 5 – 10 minutes at a time. Put the lead on him and walk around your backyard (I’m assuming you have a backyard – if you don’t go down to a park). By using a reward he really likes (a



</answer>



<answer from>



Accept Reality-face the facts
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 2592 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only "bad"experience was your catering to a dog!
You don't "ask" dogs,you TELL them what to do!



</answer>



<answer from>



Alyssa P
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 201 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not much then adding onto what the others answered, but I would advise walking the dog around the yard for the first walks. Sounds silly, but that makes him less likely to run off, and more likely to take longer walks.



Source(s):



I've owned 7 dogs total. I currently own 2.



I've also done research on animals for 4 years, though it mostly centers around dog care and the way a dog is built



</answer>

<question from>



Memphis Belle
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 14679 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



£37,390 to pamper pet dogs ~ excessive but harmless?



Louise Harris, 29, lives in Essex with her partner Sam, 30, a metal worker, and Lola and Lulu - two Teacup Yorkies.



Louise says: Lola transformed my world both personally and professionally when I bought her four years ago.



For the first six months, I spent all my free time buying her lovely trinkets and treats. I was so inspired that I quit my £40,000 City job as an analyst with Reuters to open my own dog boutique and parlour.



Lulu is a year old and a recent addition to the family. She looks so uncannily like Lola that they could pass for sisters.



They have everything they could possibly need. Every morning, I cook them a warm breakfast of either scrambled organic eggs or porridge.



I wash them daily with Paul Mitchell Tearless Puppy Shampoo and spray them with Lola's specially-made perfume, Lola Love, which costs £6 a bottle. It's a very refined, subtle smell - like talcum powder.



take them to the grooming parlour every Friday where they have a shampoo, a conditioning treatment, a blow-dry, a massage and a paw-dicure (pedicure). I don't like them using towels that have been used on other dogs, so I take their own special cotton zebra-print ones.



Every morning, I select an outfit for Lola and Lulu from a wardrobe of clothes worth about £12,000, and I make sure they stay current with the trends.



Right now, animal prints are all the rage so I've got them in cheetah-print coats that cost £28 each. I also have ten £100 designer bags to carry them around in.



They have three beds.



The one next to mine in the bedroom is a £2,000 Moroccan-style four-poster dog bed with pink organza curtains. The wrought-iron bed frame has a gold L in the centre, like a crest. They have their own special steps to climb up and a cashmere pillow and blanket, which cost £250 each.



There is another dog bed in the study, worth £650 and covered with black ostrich feather-trimmed cushions. I keep a third bed for them in the lounge which cost £500.



They eat only the highest-quality dog food - which costs £7.99 a packet - and have gold-standard pet insurance.



I had their feeding bowl units specially made for £120 each. They eat out of two stainless steel bowls elevated on a cast iron stand so that they can eat at the correct angle and height.



I can't bear being separated from my dogs and I would never dream of putting them in kennels. I hire people to look after them for £20 a day if I absolutely have to go away.



My friends think I'm completely barmy to have professional photographs taken of Lola and Lulu. The photographer charges a daily rate of £500 and she's been with us for five days in the past year.



I am the proud owner of not only two wonderful pets, but of 15 lovely photographs of them.



COSTS: Clothes: £12,000. Collars: £2,500. Food: £700. Vets/Insurance: £8,000. Bed/bedding: £3,650. Bowls: £240. Grooming: £7,500. Perfume/toiletries: £800. Photography: £2,000.



TOTAL: £37,390



http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/articl...
Link to full article



Do you think it's excessive but harmless for the dogs to be pampered in the way that they are?



http://flickr.com/photos/fallonbrooke/30...



</question>

<question from>

<question>



Why do dogs enjoy us patting them?

</question>

<answer from>



john n

<answer>



just like us when we get hugs and affection from our loved ones dogs feel loved and wanted too. they are social animals and want to be treated with love and care and haveing a good rub or pet makes them feel a part of the family.when my family come home or hubby gives me a hug my dogs jump up and want one too, so its all part of showing affection and being included in the family.



</answer>



<answer from>



i0igeorg...
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 163 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dogs and most other animals that have become accustomed to humans like being touched just like you like them touching you.
The power of touch has been studied and written up in at least one journal of medicine as humans, every human, will react positively to the touch of a loved one.



It may have something to do with the way our brains work.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lily K :)

<answer>

dont have hands to scratch themselves



</answer>



<answer from>



Los
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 246 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everybody needs love. We need hugs kisses etc. Animals need touching from their owners to feel loved.



</answer>



<answer from>



Thought
Member since: 05 March 2006
Total points: 7277 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dogs are social animals and physical contact it part of that (can you imagine a social animal who hated to be touched?) By patting them on the head, rubbing their bellies, etc, we are reassuring them that they are part of our social group. They show us the same when they lick us, lay their head on our laps, etc.



There is also, to my understanding, a grooming instinct in most social animals (and thus, I would assume dogs as well, but I am not positive). The very act of combing through an animals fur is necessary for community health, so social creatures have evolved to enjoy that behavior in order to encourage it. I know most primates have this behavior (including humans, which is why people tend to enjoy it when a spouse plays with their hair), and I believe dogs do too. Thus, by petting and scratching them we are satisfying to needs in one go.



</answer>



<answer from>



nvr2mnyd...
Member since: 05 December 2007
Total points: 251 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



its attention, they like it.



</answer>

<answer from>



Hanna
Member since: 21 April 2007
Total points: 207 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My dog slept incessantly when I first brought him home, although it has changed some now that he is a bit older.



Under controlled laboratory conditions both cats and dogs sleep about 13 hours per day but they wake up more frequently than people do.



According to Planet Dog:



• Adult dogs spend approximately half their life sleeping,



typically 12 hours a day.



• Some breeds need more sleep than others –



as much as 18 hours per day! (typically larger breeds).



</answer>

<answer from>



BVC_asst
Member since: 09 October 2006
Total points: 9282 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Microchipping is a way of identifying your dog (or cat) should they become lost.



A tiny device (looks like a tiny capsule) is inserted under their skin between the shoulderblades. It contains a number that when scanned by the microchip scanner will be able to link that number with the number registered by the owner.  When an animal is microchipped, the owner will need to mail in the registration (there is a fee) so that the owner and the microchip number will go together and the animal can be brought home.



Home Again is the company we use, you can see if they have a website and that should be able to answer other questions.



Source(s):



use at work



</answer>



<answer from>



coax_me_...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 2506 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



They implant a small chip into the dog, if the dog ever goes missing or you have to leave it somewhere due to an emergency the dog can be scanned and your contact information will show up. It is alot more reliable than a collar since it is permanant and gives instant information like your name phone number and address without it having to be looked up like with a tattoo identification number. It is also less painful than a tattoo and a faster procedure.



</answer>



<answer from>



john n
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 8715 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



it is a little disk that they put under the skin on the dogs neck so if he gets lost or stolen they can scan his neck and find out where he belongs. the disk has ur info on it so he can be returned.



</answer>

lala

</answer from>



<answer>



the vet will put a microchip in ur dog by a needle  so if she get lost someone can turn her in and the vet or dog pound will scan were the chip is and info about were the dogs owner or  lives  will come up on the Scanner



</answer>



<answer from>



whiskeyc...
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 823 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A microchip is smaller then a grain of rice.  It is injected under the skin generally between the shoulderblades of the dog/cat.



If the dog gets lost, if the microchip has been registered (the chip is only as good as the person registering it!) then the company can tell the vet/shelter who found the dog who ownes it and the process to get the dog back can begin.



I use AVID chips, but there are three or four differnent brands available out there.  I suggest that if you are planning on chipping your dog to call your shelter and see what brand they recomend or call around to the vet clinics.  Some chips have to be read by a specific reader where others are "universal."



Chips are a great tool to help get a dog back if lost, but unless people have the "reader" for it and the chip is registered to the owner, then the chip is useless.



</answer>

<question>



I just found a flea on my Dog. How do I sort this?



I have a Border Collie who is 2, and we have had him since April. I have just found a live flea on him whilst playing with him and I'm unsure how to go about clearing them.



I have been reading online and there are many warnings about bedding/carpets/furniture being a resting place for fleas, but I've also read that some treatments don't require the household to be treated (ie drops etc keep the pet flea free - and and contact with others will kill them.)



What makes this a little more complicated is 2 days ago I put some drops on him. I usually do this monthly but this time was a little later than usual so this is obviously been a long enough gap for some to get in there and make a home. These drops say they kill fleas for four weeks before the treatment  needs to be repeated.



So, in short. Do I need to take anyfurther action with him, or shall I leave the drops to do their thing?



And, do I need to treat my household?



Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>

<answer>



if you used something like Revolution, then yes, it will kill the fleas on your dog.  If you use it again in exactly 4 weeks, it will keep them off, too.



You should be fine!

Just make sure you don't bathe your dog for the next few days after using those drops!

Hanna

Total points: 207 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I use the Frontline Plus Blue Flea Medication on my own little puppy but also take care to something like Carpet & Upholstery Flea & Tick Spray on my carpet and furniture. Nearly all of them are safe to use without worrying about your own health =)



I spray it on areas where I see my dog spend a lot of time; his sleeping area, his eating area. However, I use another spray for the lawn. While I know this may seem overboard for a simple flea, I wouldn't want something like a flea crawling all over me and I certainly wouldn't wish it for my dog either.



Furniture/carpet spray:
http://www.petsmart.com/product/index.js...



Lawn spray:
http://www.petsmart.com/product/index.js...



In regards to the flea medication for your dog, as long as you follow the monthly applications, the fleas shouldn't return. The only reason I keep up my regiment is because we have cats who like to roam into our yard and I simply don't trust them.



The medication should still be present on your dog, despite your having applied it a few days prior, and should still be able to work its magic and kill off whatever nasty fleas have found made their way onto your dog.



You could try calling the local vet where you acquired the medication to double check.



</answer>



<answer from>

I would recommend you use frontline or advantix and not the cheap stuff you can get at the local wal-mart.  Those treatments don't work and they are basically a straight pesticide.

<answer from>



kanayd
Member since: 17 April 2006
Total points: 1115 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only drops you should be giving your pet for fleas are Advantage or Frontline. Those over the counterdrops like Hartz are NOT good for pets. I took my cat in for a routine checkup once and told the vet about his neck- I had given him Hartz flea drops and it gave him a scab. He had always freaked out before I gave it to him too. Anyway, the vet told me that Hartz stuff is highly toxic to pets as well and doesn't even know how it got allowed on shelves. I guess it's not regulated. Anyway, she told me the only stuff that truly work is Advantage and Frontline, which is why you can't buy them over the counter. You used to only be able to get them from a vet but you can buy them on ebay now.



Anyway, in terms of getting rid of them, you basically have to vacuum the bedding area and spray the surrounding area. You want to vacuum probably every day for about 2 weeks in case you have eggs laying hidden somewhere and they hatch. Otherwise you'll have to bug bomb your house if they get out of control and that's a hassle. I had a HUGE flea infestation here not too long ago and got rid of it in about 2 weeks using nothing but Advantage and the vacuum along with lots of patience. Monthly drops sterilize (I believe) any new fleas too that the pet picks up. Good luck. Cheers :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Shelly t
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 16368 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



with 5 dogs and 1 cat the one thing I hate is flee's.



first do not buy cheap flee treatments. Use frontline or revolutioin. I use frontline. spray last longer than drops.



second the first thing flee's do is make babies. These babies are made in there poo. So you want to remove this poo. check your dog for any brown spots. Rub them off as much as possible with an oil like skin so soft, or baby oil. You should be able to see a cotton ball turning brown. this is removing the flee poo. which is what will hatch in about 4 weeks. That is why it is important to redo your dog with flee spray or drops each month because it doesn't kill the lava. Just wash bedding where dog sleeps. If you want you can flee bomb the houes. really not necessary if you keep up with the steps of removing the new flee lava you should be rid of flee's



</answer>



<answer from>



BVC_asst
Member since: 09 October 2006
Total points: 9282 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Flea and tick preventative is recommended where I work all year round.  Fleas can die off in the winter but the ticks don't.



Continue to use the preventative faithfully every month.  Give your dog a good once over looking for fleas.  Generally, there's not just one flea, but that doesn't mean that you're dog is infested.  Check where fleas hang out...on the belly, by the base of the tail, by the neck.  Go over with a flea comb if possible and look for signs of fleas, which is flea dirt (poop), brown sand like particles.



It can't hurt to treat the areas where the dog likes to lay, his bed or his rug.  If you find yourself being bitten, then you have a problem that would require professional treatment.



And, you can always ring the vet and see if he recommends shampooing.  You would have to wait a few days (either before or after applying the flea preventative) before giving a bath.



</answer>

<question>



Why do dogs put their tail down when burying?



I gave my dog a bone, and watched as he buried it in his basket. I've watched him do it a thousand times but the question is nagging me now!



He always put his tail down over his bum, why is that?



</question>



<answer from>



Camillaa...
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 320 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



DOES IT REALLY MATTER? =|



</answer>



<answer from>



perry
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 190 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i think its bc when theyre digging they kinda dig downwards so they have have to pt there tail down for balance



</answer>



<answer from>



Hanna
Member since: 21 April 2007
Total points: 207 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Camillaa: OF COURSE IT MATTERS



We're all here because we want things answered. I've a dozen questions as to why my own dog does the oddest things, if everyone answered a question like you this site would be in a terrible mess.



I thought this site was cute, you might want to check it out as it gives a bit of info on dogs and their beloved tails:
http://www.wagntrain.com/BodyLanguage.ht...



But also:
http://www.petplace.com/dogs/what-is-you...



</answer>



<answer from>



BelleK
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 906 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Because of the position their body is in while digging. Head down, rear up. They put their tails down to protect their genitals. It's the same reason dogs put their tails between their legs when they feel threatened. They are very vulnerable there, and it is instinct to preserve their ability to procreate which is vital for survival of the species.



</answer>

<question>



Is it possible for a dog to vomit there poop?



My neighbor's dog did not poop for a day and the next day she told me that her dog vomited poop. Is that really possible and is this a sign of a sick dog? why didi it happen?



</question>



<answer from>



redrockc...
Member since: 19 September 2006
Total points: 4620 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes that is possible because they eat their own poop.  I know that's gross and I want to upchuck just thinking about it.  I wouldn't give him kisses on the mouth .



</answer>



<answer from>



BVC_asst
Member since: 09 October 2006
Total points: 9282 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It can be possible if their intestines burst and filled the stomach with feces.  It has happened to my friends sister, and it's an emergency obviously.



It could be that the dog is constipated and vomited and the vomit just looks like poop.  Either way, a trip to the vet is needed asap.



</answer>



<answer from>



Zach F
Member since: 11 August 2007
Total points: 2416 (Level 3)

<answer>



No, it is totally impossible for that to happen,  the dog just vomited up something it had eaten that was brown in colour.



Sometimes dogs that vomit are sick, they may have eaten something they shouldn't have, or they have caught an illness.  sometimes they vomit if they have eaten to much, eaten to fast or eaten some grass that has made it sick.

Yes and humans can do it to. It happens normaly when there is a blockage(or they just refuse to go) and the fecese has formed in the digestive track but cannot be expelled. It then builds up to a point and will travel back up the intestines and come out the long way.

<answer>



If the dog eats poop, then it can vomit poop. If there is blood in the vomit, it's accompanied by diarrhea, there's heaving with no vomit then the dog needs to see a vet. If the dog's been tired, inactive, and the belly looks swollen then it needs to get to a vet - there could be something stuck in the intestines.

<question from>



Jenna S
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dog injuring herself at being left alone ?



My dog is now 3years old, large breed. is in split season, just finished bleeding, before she started her initial season she was fine but since she has been a nitemare! the vet wont spay her until 3months after this season and in the meantime I just dont know what to do with her, She started messing in the house becoming totally insecure at being left alone chewing digging etc... so we brought a crate on advice of our vet, we brought a super large one she has enough room to turn, stand sit and more,, we brought a really good quality chunky metal one as she ate her way out of the one she had as a pup. For the first couple of days she was fine with it but then started peeing in it which we ignored completely gave her a trat anyway, dont give her excess attention when we get back in. Yesterday she tried digging herself out and her paws were bloodstained and also grazed her nose as she uses her nose to try to get out. Today i get back and theres more blood over her paws and nose as well as she had defecated and peed in the cage. She is obviously in so much distress at being left on her own but what can I do? Im expecting another baby which tied in with her split season, cleaning all this up twice a day everyday is becomin beyond a joke. I only do the school run 20 mins morning and afternoon otherwise Im always in... She is absoloutely fine when we are in the house with her,, she has not in anyway been punished as I beleive that would make things worse. The vet  just says its because of her hormones she will calm down but in the mean time she is injuring herself and i worry and really worry it will end up tragically! Any tips??? I cant take her to school with me as dogs arent allowed, nor can I leave her in the garden as it is not secure enough for her especially when she is in season and trying to find a way out! I love my dog BUT I am considering handing her over to rspca for her own safety as it isnt right she should be so distressed as she is.



</question>



<additional details>



by split season I mean she went into season then finished then went straight into a second season. She was fine in her last seasons and so I was happy to not have her spayed as it is a major op but as she has been so different with this one we and the vet decided it was a better option for her.



to the first answer- id never really thought of it that way, thats some good advice and maybe I shall go back to leaving her to get used to the crate door open for a while- THANKS!



The school run began just before her season, my daughter has only just started school. A lot of changes went on in this time, my son started crawling so stair gates went up as well which she dislikes as well as her having to leave the room with me as my son tends to make a beeline for her now he is mobile. She doesnt follow me round in the house except for to leave the living room with me. I also cant see why a season would change her so much but the thought that something may of scared her seems more likely it as was more of a sudden change in her, just cant think what.



</additional details>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Oh my.  What a situation and of course lack of education and support from the breeder leads to things like this.



So first up I am going to ask why didn't you have her spayed before her season.



Second what do you mean by a split season, I have never heard of this term and don't understand what you mean.  A season is a season, normally between 23 to 30 days.  The 12th to 16th day being of optimum mating the rest is in laymans terms, before cycle and after cycle.



Of course your dog will go beserk if you crate it all of a sudden and it isn't used to it.  Secondly it will go doubly beserk to get out and find a mate when in the middle of a heat cycle because that is what nature intended.
What you have done is confine your dog into a small space in a matter of a few days which is short of locking yourself into a hall closet when you are trying to accomplish something really important in your life.



What to do?  hmmmm.  Well the vet won't spay because when in heat the bi tch has extra blood running round the veins and it causes complications in an operation of that kind, the B can bleed to death. But a good vet can still do the op but they will charge extra.



Personally I would get your dog out of the crate before she causes herself any more harm.  Ring a boarding kennel and have her boarded for the few days she is in osterus.  Or ring another vet that will spay her.



Why have you waited so long to get her fixed up.  She is 3.



Edit.....



Ok I get you now.  I see why you waited but probably not a good idea.  It wasn't a prob before.  But I have to tell you as they get older they can go into phantom pregnancies, it is a pain in the butt.  Please spay her after this.  Unsterilized B's have more probs than sterilized.  They have a greater chance of (human terms, breast cancer) and pyometra from phantom pregnancies.



The split season as best I can get it, your girl was bleeding then stopped then started to bleed again?  Count the days from when she first started to bleed.  In total they go appx. 23 days but some can go as much as 30 even a bit longer.
They can bleed at the beginning, stop for a few days then bleed again.
How long has she been on heat altogether?



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thankyou. Am going to revise my introduction to the crate and go from there.



</asker's comment>

kathryn

<answer>



Suzie's advice is spot on ...  You are correct about the need to act fast



to alleviate her distress , which is acute. You are also correct on not punishing her or even raising your voice ,, which would ADD to her distress not lessen it.



(look up separation anxiety on the internet and learn as much as you can about it)  The only thing  I would add to suzie's comments ... is ... desensitise her to being left alone ... if she follows you around the house then obviously the difference between when you are home and when you are not is extreme .. So, sometimes close a door briefly so she cannot be with you  for very small periods of time  I am talking about half a minute , and building up the time gradually... being very calm and casual about it with no words to her and no fuss AT ALL, both when you leave and when you return to the room she is in. You don't kiss, cuddle and give explanations to other PEOPLE who might be in the room with you .. when you leave briefly or return so don't do that with her. So she becomes used to being alone sometimes even when you are IN the house.  Lots of info on the net I am sure ... so do some homework on desensitising before you start. I also think it might help to consider why she has suddenly started this distress on being left .. I think there is possibly some other change in the family and / or routine  rather than a season being the sole or even part of the cause of it. She is 3 years old .. this is not her first season. You have done the school run on numerous occasions before, presumably with no problem for her. Possibly a loud noise or something else startled her while you were out and has caused a fear of being left .. Have YOU become anxious about leaving the house  or returning, fearing you will find a mess or more injury and she senses this?  Could be any number of reasons why.  Oh .. also get her a Kong or similar large safe toy ... fill it with treats and give it to her ONLY when she is to be alone and pick it up on return so that your leaving become a signal of a good thing about to happen and she has something to occupy her while you are not there.  All, some or none of  these may help.



Good luck .. I hope she recovers from this distressing problem very soon .
Kath.



Source(s):



I am a Canine Behaviourist



</answer>

Good luck.

Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Separation Anxiety.
There are numerious dogs who suffer from separation anxiety, consequently i have pasted a solution to this, please please try it, it works.



If your dog suffers from separation anxiety, don’t give him free access to every room in your house when you leave him. . If you allow him free access you are doubling his burden. As well as having separation anxiety he will think that he has to guard every room in your house.



If he is restricted to one room he will not see you leave. You could also con him into thinking that you are always at home by carrying out the following procedure.



Try to do this when you are at home all day, or in the evening when you are there. After your dog has had a long walk, put him in a room with his comfortable bed, this should be a room where you will leave him if you need to go out and where your dog will sleep at night.



Walk out of the room and close the door.  Open the door immediately and go back into his room, close the door behind you and try to ignore him.  Pretend or actually do something which excludes your dog, for example if he is in the bathroom you could do a bit a cleaning for a couple of minutes. Then walk out of the room, go back again immediately and continue with the pretence. Keep doing this to ensure that your dog won’t feel isolated and eventually leave a small gap before you go into his room again. Over a period of days increase the gap before going back into his room. When you know that your dog is asleep stop going into the room, however you MUST try to go onto the room before he wakes up and starts to cry. If you carry out this procedure for a couple of days, your dog will always think that you are at the other side of the door. I do this when I get a new puppy and this PREVENTS separation anxiety.
Don’t neglect his long walks and playtime in the garden whilst you are re-training him, he needs his fun



When you are leaving your dog on his own please don’t make a dramatic exit, or this will give the game away. Simply put him into his room and walk out. When you come home don’t give him a big hello, just walk into his room and let him out for a pee. You can then play with him and give him cuddles.



Please don’t get a dog if it has to be left alone all day. Try to get a friend or a professional to take him out for pees and poos, if you need to leave him for any length of time...



Source(s):



dorothy s



</answer>

<answer>



Not necessarily. Some dogs react differently to others. While some will vomit have runny stool, etc some will show no outward signs. Especially in a large dog. This does not mean his organs have not been affected. While short term there maybe no signs of effect at all long term it can still cause damage.



Give your vet a call and see what he has to say. It's probably too late to do anything at this point, but he may want to check the dog over.



It very much looks as if the dog ate the chocolate. Wrappers and all. The foil wrappers could cause problems too so you must speak to a vet.



Make sure the chocolate is somewhere the dog can't get at them again. Looks like you guys will have to pay for all the bard he ate maybe in more ways than one.



</answer>

Kari M
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 3263 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends.



I work at a vet.  The size of the dog plays a very large factor in addition to what type of chocolate it is.  Milk chocolate is much less dangerous than dark chocolate.



If they received a very low dose of chocolate poisoning - they will not show any signs of problems.  If they receive a moderate dose, they will have an upset stomach causing diarrhea and vomiting.  If it was an extremely high dose they can die from the toxicity.



In the future if your dog ever eats chocolate you need to make him vomit immediately (within 2-3 hours of him eating it if possible) using hydrogen peroxide.  For a dog that size give him 1.5 cups of peroxide every 10 minutes until he vomits.



It would not do any good to make your dog vomit now that it's been a few days.



I am suspicious though about him eating the chocolate.  Most dogs pull of atleast most of the papers.  If he ate the papers and foil along with the chocolate that might give him an additional upset stomach.  I would check some of his stool that is outside and see if you can see the papers/foil in it.  That would give you a good idea if he really ate the chocolate.



Your dog weighs ~53 kg. It requires 100-150 mg/kg of theobromine (that's what's in chocolate that dogs are toxic to) to cause a toxic reaction. So your dog could eat as much as 5300-7977mg to have a toxic reaction. Usually milk chocolate contains 44 mg of theobromine per ounce. So, if each candy bar weighs 2 ounces (most are not that big), then he would have eaten 88 mg theobromine per bar times 16 bars equals 1408 mg of theobromine injested. So, mathematically your dog may have an upset stomach - but should survive. Usually the chocolate is out of the system within 36 hours.



I don't know if you can follow that math - but, it should make you feel better!



Best wishes!



Source(s):



Work at a vet



</answer>
