<answer from>



BelleK
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 910 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Well dog years is not a "made up" thing. It's very real. It's a comparison between how a human ages in years and how a dog ages in years. And since humans relate to time in years, that's how "dog years" came to be.



And by the way, a dog does not age exactly 7 years for every 1 human year. To be more precise, a dog ages rapidly in the first 2 years. Every month is equal to one human year. A 3 month old puppy is like a 3 year old child in regards to his learning, growth and development. A 2 year old dog is like a 24 year old human. After 2 years, every year is like 4 human years. So a 5 year old dog is like a 36 year old person in terms of how their body is aging and their life expectancy.



This of course varies from breed to breed as large dogs have a shorter life expectancy and small dogs live longer. But it is a much more accurate guideline than the typical 7 dog years for 1 human year ratio.



Edited to add: I don't know anyone who says their dog is "36 in dog years" when they have a 5 year old dog, they say "he's 5." My pups are 8 months old, I don't say they're "8 years old in dog years". But realizing that they are developmentally equivalent to an 8 year old child is helpful. I know what I can and can't expect from an 8 year old. The dog years comparison is only to help understand a dog and how it develops and ages. We are humans and therefore understand human development better than any other species, which is why the comparison is *helpful*, but not written in stone.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hanna
Member since: 21 April 2007
Total points: 223 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Although it's 'very real' I simply do not go for it. Why convert their age into something 'human'. They aren't human and that's a simple fact. They have birthdays every year as we do, not every 7. While I understand the fact that humans need to make sense of everything, I just don't like it, nor do I go along with it.



</answer>

<question from>



Alberto Cinco

<question>



How long will a female dog stay in heat?

<question>



Should I get another dog her age, or a puppy?



I'm considering getting a sibling for my dog, so she can have a someone to keep her company while we're not home, and so she can have a playmate. She'll be 4 in January. I don't know what age of dog to get though.



On one hand I'd like to get a puppy so I can train it myself and make sure it grows up well-mannered and healthy, and so it can grow up with my dog, and of course puppies are just so cute...but on the other hand, there are tons of older dogs out there that are in shelters, I'd be able to find one that's very sweet and well trained I'm sure, and my dog is huge so if I got a puppy it would be a while before they could actually play with each other without me worrying about the little one being crushed.



I don't know which age my dog would prefer or which would be best. What do you guys think?



</question>



<answer from>



Jilly M
Member since: 24 July 2008

Plus i don't have to worry about all the puppy shots, so that saves on some vet bills. <answer>



Personally I would go for a slightly older rescue dog.  The shelter will normally let you see how the two dogs get on before you make a final commitment.  Puppies are fine but they quickly get into adolescence and are adults before you know it.  You will not know for certain how the hierarchy will work out and how well they will get on until the puppy is sexually mature.

I would go with looking for a dog maybe a year or two younger than your dog because by then it will have grown it it's full size and should be trained and if your dog is in your house, house broken. <answer from>



Talltail
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 6876 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



A dog is not a child. Make sure you don't treat a dog like a child. And there is no such thing as a "teacup" dog. You may be able to adopt a sickly and small yorkie, but the price will be high. These dogs have medical problems up the wazoo. I suggest you stick with rescuing a normal-sized yorkie.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hanna
Member since: 21 April 2007

<question>



Bichon Frise - pros and cons of owing one....?



We are thinking of buying a Bichon Frise - what are the pros and cons of those types of dogs?



</question>



<answer from>



Accept Reality-face the facts
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 2625 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's a BREED,not a "type"!



Personal preference-I'm NOT interested any wittle white hairy (needs LOTZA grooming!)wap-dogs.
Are you?
Go READ the breed standard at the AKC  site *first*!



</answer>



<answer from>



kelsy&lt;...
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 690 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My grandparents had one and they live 2 houses away from me and she was a fantastic dog! everything was good with her except one thing her eyes had this brownish color below them but it wasnt that bad!! ughh I miss her. My neighbor didnt like dogs and my grandparents dog got loose and she came back home to their house and she got poisoned by antifreeze from my neighbor it was so sad..we had to put her to sleep after that..;( I would highly recommend this dog!! For us she was such a great dog!



</answer>



<answer from>



Coley
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 2240 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A Bichon is higher maintence with grooming.  Any non-shed dog will be.  The white hair is hard to keep white & tangle free.  There is expense involved with constant professional grooming.  There is no reason however that the typical dog owner can't learn to groom their own dogs.  A good clipper cost about 150.00, during the life of your dog the savings will be vast.



As far as personality, Bichons are bouncy happy dogs.  I used to hate them because I don't like toy poodles.  Poodles are known to be nervous and snippy & yippy!  Bichons are not!  For me, they are yappers but not as much as the poodle.  Because they are not a nervous dog, the Bichon doesn't carry on with the barking indoors.  They bounce around considerable but when you pick them up they instantly snuggle with you.  They really love human companionship & are good with all age of people.



I will warn you, however, the Bichon can be hard to housebreak so you must be on top of things!  They seem to take a bit longer to mature and develop full bladder control.



Otherwise, they catch on quick and love to be taught tricks.



They are prone to envirnmental allergies themselves.



Source(s):



I just got 2 Bichons and my views of them have changed drastically.



</answer>



<answer from>



woooh!
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 7804 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



High maintenance pup! Daily brushing is a must.
They are sweet dogs that require grooming every 4 weeks to keep them looking like they should.  Will be a good 'kid' dog.



</answer>



<answer from>



pierced_...
Member since: 13 October 2007
Total points: 17069 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



The pros and cons to any breed will depend on what you are looking for in a dog as well as what suits your life style.



They are small dogs so they are good for someone who lives in an apartment b/c they do not require much room or as much exercise as say a lab would need. Since they need less exercise they can be good for someone who doesn't have much time or doesn't like very long walks... However no one should get a dog if they can not spend a descend amount of time in the day with their dog...they are social animals. This would be a con for those who want a dog that they can go on runs with... smaller dogs can tire out more easy then bigger dogs.



They require a lot of grooming. This can be a con or a pro... if you like to pamper your pooch then this would be a good dog to do so. If you don't like the idea of daily grooming then this wouldn't be a good breed.



Health issues are also a concern and should be known when getting any dog... for this breed they are:



Some are prone to watery eyes, cataracts, skin and ear ailments, also epilepsy and dislocated kneecaps. They can be very sensitive to flea bites.



They are easy to train which can be a pro. They also make good show dogs if that is an interest. But they can be hard to house train.



These are just a few points and you can find out more about the breed off this site



http://www.dogbreedinfo.com/bichonfrise....



Source(s):



The site mentioned, a dog breed book ( encyclopedia of dog breeds, by joan palmer) and my parents own a bichon.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chick with Brains
Member since: 20 March 2007
Total points: 232 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My sister had one with several health problems that died just after her first birthday.  What ever breed you choose, check out the breeder and see the conditions the dog was bred in.  If you purchase the animal from a pet store, see if you can find out where the puppy came from.



Regardless of where you decide to purchase a puppy from - store or private individual - see if there have been any complaints about the breeder before you buy and always get (and carefully read) a warrenty.  A friend a mine bought a Papillon from a private breeder.  Two days after they brought her home they were at the vet.  After spending $800 the dog still died.  The breeder offered to give them $200 off another puppy.  Had they done their research, they would have found several complaints had been filed against the individual.



Good Luck.



</answer>

<answer from>



Overcast...
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 4234 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're all pretty good with children- as long as the children know how to treat them nicely (no pulling tails, pushing down on their backs, etc.) so you need to make sure that your girls know not to do anything like that, or anything worse, because small dogs are much more fragile, and even a little kid pushing down on their back, can cause damage to that back for their entire  life. I do know, however, that the bichon frise tends to be a HUGE show-off, and will most-likely be the most entertaining.
ALthough I do have to suggest that since they are all great dogs, you should wait until you can get one in an animal shelter- one that NEEDS a home, not a dog from a store that most likely came from a puppy mill, not only does it support puppy mills, but they are more expensive, AND usually have more health problems. That's why some pet stores will sign the animals with problems over to the vet- they have health problems, but don't want to pay for it, so they ask the vet to put them down, but some vets will ask to have them sign the dog over to him, so he can find a proper owner who will pay the vet bill (and no extra fee!)
So check online shelters, and local vet offices, because then you can feel extra good about your new family pet :]



</answer>

<answer from>



Kari M
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 3265 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the best dogs are Shihtzus - they are the most even tempered out of all of the small dogs.  After that come the yorkies and poodles - but they can get crabby with age.



Bichons and Cavaliers are both VERY energetic dogs.  They arent' bad dogs - but their energy often turns a lot of people off.  Bichons can be affordable, but Cavaliers are usually very expensive.



I would recommend vising your local shelter.  They will have small breed dogs.  Adults are great - you can find one that is already house trained and kid friendly.  With small breed dogs though,  you MUST use a crate or they will never be house trained (take them outside regularly to go to the bathroom)  and just put them in the crate when you can't watch them closely.



An adult dog (they do have puppies) you can check their temperament.  Will they allow you to take away their food?  Can you turn it over and hold it upside down?  How does it feel about being restrained - can you touch its feet for a nail trim or ears to apply meds when restrained?  Have it on a leash in a large area and have someone jog up to it.  Does it happily greet the person or does it cower away or growl?  Our shelters are full right now - and the animals desperately need help!



There is nothing wrong with adopting a mix breed dog from a shelter.  They're not as expensive as the $1000 bichons and cavaliers and they can make great dogs.



Best wishes and enjoy your new dog!



EDIT:  If you do end up buying from a breeder - search far and wide for a breeder that has kids!  The breeders that don't have kids keep their puppies crated most of the time and really aren't that well socialized.  When breeders have kids - the puppies can't help but be socialized.



Source(s):



Work at a vet, foster mom for dogs



</answer>



<answer from>



getyourl...
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 808 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Boston Terriers are notoriously good with children. Mine LOVES kids. They are funny, entertaining and they love to be loved.



My dog was at the dog park a few days ago and two young girls were there - one had cognitive deficits - clearly limited mentally and my BT just loved on her and played with her and allowed her to pick her up and play with her.



The other girl, who appeared very normal, played with her too, with no troubles or problems. They LOVED her.



**note: for those who recommended Cocker Spaniels -- they are notoriously NOT good with children and snap and bite if annoyed or upset. I would NOT recommend a Cocker Spaniel to anyone with children...or a Dalmatian...or a Chow  Chow...or a few other breeds. Most terriers do tend to be good with children provided they aren't rough with the dog. My pit bull loved children.



To Kari:
I would not assume that a reputable breeder that has children is always the way to go for a dog that's good with children. I got my Boston Terrier from a single older woman who has been breeding, showing and training Boston Terriers for 30 years. My Boston was not raised around kids and she's just LOVELY. She will allow kids to handle and play with her her. She loves adults because she was in the show ring for a time. The right breeder can raise good, socialized dogs without children on the premises.



Source(s):



BT owner, experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Lookie Baby
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 194 (Level 1)

<answer from>



Coley
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 2240 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Both would be good choices but I will mention the differences in the breeds.  I personally would go with the Cavy (I raise & show them & am totally in love with this breed!)



The Cavy will shed.  Drawback for many.  The Bichon needs constant grooming.  So you are swapping and undesirable for an undesirable.  My opinion is shave the cavy in the spring- good to go!



The Cavalier nature is much mellower.  They are sweet and gentle (as is the Bichon)  The Bichon is a clown the Cavalier is a that mellow understanding dog.  The Cavy is quick to pick up housetraining the Bichon will take a lil longer.



The Cavalier will cost you more initially the Bichon is much cheaper.  You must be careful when shopping for a Cavalier breeder!  They are prone to heart problems just to name the biggest concern in the breed.



The choice should be dependant on the energy level of the family.  Can you tolerate a happy dog bouncy around in the midst of things? (Bichon)  Or would a snuggle buddy who lies on your lap or at your feet suit your family better? (Cavalier)  The Bichon IS a goer!  Don't get me wrong the Cavy has a wonderful explorative nature and loves walks and playtime but overall much more low-key.  Another thing that needs to be considered is the amount of time you are away from home on a general week.  If the dog is to be left alone for 40+hrs, a Cavalier is not for you.  I wouldn't even consider selling one to that type of household.  They thrive on human interaction!



Good Luck in your puppy search:o)



</answer>

I just used a whole bottle of Natures Miracle on the stain itself (after getting the poo up) and nothing.  Its still very much there.



I have a little green machine but it doesn't work too well but I'm fixing to try it.....

</question>

<question>



My pug puppy's leg, is there a problem?



I just got a pug puppy. She is very small, the breeder said 2 months old, but i would say she is 6 weeks. Anyway, when she runs and walks fine, but the problem is that her left foreleg shakes when she is sitting still and applying pressure to it. The same leg, where her paw and leg connect (wrist area), it seems as if it bends forward and seems EXTREMELY flexible. She almost topples over when she applies pressure to it because it jutts forward. She is clumsy so I figured its a puppy thing. I am taking her to the vet to get her shots this Friday so I will ask him, but I really want to know now if this is normal. It almost seems like it was broken and healed wrong. She plays and runs, and shows no signs of pain or displeasure when I touch that leg. Are pug babies normally very flexible and clumsy, and does it seem like they have a "joint" problem. Will this clear up? Any suggestions or advice will help me stop worrying and also give me questions to ask the vet. Thank you!!!



</question>

<question>



Taking Dogs to New York from Dubai?



Hi,



Me and my Husband would be relocating to NY and we want to take our 2 labradors with us...Is there any quarantine perod in US??We Imported our dogs to dubai from India last month without any trouble. All vaccinations are up to date and they are microchipped. Is it necessary to do a rabies anitibodies neutralization test from a defra approved lab to take them to NY?? we had got this test done from NIMHANS, Bangalore, India ( not a defra approved lab) before importing them to dubai.



All info about taking our pets to NY will be greatly appriciated...Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Meaghan
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 2901 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no quarantine. You will need the proof of rabies vaccination as well as a health clearance from a vet. Make sure your dogs are in excellent condition before they travel because if they appear sick upon entering the states, they will be sent back on another flight.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sally S
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 245 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



To take your dogs to USA, you will need certified form filled out by veterinarian.  Similar to the one you got when you departed India.  Go online to US government website, where there is a section on bringing animals into the USA.  I am an American living in India, and have recently dealt with taking my dog back and forth.  With the required documents properly filled out, you will have no trouble taking the dogs to USA.



GOOD LUCK!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Accept Reality-face the facts
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 2619 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why aren't you asking the PROS at the airlines instead of strangers-on-line?



There's no quarantine in the US,nor is there a titer needed.



</answer>

<question>



My doggy has issues????



I noticed  red "rash-like" blotches on the back of my Silky Terrier. She's been scratching at it constantly, now there are scabs and bruising where the blotches once were. I don't recall her getting into anything that may have cause irritation to her skin, and I haven't fed her anything out of the ordinary that she may be allergic to. She don't seem to be missing any fur anywhere, her energy is normal, and her appetite is fine, and she was thorouhgly checked for fleas (none found).  Does these symptoms sound familiar to anyone? If so, is it something that could be treated at home, or should I just take her to the vet ASAP?



</question>



<answer from>



Lauren
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

Good luck!



</answer>

Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 836 (Level 2)

pierced_...
Member since: 13 October 2007

Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



If your dog is in heat they should never be unsupervised where other dogs are..so anytime outside the home and inside the home with other dogs around.



If you think she is pregnant a vcet can tell you for sure by x-rays after 55 days, ultrasound after 4 weeks and by palpation after 3 weeks.



Dogs are pregnant for an average of 63 days from when they tie (have intercourse)



Here are some useful sites on pregnancy... Also if you feel you want to do this an emergency spay and termination of the pregnancy can be done, just speak with your local vet.



Info on termination of the pregnancy



http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content...



On pregnant care



http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content...



When puppy's are born/ what to look for in trouble pregnancy



http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content...



</answer>

<question>



How to get runny dog poo out of carpet?



My dog had runny poo this morning and normally he tells me when he needs to go out (he had just been out 2 hours before) but this time he didn't wake me and got down on the floor and went....well it was sticky and as I tried to clean it up it tried to stick to my carpet.....



I just used a whole bottle of Natures Miracle on the stain itself (after getting the poo up) and nothing.  Its still very much there.



I have a little green machine but it doesn't work too well but I'm fixing to try it.....



Any tips would be great (Also he got some on my favorite shirt I brought back from NYC is it salvagable?)



</question>



<additional details>



He is not sick by the way just going through a food transistion



</additional details>



<answer from>



Monst3rE...

<answer from>



coax_me_...

<answer>



Tide with Bleach or any other color safe laundry detergent with bleach or stain remover works wonders. Get a really good brush and scrub it in really well, let it sit for a few min and then scrub again. Whenever I use this method I end up steam cleaning the whole carpet because the spots where the stains were turn out whiter than the rest of it.



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer from>



Sally S
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 245 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



After you have cleaned the carpet with something like Simple Green, use club soda to take out the smell.  Sometimes a solution of vinegar and water will help remove sticky runny poo.  Keep club soda around to take odors away; works great.  Try a vinegar solution on your shirt, too.



Source(s):



About fifty years experience with dog poop of all kinds.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sassy
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 836 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



First try to sponge up as much poo as you can with a wet sponge.  Then soak up as much wetness as you can.  Mix up a solution of 50% white vinegar and 50% water.  Fully saturate the stain with this solution and work into the carpet with a scrub brush.  Blot up the wetness again.  This will neutralize any odor.  When the area has dried sprinkle a good handful of baking soda over the soiled area.  Mix 1/2 cup of 3% hydrogen peroxide with a teaspoon of dish detergent.  Put on rubber gloves and slowly pour the solution over the baking soda.  Work the dissolving baking soda well into the carpet, first with your fingers and then with a brush.



Allow area to dry completely and the vacuum thoroughly.



Important.  Never use ammonia or ammonia based products.  One of the ingredients of urine is ammonia and may encourage your dog to urinate in that spot.



</answer>

<question>



What do you think about...?



Natures recipe puppy formula with lamb and rice. It has no corn and suppose to be free of preservatives and fillers.



</question>



<additional details>



I am feeding my poodle this. I do add canned food to her mix at least once a day and sometimes twice depending on her excercise.



</additional details>



<answer from>

Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 447 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<answer from>



Sally S
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 245 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nature's Recipe is OK.  Eukanuba or Iams are better.  If you can get her to eat only dry kibble, is much better than adding canned food.  Poodles are notorious for becoming very picky about their food, just as soon as they figure out they can manipulate you into giving them the "goodie".



</answer>



<answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



migitalw...
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 132 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It really depends on what you need it for. If your dog has an allergy to grains, preservatives, colorants (like red beet juice), or a filler, you're better off getting a prescription dog food. Commercially available dog foods don't have to meet FDA requirements, so if the company makes dog food that does have any of these ingredients in the same building, there could still be some in the food you're buying. A prescription food has to be manufactured using the same guidelines as any other drug, which means all equipment must be washed down between production runs.



If you're just looking for a premium pet food, Natures Recipe, Nutro, or Eukanuba are all great foods. Purina and Pedigree have premium brands as well, but they're not anywhere close to the level the above mentioned are. The best way to gauge the quality is to compare the feeding charts. The foods that require less per day have more nutritional ingredients.



Source(s):



6 month food allergy trial with my boston. I went through 4 different prescription foods.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kaetlyn
Member since: 31 March 2008
Total points: 7086 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nature's recipe is a decent food. In contrast to what someone else had commented-it IS better than Iams, Eukanuba (aka pukeanuba), Science Diet, etc. All of these foods contain fillers, chemicals, preservatives, and the quality of actual "meat" in them is terrible (byproduct-which consists of ground up beaks, feet, feathers, and anything else that isn't exactly good or nutritious)



You may look at hollistic foods-which contain only natural products and don't have any chemicals (Science diet, for example, contains a chemical called copper sulfate-this is a PETSTICIDE. It is put in the food at the food plant in order to keep vermin out of the it. It is carcinogenic, tumerogenic, and absolutely NOT something you want in your dogs food!)
Some good brands to consider:
Fromm, Orijen, Wellness, Innova EVO, Chicken Soup for The Dog Lover (yes, not only is it a book-but a food!), Merrik, and California Natural, just to name a few.



These foods won't be found in big-name pet stores, but if you visit the websites for each food (such as Natura's website) they have a list of suppliers that you can find. I do believe that Petco carries Solid Gold, which isn't a bad food either.) They ARE more expensive, but since they are so healthy your dog doesn't need to eat as large of an ammount of food as they would on...say..Purina. Also, in the long run, it will spare your dog some health problems caused by feeding bad foods with chemicals.



Hope I helped =]



</answer>



<answer from>



b.w.
Member since: 17 May 2006
Total points: 19472 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not the best but certainly not the worst. The first ingredient should be lamb, not lamb meal. Also dogs should have whole egg, not dried egg.



</answer>

<question>



I did the Cesar Millan move on my dog...?



When me and my giant 1yr old great pyrenees wrestle...he gets on his back and starts pawing and kicking me with all of his legs.  Then I calmly place my hand on the bottom of his face and the top of his neck and push it to the ground gently, pushing his body on the other side.



He calms down and looks away.



What does this mean?



</question>



<additional details>



his body is the same side as his face so in other words I'm restraining him.



People say this is a bad thing to do but he's not a dominant dog.



Now if I did this on my brother's golden I might get bit right?



the golden is a dominant pup



no I was just doing this for fun as to say "haha I win"



and it's not a Millan thing I made that up.  Id on't know what you call it



I'm not choking him at all.



he was playing. Wasn't aggressive at all.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sasha
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 331 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Quite simply he is accepting you as the alpha of your pack.  This is very common behavior.  It is also a good thing.  This is a good way to show dominance without hurting your dog.  He will respect you for it. I have done this type of play for 28 years and have never had a dog turn aggressive.  Good for you.



Source(s):



Over 28 years of training, showing, breeding giant breeds of dogs.



</answer>

k



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Why are you dominating him when he is trying to play ? Aggression builds aggression.. Do you know that Cesar does things on TV that he should never be showing people.. People who don't have the whole story, who don't know how to train, shouldn't be doing the things that Cesar does.. Alot more goes on behind the scenes that you never see..



Quit dominating your dog, your going to make him fearful or aggressive.. Yup your brother's dog might bite you.. IF he is truly dominant.. People often have no idea what to look for when deciding if a dog is dominant..



Take some training classes.. Playing and pawing isn't a problem that should be dealt with by using aggression.. It should be corrected properly.



</answer>

<answer>



It means he doesn't want to be choked on the neck. What would YOU do if somebody you loved "calmly and gently pushed your neck to the ground", and you couldn't communicate verbally with them?  Why are you "doing moves" on your dog that you don't know what they "mean"?

Dogs don't "make moves", anyway -- certainly not moves that mean "haha" anything...He's just putting up with the weird stuff you do to him.

<question from>



Kat S
Member since: 23 October 2006
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Puppy growls and barks at me when corrected.  Is this normal? ?



When I correct my 15-week-old Boxer-Lab mix puppy, she stops the behavior but barks and/or growls at me in response to the correction.  She will sometimes also lunge at me while doing this (occasionally touching skin), and then run off quickly out of my reach and then give more growls/barks.  When this happens, I don't chase her.  I say "No!" again and walk away and ignore her for several minutes.  I've been consistent with these responses since we got her at 9-weeks old, but the behavior is continuing.  Any ideas?



</question>



<answer from>



Ty B
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 5298 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You didn't mention what your corrections are



</answer>



<answer from>



Weimaraner Mom
Member since: 21 March 2007
Total points: 19666 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



You need professional training enroll in an extended obedience training facility [not Petsmart] and learn how to train her properly.  Problem is even though you are ignoring the behavior you are still reinforcing it with the NO.  You shouldn't correct you should just walk away and ignore and don't reinforce it further by saying no or yelling at the dog.  Aggression begets more aggression.



You need help on properly correcting unwanted behavior and that's where a professional trainer can help.  Please seek help before your 15 week old boxer turns into a huge aggressive adult.



</answer>



<answer from>



migitalw...
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on how you're correcting her. If all you're doing is telling her "No!", she's not really going to respond to it if she thinks she's the alpha dog of the pack. You need to assert dominance by flipping her on her back and holding her there until she submits. Do this now while she's still a manageable size, and she'll eventually learn to listen to you and respond accordingly when she knows you don't like something she's doing.



If that doesn't help, My obedience trainer uses a spray bottle set to shoot a stream of water with a very small amount of hand soap in it. When a dog gets out of line, you say "No!" and shoot for the forehead and they immediately stop what they're doing. The soap won't hurt their eyes as long as it's a very tiny bit. Just make sure the dog doesn't see you grabbing the bottle, or they'll only respond when they see you go after it.



</answer>



<answer from>



pierced_...
Member since: 13 October 2007
Total points: 17080 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Correction can lead to fear aggression.



She is also 15 weeks old... she still doesn't know what is bad and good behaviour and is learning by how you are reacting and teaching her.



Enrolling in obedience training should be the first step. Talk with your vet and ask for a recommendation for a trainer in your area.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael Krivolenkov
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 363 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question from>



freakywe...
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I have a medium sized (75lb?) dog. 10 months old. How often and how much should she be fed?



Currently i feed her about six to eight cups of dry food daily. Half in the AM half in the PM. Problem is even if I take her outside as late as 11 PM, she has done number 2 on the carpets by morning. Usually when she does this, it is done in several spots, not just one accident. Am I feeding her too much? I got her from a friend and they claim to have fed her this much, but she is really skinny. She looks too skinny.



</question>



<answer from>



Meaghan
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 2903 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is a LOT of food, for any dog. My dogs are 50 lbs and they only eat 3 cups a day. Take her to the vet and see if there is any underlying problem, worms is the first thing that comes to my mind.



</answer>



<answer from>



Weimaraner Mom
Member since: 21 March 2007
Total points: 19666 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree that's a lot of food, if she's skinny and she's eating that much sounds like she has a tape worm or a parasite that is causing her to be skinny.  I have a 60lb dog and all she eats is 2 cups a day.



Make sure you don't feed past 5 pm at night if she's pooing in several spots there's an underlying problem or she's not completely housebroken, dogs are usually not reliable until about a year old.  Keep her in your room at night so you'll hear when she gets up, that's your cue to take her outside to potty.



Have her checked by a vet and take in a stool sample, that much food and skinny don't go hand in hand, with that much food she'd be very fat not thin.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jordan L
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would take her to the vet because surely she has a problem somewhere. The first thing i think of is worms, but there could be other problems. She needs to be on a schedule, what ever your work or school schedule may be that needs to be the feeding times. Once in morning and once at night. My 3 dogs eat 1 1/2 cups each. twice a day and they are good sizes. i have a 50 pd 33pd, which he never eats all of his but he usually will share with my new pup who is only 10 pds. definalty get that pup to a dr. as far as the potty on the carpet, try using a crate that is just big enough for her to turn around in that way she wont do that. Dogs wont potty where they sleep, they will if where they sleep they ahve lots of room and can get away from it.



</answer>

<question>



Legal advice...What would YOU do in this situation?



Me and my husband just had our beloved dog Marley euthanized because of aggressive behavior to our 3 year old daughter.  It was a very tough decision, but we know we made the right one.  We miss her terribly!!!



Anyways, my question is this...The vet gave us our options for what to do with her remains and we choose to have the private one which means we get her ashes back after she gets cremated.  We were told it would be within a week.  We'll tomorrow will be 2 weeks to the day and we still have had no call from the vet indicating that we can come pick her ashes up.  If the vet screwed up, what legal actions should we take?



</question>



<additional details>



The reason why I havn't called the vet directly yet is because I don't want to ask them "where are my dog's ashes" and have them look into it and after they realize they screwed up they try to cover themselves by giving me some bulk ashes of some other dog or whatever so I don't think none the wiser.  Know what I mean???



And for the people who are looking down at me for euthanizing my dog for behavior aggression to my child, you obviously do NOT have kids!!  I tried to rehome her to 3 different places.  No one would take her!!!  This is the last thing that I ever wanted to happen, but like i said, I had no choice.

<answer>

<answer from>



rescue member
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 24241 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You had your "beloved"  dog euthanized and now you want to sue the vet over the ashes - if you had taken this much trouble to re=train or rehome your poor dog that you are putting into a possible lawsuit, I would have some respect for you.



As it is, all I want to do is tell you never to get another dog - they really aren't disposable when they become inconvenient for some reason, and don't get all huffy about your child being more important - lots of people have kids and dogs, they make the effort to train both to be respectful of each other - and they are usually successful.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



First let me say how very sorry I am for your loss and the very difficult choice you made.



My suggestion is to contact the vet clinic instead of waiting for them to contact you. Pet remains are typically sent out to a cremation service and it can sometimes take up to a month to return the ashes if there is a lot of work that arrives in the same time frame. I know you are grieving, but please be patient with the process of returning the pet ashes. Your vet has very little control over the timeline of an outside company.



</answer>



<answer from>



pierced_...
Member since: 13 October 2007

<answer>



You may want to re-post this in the legal section on YA. They may be able to help you more.



If there was a written agreement then there is a good chance you will have some legal ground, for what I'm not sure. I wouldn't hold the vet office fully accounted in the mistake if there is one.. The cremation place may be to blame here and not your vet



Personally I'd call up the vet's office and ask what is going on. A key to get a more effective response to ask politely and try to hold your anger. There could have been something that is taking longer on the cremation places behalf. Or the mail could have an issue sending it back.



I'd also make sure to find out all info before taking legal action...you'll want to know who is really at fault instead of just pointing fingers.



I am sorry for your loss, and i hope everything works out for the best for you.



</answer>

<question from>



Jordan L
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do you handle new puppy aggression?



I just recently adopted a new pup. Her name is Trinity Eclipse and she is a beautiful pure white, blue eyed, siberian husky. She is the sweetest thing until its time to eat. Now I know that puppies need food and water at all times until they grow so needless to say she has food and water at all times. My other two dogs love her, they are teaching her to play with them, they actually gave her a bone to chew, its the sweetest thing. The only problem is the other two have strict eating schedules. Morning and evening when i get home from work. I put their food down when i get home at 5pm and they nibble as they please, well Trinity decided she wanted to eat out of their bowl and when she did she growled and bit me and my other two dogs. I have continued to try to correct the problem by giving her her own food bowl, didnt help. I have also supervised them all while eating and everytime she will do it i will speak loudly the word "no" i'm just lost...i have never had a dog that was food aggressive??? help?? She is also toy aggressive, she will tear the others up over a toy. The other two are lovers so they will walk away from her and let her have what she wants, including the food. I know i couldnt convience the other two to eat on sunday at all, until i put her outside because they dont want to fight with her. someoene please help



</question>



<additional details>



Sorry i forgot to mention its only with my two dogs. Not with me or my hubby in anyway. I can put my hands in her food/do whatever i want with her toys but my two she will eat up. Whats interesting is she wotn do that with my moms dog.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ty B
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 5298 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Two things:
1- Puppies should not have access to food at all times.  They should be on an eating schedule.
2- You shouldn't be feeding these dogs together.  You need to separate them to feed them



</answer>

<answer from>



Weimaraner Mom
Member since: 21 March 2007
Total points: 19666 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Does Trinity have a crate? Trinity needs to be fed in her crate with the door shut until the other dogs have finished their meals.  don't leave food down all day for Trinity she needs to eat the same time as your other two dogs.  Start feeding her a bit of her kibble by hand to make her understand the food comes from you and therefore she should never bite the hand that feeds her.  Puppies can become food aggressive but you need to stop that behavior immediately by nipping it in the bud.  Standing over her bowl [feet on either side of the bowl] will show her you're the boss and you are claiming the bowl as yours, she should back off and give you space until you release her to eat.  You should also control when she eats and she should eat only on your command.  Once your other dogs have finished their food you need to pick up their bowls.  No more grazing they must learn to finish or it's gone.  You should be able to put your hands in the bowl or pet your dog while they are eating and the dog not have a problem with it infact they should back off and stop eating [mine do]  I never wanted a dog that was food aggressive so I worked from 8 weeks old, putting my hand in the bowl and petting her while eating, even taking the bowl away and then replacing it.



My dog is toy possessive at the park, she will growl at another dog if they try to grab what she has in front of her, it's ignored however she will allow me to remove things from her mouth without problems.



Start training now, pick up books to help if you are unsure and sign up for obedience classes now before your pup turns into a 60lb snapping growling aggressive adult.



Add:  You should never use your hands to remove a dog from somewhere, always use your body and move them with your legs with your hands out of the way, sort of body blocking, dogs understand this behavior, this prevents you from having your fingers bitten off.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kaetlyn
Member since: 31 March 2008
Total points: 7096 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Start hand-feeding her her food. Just start by giving her the meals out of your hand-once that's going well, keep feeding her out of your hand-but put your hand over her bowl. As that goes well, lower your hand into her bowl, and feed her that way. After that, you can put your hand in the bowl, but let the food be in the bowl and just sort of play with it with your hand.
This way, she will learn to associate your hand and food/her bowl with being fed, rather than being afraid you are going to take her food away (this is why she is resource guarding her food).



With puppies one thing to keep in mind is that older dogs are often a bit leanient with them-they know they are young, and they do let them get away with things. However, as she gets older, the older dogs will start to put her in line a bit.



With the toy-when she begins guarding the toy like that and snapping-take it away IMMEDIATELY. What you need to do with that is slowly introduce yourself into it. When I first brought my pup home he would resource guard his toys or treats-the first time I sat down by him while he was chewing one he snapped right at me! I took it away immediately. From then on out, you have to take it very slowly. Introduce a toy by holding it, let her mouth it a bit, and then take it away and hold her back from trying to take it again/snapping you, once she is settled and you have the toy away from her-give it back so that she knows just because you want the toy doesn't mean it goes away forever (again, this is resource guarding-she snaps about her toys because she doesn't want them taken away!). When Brogan (my pup) would have a toy, I would approach him slowly and just sit down next to me. I would hold his collar so that he couldn't snap at me when I grabbed the toy-and then I would just take it from him-very calmly and relaxed. After a few seconds of me having it, and him sitting quietly-I would give him a treat, and then give him the toy back. He, over time, learned that I wasn't going to take the toy away forever, and that if he gave it to me-he got a treat.



You should also consider puppy classes-they are fun, and will help you gain some knowledge about the way. You can ask your trainer questions dealing with any troubles you are having and they will help you out to fix them.



Hope I helped a bit.



</answer>



<answer from>



Loki Wolfchild
Member since: 13 December 2005
Total points: 32802 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually, puppies do NOT need food at all times. Leaving food out for them all the time makes it pretty well impossible to housetrain them.



Separate her when you feed the other dogs. Put her in a crate, or a different room. Use a baby gate.



Have you called her breeder? A responsible breeder would be happy to help you with a situation like this.



What you have is a pushy Siberian puppy. This is the breed. They like their resources, and will push to get what they want. Don't let her get away with it.



DON'T feed her with the other dogs.
DON'T free feed her. Give her a set schedule.
DON'T allow aggressive behavior. If you reach for her bowl and she growls, pick her up by her little scruff, raise her to eye level, and tell her to knock it the hell off. You are bigger than she is, and you are the human.



DO this exact same thing when she guards/growls over toys.
DO make her work for everything. Google the "Nothing in Life is Free" method of dog training. It works well for the breed.
DO enroll her in a puppy obedience class. You will both benefit.
DO some research on the breed. Siberians play "soft" owners like a harp. If you're having this much trouble now, her adolescence is going to be very rough for you.



These are things her breeder should have told you!



Good luck!



ADD: Here are a couple of NILIF articles to get you started:
http://k9deb.com/nilif.htm
http://www.westwinddogtraining.com/NILIF...



Source(s):



Siberian husky owner/exhibitor, musher, rescue, breeder for 20+ years.



</answer>



<answer from>



JenVT
Member since: 12 March 2007
Total points: 1953 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to feed her separately and make her wait until you say it's OK to eat.  Put the food down and hold her collar and tell her to wait.  When she stops struggling, let her eat.  It will take a few times before she figures it out.  You can also block the dish with your legs.  WHile she is eating, touch her and put your hands in the food dish. If she growls or nips, take it away and start again.



</answer>

<question>



Can my German Shepherd get pregnant by her own German Shepherd puppy?

<answer>



Yes of course he could get his mother pregnant? Why would you think that he could not. I had a friend her dog had four puppies. Unfortunately she waited too long to get them fixed and two of the puppies got it on when they were roughly 10 months old and thus she ended up with 3 more puppies.



Mating is a natural instinct animals don’t care who they get their thing on with their purpose is to pass on their seed.



Not knowing that the mother could be impregnated by her son just shows that you should not be breeding dogs. So either you need to educated yourself more or you need to get your dogs fixed

<answer from>



King Les The Lofty
Member since: 19 November 2007
Total points: 5524 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Very definitely.
I imagine that he has already mated her, unless she is one of the unusual bit.ches who comes on heat only once a year. He would have been fertile by 4 months old.
Whatever genetic defects she carries will be inherited in double-strength by some of their pups. As you had to ask HERE, instead of from the breeder of your bit.ch or a mentor, it is certain that she has no real virtues; but whatever she does possess will also be inherited doubly by some of their pups.



People who don't know that incest is normal among dogs probably don't know anything else important, either, such as testing for hips & elbows, having their bit.ch checked for type to see whether she IS breed-worthy, and checking ancestry & offspring of each ancestor to make sure that each stud being considered has superb hips & elbows & temperament and is unlikely to be carrying any genetic nasty that the brood is likely to be carrying.



Anyone intending to set up as a breeder should:
• have one escape-proof mating-proof pen per pooch.
• have a top breeder as their mentor
• subscribe to a breed club and compete in events run by their club.
• belong to several discussion groups about their breed. There are over 300 YahooGroups dedicated to various aspects of living with a GSD.
• have a library of books written by experts on their breed.
• study genetics.
Les P, owner of GSD_Friendly:  http://pets.groups.yahoo.com/group/GSD_F...
"In GSDs" as of 1967



</answer>

Mina
Member since: 19 December 2006

You need to keep them apart. Dogs (and other animals) don't recognise family relationships in the way humans do and will just see the chance to get frisky!

<question>



9 yr old dog neutered yesterday, wont drink, eat or pee, just sleeps?



Of course the vet office is closed today. I am very worried. All he will do is sleep. He hasnt had anything to drink for over 36 hours. I hand fed him some chicken, but then he went back to sleep. He wont go outside or pee or walk. What do I do?



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks for the responses. I made him drink a little water from a straw (I sucked it up and put it down the back of his throat). He actually got up to bark at the UPS man...so this is a good sign!



</additional details>



<answer from>



girl
Member since: 25 May 2007
Total points: 66 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't worry about it too much. When my dog got spayed she hardly got off the couch for 2 days. she slept a ton, didn't eat, i had to carry her to go do her business. the vet said this was all normal, its all part of the healing process



</answer>



<answer from>



Carrie L
Member since: 12 June 2007
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's normal to be exhausted after the anesthia, but your dog needs fluid.  You can use an eye dropper or liquid medicine dropper and force the water down to the back of his throat.  He will swallow it. As long as he is getting a few teaspooons of water every couple hours, he won't risk being dehydrated.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



doris s
Member since: 21 March 2007
Total points: 2246 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Give him some more time.  I am sure the surgery was a little harder on a 9 year old than a young dog.  My two young dogs slept a lot and did not eat much or drink much for 2 days after surgery.  When your vet opens tomorrow give them a call if you are still worried about him.  Good luck, I am sure your guy will be fine.



</answer>

<question>



Dog throwing up white foamy liquid?



I have a terrier mix, one y/o. She had a skin problem and she was perscribed a sterorid medicine, im not sure if this has anything to do with it. She is still eating fine and haveing bowel movements. She seems to throw up a lot of mornings with this white foamy liquid. Please Help!

</answer from>



<answer>

and if you have left out any Chocolate it could be that.



Source(s):

<answer from>



MamaB
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 4099 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Another similar question to one in the last few days.  White frothy upchuck can be an indication of a condition called Bloat - Gastric Torsion.  It's serious if so.  Is her tummy hard, and distended?  If yes, get her to a vet IMMEDIATELY.  This condition is life-threatening.  Even if this isn't the case, you can't hang around.



Of course, it may not be the case - but check her tummy size and don't delay if you at all suspect this is what's happening.  And I'm assuming, perhaps wrongly, that this is a one-off, or has it been happing over a number of days?  If so, yes, I suppose it could be a reaction to the steriods.  Again, check with vet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sampson
Member since: 11 October 2006
Total points: 794 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you considered the possibility of rabies?



</answer>

<question from>



grays113...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do  i  need  a  licence  to  stud  choclat  lab  he  is  hip



scored  eye  tested?



he  as  had  all  the  health  test  and  some  champions  in  hes  line



</question>



<answer from>



Meaghan
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 2913 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't need a license. You may want to consider getting him a working or show title. Champions in the line doesn't mean a whole lot. People want a proven dog. A dog with titles would be more valuable to someone looking for a stud. Think about how many chocolate Labs are out there in the world. Yours needs to be a lot more special than the next to have someone want to consider breeding to him. Getting a title would prove that he is breeding quality.



</answer>



<answer from>



rescue member
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 24249 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't need a license, you do need to show your dog and get him some championship points and titles, - and contacts, then you wouldn't have to ask on here.



"champion lines" means nothing, lots of champion dogs throw off pet quality dogs, means nothing at all .



</answer>



<answer from>



Accept Reality-face the facts
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 2637 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nope but you DO need a PROVEN quality dog *&* a brain-neither of which appears to be the case. You can't even spell chocolate-not that color matters.



"....some champions.." means squat!
"Health tests" mean squat!
Having "plumbing" means squat.



QUALITY & ability to pass that on means EVERYTHING!



</answer>



<answer from>



MamaB
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 4099 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



No Licence required in the UK - other than some Councils require a Breeding Kennel Licence if you are setting yourself up as a breeding kennel.



What you do need is a good dog, not just on paper, or in your eyes, but one with a good number of show wins under his belt, and possibly even a Championship title.  He's probably got a pedigree second to none, but forgive me, you are going about this the wrong way.



Have you spoken to his breeder about your lad?  Had her run her eye over him to give you her presumably expert view of his faults and his virtues.  Have you had him out to some shows.  If you are lucky, and the dog really is as good as you hope, he will attract attention from other exhibitors, with equally good b itches.  They might approach you for a stud.  But believe you me, it's not as easy as you think.  I've had good show dogs, who have probably had half a dozen studs between them.



Otherwise, I'm afraid all you are going to attract in the way of b itches for him, will be second rate, perhaps carrying the exact same faults as your dog, and the resulting puppies will carry a double up on those faults.



So first step - get an expert to give you an honest assessment of your dog.



</answer>

<original file>18423.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk108778.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



Mutt Dog™  Lover®
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 1953 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Help Please, My Mom *really* wanted me to ask these 2 questions and send her the link.?



Is it Ok to give my dog raw meat? If you are a raw feeder, please mention it in your answer. My mom wants me to send this link to her. Another question she wanted me to ask: Can you list of bad brands of dog food?



Thank You!!! Now maybe she'll stop bothering me.



</question>



<answer from>



Meaghan
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 2913 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, dogs have the stomach of a carnivore, it is designed to digest raw meat.



As for *bad* brands, that is really a subjective question. Some dogs do exceeding well on *bad* brands of dog food. The #1 Boxer in the country eats Purina, and I know this for a fact because I fed her myself every day for a year. Are there better foods out there? Sure. But a *bad* dog food food isn't bad for every dog.



</answer>



<answer from>



rescue member
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 24249 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just do a search for "raw diet" and send her the link.



Any supermarket dry is mostly corn meal based, as is Science Diet, even though some vets sell it (they get paid to stock it).



Tell her to read the ingredients for herself -corn meal is cattle feed, not dog nutrition.



Good brands have meat listed as the first ingredient, no corn meal fillers, no artificial preservatives - there are many, but they are not found in supermarkets or Walmart and they cost more.



I feed my dogs Canidae, which is excellent - but there are other good ones - just have her read the ingredients on what she buys.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sky's Mom
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am not a raw feeder and so I really don't know a lot about that, but here is a good website to check it out http://www.rawlearning.com/rawfaq.html.



As far as quality dog food brands, almost anything you find at supermarkets is not quality. They all contain corn fillers (even "good" foods like Iams and Science Diet). I recommend going to a feed store and finding something with a meat meal as the first ingredient (and second if possible). I will not buy my dog anything that contains corn, as this is not a good source of nutrition and a cause of many animal allergies. I check out any food I buy at http://dogfoodanalysis.com/.



Hope that helps!



</answer>

<answer from>



migitalw...
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Raw meat is typically ok to give to a dog, so long as you're sure it's not contaminated with something like salmonella. They wouldn't cook their food in the wild, so why should you feel the need to make sure everything you feed them is cooked?



Purina and Pedigree are bottom rung dog foods as far as I'm concerned. They're loaded with preservatives and fillers, don't specify protein sources, and are packed with grains (which dogs can't process well anyway, so it just comes out the other end).



If you're wanting to feed your dog a good food, but are worried about raw meat making them sick, you can either cook meat and veggies for them, or you can get a premium dog food that lists the sources for all of its' animal derived ingredients ("animal fat" is not specific enough)



</answer>



<answer from>



2008© Aliens know stuff



=-∆
Member since: 12 February 2006
Total points: 317 (Level 2)

My dogs are hunting dogs though so it just might be them.



I am not sure there is any "bad" dog food its different for every dog.

I am going to college to be a vet.

<answer>

<answer from>



pierced_...
Member since: 13 October 2007
Total points: 17082 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



IMO, No... I do not feed raw..but I have taken the time to research it as well as other foods and ways of feeding.



Here are the reason why I do not think giving raw meat is a good idea.



Raw meats can cause a dog to get worms, this is for raw beef. this type of worm is called coccidia.



Here is a link about these types of worms
http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content...



My next reason is raw meat can transfer salmonella and or e.coli. Not all professionals are certain that is can or can not be transferred through raw feeding but some have seen cases of these disease in animals and believe raw feeding can cause it. Also in some cases if the raw food has these and the dog is unaffected that doesn't mean you can not be. The dog will still shed the disease through their poop later on.. which can cause problems if it sheep into the ground in your yard..especially if your dog goes where you water system is. This also causes an issue with food dishes and they should always be cleaned after feeding.



here is one on E.coli and one on salmonella



http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content...



Some people believe that dogs were eat raw food in the wild so therefore they can digest it and they should be fed that. I think through the many years of evolution dogs can not digest raw food as easily as they could when they were wild. Also depending on what you believe some people think dogs are carnivore while others think omnivore. I believe omnivore based on research and what I learned in the vet assistant classes I took.



Raw bones... bones of any kind cooked or raw can cause obstruction to your dog anywhere along the way that their food goes. Most common are choking which is caused in the esophagus, and then next are along the gastrointestinal tract..



Here are some more pages on nutrition



http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content...



http://woodhavenlabs.com/dogfoods.html



I just wanted to add that I do not think feed a dog a natural diet which consists of raw veggies and cooked meat, and grains is bad...I think that this type of diet is a great idea, however before feeding this type of diet and raw feeding is you choose to do so it is very important to speak with a board certified nutritionist...there are only 5 in all of north america, your vet will be able to supply you with a number to reach one. The reason I say this is important is b/c all dogs need a certain amount of nutrients and vitamins/minerals in their diet and most people do not know what these are.. A nutritionist will formulate a diet that is right for your dog.



Source(s):



Sources are listed on my profile



</answer>

<answer from>



alias boxer
Member since: 18 September 2007
Total points: 7360 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, it is OK to give your dog raw meat.  Even bones are good for him as long as they are RAW (chicken bones, when raw, are actually safer than other bones!).



You can alternate feeding kibble and raw food, even just throwing in an occasional raw meal.  But you should NOT feed raw in the same meal with kibble (or with any carbohydrates for that matter).  The reason is that carbs take a lot longer to digest in dogs' systems, and if you fed raw meat at the same time it would also cause the meat to move through the system at a slower rate, potentially giving bacteria a chance to grow.  Dogs are well equipped to handle such bacteria, but one of the reasons they can is because they have very short digestive tracts that meat can pass through very quickly.



Good sites on RAW feeding:
http://www.rawlearning.com/rawfaq.html
http://www.rawfeddogs.net/



Bad dog foods:
Iams, Pedigree, Purina, Beneful, Ol' Roy, Alpo, Royal Canin, Science Diet, Eukanuba....
http://www.dogfoodanalysis.com/dog_food_...



</answer>



<answer from>



Forest Basenji
Member since: 10 October 2007
Total points: 9121 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't feed raw as a diet, only due to my job (truck driver) not making it feasible while on the road.  It is a treat for my dogs when we are home, but I have done so NUMEROUS occasions in the last 10 yrs with NO problems.



My dogs get raw bones, oxtails (cow tails) and chicken wings & necks as treats.  If I am making hamburgers or something with ground beef, they'll usually get a little raw "meatball" thrown to them.  If I am making beef stir-fry, they'll get a little piece of raw meat.  On Thanksgiving they get the turkey neck & all the "giblets" before I cook a turkey (no, I don't like giblet gravy LOL)....and both my mom & mother-in-law usually at least stick the turkey neck in the freezer for my dogs if we go to visit, since they know how much they enjoy it!



NEVER had a problem- and neither of my dogs really has a "iron clad stomach".  Eating junk human food & carb-heavy treats & dog food plays havoc with their insides- they'll get the farts & loose stools.  (Experience from a couple times where they accidentally got into something or people fed my dogs table food & crap treats behind my back).  Raw meat never gives them gas, and always makes for a nice firm, compact stool the next day.



As for "bad" foods- I know what works and what doesn't work for MY dogs....but what's "bad" for one dog may not always be "bad" for another.



Personally I wouldn't feed anything you can buy at Wal-Mart, but I know people who do, and their dogs do alright.  It's more about being able to accurately assess the overall "picture of health" your dog presents.  Some folks think a stinky dog-odor and copious shedding is "normal" until they switch to a premium brand and see the difference.  My Boxer of 14 years lived on Purina Dog Chow until she was 6, smelled like a dawg and shed buckets, year-round.  I figured....normal, dogs smell, and shed.  Taking a step up to Nutro Ultra almost eliminated ANY odor and brought her shedding down to a minimal once-yearly affair.  Her coat was gloriously soft until the day she died.



I will say I'd feed a dog out of my garbage can before I fed some of these "dollar store" brands of dog food....I like the dollar store for an occasional good bargain but WOW....I read the pet food labels just to see how horrifying it really is :).  The cheaper it is, the worse it usually is....Ol' Roy, Kibbles & Bits, any "generic" store brand....



</answer>



<answer from>

<question>

I have a 5 month old puppy who used to vomit 1 to 2 times a week. In the past month or so things have gotten a lot better. I got him a "slow down dish" so he cannot just gulp his food down. I figured maybe it was just a puppy phase and/or him eating too fast.



The past two days, however, he has vomited after his morning meal. He has not thrown up any other time, not even after his evening meal, and he is acting like his normal, wiggly, cat-chasing self.



I called the vet and he did not seem concerned, just said to keep on eye on it and if it keeps happening we might want to put him on a medicine that will help keep his stomach calm.



I did switch his food over last week to Canadae Lamb and Rice because he has had some allergy problems (chewing his paws). Also, about a week ago I started giving him a Clariton every night (vet suggested), also for the allergies. I have not seen him bite his paws anymore, but now we have this new problem. He never vomits after he gets the Clariton in the PM, but could it still be related?



Has anyone else had a puppy that had problems like this? It seems very odd to me, but he is my first dog so maybe this happens more than I think?

Contributing In:



Dogs



</question from>



<question>



What stops the pain after euthanasia?



I euthanized my dog yesterday. She was 1 month shy of being 2 years old. Whenever I have half a second to think I either see her smiling or her dying. The only difference is one causes great guilt and the other despair.



I have two other dogs that I love dearly but they aren't helping much. It's hard to concentrate on them when all I want is my Riley back. Worse yet I know that right now her body is in a refrigerator waiting to be cremated which may not be until 2 weeks from now. I used to believe in an afterlife but now I'm not so sure. We tried so hard to help her and we gave her a great life so why did the higher power give us no other options? Why don't I feel her presence anywhere? And if there is an afterlife will she find new people-companions since she only spent a year and a half with us?
I just want to know how to move on from this. No one seems to understand the pain I'm in. It's one thing to euthanize a dog because they are sick and old. It's another thing entirely to have to decide to euthanize because they were a danger to everyone and everything but yourself and no trainer/behaviorist/veterinarian/medicat... could help her.



Please do not mention Cesar Millan. First off her problem wasn't dominance, secondly he does not come to Maine, third he doesn't have room for the thousands of dogs people want him to rehabilitate, and forth he doesn't even reply to his e-mail (which I have tried 3 times). I can't believe how many people tell me to "just see Cesar Millan."



What's done can't be undone now so what I really need are some ways to heal. Thank you.



</question>



<additional details>



Seriously, this was a legitimate question and no one forced you to answer it. Getting professional help is very useful in clinical cases of depression not just to get you though the first few days. I have a B.A. in psychology. And there should be no shame in asking for a little help from people online who have gone through the same sorts of things. That's what yahoo answers is for.



Make that X2



For all of you people who are giving me genuine answers- thank you. They are much appreciated and a great comfort.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Jessica G
Member since: 18 April 2007

<answer>



I am so sorry for your loss.  I can't imagine what you must be going through.  Just know that it does get easier.  Right now, it probably feels like the pain will never ease.  And it may not for a while.  You will wake up one day, in a few days, weeks, months, who knows and realize that it hurts a little less today than it did yesterday.  I promise you it does get easier and start to hurt less.



</answer>

<answer>



I don't think you ever get over the loss of a dog, and I am sorry about Riley, I do know how you feel.



I stood by your bed last night, I came to have a peep.
I could see that you were crying, you found it hard to sleep.
I whined to you softly as you brushed away a tear,
"It's me, I haven't left you, I'm well, I'm fine, I'm here."
I was close to you at breakfast, I watched you pour the tea
You were thinking of the many times your hands reached down to me.
I was with you at my grave today, you tend it with such care.
I want to re-assure you, that I'm not lying there.
I walked with you towards the house as you fumbled for your key.
I gently put my paw on you, I smiled and said, "It's me."
You looked so very tired, and sank into a chair
I tried so hard to let you know that I was standing there.
It's possible for me to be so near you every day
To say to you with certainty, "I never went away."
You sat there very quietly, then smiled; I think you knew...
In the stillness of that evening, I was very close to you.
The day is over... I smile and watch you yawning
And say "good-night, God bless, I'll see you in the morning."
And when the time is right for you to cross the brief divide,
I'll rush across to greet you and we'll stand, side by side.
I have so many things to show you, there is so much for you to see.
Be patient, live your journey out... then come home to be with me.
~Author Unknown~



I Loved You Best
Author Unknown



So this is where we part, My Friend,
and you'll run on, around the bend,
gone from sight, but not from mind,
new pleasures there you'll surely find.
I will go on, I'll find the strength,
life measures quality, not its length.
One long embrace before you leave,
share one last look, before I grieve.
There are others, that much is true,
but they be they, and they aren't you.
And I, fair, impartial, or so I thought,
will remember well all you've taught.
Your place I'll hold, you will be missed,
the fur I stroked, the nose I kissed.
And as you journey to your final rest,
take with you this...I loved you best.



</answer>

<answer>



Three weeks ago you wrote: "Riley has never harmed or threatened to harm myself, my fiance or my second dog, Chester. When we introduced Madoc there were a couple minor scuffles for dominance but nothing to be concerned over...and then she attacked him...out of the blue...no warning signs."



A few days ago, you vaguely wrote she is a danger to "those within the house..." You meant the new DOG.



I wonder what kind of mixed messages your dogs get. Pack order among dominant breeds in a family is sometimes NEVER completely settled. You ought to know things can get pretty nasty between them. When you already have one that won't get along well with other dogs, you don't just keep getting more. I think you chose to ignore the warning signs in order to be able to keep the Staffy, even though it would mean throwing the other dog away. And now you want emotional support on top of it. What a shame.



Remember...the "Rainbow Bridge" isn't accessible from the Lake of Fire.
