<answer>



Dear "save", I am so terribly sorry for the loss of your loved one. I do know how it is to lose a dog that meant so much more to me than just a pet. Of course your other dogs can't take Riley's place. It must hurt so badly to know he was euthanized because of an aggression/behavior problem you could not fix. Try to remember though you didn't really have an option. He was the result of breeding you could not control. Try to focus on the fact that he had 2 years of a good life he wouldn't of had if it weren't for you. I'm sure you did everything you could for him. Sometimes, when we do the very best we can, it's just not enough. When that happens all we can do is wait, wait for time to lessen the pain. I still believe in an after life. I can't explain why bad things happen or why good people (or animals) suffer. I don't "feel" any of the dogs I've had in the past around me but I don't need to. What we believe doesn't depend on feelings. Feelings change far too often. All you can do now is get through each day as best you can. Don't forget about your other dogs. They can't take Riley's place but they do understand when you are hurting, they can sense that. I'm sure all the want to do is make you happy. That's the way dogs are. A little over a years ago my cat of 15 years died. I'd never had a cat before and didn't know you could become so attached. Well I did and it broke my heart when she died. For the next couple of days whenever I would think of her I would start to tear up, cry. Yes, I'm a man but I'm not ashamed to say I cried about my cat. Anyway my dog would not leave my side for anything during that time. In fact, when I took a shower she would insist on laying next to the tub. She was just about 1 1/2 years herself but she knew I was upset and wanted to make me feel better. Just hang in there and give it some time. Time and your other dogs will help make it better. You'll never forget Riley but you'll remember the good times not the guilt and sorrow. I hope this has helped, if you need to talk more please feel free to e-mail me. Take care !



</answer>

<answer>



Well if you are thinking reincarnation.. there is no such thing. Dogs going to heaven? I just don't know.



If you are sure that you did everything you could, it's only going to take time til you are feeling better about your decision. It's a hard thing to do, a hard thing to get over.. You were responsible for the death of an animal.. Even tho you did it for the right reasons, as people ( normal people ) we have a hard time being responsible for someone else's death.



WIth time, when you see that your other dogs are doing better, and you realize how much more peace you have in your life, and you see that your dog must have been very upset each day, dealing with her problems. You'll realize you did the right thing and you can move on with it.



Why didn't God give you other options? Cause we live in a world where things aren't perfect. People breed dogs without regard to health and temperament, and they produce dogs that need to be euthanize at a young age. You are fighting the sinful nature of people.



Their Greed... You can educate and you can avoid buying dogs from people who aren't producing quality dogs, and it will help you to avoid this in the future. But surely you do not blame God for your dog's problems ? God didn't intervene, but God didn't produce a dog that needed to be euthanized at a young age... Blame people.. They are the ones that do these things.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Answer hidden due to its low rating</evaluation>



Er,sorry....I can't understand the attraction of "on-line pity-parties".
If you are need of professional help,get some,OK?
This is not the place.
I've had to euthanize several dogs. I know it was the "right" necessary & only thing to do.I didn't & don't need strangers on-line to "cyber-sympathize".

<question>



How to get my boxer puppy to stop crying !?



I adopted a one year old female boxer from a shelter about a month and a half ago. When she came home she was the best dog ever !!
now.... well things have changed
She cries all the time no matter where she is. I thought maybe she just needed a place of her own to feel safe, so i got her a crate, but she just cries in there !!



She cries when im not home and is driving my neigbors crazy !
Even if you are sitting with her , she will randomly start crying !
I DONT KNOW WHAT TO DO !!!!



Another thing, she is very food driven and will steal your plate anytime you have food no matter what you do.



Does anyone have some tips on what i can do to control the crying and also get her to stop stealing food?



</question>



<additional details>



thank you so much for all your help guys !!



as for bonnie L. shut up.
if you dont now how to fix something dont answer the question.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sky's Mom
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If she is crying that much, even when you are around there could be one of two things happening.



She has gotten attention for crying in the past and so now she is crying as means of getting attention- if this is the case then you need to ignore her crying; she only gets attention when she is being quiet.



The other possibility is that something is wrong with her and she is in pain. Crying is one of the few ways dogs have to tell us something is wrong. You might need to get her checked out by a vet just to make sure nothing is wrong and there is nothing causing her any pain.



If anything medical is ruled out then do not pay attention to her crying behavior and perhaps consider having a one-on-one session with a dog trainer/behaviorist to discuss training solutions. Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Audrey N
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 140 (Level 1)



</answer from>

ladykenm...

<answer>



Check to make sure she healthy.  She sounds like she has separation anxiety.  Try leaving a radio on when you leave or give her a Kong toy filled with peanut butter to occupy her time. If she cries while you are sitting with her, just pet her and talk gently to her saying everything is ok.  Even give her a hug and tell her she is a good girl.  She may need re-assurance that you love her.



As far as stealing food, she is either hungry or she is afraid she isn't going to get fed.  Did you try feeding her before you eat?  Maybe you need to increase the food amount you are feeding her.



</answer>

<answer>



It is normal, usually the after effects from the anesthesia they used for his dental surgery.  For some reason too, maybe because of the anesthesia, the surgical room being so cold, and having some pain, the shaking is from all these things.  Keep him warm, put a blanket over him, and comfort him, because he doesn't understand what has happened to him.  If the vet sent home any pain meds, give them as prescribed, it will help your dog to rest and recover from the surgery. He wil get better.  Best of luck to you and your puppy!

<question from>



Razo
Member since: 21 June 2007
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



I have a Corgi puppy and in the process of house training but need some help please!?



My Corgi is about 12 weeks old.



I am training him and he uses the pads to pee on and also has learned to pee and poop outside when we take him out (even tho it takes him a lil while).  Both my fiance and I work 7am - 4/5pm weekdays so we have him locked in his room which is our entrance hallway.  He has plenty of room including his bed, crate, toys, food, and pee pad.  He pees on the pad while we are away, no problem.  My question is - when in his room all day he will not poop on his pad.  It is sometimes a few inches away or a couple feet from the pad.  I just don't know why he can pee on the pad but can not poop there?



Also ,when we are home he poops outside so we do not let him poop inside or in his room  -then we reward him with a treat.  Will he just learn to poop on the pad in the coming weeks?



FYI - I'm slowy trying to crate train but since we are gone for at least 8hours a day that is too long to keep a puppy locked up.



Please help and thanks for your input.



</question>



<answer from>



wishnuwe...
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 17854 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



Sociology



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Bladder isn't grown until 6-months-old, this puppy can only be alone/hold its potty for 4 hours at the most.  Pee pads are confusing him.  I use a crate* to potty train with, but only for potty training and then I break it down and store it.  I put blankets and a small food and water dish in the crate.  Dogs don't potty where they eat and sleep.  When they are first little, I only expect them to hold their potty for 4 hours, and then 6 hours, then 8 hours and so on.  So when they are first little, I set a timer or alarm clock to wake myself up at night to take them *out.  I only allow my puppy in the bedroom* or the living room, only one room at a time.  They have to graduate to more space.  If I allow them to have full run of the house, it will overwhelm them.  I take them out the same door each time.  I tie a dinner bell to the door handle.  Do not use a jingle bell as they could get their toe caught in it.  So when they are little, I ring the bell for them, and then open the door to go *outside to potty.  When they get bigger, I take their paw and whack the bell and open the door to go potty.  Eventually getting to the place where the puppy will ring the bell and let me know when they need to go potty.  Dogs want to please you, so it is your job to let them know what behaviors please you and what doesn't.  So when my puppy goes potty, I give her a treat*, and clap, and make a fuss and praise her.  So she learns that going potty outside makes me happy.  If she has an accident, make a disgust sound like “tsst” and take her out right away.  I never yell* or spank* my puppies.  Take them out when they first wake up, after they eat or drink, before nap, finish romping, when their activities change, or when they are sniffing around. Some puppies go pee right away, but may not go poop until 10 minutes later, so wait for the poop.  I have a little play time here, because sometimes I think they are done, and they are not.  Puppies train at their own pace.  While I may have a puppy that hasn't had an accident in several weeks, I don't let my guard down.  I don't expect my puppies to be "fully potty trained" until one-year-old.  If they have a setback, shake it off, and start over.  I only have my puppies in the crate when I am not watching them.  When I am sleeping, cooking, ironing, doing chores, basically when I am not watching her.  All other times, she is out of the crate practicing being a "big girl."  This is the time I train her how to behave in the house.  So we are practicing "no barking", 'no biting", "no jumping", and "don't eat the furniture."  I also have to practice "playing inside" so she doesn't knock over things.  You must keep the puppy in sight when they are little because they don’t know the difference between newspaper and carpet, and you don’t want them sneaking off and getting into trouble.



Some puppies can sleep through the night around 3-months-old, but their bladder is grown around 6-months-old.
REVISIONS:



*I use a CRATE to train with.  It is the method I prefer, compared to other methods I have tried.  I noticed that if they are in the crate, while I am doing chores, they are o.k., because the crate allows them to see me and be re-assured.  The crate can also be a comfort when stored in the basement for dogs who live in areas where thunderstorms and tornados are an issue. .  However, use the method that works best for you.....a laundry basket, a cardboard box, a woof-woof house, x-pen, child gates, whatever works for you.
*OUTSIDE, pee pad, litter box, whichever method you are using.



When the puppy is first little, keep the pee pad, litter box near the food and water dish, so the puppy can eat and drink, and then go potty.  You can move it away as they get older.  The pee pad has a scent that smells and initiates potty.  Sometimes a pee pad makes a sound that scares some puppies, so you might want to use a litter box if that happens.  The pee pad allows a puppy to walk around, but a litter box keeps the puppy in one place.



*BEDROOMS, I use the bedroom and living room for training, because it works for me.  Choose rooms that work for you, but watch for rooms that are damp, or drafty.  While my puppies sleep in the bedroom during training, once they are trained, I let them sleep where they want to.  They don't have to sleep in the bedroom forever.
*TREATS.  While I use treats for training, you don't have to.  I like Charlee Bears for training (a little cracker for a little mouth,) I use them for training, but once they are trained, I cut back on them.



*SOME PUPPIES will go potty in the same spot each time.  Some puppies have to be told to go potty.  A command like "go out" for pee, or "go finish" for poop, might work for you, keep saying “go finish” until the puppy poops.  This is a good thing to train if you travel with your dogs.  By using commands, the puppy won't get confused when you are visiting someone, on vacation with you, or when you get to a new home.  The command w



Source(s):



Maybe come home during lunch, or dog walker, pet sitter, family help, someone from church.  They don't know the difference between pee pads and carpet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jessica G
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 395 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not sure about the pooping issue but work on crate training.  He is 12 weeks old.  He is physically able to hold his bowels and bladder for 8 hours.  My 9 week old puppy was able to as soon as we got him and my 2 labs were able to at 7 weeks.  It should not take more than a week or so to get him totally crate trained.  Use the divider the comes with the crate.  Give him enough room to stand up, turn around, and lay down.  He will learn quickly to hold his bowels and bladder because he doesn't want to sit near the pee and poop all day.



</answer>



<answer from>



texelgir...
Member since: 15 January 2007
Total points: 23370 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your right. You are gone too long and should not have gotten a puppy in the first place with out making a few arrangements to have someone let him out after 4 or 5 hours. you will need to see if you can get a friend or come home for lunch and give him a break till he is fully housetrained. Potty pads are the WORST thing that anyone should use for training. You have just trained your young, impressionable dog to go to the bathroom in his house. Crate training may never reverse this behavior now. Puppy pads are infused with a hormone and smell to attract the dog to pee on the pad but its not the same for pooping. Dogs dont want to poo where they pee, and dogs sometimes like to take time and search the best spot to poop. Is the pads close to the wall? Corgis are long bodied and take room to poop they dont want to be next to a wall. I suggest you stop the pee pads RIGHT NOW and get him crate trained.Take a week off if you can come home for lunch. A week of constant training would do wonders for him.



Source(s):



9 years as Shelter manager, wildlife rehaber, raising orphaned animals, investigator for animal abuse\neglect and years of owning,training, breeding many types of Animals



</answer>

<question>

It is about the diameter of your standard number two pencil eraser.  around this scab-looking thing there is a thin red ring. I am very worried that this is lyme disease seeing as we live in Kansas but we Frontline her monthly even in the off season.



Does this sound like Lyme Disease to you?



i am planning on taking her to her vet anyway because of her age.
other than this little spot she is acting completely normal in every way. happy, healthy, goofy and very active.
- emily

<answer>



good question well if her puts his paws on people or jump up on people what you need to do is have the person stand up make a loud short noise and walk in front of the dog like your pushing the dog the dog will go down and he will probably do it again but you need to do the same routine and every time the dog listens reward him with a treat.



</answer>



<answer from>



gemma r
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 189 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to go back to basics and teach him to never jump up at people - then he'll transfer that to when they're sitting down too.



Don't let any visitors (or anybody else) greet him until he's calm and in the 'sit' position - then get them to make a huge fuss of him.  That way he'll learn that he only gets attention when all four paws are on the ground.  If necessary, put him on the lead to start with.



And best not to use flicking his leg, shouting at him, spraying water, etc - positive training methods work much better with most dog breeds.  If you keep doing things like that then you might end up with a dog with submissive problems.  Praise when he's good and ignore or just use a calm quiet 'no' when he's bad, he'll learn much quicker that way.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



ginger
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 203 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try pushing him off without speaking to him. If this doesn't work stand up each time, still without speaking.  My dog got the idea pretty quickly.  He's looking for attention and you give it to him every time you tell him off.



I wouldn't use the rattly thing without professional input, can make some dogs nasty.



</answer>

<answer>



when he puts his paws on someone he eather A) wants any food that you have with you or B) wants some attention



your probable not giving him all the love he needs so he figures that the best way for someone to know he is still there is buy putting his paws on someone. when he does that just pet him behind the ears or on his chest then when your tird stop. if he puts his paws on you again then just tell him to go lay down and thats it. dont talk to him, dont fratinize with him in any way. he will soon learn that when you say lay down you don't want his paws on you.
ovesly watter dont work. telling him NO wont help because you are only confusing him. grabing his paws and putting them on the floor, its basickly a game. you know how if someone picks on someone else the person getting picked on will say stop or cry or something, the person bulling things its funnie and will keep doing it.
BUT if the person getting picked on doesn't say anything or show any signes that their feelings are hurt then the bullie will loose intrest in that person and will leave him alone.
same thing here, by touching him and putting his paws on the floor, its a game to him, he is enjoying that you are stoping what ever you may be doing to, in his mind "play" with him.
after you pet him for alittle bit. tell him to lay down or go somewhere else, DON'T EVEN TALK TO HIM!!! pretend he isn't there. dont talk, pet, touch or even look directly at him. he will loose intrest in wanting love and then go away. but you still have to play with him on a regular basic.
you are soposed to play with you dog any chance you get. by the end of the day your dog should be laying down my your feet or on a comfortable rug/carpet or something and he should be ....practilly asleep.

i have raises over 24 dogs and baby say so many dogs i can count them but anyway. trust me.

<answer>



There's no magic "growth chart".
A pup that size now will likely be bloody HUGE for the breed at maturity.
Read the breed standard,have you?
see where it says "over 6 lbs." is a disqualification?



</answer>



<answer from>



Ista
Member since: 26 October 2007
Total points: 17374 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



With small toy breeds, especially the chihuahua you can take their weight at 8 wks old and multiply by 4 for a good guesstimate of adult weight. So your pup will weigh around 8 lbs full grown.



It's only a guesstimate, but it's usually pretty accurate as far as guesstimates go. Those weight charts really aren't quite as accurate.



</answer>



<answer from>



1chefinv...
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 621 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My winchester chihuahua weighs about 13 pounds.The sizes of these dogs can vary.



</answer>

<question>



Dog attack victim help?



i was wondering if anyone knows of a website or forum for people that have been attacked by dogs?
i looked on Google but there is nothing.
i just want to tell my story of my attack when i was 7 (now 18) and perhaps meet someone else who has been through a similar experience.



so does anyone know of any websites that do that or does someone else have a story of a dog attack.



you don't have to read it but mine is something like this:



i was 7 and i was taking my brother some shoes and money (he was staying at a friends house) and i was skipping up the drive way and my brother told his friend to hold the dog back (bull terrier cross Staffy) he did nothing and the dog came running up and bit me 3 times in 15 seconds across my face. my mum came and grabbed me from the dogs mouth and took me to hospital. they found my eye lid on the porch about 4 hours later and was able to stitch it back on. after about 8 operations and over 500 stitches later I'm lucky i didn't lose my eye or eye sight. I'm missing half my eye brow but have gained a story that may help people.

<question from>



olivejui...
Member since: 24 January 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why does my puppy whine when she's playing with her favorite toy?



She is young, very happy and extremely friendly. When she's in her crate she doesn't whine often. And when she plays with toys other than her favorite she doesn't whine either, so I find it pretty strange.
Any ideas of what could cause this?



</question>



<answer from>



bornagai...
Member since: 22 February 2007
Total points: 2173 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My dog does the same thing...............he acts like he is trying to find someplace to hide it and whines............strange.



</answer>



<answer from>



Starligh...
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 4528 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



One of mine does the same thing. He will also stares at me if it goes somewhere that he can't retrieve I would love to know why also



</answer>



<answer from>



andie...
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 1016 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be that she's whining in excitement or anticipation..whining isn't necessarily a sign that something's wrong. Dogs don't have many ways to communicate as we do with words, so what they do have (barking, howling, whining..) can be used for different things. A dog may whine when they need out, when upset, or even when excited waiting for you to come in the door when they see your car pull in. So her whining while playing with her favorite toy may very well just be that she's excited, or maybe she's trying to do something with it that she can't figure out (mine sometimes whine when trying to get treats out of their kongs, or when they can't find the squeaker in a toy that only has a small one in the one arm). She sounds like a very happy young pup so I'm sure it's nothing bad..just enjoy her :)



Source(s):



dog owner/lover/volunteer



</answer>

Fearghal
Member since: 21 May 2007
Total points: 4094 (Level 4)

<answer from>



Sound Bay Newfoundlands
Member since: 06 October 2008

<answer>



Yes you do need to get this under control.  I would call the vet and see what they suggest as to what products are safe to use around pups that age.  You should start by getting rid of the fleas on the mother and get rid of all the bedding the pups are on.



</answer>

<question>



New Puppy Snapped at neighbor.........?



We have a new 3 month old Pekingese puppy, he is a very sweet little boy, loves to lay in your arms like a baby. I also have a 3 year old Pek as well, a male. He came from a home of children and 1 other puppy ,a female.My Question Is......The problem is the other day my sons girlfriend picked him up (the puppy) to love him and he showed his teeth and snapped at her face ! I have never seen him do anything such as this! She was with us when we got him and has held,feed and even slept with him. He has never done anything like this. We have had him for a little over a week. He gets along fine with the other pets,no problem with the food (they all eat out of the same bowl)When this happened I took him from her and scolded him and placed him outside. What should I have done and how do I keep this from happening?He shows no signs of doing this again but now I'm worried. The girl will not hold him again she is afraid.of him. He does growl at the doorbell from time to time but I think he just thinks he is bigger then he is.. I am going to have him fixed as soon as I can, What is a good age? If anyone has any advice I would love to hear it. Thanks so much.



</question>



<answer from>



tenelkad...
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 1722 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your puppy is testing his dominance and finding out where he is in your pack.
At three months, (12-16 Weeks) it is during this critical period that your dog will begin to test you to see who the pack leader is going to be. He'll begin to bite you, in play or as a real challenge to your authority. Such behavior is natural in the pack and not necessarily undesirable. What is undesirable is an inappropriate response on your part. It is important, at this stage, that you establish your position as pack leader, and not just another sibling. Other behaviors, such as grabbing at the leash, will be observed, and all are attempts to dominate you. Biting , in particular though, should always be discouraged. Therefore, you should not wrestle or play tug of war. Such play is aggressive-inducing. What you see as a fun game may be perceived by your dog as a situation in which he has been allowed to dominate. Wrestling, of course, communicates to your puppy that he is allowed to bite you. Tug of war sets you up in a dominance confrontation over an object. He learns that he can keep objects away from you. During tug of war games, puppies will often growl. Growling is a dominance vocalization, designed to warn another pack member that they better not confront the growler or he will bite. Puppies see these games as situations in which they have been allowed to dominate. They do not understand that these are games designed by humans to entertain them. You can continue to play with your dog during this period, but, the relationship between you during the play must change. No mouthing of your body should be allowed and when your dog does mouthe, you should respond with a quick and sharp "NO!" or "No Bite!" Play that does not get rough is best. If you cannot keep the dog from getting overly excited during a game and he persists in biting at you, don't play that way. This will only stimulate additional dominant behavior in the future. For these reasons, this is the stage when serious training should begin. Training establishes your pack leadership in a manner that your puppy will understand. By training your puppy, you will learn how to get him to respond to commands designed to show that you are in charge.



</answer>



<answer from>



ladykenm...
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 1052 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe she picked him up wrong and hurt him.  He let her know by snapping at her.  Maybe he just wanted to play. If you notice how puppies play with each other, they show their teeth and growl.  Maybe he thought she was a playmate.  If it happens again, I would worry.  But if this is the first time, I wouldn't think too much of it.  It is a pup and needs to start being trained.



</answer>

Fobo

</answer from>



<answer>



If you're into interesting names (I'm assuming you are, as you're looking into originality) you may have fun researching the history of the types of dogs. For instance, Yorkies (Yorkshire terriers) were bred from Skye and Manchester terriers, so names such as Skye or Manc come to mind. Papillon is French for "butterfly," so perhaps you could think of a type of butterfly (Elfin, Mylitta) or words for butterfly in other languages (Kupu-Kupu, in Indonesian). These are all just examples, have fun. :)



Source(s):



http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_7615...
http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_7615...
http://greennature.com/article1967.html
http://dictionary.reference.com/language...



</answer>

<question from>



mes
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 438 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Can you give a 2 week old chihuahua a bath?



Can you give a 2 week old chihuahua puppy a bath?



</question>



<additional details>



When I checked on them b4 bed tonite they were wet. I don't know why.  Maybe urine.



I dried them asap, when I found them wet. I didnt think it would be good to bath them. I just didnt know if it would be harmfull to leave the urine on them.  And to " mycatwalksalloverme" ...  Im probably older than you. Just have never had puppies before. Not everyone on here are kid's.



</additional details>



<answer from>



DP
Member since: 15 October 2006
Total points: 71801 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Change the bedding more often. Puppies should not be wet.. They cannot maintain their own body heat yet.. Being wet all the time only makes that worse.. They will get wet, cold and die.. You must keep them dry and warm.. Do not bath the puppies.. Better they smell like pee and are dry and warm than to be clean and wet and cold and dead..



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



suzie
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 1208 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Definitely not.  It will chill very quickly.  If they are wet it is most likely from the mother cleaning them.
Mum will do everything they need till they are 3 weeks of age, then you should start to introduce some solid food.
Once you do though you will have to start cleaning cause mum won't clean up after them as much.



When they are 8 weeks of age it is fine to give a bath but you must dry them thoroughly and keep them away from any drafts.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tinkerbe...
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 273 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not yet. The puppy has a scent of its own and the mother recognizes him by that scent, it may cause confusion or rejection to bath the puppy this early. I would wait until the puppy is at least six weeks old. You could try using wipes to get rid of the smell somewhat. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



hutmaste...
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 226 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why would you? The mother should be doing all the cleaning the puppy needs. You need to be careful with puppies and chemicals such as soap or shampoo, their skin is very sensitive and like the previous answerer stated about body temperature is also true.



</answer>

<question from>



YOUNME
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 1110 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Whats the biggest dog breed i can bye ?



im looking for a giant dog for a pet whats the biggest dog breed i can bye



</question>



<answer from>



kathryn
Member since: 23 July 2006
Total points: 232 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I also am inclined to ask you why you ask this?  You say you want a giant dog so surely you have done some research into breeds.  There are more important questions to ask than which is the largest dog .. which is infomation surely you can find anywhere on the internet!



I would urge you  to investigate several breeds and then investigate further



all aspects of those breeds you shortlist , re temperament , health issues, what work was the breed  developed for and what characterstics does that work give the dog ..  Will the charactaristics of the breed suit your life style, home and family?  Can you provide all that dog will need in respect of excersise , training , feeding and vets bills remembering  that Vets bills are much larger, the larger the breed is, Larger breeds require larger doses of everything including worm tablets , flea treatments, anaesthetic etc etc,.



Oh well  ...everything is bigger , the bigger the dog is , muddy foot marks, Muddy tail swipes high up on the walls, bigger beds, bigger teeth ... lol  mouths that can reach onto work surfaces,, also slobber ... lots of giant breeds produce lots of giant slobbers. More body to groom...bigger car and house and garden needed  and on and on ....



Ok ... if you are still interested ...



Then BEFORE you buy a puppy from a breeder ... please consider breed rescue centres and other rescue centres ... You may be able to give a lovely  dog in great need,  a wonderful life and find yourself a wonderful companion there.  Lots of these giant breeds become homeless due to the lack of owners considering the forgoing...



If you consider all these aspects carefully  ...you are doing the best you can to ensure you choose the right breed for you and that is the best way to ensure that you and your new dog are happy together for many years. Such careful consideration also helps to avoid  having to pay large sums of money to people like me to help sort out the problems that can occur with a good  dog living in the wrong home!!.



Good luck , Kathryn



Source(s):



I am a canine behaviourist



</answer>



<asker's comment>



well seid, and say all of us ......thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



TankMan
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 507 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



well first theres the question, why do you want a dog you yourself describe as "giant" i mean that just speaks for itself....



but if you think your fit to be a good "canopener" id reccomend a mixed dog of either great dane & mastinos or great dane& newfoundland retirever, my girlfriend "owns" the latter one, someone just dropped her off at the local pound and by god ive never seen a puppy that big (4/5 months and as big as an adult spaniel) , now shes about 4 yrs old and as tall as a great dane, as big as a newfoundland retriever plus as calm, theres nothing, that can get her to freak, ever, you could set her on fire and shed just look at u like "whats that supposed to do now? would you be so kind to put that out for me?"  but then she can be a diva, too when it comes to eating habits........



you might also wanna look into bully kuttas, originated from india and pakistan, but those really got a temper issue that make those dogs impossible to handle for dognoobs.....



and think about the fact that a bigger dog wil eat more than your avarage labbie or shepherd, plus they tend to have alot of health issues due to sometimes centuries of inbreeding of the breed...



go to your local animal shelter and look for a german boxer, a rottweiler, or a Bordeaux Bulldog, and dont shy away from mixed dogs, that usually saves you vet money, since they r genetically far more stable and healthy than purebred dogs



above all make a wise decision and support your local pound (where u dont have to "buy" a dog, which is morally kinda wrong i think, even tho some folks from the AKC will of course tell you the complete opposite, like they would on the health issues)....



Source(s):



danes, bulldogs, bullterriers and i still dont want a cat.......



</answer>

<question from>



Bonnie K
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Oldest a dog has had her 1st heat ?



What age did your dog have her first heat cycle?



</question>



<answer from>



Patiently awaiting the Puppies!
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 1915 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



She was 8 months old



add: graygerm. Often times pet insurance does not cover things like this. Stop pushing your issue...Most people know that pet insurance costs MORE a year, than it would cost you in a year to take your dog to the vet 15 times.



</answer>



<answer from>



graygerm...
Member since: 31 March 2008
Total points: 1722 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Each on is diffrent , I have had a dachshund go into heat at 9 months and a German shepherd wait until she was over 1  year old. Heat has alot to do with growth and hormones , when the body is ready it will do its thing.



After the first heat is the PERFECT time to fix your pet :)



Get pet insurance , it helps defer the cost :)



</answer>



<answer from>



grays113...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question from>



Leela

</question from>



<question>



I want to learn to clip my Old English Sheepdog myself. If I want to leave about an inch of fur, do I...?



go with the hair or against it? The pup I'm going to clip is obviously not for show purposes so it's not the end of the world if I need to shave him down after I ruin his haircut.



</question>



<additional details>



Poor dog? The worst that can happen is he'll be shaved down, and he loves to lose his heavy coat. He dances around all day. So please!



</additional details>



<answer from>



ladykenm...
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 1052 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Poor dog!  Take the pup to a professional groomer.  Watch how they do it, ask questions and then attempt the clipping the next time the dog needs it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Aussies are my ♥ Dogs!
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 4539 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Always shave WITH the growth of the hair.  And don't use those flimsy black little attachments, they don't work, and you have a heavy duty job.



Do you have a high quality clipper?  I would suggest getting one, they make a world of difference when trimming.



You can check out: http://www.kvvet.com/KVVet/product_famil...  These is all of the blades you would ever need.  Also Kvvet charges no shipping, and there is a coupon code: 054 to save $5.00.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bekah
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 1991 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



use a good quality comb attachment and go with the grain of the hair and do it while the dog is dry. when you use a comb attchment there are several lengths to chose, so look for one that looks about the length you need also brush the hair backwards often to make sure it gets even... the key is practice..good luck!



Source(s):



work at a kennel that does grooming too



</answer>



<answer from>



Starligh...
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 4530 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I strongly advise against home clipping especially a Sheepdog.  There are lots of things that can go wrong, razor burn, cuts, not to mention a really bad haircut. I have groomed for well over 20 years.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kermit the Dog
Member since: 28 June 2006
Total points: 73191 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



If you want to leave an inch of fur, that will involve using a clipper comb.



But first, you need to make sure that the coat is clean (bathed), dry, and COMPLETELY brushed out.  If there are tangles, either you won't be able to cut it at all, or you will get gouges whenever the blade hits a knot.



You should also completely scissor the dog all over to make it even.



As a professional groomer, if your dog is in excellent shape I could probably do it in 3-4 hours.  A pet owner will take considerably longer.



The best thing is to have a professional groomer show you how.  It will be worth the money to know how to do it safely.



</answer>

<answer>

<question from>

Member since: 05 October 2006
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Would you kill for love?



What would you do if your dog was poisoned with rat poison on purpose and you know he'll suffer for a couple of days,would you kill him to save him the pain?



</question>



<additional details>



Rat poison causes extreme bleeding for a couple of days, really bad pain...it's basically a torture and then the dog dies. It's a horrible death.



by "on purpose" I mean that he didn't eat the poison by mistake because it was on the floor or whatever. It was given to him in his food while I was out.



ok...so a lot of answerers are asking me what am I doing on Y!A; well, my dog is dead already, I just asked the question to know about personal feelings towards a decision like that. I couldn't save my dog, it was too late for him. I tried very hard, and looked for many options, but it was too late. I loved him very much. People talk without even being in the same situation and give out opinions about it without observing all the sides of the story.



I was just asking for an opinion and thoughts on the decision I made for my dog, I cannot do anything else for him.
Thanks to all of those who gave me honest and understanding answers.



</additional details>

<answer>



Someone *did* attempt to kill my dogs with rat poison.  They were put on a Vitamin K supplement and didn't have any ill effects from it.



Truth is, there is very little poison in household products.  Unless your dog is given a MASSIVE amount... or you don't catch it to have vomiting induced or get that supplement, they should be okay.



If my dog was to suffer for a few days and then be okay?  No, I would not euthanize.  If my dog was doomed to a lifetime of suffering?  Of course I would have the dog put out of their misery.  It is part of your responsibility as their owner.

an example tried to be.

and set my spirit free?

I fought with all my might.
But something seems to draw me now
to a warm and loving light.
I want to go
I really do.
It's difficult to stay.



But I will try as best I can
to live just one more day.
To give you time to care for me
and share your love and fears.
I know you're sad and afraid,
because I see your tears.



I'll not be far,
I promise that, and hope you'll always know
that my spirit will be close to you
wherever you may go.
Thank you so for loving me.
You know I love you too,
that's why it's hard to say goodbye
and end this life with you.



So hold me now just one more time
and let me hear you say,
because you care so much for me,
you'll let me go today



PUT ME TO REST



Time to let me go my friend,
Because my life no-one can mend,
It’s better to let me go this way,
Than watch me suffer night and day.



I'm happy to go, my time has come,
My quality of life is no longer fun,
I’ve been so ill, so it’s not a bad thing,
To let me go forever resting.



Stay with me till I drift away,
Fast asleep forever I pray,
To relieve me from suffering and pain,
What more can I ask from my best friend.



Don't be sad, I'll be free from pain,
Never to be ill ever again,
I know you'll miss me being there,
But all the memories you have to share.



Thank you for being my best friend,
And all my needs that you did tend,
Try not to be sad, try not to cry,
Now is the time to say goodbye
Put me to rest.

<answer>



First of all, I would take the dog to the vet ASAP because they may be able to give an antidote. Most rat poisons are actually based on Warfarin, which causes the blood to thin out and not coagulate. Thus, the animal that eats it will basically bleed to death internally. It is a common medication to prevent clots after surgeries, etc. (for humans too). So, the vet may be able to either induce vomiting to rid the dog of the poison before it is digested or give another med to counteract the poison's effects.



Otherwise, if the dog will just suffer for a while and then die, I would end the suffering as soon as possible. If the dog will suffer and then recover, then I would do everything to make recovery faster rather than jumping the gun and killing it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bonnie L
Member since: 01 September 2007
Total points: 1337 (Level 3)



</answer from>

<answer from>



Animal Artwork
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 1354 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most rat poison works as a blood thinner.  Many times, with adequate veterinary care, a dog is capable of surviving this type of poisoning.



When I was a child, a neighbor killed one of my dogs by feeding it ground glass mixed with hamburger.  Sadly, she didn't manage to kill the dog she was trying to kill... but instead killed the most dominant (and least aggressive) dog we had.  Yes, we euthanized the poisoned dog.



The neighbor was caught when she attempted again to poison the more aggressive dog.  She spent a couple of months in jail, her husband put their house up for sale and divorced her .. and took custody of her children.  Her reason for doing it- she was afraid of the dog because it would bark like all heck at her when she screamed at her children playing with us in our yard.



</answer>

<answer>



Breed has no bearing on this at all.
Most pups will open their eye in 10 to 14 days.  Some may take a bit longer.  Beyond day 17 I'd have them vet checked.
Ears follow the eyes so they should open with in a few days after their eyes open.
Hope this has helped!

Former Golden breeder and owner for over 20 years

<answer>



The best I can do with the kibble Q is to direct you to the Dog Food Analysis site.  I have no idea about prices either =/



You can definitely feed raw and kibble (not in the same meal, but alternating is fine, as is throwing in a raw meal every once in a while).  I WAS converting mine to raw, but funds right now are tight so they are still getting kibble the majority of the time.  You are at an advantage since your dogs are so young; often older dogs that have always eaten kibble don't take to it so well (not digestion-wise, but just that they're not used to it and some don't like it).



Home-cooking is another option that you could do, but many owners that cook for their dogs end up just going raw because it is so much easier to just toss them a hunk of meat.  ;)



Here's my "getting started" thread, you might find it helpful:
http://www.boxerworld.com/forums/showthr...



Two GREAT raw feeding sites:
http://www.rawlearning.com/rawfaq.html
http://www.rawfeddogs.net/



Also, BoxerWorld has 4 nutrition forums that you can browse -- Feeding (kibble), RAW Feeding, Homecooking, and Recipes.  You might even consider joining for those forums (lots of people do).  You don't have to have a boxer to be a member ;)
http://www.boxerworld.com/forums/forumdi...



</answer>

<answer from>



darksong...
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 14397 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nutro really isn't that great a dog food, I wouldn't switch to it.



Not all pet food is made equally. A lot of it is full of corn, by-products, dyes, unhealthy preservatives, filler grains and all sorts of nasty stuff. A lot of pet food companies are perfectly happy to the dump cheap leftovers and things that aren't safe for human consumption (from human food processing plants) into their foods. Will it kill your dog? No, it has to be nutritionally complete and safe to even be marketed. Is it healthy? Not by a long shot.



Corn is a low quality ingredient you never want to see in your pet food. Corn and low quality grains are two of the biggest culprits when it comes to food allergies in our pets.



Thankfully, there are some excellent dog foods being made these days that include organic, human grade ingredients rather than trash not fit for human consumption.



Examples of low quality foods to avoid: Anything you can find in a grocery store will be low end, Purina, Iams, Eukanuba, Science Diet, Royal Canin, Pedigree, Kibbles n' Bits, Beneful, Ol'Roy.



Examples of high quality foods to look for: Innova, Wellness, Solid Gold, Canidae All Life Stages, Fromm Four Star, Merrick, GO Natural, Nature's Variety Prairie, Nature's Logic, Artemis Fresh Mix, Timberwolf Organics.



Although the high quality foods are more expensive, you're getting what you're paying for. Less filler material means more concentrated nutrients... this means you typically need to feed far less of the high quality food than you would of the low quality one. Which also means less poop!



Before following your vet's food recommendation, keep in mind that vets get /very/ little nutritional training during their schooling. Besides that, what training they /do/ get is usually sponsored or taught by the crappy pet food companies! They also often get paid to sell some of their products at their clinics (Science Diet, Royal Canin etc.)



A great option is to go with an entirely grainless diet. Many of the high quality foods now put out grainless formulas. Some good grainless diets include: Innova EVO, Wellness CORE, Blue Wilderness, Nature's Variety Instinct, Orijen, Horizon Legacy, Merrick Before Grain, Canidae Grain Free All Life Stages, Fromm Surf & Turf, Now! and Sold Gold Barking At The Moon, Taste of the Wild.



Some pretty decent foods can even be found in common pet stores. Petsmart carries Blue Buffalo products (such as the excellent grain free diet Blue Wilderness). Petco carries Wellness, Solid Gold, Natural Balance, Eagle Pack Holistic, Blue Buffalo, Castor & Pollux Organix, Pinnacle, and Halo. If you can't find a food, most of the high quality food brands have websites with store locators on them.



Another option, if you can't find anywhere around you that sells good foods, is to order your pet food online. Here's an excellent place to do so: http://www.petfooddirect.com/store/



Remember that foods should be switched gradually (mixing new slowly in with the old over about a two week period), especially when switching to a higher quality one, so as not to upset tummies.



Another option for feeding dogs is to feed raw. This is something that should be thoroughly researched before being attempted:
http://www.barfworld.com/
http://www.rawfed.com/
http://www.rawlearning.com/
http://www.wysong.net/controversies/rawm...



More on dog food:
http://www.dogfoodproject.com/index.php?...  (Learn how to determine the quality of your dog's food.)
http://www.dogfoodanalysis.com/dog_food_... (Dog food reviews. Four stars is a decent food, five stars is a great food, and six stars is an excellent food.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Tsunami
Member since: 26 July 2007
Total points: 35830 (Level 7)



</answer from>

<question from>



ashley09...

<question>



What kind of dog food is good for weight loss?



okay, well my mom has an 8 yr old wienie and jack russell dog which she weighs 43 lbs i know a really fat wienie. anyways, i think she's fat as hell but my mom denies it and says 'she's not fat just broad'. i standing over here raisin one eyebrow saying 'you don't see her stumpy little legs?? if she gains any more weight, her boobies will be dragging on the ground!' anyways, i want to know what kind of dog food is good for loosing weight, especially on this one particular dog???



</question>



<additional details>



she's not been spayed because of previous medical problems therefore the vets will not spay her.



</additional details>

<question>



I Went to a Vet on Tuesday & They Said Puppy Chow is Bad?!?



I went to the vet on Tues. to have my puppy checked up before her spaying on Wed. and when I told the vet that I'm feeding her puppy chow they said that it's BAD for them and has the 3 D's (of something) one of which was 'Death', of course! Has anyone EVER heard of this? I tried google but found nothing bad written about this stuff. I'm new to the dog world so I'm a little clueless but the breeder I got my puppy from said that Puppy Chow's good and she recommends it, etc. I think the vet was trying to push off some expensive dog food my way or something. Anyone? Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Holly K
Member since: 10 December 2006

i♥theMD

</answer from>



<answer>



Regular store-bought dog food is, in fact, very bad for dogs. The meat they use in it is the meat from slaughterhouses deemed not fit for human consumption. The sad thing is, very few dog owners are aware of this, and continue to blindly feed this damaging food to their beloved pups. A lot of professional dog breeders do this, too, and recommend the food they use to their customers.
If you want to give your dog healthy, or at least decent, food, you need to buy it from the vet, or buy those giant industrial packs of dog food.



</answer>

<answer from>



darksong...
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 14404 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are absolutely right, Puppy Chow is a terrible quality dog food.



Not all pet food is made equally. A lot of it is full of corn, by-products, dyes, unhealthy preservatives, filler grains and all sorts of nasty stuff. A lot of pet food companies are perfectly happy to the dump cheap leftovers and things that aren't safe for human consumption (from human food processing plants) into their foods. Will it kill your dog? No, it has to be nutritionally complete and safe to even be marketed. Is it healthy? Not by a long shot.



Corn is a low quality ingredient you never want to see in your pet food. Corn and low quality grains are two of the biggest culprits when it comes to food allergies in our pets.



Thankfully, there are some excellent dog foods being made these days that include organic, human grade ingredients rather than trash not fit for human consumption.



Examples of low quality foods to avoid: Anything you can find in a grocery store will be low end, Purina, Iams, Eukanuba, Science Diet, Royal Canin, Pedigree, Kibbles n' Bits, Beneful, Ol'Roy.



Examples of high quality foods to look for: Innova, Wellness, Solid Gold, Canidae All Life Stages, Fromm Four Star, Merrick, GO Natural, Nature's Variety Prairie, Nature's Logic, Artemis Fresh Mix, Timberwolf Organics.



Although the high quality foods are more expensive, you're getting what you're paying for. Less filler material means more concentrated nutrients... this means you typically need to feed far less of the high quality food than you would of the low quality one. Which also means less poop!



Before following your vet's food recommendation, keep in mind that vets get /very/ little nutritional training during their schooling. Besides that, what training they /do/ get is usually sponsored or taught by the crappy pet food companies! They also often get paid to sell some of their products at their clinics (Science Diet, Royal Canin etc.)



A great option is to go with an entirely grainless diet. Many of the high quality foods now put out grainless formulas. Some good grainless diets include: Innova EVO, Wellness CORE, Blue Wilderness, Nature's Variety Instinct, Orijen, Horizon Legacy, Merrick Before Grain, Canidae Grain Free All Life Stages, Fromm Surf & Turf, Now! and Sold Gold Barking At The Moon, Taste of the Wild.



Some pretty decent foods can even be found in common pet stores. Petsmart carries Blue Buffalo products (such as the excellent grain free diet Blue Wilderness). Petco carries Wellness, Solid Gold, Natural Balance, Eagle Pack Holistic, Blue Buffalo, Castor & Pollux Organix, Pinnacle, and Halo. If you can't find a food, most of the high quality food brands have websites with store locators on them.



Another option, if you can't find anywhere around you that sells good foods, is to order your pet food online. Here's an excellent place to do so: http://www.petfooddirect.com/store/



Remember that foods should be switched gradually (mixing new slowly in with the old over about a two week period), especially when switching to a higher quality one, so as not to upset tummies.



Another option for feeding dogs is to feed raw. This is something that should be thoroughly researched before being attempted:
http://www.barfworld.com/
http://www.rawfed.com/
http://www.rawlearning.com/
http://www.wysong.net/controversies/rawm...



More on dog food:
http://www.dogfoodproject.com/index.php?...  (Learn how to determine the quality of your dog's food.)
http://www.dogfoodanalysis.com/dog_food_... (Dog food reviews. Four stars is a decent food, five stars is a great food, and six stars is an excellent food.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Budduha Poopoo
Member since: 06 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)

<question from>



Mikki
Member since: 06 November 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do i get papers for my dog?



i have a 9 month old, long hair border collie, black/white with tan markings also.
he has Eulo, Argyle and Sevilles Bill bloodlines ( all Australian champ. working dogs ). i was wondering on how to get papers for him as i eventually want to breed him.
can someone help me out??



</question>



<answer from>



shigirl_...
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 263 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unfortunately it is too late to get papers this has to be done early on within about 8 weeks from the puppies birth though I am not positive check the american kennel club for more specifics. Both the mother and sire must be papered in order for your puppy to be papered.



</answer>



<answer from>



Samantha E
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



His litter would have had to have been reg with the canine council. If the breeder did not  do this it dose not matter what bloodlines he has you have no hope of getting a pedigree & reg certificate.



Source(s):



dog breeder 10 yrs



</answer>



<answer from>



Honeybelle DILLIGAF
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 4578 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



You would need to contact the breeder with regard to this.  I am not familiar with the Working Dog register.



I am only familiar with dogs that are registered as purebred pedigreed dogs with the ANKC (Australian National Kennel Council), or more specifically with the State bodies affiliated with the ANKC.  I can tell you that to register a dog with them the breeder would have had to have been a registered breeder with the ANKC and it would have been up to them to register the litter and pass the registration papers on to you.  Oh yes, of course, both of the parents would have had to have been registered pedigreed dogs as well.



I do think the Working Dog Register works differently though but your breeder should be able to help you in this area.



</answer>



<answer from>



blingque...

Total points: 127 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer>



All pure bred dogs are registered with the AKC by the papered breeders. you just can't breed any dog and ask for papers.They have a linage protocol that they follow with a registry so that all blood lines can be followed and no inner breeding takes place. So your dog would have to already have AKC papers  then you would register the stud service papers from the AKC female  and they send you the paperwork to complete and it has to be approved  and registration numbers are assigned to each puppy.



Source(s):



http://www.akc.org/breeders/resp_breedin...



</answer>

<question from>



Pita
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 347 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How do you know if the puppy is came from puppy mill?



I know puppy mill is a crappy kennel club.  Do pet store tell people that the puppies came from puppy mill?



What's a backyard breeder?



thx



</question>



<answer from>



Kermit the Dog
Member since: 28 June 2006
Total points: 73275 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If it came from a Pet Store, it's likely from a puppymill.  If not, it's from a BackYardBreeder.



A GOOD breeder would never, ever, sell their pups to a pet store.



And pet shops NEVER say "it's from a puppymill" because if they did no one would buy the pups.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Wow so many answers have answered to the question.  I agree your answer, and others too.



Thanks  I've learn something today :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



moof
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 3835 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



A puppy mill isn't a "kennel club."



A kennel club is an organization that deals with the breeding and showing of many breeds of dog. They have the dogs' interests at heart and work to promote well-bred pedigree dogs.



A puppy mill is a breeding facility that churns out puppies like a factory for profit. The conditions are extremely substandard and the puppies almost always come with serious health issues, temperament problems or genetic defects.



Pet stores, who purchase their "goods" from puppy mills, do not tell their customers that the dogs are from puppy mills. They would never do such a thing because it would devastate their sales. That's why there are so many sites dedicated to this topic, to spread the word.



A backyard breeder is like a small-scale puppy mill. It's a single person (or a couple, or friends, or whatever) who breed their dogs without performing the proper health tests and without the proper knowledge of breeding. They're often interested in selling the puppies for a profit, although sometimes the term is applied to just any person who breeds pretty much in their backyard, like wham-bam-thank-you-ma'am style.



</answer>



<answer from>



alias boxer
Member since: 18 September 2007
Total points: 7376 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Puppy mill is NOT a crappy kennel club.  A puppy mill is a facility where MANY dogs are kept in cages and bred over and over and over until they cannot breed anymore, and then they're usually sold at auctions or killed.  Have you ever seen a chicken farm, where the chickens are all in filthy cages stacked on top of each other?  That's what lots of puppy mills look like.  They treat dogs like livestock, NOT companions.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OdcNl5Fqc...



A Backyard Breeder is any breeder who does not stick to ethical standards of breeding.  Responsible breeders, also called hobby breeders, spend years and years studying their favorite breed, and they breed only to improve the breed and NOT for money.  Hobby breeders spend lots of money showing their dogs, screening them for hereditary diseases before breeding, ensuring that the breeding dogs are the best possible match, and making sure their dogs and puppies have the best care.  Backyard breeders often breed dogs for money, or maybe they are just a naive pet owner who'd like to see their dog have puppies (or maybe their dog accidentally becomes pregnant because the owner neglected to have it spayed).  Whatever the reason, BYB's don't take the time, spend the money, or do the research that is necessary to produce the best possible pups.



A puppy mill is basically the same as a greedy backyard breeder, just on a larger scale.



Pet stores get their puppies from both puppy mills and BYBs.  All of them.  No matter what they tell you (and they will NEVER admit that puppies come from bad places).  Sometimes they say their pups come from "commercial breeders" -- that's just a nice way of saying "puppy mills."



It states in the Code of Ethics for nearly EVERY breed club (and I say "nearly" only because I haven't actually checked them all, but most likely it's ALL of them) that breeders shall NOT sell their puppies to pet stores or puppy brokers.  So... by definition, we can say that NO reputable breeder sells their dogs to pet stores, and therefore NO pet store gets puppies from good breeders.



</answer>



<answer from>



Craig H
Member since: 23 May 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Usually you can tell by how they're sold, if the person selling them (if a private breeder) is more trying to force the dog onto you then it's more likely has problems with it and more likely to be a puppy mill puppy. if the private breeder is more concerning and less willing to make a deal then it's more likely to be a better dog. Now with buying a puppy from a store ask for a family tree of the dog if there aren't any, don't trust them. Petland puppies are about the best dog's you can find (without extensively searching) I'd say and they only come from well respected breeders!

Dog trainer and rehabilitator

<answer>



If your puppy came from the puppy mill, it could have certain health problems.



A backyard breeder is someone that breeds dogs( or other pet animals) at their house as a hobby/ way to make some extra cash. These animals are usually cared for better than those in a puppy mill, because they are given the love of the person raising them, and there is usually only one litter at a time being raised, whereas in puppy mills, the purpose is only to make cash, the animals are crowded, and their health is not of primary concern.

<answer>



If a pet store is selling a puppy, the dog came from a puppy mill.



Reputable breeders do not sell their dogs to pet stores, and pet stores do not sell rescue dogs. Therefore most if not all all pet store dogs that are for sale, are puppy mill dogs. Some pet stores will adopt out rescues, like Petsmart. Prices are much, much lower, like $200 (to cover vet care) versus $800 at a pet store.



A backyard breeder is just a small scale puppy mill, but they're the same thing.



</answer>

<answer>



A puppy mill is a place where many dogs are kept purely for breeding purposes. They are awful, often dirty and the dogs are in poor condition. People who run puppy mills are in it stricklty for the money.  They have no consideration and no knowledge of the dogs health problems, pedigree lines. They do no do health screenings as recommended by the breed standards.  They mostly sell to pet stores.
Pet stores will never tell you that they got the dogs from a puppy mill.



Backyard Breeders:
These people can be subdivided into 3 categories.
1. Out for the money - or perceived money since you really can't make that much.
2. People who just want to have puppies (I can't understand that)
3. People who really do love their dogs but are not educated enouh to know much about the breed they have and therefore should not be breeding.



These type of breeders produce poor quality samples of their breed, and can have an impact on the health and welfare of the breed.



Most responsible breeders have very strict rules on who and when to breed.  They will give the dogs all appropriate health screenings and will often sell puppies with a spay/neuter contract (especially to first time owners and those who only want pets). They screen each home to make sure that the puppy will have everything it needs fo live a happy and healthy life.
There is a lot more to say but this may already be too much info.
Hope it answered your question.



</answer>

Puppies in newspaper ads, for sale on websites, puppies on craigslist, puppies for sale in front of the grocery store, all come from backyard breeders.

http://au.youtube.com/watch?v=EH6QYBg2LF...

<answer from>



Westley's mom
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 1466 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have a puppy that you think might have come from a puppy mill, you can get a free puppy report at www.petshoppuppies.org.



What is a Responsible & Reputable Dog Breeder?
These are people who breed to improve the breed because they love it.
Their notable traits:
-They show & compete their dogs.
-They win titles.
-They have researched animal husbandry & genetics.
-They have only a few breeding dogs.
-The females are at least 2 before having the first litter.
-The females are bred only a few times in their lives.
-The dogs live with the family.
-The dog’s eyes, knees and if necessary, hips are checked at the appropriate age and they are also tested for any breed-specific health issues.



-They have waiting lists for the pups before they are conceived.
-They give potential puppy owners the 3rd degree.
-The require new puppy owners to sign a contract that if they can’t keep the puppy for any reason at any time in its life, it must be returned to the breeder.
-They have a spay/neuter clause in their contract.
-By the time the puppy goes home it has been to the vet more than once for vaccinations and check ups.



What is a Back Yard Breeder?
This is anyone who intentionally or unintentionally allows dogs to breed who are not the best representatives of the breed.



Their notable traits:
-They may only have one dog, or they may have several.



-They want to make some extra money.



-They sell through the newspaper.
-They may keep their dogs inside as pets and may love them, but they are not educated about animal husbandry or genetics.
-They do no health testing.
-The pups may go to the vet once to get vacs, or may not go at all.



-Their dogs may or may not be registered, but they don’t show or compete.



-They will likely let the puppy go to anyone with the cash.
-They don’t care if the puppy gets spayed or neutered or what happens if its new owners can’t keep it.
-They may be breeding intentional mixes, aka designer dogs.



What is a puppy mill?
A puppy mill is a large commercial operation that treats dogs like livestock or factory machinery.



Their notable traits:
-There may be hundreds of dogs.
-They are kept in tiny, wire bottom cages, sometimes stacked.
-The breeding dogs never see a vet or groomer. The puppies may see a “vet” employed by the pet store before being put on the sales floor.



-They see dogs as commodities, not living things with feelings.



-They sell through pet stores, brokers, the internet, or flea markets.
-They do no health testing.



-Puppies are registered in batches, if they are registered at all.



-They may be breeding intentional mixes, aka designer dogs.
-They breed the females every heat, and when they are too weak to keep breeding, they may turn them over to rescuers, or they may just kill them.



-They provide only the minimum heat, cooling, shelter, and cleanliness required by the USDA, which is minimal.



Source(s):



www.petshoppuppies.org
www.prisonersofgreed.org
www.petstorecruelty.org
www.ararebreedoflove.com



</answer>



<answer from>



alrightm...

Total points: 17355 (Level 6)

<question from>



Agility ganna b a 6/7
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 86 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dog Agility: The weaves...?



1- How can i speed them up (he's a dog learning them)



2- How can i fade out the target at the end of the weaves without losing speed etc?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



The technique of teaching Weaves.



First of all, you -lead- the dog through the poles - by his nose.  To start with, use the command "Weave" then use the -away-, -come- for each pole.  Take it REALLY slowly.



Later, once the dog understands the concept, the command "Weeeeeave" should do the trick.



Your dog, may or may not pick up the "Collie" trick of left-right-left-right leg that is so fast, most just bend their bodies around the poles.



You don't usually need to "fade" at the end of the Weaves, the dog will eventually see all the poles as one obstacle.



Source(s):



Competed with a Papillon for 4 years. He adored the game!



</answer>

<question>



How can I keep her at home?



My 9 month-old golden retriever/border collie mix takes off when she wakes up at 5:30 a.m. and proceeds to run the roads and half the countryside around our house, dragging up garbage, clothes, and miscellaneous items from our neighbor's yards, and then comes home and passes out.  She is a beautiful dog, very affectionate and funny, like a little clown.  My husband wants to put her on a harness and run a line for her to run on.  I am adamantly against that, because I don't want to break her spirit -- she's so energetic and can't help it!  How can I keep her inside our 3 acres without a fence and without putting her on a line?  Thanks for any advice.



</question>

you could get an electric collar.



we have a medium sized dog (shiba inu) who is very engergetic and we used to have her tied up. i think this caused a lot of behavior problems. now that we have an electric fence she is very happy and does not bite anymore or go in the house.



</answer>

<answer>

Also, if she's not spayed, spaying her will help calm her down a little, and prevent unexpected pups if she's allowed to roam free.

<answer>

<answer from>



beseder1...
Member since: 12 February 2006
Total points: 4242 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to listen to the experienced dog owner answers here.  Even though you see her as cute and sweet and funny, the people who are having to pick up their garbage or retrieve their belongings are not seeing her that way.  They are getting mad.



And how would you like to accidentally hit a dog out on the road and kill it?  I'm sure you wouldn't-- and by letting your dog roam and run the roads, you are setting her and some innocent motorist up for serious injury or gripping pain.



As the parent, you have to set limits for your child or your dog.  You and the dog need to go to obedience school for the dog's safety.



You can worry about breaking her spirit (which will not happen) or you can teach her how to coexist with humans so that she is not killed.



If you had a two year old who insisted on playing in the street, would you let them or would you worry about breaking their spirit?



You have to be responsible for your beautiful dog and train her.  Discipline means you take the time to love and train her for her own good.



</answer>
