<question>



What are dew claws and why do they need to be removed?



I have a Yorkie puppy and I've heard that when they are real young, they should have their dew claws removed.  What are dew claws?



</question>



<answer from>



Greg C
Member since: 13 May 2007
Total points: 1388 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think they reside on the mid to lower leg and they get caught on stuff and tear.



</answer>



<answer from>



Leslie
Member since: 24 July 2006
Total points: 6786 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are a toe, like a thumb....on the inside of the foot, up a little higher than the paw....if left on, the nail can grow around and back into the leg before the owner may realize, and they do get caught on things.  Like carpet or bedding. They  are usually removed at 3-4 days.



</answer>



<answer from>



Princess Nisa
Member since: 19 April 2006
Total points: 833 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dewclaws are similar to your thumbs. Most breeders remove them when they are 3-5 days old.  They say it's not used toe so they remove them so they won't get stuck on rugs and break the toe itself.  Which I think is unnecessary pain for the puppies. I work for an animal hospital and I hate when I have to assist the doctor when he remove them.  Now if they have dewclaws on their hind legs I would remove them because more often than not when people bring their pets to the groomers they oversee the dewclaw and don't trim them.  What ends up happening is that the nail grows too long and can curl into the skin which is more painful.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tyra Dobe
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A dew claw is like the dogs thumb (only useless!) on the front paws and sometimes on the hind legs as well (bad bred dogs!)



It is the claw that sits half way between the paw and the dogs elbow.  The claw is useless to the animal and can get caught and damaged very easily.



I had a kelpie who caught his dew claw and it ripped up his leg about 2 inches and broke the bone beneath.  It caused him much pain and the vet ended up removing both when the dog was 9mths old so that he wouldn't do it to the other claw at a later stage.



If done by a professional it shouldn't bother the dog too much and should heal very quickly.



Enjoy your little yorkie :)



</answer>



<answer from>



papaw
Member since: 26 March 2007
Total points: 33865 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Dew claws on a dog are equivalent to a thumb, or a big toe on a human, except on a dog they are 2 - 3 inches up on the side of it's paw / leg. They do no damage, but some people like to remove themwhen they are small so they don't get snagged and torn, but it's OK to leave them. Just remember, since they don't touch the ground, the nails will grow longer quicker, so you must be sure to keep them trimmed.



</answer>



<answer from>



pvh nurse
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dew claws are the first of five digits and represents the thumb. In the dog they are not really needed and generally become an annoyance. It is recommended that they are removed when the puppies are a few days old or at the time of desexing.



Some dew claws are attached with a joint and some are only attached by flesh.



If attached by flesh they are more at risk of catching them on something and either damaging it or ripping it off.



If they are securely attached and aren't bothering the dog I would not risk having an anesthetic just to remove dew claws. You just have to remember to clip them regularly or they can become overgrown



Source(s):



Veterinary nurse



</answer>

<question from>



Amelia

</question from>



<question>



Buying a Chihuahua Puppy?



I live in a medium sized one bedroom apartment by myself. and i thought that i would appreciate the companion of a dog. After some consideration, i've decided i would like a chihuahua, it's size is better suited for a small apartment and it would be easy for traveling.



Since they are small dogs i'm sure there are a lot of possible health problems. i wanted to know what signs i should look for when i go to buy one. how can i tell a potentially healthy puppy from a sick one?
also what special needs do they have?



can they be litter trained?



and how much should i expect to pay, i've seen pricing from 250 to 1000+, what's fair?



</question>



<answer from>



maria
Member since: 17 October 2006
Total points: 3926 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



hi, i have lots of chihuahuas they are great little dogs, they would be happy in a big house or a small flat. Yes they can be litter trained, and prices do vary, unfortuntly due to the film beverley hills chihuahua breeders have put prices up, so go careful. The film has caused some bad breeders to breed more heavy to meet demand. If you want a good pedigree chihuahua then go to the kennel club web site and they have a list of pups that are born in different areas.



Chihuahuas are a fragile dog that cannot take the physical abuse that a child is destined to give it. So if you are planning on getting a Chihuahua for your kids then you may want to think again.



Be wary of a breeder that tries to sell you a Chihuahua that is four pounds or less. One of the biggest Chihuahua problems is the misconception that the cute little Chihuahuas that fit in teacups make the cutest little pets. Chihuahuas that are bred to be four pounds or less are unhealthy animals and very fragile. Their bones cannot withstand much stress and a simple jump from the back of the couch to the floor can cause a bone to break. So be suspicious of a breeder that tries to sell you a tea cup Chihuahua because no such healthy animal exists.



Chihuahuas  have a few hereditary defects. Patella luxation affects many breeds of dogs. Chi breeders have always been very aware of the condition. Conscientious breeders have worked to try to eradicate it from their lines by not breeding from afflicted lines, which has reduced its incidence. A chi's energetic lifestyle will always put strain upon what is basically a rather complex and fragile joint. Breeders and judges who weed out dogs with patella luxation from breeding programmes and awards are doing everyone a great service whether they be two legged or four legged. The original chi breed standard described a molera as being desirable. Our previous U.K. standard stated "with or without molera". The current U.K. standard omits all mention of it. Breeders do not breed for it and exhibitors certainly do not want judges poking at little dogs skulls. Because chis have brachycephalic skulls and large heads, the bones of the skull need to be able to give during the birth process. Like babies they have a fontanelle but in the chi it is called a molera. Chis are not particularly good whelpers. Quite often the molera does not fully close until the pup is several months old, sometimes this is seen and misdiagnosed by some vets as hydrocephalus. These days few chis have permanent moleras which persist into adulthood. A quite common little habit some chis have is snorting when they are overexcited or alarmed. This too has on occasions resulted in some scary diagnosis. Quivering when keen, alert or anxious is very common. It seldom signifies the chi is cold or frightened.



Most young people now adays want a chi so they can dress they up in dresses etc, they dont like this, and again they love to go out for walks so they dont need carrying around in a bag.



I have pasted two links where you can see my chihuahuas, the first link shows them at there age now and later on as a puppy, so you can see how they change. If you have any other questions i am happy for you to email via my 360. Good luck, and i hope you find the right dog for yourself.  All the best Maria



Source(s):



http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=aNl2oTXvFs...



http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=6InEhDnlCq...



</answer>



<answer from>



Leslie
Member since: 24 July 2006
Total points: 6786 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Chihuahuas used to be short legged fat little bugeyed  yappers. Breeders have worked long and hard to change that. They are now, lovely little loving pets.  If you want a good one...they should look square...in other words should be slightly longer than they are tall...their heads should look like an apple, w/a pronounced stop at the head.  Muzzle and then a rise to the head.  There are those that are called Deerheads, I don't personally think they are as cute.  Go on line and look at them, so you will know what you want.  As for their health.  Chihuahuas are tough.  And have really no real serious weaknesses.  There are long haired ones and smooth.  Just depends on what you like..they are  spunky little guys.....if you go look at puppies...go to one place, and do not go to a pet shop.  Oh, you can go to see what they have, usually low quality....but go to a person who just has a couple and breeds them once in awhile, talk to them and see if they know about the breed, and seem to have a genuine love for the breed.  Pedigrees mean nothing.  Some of the best pets have lousy pedigrees.  Just spend some time and watch the puppies.  If one has a problem, it will jump out at you in time.  Watch for signs of diarrhea...dirty behind, or not too lively.  They should be playing and fighting w/each other...not really fighting, but tusseling w/each other.  Spend the time....and watch.  One will jump out at you, or come to your lap while you sit there.  You will know when you have found him. But please look at more than one litter.  And check the cleanliness of the place that has the puppies and ask to see mama and daddy.  If you can't,  I would like a good reason why.



</answer>



<answer from>



they call me jenny :]
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 1305 (Level 3)

actually big dogs generally have more problems than little dogs, thats why little dogs typically live longer...



i have never heard of a dog being litter trained...but if there is a such thing, then go for it.



if your buying him/her from someones house its probably gonna be 300-700...its gonna cost more to buy him./her from a shop.



chihuahuas dont have any special needs that i know of.

<question>



Why shouldn't dogs eat dry dog food and have a drink of water in a short amount of time on a hot day?



My teacher had a dog and told me a story that he died because he fed him dog food on a very hot day and let him have a drink and the dog died. Don't know why......

<answer from>



thelittl...
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 627 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



thats ridiculous. it died from something else



to the post below- that is untrue. it is necessary to life to drink liquids with food. it helps the food be digested (ever wondered why you get the urge to have a glass of water with dinner?). Your stomach will not expand to crush surrounding organs. The stomach is a storage point before the intestines and muscles make sure that does not happen.



Source(s):



study anatomy



</answer>



<answer from>



Marrr-ta...
Member since: 29 December 2007
Total points: 412 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well some dogs will just keep eating and eating until they are stuffed.  If the dog then drank a large a amount of water the dry food in it stomach would expand and cause internal pressure on its organs.  Have you ever ate too much your self and found it hard to even breath?  Kinda like that.  Thats my first theory..



Feed the dog in the cool of the morning instead  :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



Euny
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 257 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it may have died from bloat, which was not caused by the weather but rather, from eating or drinking while it is excited. The dog most likely came back from being outside (it was probably running or doing some other active activity) and drank/ate too hastily.



Bloat is a serious condition which is almost always fatal; it occurs more often with breeds that are deep chested, and studies have shown that dogs that eat dry kibble are more likely to get this.



What he told you was based on a lack of knowledge. I feel really bad for the dog... poor boy.



</answer>



<answer from>

<question>



If you say dogs have such bad memories, why do they always remember things like going to potty outside?



Or why do they remember that the leash means that they are going out for a walk?



People say that after 2 seconds, you can't punish a dog, because "they won't remember it."



</question>



<additional details>



No, I do not mean 3 hours later. I mean, maybe a little MORE than 2 or 3 seconds.



Seriously, people here have double standards. (well, some people.). They think that dogs remember everything when it's convenient to (like when you guys are lecturing about potty training) but then at other times, you guys say , "OH NO, your dog won't remember anything past 2 seconds, because dogs live in the present."



Seriously, stop trying to sound smart and contradicting yourselves. It takes away your credibility.



Of course, I'm not talking to everything. Just most people.



No, I do not mean 3 hours later. I mean, maybe a little MORE than 2 or 3 seconds.



Seriously, people here have double standards. (well, some people.). They think that dogs remember everything when it's convenient to (like when you guys are lecturing about potty training) but then at other times, you guys say , "OH NO, your dog won't remember anything past 2 seconds, because dogs live in the present."



Seriously, stop trying to sound smart and contradicting yourselves. It takes away your credibility.



Of course, I'm not talking to everything. Just most people.



</additional details>



<answer from>



HaWkDriV...
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 180 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A dog has learned that the leash means a walk after repetitiveness. If you punish a dog after he or she did something wrong and some time has passed, the dog will not learn why the punishment is occurring. It's the same way we all learned when we were children. It took our parents a thousand times of saying "no" before we learned.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



That makes PERFECT sense. Thanks for giving an educated answer and not saying something stupid and obvious, like "Your dog won't remember what you're punishing him for if you do it three hours later." DUH! xD



Moral of the story: need to continue discipline pup when she does something wrong.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Patient Paws
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 5898 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you ever put it past 'memories' and into the world of repetition?



If a dog does something 3 times a day, like going outside to pee, they will remember that for the rest of their lives so long as it stays consistent.



If a dog has chewed up a shoe three hours ago and you come home yelling at it for what it did three hours ago, its going to be entirely clueless.



"Showing" the dog doesn't magically jog its memory either. All they're going to notice is "hmm, this smells like me" and then you start punishing them because of what the recognize, but do not understand.



</answer>



<answer from>



andie...
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 1022 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Of course dogs have good memories..it'd be hopeless to train them if not! With time and repitition they can remember commands or actions. However, in other situations like cause/effect and punishment, there is a difference in the way their brain works from ours. It's not that "they won't remember it." It's that they are unable to connect the act with the punishment if it's not immediate. They simply don't realize what you're yelling about if you don't do it at the moment they're commiting the act.



</answer>



<answer from>



alias boxer
Member since: 18 September 2007
Total points: 7376 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Habit.  You TEACH them to go outside to potty, and it becomes routine.  They LEARN that the leash means they're going for a walk, because every time you get the leash... you take the dog for a walk.  If you were to take the leash out and wave it around many times a day, without taking the dog for a walk, the dog would not associate the leash with walks.



Dogs don't have an associative memory like we do, and we can't communicate in sentences to them to get across that something they did in the past was wrong.  Instead, they learn by habit, once again.  That's why in order to stop the behavior, you must catch them in the act or, even better, immediately before.  If you say "NO" right before the dog jumps on the couch, it will stop him from jumping.  And if you do this enough, the dog begins to get into the HABIT of "hearing" you say NO right before he jumps on the couch -- in other words, the thought or premeditation of jumping on the couch becomes associated with the thought of you saying NO followed by the dog stopping himself from jumping.  This is even more affective if you treat or praise the dog after he stops himself from jumping; then he associates NOT jumping on the couch with something positive. =)



If you punish AFTER the fact, the dog still has no conscience telling him to not jump before he actually does it.  Instead, he gets on the couch, and when he gets OFF (or when you get home), that triggers his memory -- he's learned out of routine that he gets punished AFTER he gets on the couch.  That's why they look "guilty" afterwards; it's not because they actually know they did something wrong, but because they anticipate the punishment that always follows.



</answer>



<answer from>



Crys
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 384 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think they have bad memories, they remember a lot! I think its wrong to punish them over something that happened a while ago, if they're still at the scene then they get in trouble, but if they're doing something else, its mean to get upset, they'll think that what they're doing then is wrong instead of what they actualy did wrong.



</answer>



<answer from>



Purebred...
Member since: 29 September 2007
Total points: 4787 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs

<answer>



It's not that they don't remember having done something wrong. But they don't understand when you punish them after the fact, why you are punishing them.. You can yell all you want and tell them not to pee on the floor, but they don't associate the yelling with something that happened earlier.



</answer>

science chick

</answer>

<question from>



Paigeroo...

</question from>



<question>



Ok, so I have always been a pitbull lover but....?



My best friend's neighbor has owned 2 pitbulls for several years. They are the sweetest dogs and have always been one of the reasons I changed my attitudes about pitbulls in general.



Well, 2 days ago one of them escaped from under the fence, dug under my my best friend's, dragged out his 2 year old dachshund/lab mix and attacked it right in his front yard while a neighborhelplessly looked on. His other dog, some kind of boxer mix, managed to squeeze out of the hole and attacked the pitbull causing it some minor injuries and eventually scaring it away, but it was too late for Bear, the smaller dog. He died on the front lawn from bleeding to death.



now, I know you can't blame the dog, and it is usually the owners fault for not knowing how to properly train and socialize a pitbull, but seeing this friendly dog snap like this got me really scared for my own dogs as our neighbor down the street owns a pair of pitbulls.



My question is, how do you explain this? Is it simply in the breed for pitbulls to be dog aggressive? They have played with Bear before in the company of their owners and have always been friendly. What caused the change?



</question>



<additional details>



And the owners don't abuse their dogs or train them to fight. I certainly wouldn't go as far as calling them experts, but those pitbulls have always seemed pretty well trained to me. AND they have a 2 year old and infant at home. the attacking pitbull has now been put to sleep. sad, but necessary.



Nope, thats the story. A neighbor saw the whole thing. Bear did nothing to provoke an attack. And dogs CAN snap, actually. All animals can be unpredictable.



Oh, and Bear was a lab/standard dachshund mix. Probably a 40-50 pound dog. I would understand if he was some teeny chihuahua, but he wasn't.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Honeybelle DILLIGAF
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 4578 (Level 4)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think there is a difference between being "dog aggressive" and going to measures such as digging under a fence to drag a dog out for the purpose of killing it.



One could be considered an attack of opportunity, the other to me seems to be pre-meditated.



One would be the equivalent of manslaughter, the other the equivalent of murder.



Edit:  Jase, there is a difference between your dog killing one of your own pets and this dog going to the extremes to kill the neighbour's dog.  I certainly think this dog needed to be put down for showing such extreme aggression.  If it was my dog that was dragged from its yard to be savaged I would be screaming for blood.



I am not going to get into breeds even though some breeds do show more propensity for this type of extreme aggressive behaviour than others.  Therefore the owners of these breeds need to be aware of this and take more stringent measures to ensure the dogs never have the opportunity to cause such damage.



Edit 2:  The more I think about it the more this story disturbs me on so many levels.  I don't understand why so many people are so ready to jump to the defence of the dog which, quite honestly has committed a heinous act, even for the dog world.  As far as it being Terrier instinct - a Jack Russell or even a Fox Terrier would not do the same damage as the breed in question.  Therefore I question the need for dogs that can do this sort of damage without any provocation.



No Pit bull owners seem to have any compassion for the dog that was viciously killed or the poor owner who had to helplessly witness this.  It makes me feel sick in the stomach and I would hate to have to go through this.



I understand an animal carrying out its natural instincts.  I lost a dog to a croc many years ago.  My FIL wanted to shoot the croc we suspected got my boy but my view is - what was the point as the croc was only doing what it does best and my dog was in the wrong place at the wrong time.



Likewise, if Bear had dug into the Pit bull's yard and was killed I would say the same - the dog was in the wrong place at the wrong time.



But this dog was doing nothing wrong - he was in a place where he should have been safe.  The poor poor thing.



So please, Pit bull owners, while I realise that you love your dogs and believe them to be beyond this, just realise that the owner of the attacking dog may have felt the same about his dog.  Please be aware of the damage that your dogs are capable of and take measures to prevent this from happening with your dog, if you already aren't.  Also, have some compassion for the victims.



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<answer>



Terriers have high prey drives and its well known that smaller dogs are considered game by dogs with high prey drives. A Dachshund looks a LOT like small game to an APBT.



Its not the dog-dog aggression, its the prey drive. My APBTs have no dog aggression, but if I show them a sprinting Chihuahua, there is no guarantee that they wont go after it to catch and kill it.



</answer>

<answer>



The dog did not just snap.  It's dog aggressive and  dog aggression does not have to be trained into any breed of dog.



I did not read all the responses but saw one person saying dogs have to trained to fight and such no they do not.



A dog can become dog aggressive regardless of how well socialized and trained they are.



It's called genetics.



No dogs do NOT just snap.  There is always a reason behind it.  Medical or whatever.  The dog did not just decide to dig out and go after the neighbors dog.



There was something people did NOT see.
Not everyone knows how to read a dogs body language, eyes,stance etc.



Something did happen to provoke it weather you believe it or not.



No the dog does not need to be PTS it was being a dog.



Attacking another dog does not turn into human aggression.



Dogs know the difference betweend humans, small child and prey.



You say you love Pit Bulls but you don't know anything about them.



You want a dog put down for being a dog.  Then all the cats better be put down for killing birds, rabbits, mice.



Better put down all other breeds like Jack Russells who love rabbits and other prey also.  I could give you a whole list.



Better put down all terriers.



Better put my dachshund to sleep cause he is doing what is natural to him too by trying to get him a rabbit.



Are all dogs intact or altered?



Was the one dog giving stink eye through the fence.



There is much you do not know and did not witness.



Both parties are responsible you do NOT leave your dogs outside unattended.



This could have been something building up for awhile now.  And no one noticed it.

Rescuer, Trainer, owner of 6 Pit Bulls and several other breeds.

<answer>



With any dog does not matter the breed, if it is not socialized, trained properly or if not properly exercised can lead to a bad situation. Many things could have happened in this situation. Maybe the Pit bull was excited to see the other dog but the other dog was not excited to see it. The problem maybe that people do not understand the strength of these "bull" breeds(pit-bull, english bull dog, bull terrier, ex...). I have played with a 4 month old english bulldog puppy before and ended up getting hurt. It's not the puppies fault it was not being aggressive it's just that they are ruff players, they are pretty heavy in weight for being so short, the same goes for pit-bulls. Any little thing could have happened where the other dog did not want to play, or the pit-bull did not know how to properly introduce himself once again to the other dog, but the strength that the pit-bull had dominates over lots of other breeds. I'm sorry this has happened. The best thing would be to be very careful with your pets and any other dog, does not matter the breed, it's our own faults for not properly showing our dogs the right way.

<answer>



This is PREY DRIVE and nothing else.  The pit MORE THAN LIKELY saw this dog as fair game.  To be honest, it's not the pitbull thing, it's the TERRIER thing.  Terriers were originally bred to kill smaller pests.



Now, the dog probably didn't do anything to provoke an attack.  It's a natural prey drive.



NO, dogs do not "snap", what happens is is that PEOPLE FORGET that dogs are animals who live on instinct, people start treating their dogs like people and taking on a perspective that SHOULD HAVE NEVER developed in the relationship.  Yes, all animals are unpredictable BECAUSE of this, but its not just them 'SNAPPING"
And my girl was rescued LITERALLY off the street at 1 1/2 years old from an abusive and neglectful life, so I just pray I have trained her well and count my blessings for giving me such a wonderful, loving dog.



I really hope this does not change your view on pits.  My own pit attacked both of my cats in a week.  One of my cats did not make it through the attack.. I was helpless in getting her off my cat.



My view on pits has not changed, because I know it was not a "personal" thing, it was MY DOG being  A DOG. It was my fault when it happened for not keeping her out of that room. She figured out how to pull and lift out a METAL gate that is drilled to the wall.



IT NEVER CROSSED MY MIND TO PUT MY DOG DOWN BECAUSE OF THIS, AND SHE IS STILL GOOD WITH MY 3 YEAR OLD GODSON AND DOGS.



Animal aggression and Prey drive ARE NOT to be confused with plain aggression/people aggression.



Source(s):



love my pit, will always love my pit, and will always love the breed

<answer>



Answer hidden due to its low rating



Some pit bulls are defensive of their territory. If the little dog was "invading his space" he might have gotten aggressive. Also, they might have been play fighting and something went wrong. Pit bulls are sweet dogs and are only trained to be aggressive. I had the sweetest pit bull mix for 15 years. He was trained to be the leader of a hog-hunting pack and was supposed to go in and kill it. We adopted him, and he was so sweet you could do anything to him. I hope this helps! P.S. Don't immediately think all dogs are nice. Any dog can be improperly trained. I'm not saying your friend was responsible for the accident, and anything could have been the cause of the attack.



</answer>

I decided it would be a good idea to agree to look after my friends springer whilst she went away, BIG MISTAKE! It has given my 4 dogs and 2 kittens fleas, I rang the vet and he said I should be able to treat the problem with over the counter tablets and household insecticide, well, I have done this, 4 bloomin times and I still keep finding the odd little bugger hiding on one of my pets, I have completely fumigated the house with this spray stuff, hoovered obsessively and washed everything on a boil wash, it makes you feel so dirty, eeewww!!  Well I have finally given in and booked into the vets, I dont care if they think im daft for not being able to treat this myself but it is disgusting and I dont know what else I can do, has anyone got any ideas on what I can use in the house to kill them, it needs to be strong, these little terrors are like the SAS of the flea world!! <answer from>



vegachan...
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Alright, you might think me to be crazy but there are 3 things I want you to do if you have the resources and time. 1, get a flea collar from the local grocery and put it in your hoover bag. That should stop the fleas from breeding in there and kill any new and existing ones.



2, mix equal parts baking soda and salt and sprinkle it as heavily as you want all over your house, under the furniture on the carpet, bedding, mattresses, bathroom, rugs, EVERYWHERE. Let it sit for about an hour, then vacuum it up.



3, if you can, get a steam cleaner; borrow, buy or rent. Which ever suits you, and depending on your carpet color, mix about 6 tablespoons of over-the-counter flea shampoo with the regular carpet detergent and go over the house. Then do a second run with just water or with water and carpet detergent.



Then you can also use the remaining flea shampoo on your dogs and, if it's recommended, you can sponge-bathe your cats as long as you can also rinse the shampoo off as well.



This should knock out your problem. Good luck!



Source(s):



Seasoned dog breeder; killer of fleas



</answer>

<answer from>



ryma
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,



Foggers and sprays are an effective way to control fleas indoors. Most experts recommend sprays, because foggers can miss crevices where fleas hide. Choose only safe, nontoxic insecticidal sprays for indoor use. It's also a good idea to vacuum thoroughly each week, being sure to get under cushions--a favorite flea hideout. You will also need to use a disinfectant and insecticide within your home somewhat regularly for a period of time. You can also opt to hire a professional exterminator to nip the problem in the bud throughout your home.



The outside of your house will need to be addressed as well, especially if your dog spends a lot of his time there. Since sun and fleas are not a compatible combination, the shady spots of your yard are the areas that you will want to target.



Check out this links to know more about flea control, fighting and preventing flea infestation:
http://dogtime.com/flea-control.html
http://dogtime.com/flea-control-tips-aah...



</answer>

<question from>



***Chels...
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 182 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Has anyone ever heard of a Pudin Jack Rusell Terrier?



I have a rescue dog that looks like a staffy x jack russell but we met someone who told us he was a Pudin Jack Rusell Terrier and that it is a type of Jack Rusell. Does anyone have one or know anything about them? Anyone got a dog favourite? Thanx :D



</question>



<additional details>



I don't appretiate the ugly comments as my dog is extremely cute but i do understand that he is a genetically modified breed which is defective. I don't idiotic comments like ugly etc. Thanks for the two long comments though as they really helped.



</additional details>



<answer from>



woooh!
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 7785 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Here is the truth on the Pudin JRT...
The Pudin JRT is considered Achondroplastic Dwarfism. Read on...



Achondroplastic dwarfism is a genetic defect and should not be perpetuated. This is not "just another type of small dog" -- this is a dog with non-proportional limbs and very clear symptoms caused by a genetic defect.. "Achondroplasia" literally means "an absence of good shape" and refers to a distortion of the legs (as in the Dachshund and Jack Russell) or head (as in the English Bulldog). Achonodroplasia is associated with back problems, weight problems, and patella problems, as the short legs make it more difficult for the dogs to run, while any added weight further compromises an already unsound skeletal system.



Some ill-informed breeders are intentionally breeding achondroplastic dwarf dogs because they think they are "cute." This is a very bad turn of events, as it simply increases the genetic load on all dogs.



This is just another pathetic genetic misfit that people are not only making a profit from but are  ruining a sound breed. If you don't understand soundness of a breed, read the standard of the JRT, the "Pudin" is not in the mix.



</answer>



<answer from>



Does Tricks for Treats
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 13256 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



A "puddin'" Jack Russell is a dog that is an achondroplastic dwarf. The clear visual signs of this genetic condition are a large chest on short, benched or "Queen Anne" legs. These dogs are also referred to as "shorties" by some people, and as "Irish Jacks" by others.



An achondroplastic dwarf is an animal that cannot run as fast as a well built dog, and it's chest will often be too large for it to go to ground, no matter how much they have "the fire called desire."



Achondroplastic dwarfs are not smaller dogs -- they are almost always larger in the only way that really counts when hunting, which is chest size.



Though an achondroplastic dwarf terrier may be only 10 inches tall, it may be anywhere from 15 to 20 pounds in weight due to the huge chest, big bones, and large head.



Breeds commonly associated with achondroplastic dwarfism are basset hounds, dachshunds, shih-tzus, pekingese, sharpeis and English and French bulldogs. These dog always have limbs that are shorter than their body and often have over-large heads as well.



Achondroplastic dwarfism is a genetic defect and should not be perpetuated. This is not "just another type of small dog" -- this is a dog with non-proportional limbs and very clear symptoms caused by a genetic defect.. "Achondroplasia" literally means "an absence of good shape" and refers to a distortion of the legs (as in the Dachshund and Jack Russell) or head (as in the English Bulldog). Achonodroplasia is associated with back problems, weight problems, and patella problems, as the short legs make it more difficult for the dogs to run, while any added weight further compromises an already unsound skeletal system.



Some ill-informed breeders are intentionally breeding achondroplastic dwarf dogs because they think they are "cute." This is a very bad turn of events, as it simply increases the genetic load on all dogs. The UKC dogs being bred as "Russell Terriers" are often (though not always) achondroplastic dwarves.



EDIT:  Don't forget your SOURCE, Woooh!



Source(s):



http://images.google.com/imgres?imgurl=h...



</answer>

<question from>



bleh
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 216 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I'm getting a 8 week puppy on Friday?



What should I prepare for the dog?  Would it cry for its mom?  What should I expect?



</question>



<additional details>



I plan to get the shots for the puppy next week, should leave it in the house first before getting the shots?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Mochi
Member since: 02 March 2007
Total points: 558 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would search around yahoo for this questions, since there's many similar questions on here.



If you've decided to bring a puppy home, chances are you've already determined that this is the right pet and the right breed for your household. If not, take a few steps back and do it. Adopting or purchasing a puppy that is incompatible with your family will only lead to stress and unhappiness for you and the animal.



The most obvious step in preparation is making sure you have all the things a puppy will need. Buy a large bag of quality puppy chow, and make sure to get a "large breed" variation if your puppy is expected to grow to a large size. Chew toys are another essential. Puppies are, essentially, four-legged newborns that grow up really fast. Everything in the world is new to them and they'll want to explore it. Encouraging a puppy to play with his or her toys and not other objects from an early age will help prevent destructive tenancies later on. Bite sized treats are ideal for puppies, as their jaws and teeth are not yet as strong as those of an adult dog. Use them to reinforce good behavior and during training exercises. Puppy pads may be helpful in house training, though not all puppies respond to them. Grooming supplies and carpet cleaner are likely to come in handy.



It's important that you don't put off purchasing the following items: a collar, a leash, and a kennel. Despite how much you may want to just let a puppy run free at first, letting him or her adjust to being restrained will make life easier on everyone. A dog that has grown used to a bare neck may not rest until he manages to find a way out of his new collar; a dog that has never been leashed may rebel when finally put on one for a walk. It's best to get a puppy used to it during a very young age, while they are easier to control.



Be prepared to start crate training a puppy the very first night. Buy a kennel that is large enough for him to sit, stand and turn around it, but not large enough that he will be encouraged to relieve himself at the other end of the kennel. Be ready to put up with lots of whining at first, but rest assured that kenneling is not cruel--dogs are den creatures and a kennel will serve as a den. Most puppy will cry in the middle of the night for the first week, so putting a clock next to the puppy or something with the scent of their mom would provide the comfort for them.



There are other things that can help prepare the household for the arrival of a puppy. Make sure that everyone in the family knows what they will be responsible for when it comes to caring for the young canine. It may be helpful to create a schedule for everyone to follow regarding the puppy's care. Also be sure to puppy proof the house and let everyone know what it takes the keep it that way. Creating a checklist of things that need to be kept out of reach/sight of the puppy may make this easier.



If there are other animals in the house be prepared to socialize the puppy accordingly. If there is a chance that the older pet(s) may become aggressive toward the puppy then try introducing them on neutral grounds away from the home and then bringing them home together.



Set up an appointment for the vet and look into obedience training if you do not plan to handle this yourself. Read up about the breed(s) and seek out others who have successfully raised a puppy if you've never done it yourself. Covering all these bases before a puppy is brought home will help make it easier to handle anything that may come up. Make life with the new, furry family member an enjoyable experience by taking the time to properly prepare.



Source(s):



owner of a 7 months puppy



</answer>



<answer from>



MamaB
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 4055 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Preparations - Bed, Food, food bowl, water bowl, lightweight puppy collar and lead.  All of the above and more!



Crying for mom - actually not for mom, but quite likely for his litter mates.  Hopefully by the time you pick him up, he should be fully weaned and only seeing mom occasionally.  He will be bewildered, at first, by his new surroundings, smells and yes, you!  And he will miss the company and rough and tumble of living with his siblings.



So expect some protests!



Shots - keep him on your premises until he's finished the course of shots.  This will probably mean until he's at least 14 weeks.  Allow two extra weeks after the last shot is given.  Carry him into the vet too - do not put him down on the floor, sick animals go to vets!  How often have I seen people walking their cute puppies into vets - shudder.



Good luck with your new puppy.



</answer>



<answer from>



Taboo
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 2241 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You'll need:



*Same food dog has been on
*Wire kennel size appropriate..small but comfortable
*no collar..especially in kennel (choke hazard)
*bedding



*no need to leave it in the home.. start potty training...just dont place the dog around unvaccinated cats of dogs..if you dont know..assume they are unvaccinated...this includes ground where they have been!
*Hangin Water bottle in Kennel
*Plenty of paper towels
*Blanket to cover kennel (muffles noise, creates cozy environment)



***lots of patients, and consistency in training practices***



</answer>

We lost our beloved dog a year ago and God, my son and I still cry over him!!!!!!!  I do animal rescue and love animals, but I would have gave EVERYTHING I own to have save my son's little brother....We miss him so much!!!!!!!!!!  Good Luck and Enjoy!!!!!!!!!!  Make sure you keep his shots up to date!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Parvo is a number one killer of puppies.  It may cry...just be patient!!!!!!!!  Puppies are puppies and play and chew so, toys are important. </answer from>



<answer>



Pomeranian pups.Why? Cause they are very flufy and have orange fur, pointy ears. If you see these status on a dog it's defenitly a Pomeranian. Here is some information about Pomeranian breed.



P.S. Hope i helped!!!!! Please choose me as best answer. Please!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Thnx!!!!!



P.S.2 Pomeranian chttp://pjbottoms.files.wordpress.com/200... also in white fur colour



Source(s):



Pomeranian
(Zwergspitz) (Dwarf Spitz) (Loulou) (Pom)



Pommania Pomeranians



Pommania Poetry In Motion and Pommania Ms Dynamite. Litter sisters from excellent lines a fabulous brood and show girl. Courtesy of Pommania Pomeranians



Find a Pomeranian Breeder
Place an Ad



Rescue a Pomeranian
List Your Rescue



Pronunciation



Pomeranian



Description



The Pomeranian is a tiny, fluffy dog with a wedge-shaped head and pointed erect ears. Some have faces that breeders liken to a fox; others have baby-doll or "pansy" faces. All have bright, dark, almond-shaped eyes with an intelligent expression. The nose is either dark or the color of its coat. The teeth should meet in a scissors bite. Poms also boast a distinctive feathered tail that fans forward over the back. There is an abundant ruff around the neck and chest area. The profuse stand-off double coat usually comes in solid colors. Any solid color is allowed, but the most common are red, orange, white or cream, blue, brown or black. Sometimes the coat is parti-colored (white with colored markings), black & tan, wolf or orange sable.



Temperament



The Pomeranian is a lively little dog. Intelligent, eager to learn, very loyal to its handler and family. The Pom is a wonderful companion dog and show ring contender. The breed's docile temper and affectionate nature endear it to many. They are alert, curious and busy: one of the most independent of the Toy breeds. Its vivacity and spirit make it well-liked by persons who do not usually care for toy dogs. They may be picky eaters. If it is properly introduced they usually get along with other dogs and household animals without any problems. Poms make good little watch dogs. Teach this dog early that it may bark a couple of times when the doorbell rings or when there are visitors, but then to keep quiet. Be very consistent about this. Poms have a delightful nature and do not cling to their handlers. Proud and happy, they are good at learning tricks, but need a firm hand. The Pomeranian must know the owner is the boss, or he will not listen. This breed may become too demanding if the owner allows it. Because of this breeds tiny size and it's adorable Ewok looking face, there are a very high percentage of Poms who fall victim to Small Dog Syndrome, human induced behaviors, where the dog believes he is pack leader to humans. This can cause many varying degrees of behavior problems, which are NOT Pomeranian traits, but behaviors brought on by the way they are treated by the humans around them. Behaviors include, but are not limited to separation anxiety, willful, nervous, bold and sometimes temperamental, not hesitating to attack much bigger dogs. Guarding behaviors, and excessive barking as they try and tell THEIR humans what THEY want them to do. They can become reserved with strangers, barking at them excessively, and sometimes growling, snapping and biting. Because most humans treat this tiny canine in such a manner that the dog does not see them as pack leader, they are not recommended for children. However, if a Pom is given rules to follow, limits as to what they are allowed to do, daily pack walks and a calm, self-assured pack leader who displays confident assertion towards the dog, this can be a well rounded, mentally stable, trustworthy, wonderful family companion. Because of its size, it can make a good companion for an elderly person.



Height, Weight



Height:  7-12 inches (18-30 cm.)



Weight:  3-7 pounds (1-3 kg.)



Health Problems



Some blood lines are prone to slipped stifle, dislocated patella (knee-cap), heart and skin problems, and eye infections. Since Pomeranians are prone to early tooth loss, feeding dry food is recommended to keep the teeth and gums in good condition. Be sure the veterinarian also keeps the dog's teeth clean. Newborn pups are rather tiny and fragile. Three newborns can be held in the palm of ones hand. Small females often need cesarean sections deliveries. When the dog is old it may become molted with bald spots.



Living Conditions



The Pomeranian is good for apartment living. They are very active indoors and will do okay without a yard. Keep the dog quiet in hot weather to avoid overheating.



Exercise



Poms need a daily walk.  Play will take care of a lot of their exercise needs, however, as with all breeds, play will not fulfill their primal instinct to walk. Dogs who do not get to go on daily walks are more likely to display behavior problems. They will also enjoy a good romp in a safe open area off lead, such as a large fenced in yard.



Life Expectancy



About 15 years.



Grooming



The Pomeranian's very long, double coat should be brushed frequently. If you work from the head, parting the coat and brushing it forward, it will fall neatly back in place, so the task, although time-consuming, is relatively easy. The cottony undercoat is shed once or twice a year. Dry shampoo when necessary. Clean the eyes and ears daily and take the dog for regu



</answer>

<answer from>



Pitbull lover♥
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 4255 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why do you want a purebred puppy?
Whats the matter with mixed breeds?



Go to your local shelter and look for a dog there.
Some good breeds to look for are:



American Pitbull Terriers
Boxers
Staffys
Australian Shepherds
German Shepherds
Labradors
Golden Retrievers

Buy a Maltipoo. It;s a cross between Maltsese and Poodle,Kanis. They are so small. You can find them in black,white fur colour. They only go 5 Ibs. and they don't grow big. Also it's the only breed that doesn't leave fur on your clothes and house so you will be clean. Thry ARE SOOOOOOOOOOO CUTE!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Friendly, easy to train, love anyone. I have one at home and she is the best!!!!!!!! Here is more info. Oh and they need time to spend with you and lot's of toys. Not much exersize. One walk per day is good. Hope it helps!!!!!! Please choose me as best answer!!!!!!!!!! Please!!!!!!!! P.S. They are cheap!!!!!!



http://crpuppylove.com/puppies/Malti_Poo...



Source(s):



Maltepoo
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia



(Redirected from Maltipoo)
Jump to: navigation, search
A small adult female Poodle/Maltese Dog mixed-breed. This one is 2.5 years old and approximately 10 pounds.



A Maltepoo (also known as a maltipoo, moodle, maltapoo, and malti-doodle), is a mixed-breed dog bred from Poodle and Maltese parents.[1][2] The maltipoo is one of many increasingly common poodle hybrids, largely the result of recent interest in so-called designer dogs. While Maltese dogs tend to have a generally uniform conformation, poodles can vary widely in size and color. Consequently, Maltepoos demonstrate this variation. The dog naturally exhibits characteristics from each of its parents. A particular advantage maltepoos are said to have is a small amount (or lack of) shedding, due to both parents being low shedders.



[edit] References



1. ^ Everything You Need to Know about Malt-I-Poo's, by Lynn Hilton



2. ^ The Complete Idiot's Guide to Designer Dogs, by Margaret H. Bonham



[edit] External links



* Poo-Mix Rescue (features "Malti-Poos" in urgent need)



* Excellent site all about the Maltipoo



A baby male. This dog is 10 1\2 lbs.
Retrieved from "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maltepoo"
Categories: Dog breeds | Companion dogs | Toy dogs



</answer>

<question from>



Rachii

</question from>



<question>



Cavalier King Charles Spaniels.?



I have been told that Cavvies do not need much exercise,
but do they suit well into a life where they will be walked everyday and would swim alot also?
thanks



</question>



<additional details>



so... in conclusion.. are cavvies ok to have as a excersise mate? as i would be running alot with it.. and swimming also..would the cavvie be up for a run or prefer to stay inside and nap?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Loki my springer!
Member since: 07 June 2008
Total points: 6125 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have owned two cavaliers in my life. Both were not the most active dogs but were always happy to walk on leash with you. I guess it depends on how your life is.



My first Cav was brought into a family of small children and not too much laying. He adapted to our lifestyle and became a very lazy little dog.



If you were to get it young and be active right from the start, it would work well. I have been told by many other Cav owners that they have the most active dog ever. So my answer would be yes :D



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for that.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



hey!! sweete
Member since: 25 February 2008
Total points: 1173 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cavalier King Charles Spaniels need a daily walk.  Play will take care of a lot of their exercise needs, however, as with all breeds, play will not fulfill their primal instinct to walk. Dogs who do not get to go on daily walks are more likely to display behavior problems. They will also enjoy a good romp in a safe open area off lead, such as a large fenced in yard.
but they will also Whatever exercise you can provide will be just fine with this adaptable dog, as they will adapt to your family's circumstances



</answer>



<answer from>



Becky
Member since: 02 December 2007
Total points: 7143 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes they're good for a moderately active household.  But please do your homework on this breed.  Despite being just lovely little pets, the breed has more than the usual share of serious health problems.



Heart issues and Syringomyelia, for starters.
So do a lot of research and make sure you find a good breeder who tests her dogs for these problems and uses only certified healthy dogs in her breeding program.



</answer>



<answer from>



Metro_Station Lover
Member since: 29 March 2008
Total points: 564 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They dont need to much excersise but they are great dogs i love them! You should get one and they do love to swim and are very playful!



</answer>

My dog, a Yorkshire Terrier, fell from about 4ft. From what we can tell, two of his lower teeth are loose and were bleeding. Is this life threatening? He is scheduled to go to the vet tomorrow.

<answer>



take it to the vet asap. sounds like he broke some teeth. it shouldn't be life threatening as long as he is eating and drinking and doing his business, but there's a chance of him getting infection in his gum, so its best to bring him to the vet as soon as possible and have him examine. hope he gets well soon.



</answer>

<answer from>



suzie
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 1182 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



4' is not that high.  No I doubt if it is life threatening.  If your dog was limping I would say yes, go immediately.  If it landed on it's head and was yelping the same.



Hopefully the teeth will settle.  If the dog is over 5 then little dogs are prone for bad teeth and lose rotten teeth in them is pretty average and they probably got knocked in the fall.  I doubt he will bleed to death from them, put a compress on to stop the bleeding.  If it continues then don't wait till the morning.
Give him a very soft meal tonight, no hard dog food, some tin stuff that he can lick up.



The biggest problem with small dogs falling is broken limbs.
Take care that he doesn't get to such a height in the future that he can fall, you have been pre warned, by your dog, not me.



</answer>



<answer from>



jan d
Member since: 29 May 2006
Total points: 1484 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Loose teeth are not life threatening. If they are not too bad they will probably stabilize themselves. Bleeding is only life threatening if he cut an artery which is a main blood vessel. So go the vet and just check it out.



</answer>

<answer>



My German Shepherd (AKC PUREBRED CHAMPION) saved my life !  I was walking in the dark to the wash-house with a laundry basket in my arms (so I couldn't see in front of me) and there was a 9' DIAMONDBACK RATTLESNAKE COILED in my path !!!  It didn't bother to rattle either !!!  My dog, TIRC, jumped in front of me -- pushing me out of harms way, and he grabbed it and threw it up in the air over and over sinking his teeth into its neck every time while I stood back in horror praying TIRC wouldn't be harmed !!!  Thank GOD he wasn't !!! He killed the snake  and he was fine and I was shaken, but fine too -- thanks to my wonderful, loving, strong bravehearted breed !!!!



He was a WONDERFUL DOG and I've had GSDs all my life!  One of our other GSDs saved us from burglers one night while we slept -- we could've all been killed by these drug crazed thugs, but one look at DUTCHESS and they took off !!!



Best Family dogs in the world !!!



Extremely Intelligent, loving, loyal, brave and will give their lives for their families !!!



Excellent with children.



Do buy from a well known breeder -- not a pet shop or an inexperienced person who is just breeding his dog for kicks & is not breeding to better the breed.  Get a book and know what kinds of questions to ask the breeder & you'll be able to weed out the poorly bred dogs from the champion bred pups !!!!!



Source(s):



Life-long experience !!!!
p.s. -- Never buy the bully in a litter & never buy the shy or timid one. Buy the one that shows no fear & is anxious to play and eager to meet you and read up on any breed -- several books, become highly knowledgable !!!!!!



</answer>

<question>



Are police dogs desexed? I want to know if desexing changes behaviour in Male German shepherds?



</question>



<answer from>



sticky lolly
Member since: 06 September 2007
Total points: 1731 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



do u mean neutered?



</answer>



<answer from>



Taboo
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 2247 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes.. It can make them more focused on task at hand and thus less distracted.



However, I believe that it DECREASES thier drive and negatively effects thier workability...were talkin hormones and they are important.



Most K9 or executive protection dogs are NOT altered.



**Rougered...what you are describing is Neurotic, Obsesive Compulsive, and Dominant behaviors...  All of which can be addressed through "working" your working dog...i.e. exercize (on leash run/walks), training (agility, protection, detection, tracking).  Your breed does not do well in a yard left to his own devices...that's why there called "working dogs"...thats why we dont nueter kids with OCD..we know to give them tasks.  If you want a pet..and not a working dog...then YES get them altered!  Question is about Police Dogs



Source(s):



Owner/trainer dogo canario, cane corso, doberman...and other large breeds over the years.



</answer>



<answer from>



RogueRed
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)

<answer>



I own a male German Shepherd and I have to tell you, I wish I had fixed him alot earlier. They are high drive work dogs that need constant attention. My dog became extremely destructive! He rips everything in front of him: plastic and metal bowls (Yes, METAL), rips his chains, breaks apart wood including the fence, ripped apart the bottom of a METAL chain link fence (I saw this with my own eyes, the dog is crazy!), and now he even tries to attack my Saint Bernard. This breed can get out of hand; I highly recommend fixing cause it can prevent all of this.



</answer>

<answer>



That is an interesting question and one I'd never really considered before.



I would assume that they would be desexed as an entire dog could lose their focus if they were to come across a bit*ch in season while working.  It doesn't matter how well trained a dog is, when their is a bi*tch in season on their radar there brains turn to mush.



The other reason why I assume they would be desexed, male and female, is because they don't have a breeding program for police dogs.  There dogs, as far as I know, are sourced from private breeders.



These dogs are sourced from litters of high prey drive parents and they are so well trained that even though they are desexed they don't lose their drive to work.  Their drive does not come from testosterone but from breeding and training.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)

<question from>



Rachii
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 89 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do you know if a breeder is reliable (for cav king charles spaniel).?



I believed that a breeder was really good but i got feedback  from an expert from the puppy i showed them that it was not a full cavvie and that the breeder had lied to me which obviously saved me some money,
please help!



</question>



<answer from>



jan d
Member since: 29 May 2006
Total points: 1484 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ask to see papers or the parent dogs. Ask for vet reports.If she has nothing to hide she will show you these.



</answer>



<answer from>



Taboo
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 2247 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Inspect the kennel...Drop by during business hours.
Ask for references...and actually call them.
Inspect the parents..and other breeding stock
Ask who the vet is...and call them.
Asses health and temperament of sire, dame, and litter.
Inspect pedigree and registration papers carefully
Inspect shot and anti-parasite/bact documentation (get copies)
Inspect sale contract and any guarantees



If you cover your bases you will have legal recourse.



</answer>



<answer from>



Nathan S
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if the breeder is to nice, the pups wont be too good, if she/he is a normal relaxed person and does not look decieving then the pups should be fine



</answer>



<answer from>



suzie
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 1182 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you bought the pup from a reputable breeder it would have registered papers.  Copies of the parents genetic tests.  An extended copy of the parents pedigree.  A full sheet on diet and training.  A guaranteed health certificate from the vet.  Full vaccination certificate.



The breeder would be proud of the pups and happy to support you with any advise and training after the sale.
You would have the breeders phone number, email address and home address.
The breeder would want follow up photographs of your puppy showing major achievements.



The breeder would want to know about your pups genetic tests.  Any showing you attempt and encourage you to show.



The breeder will want to know anything and everything about your puppy because they will want a good reputation and only YOU the new purchaser of their pup can give it to them.



</answer>







<original file>5821.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk119226.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



~~ The Dark Knight ~~
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 5374 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



What i do when my dog doesn't listen when she gets loose outside?



she never listens when she is looose and takes forever to catch, wat should i do to catch her, i tried food and stuff like that, but that doesn't work... and when i catch her, what kind of discipline should i give her?



</question>



<answer from>



Peekablu...
Member since: 03 October 2006
Total points: 9837 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First of all, when you do catch her, do not discipline her.  This will make her afraid to come to you.  Instead, praise her like crazy.  Have a toy in hand to play with her or give her a treat.  The idea is to make it a pleasant experience for her when she comes to you.  If it's unpleasant, she won't want to come.



When she is running loose, don't chase her because she's probably thinking that this is a fun game.  If anything, run away from her & make her chase you.  Kneeling down to her level may make her more likely to come up to you, as well.



If possible, practice these techniques in a closed area.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thx ;)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



anonymou...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 573 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



We had the same problem with our dog (and we still do occasionally).



Here's what worked for us:
1. First and foremost, our dog has become more obedient as he got older.  young dogs (we got ours about 1 1/2 yrs) are less likely to listen, more likely to want to run free.



2. Show the dog a treat and have them sit while you open the door. Our dog will stay in the door for the treat, b/c he knows he'll get to run in a second anyway. The trigger for our dog to go into "rocketdog" mode is when we open the door and he immediately bolts out without a look back. This is just sort of a reminder of who is in charge.
3. We hooked a leash to our dog and let him run around in the field with the leash hanging behind him. I don't know why this worked, but it is probably the thing that helped in our training of him the most. Plus it makes them easier to catch if they do get away. (just make sure to use a non-retractable leash so it doesn't break)
4. Try different types of treats-maybe straight peanut butter- and combine it with tip number three: go to a non-distracting field or something and have two people calling the dog back and forth, and give him a treat each time. The Key: stop and take hold of the dog when he starts to get bored, otherwise he'll run loose and get the idea he can do that. Best to quit when you're ahead.
5. And as other people said, don't yell when she comes back, but praise and give her treats. Yelling will make her think you're angry that she came back, and she will be scared to come back in the future. Praise her for coming back, not punish her for getting away.



I think that's it.  Practice often. Good Luck!



Source(s):



successful experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Poppy•
Member since: 28 January 2008
Total points: 16488 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Discipling wont work--she'll just think she did bad in being allowed to get caught, or for coming to you. It's the wrong message.



You're going to have to work on having her on a leash outside. Lengthen the leash as the days go on, and eventually, attempt at some slow off-leash in-yard training.



Obedience classes wouldn't hurt, either. And teaching her to come when she is called will be a lifesaver. Start with treats AND praise when she comes, then back off the treats slowly; *always* keep with the praise.



</answer>



<answer from>



Leah
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 2027 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>

2.) Or kneel down on your knees in the middle of the yard and call your dogs name that's the dog language for i want to play and she will run over to you



</answer>

<question>



My 14 wk boxer girl has reverted back to urinating in the house?



Minnie the boxer was toilet trained really early, at 8 weeks she would get up and go into the yard without prompting. Now she is 14 weeks, she has decided to start urinating all over her basket and bed linen, the sofa or anywhere she feels like it. What has caused her to revert at this age all of a sudden? </question>



<answer from>



cristone...
Member since: 05 August 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



crate! crate your dog. most important thing ever! if they are allowed to roam and aren't given regular potty breaks they will "go" where they like. and young puppies aren't able to hold it for long anyway.



Source(s):



went through the same with my westie



</answer>



<answer from>



chistine SSS
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 6238 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



It would be best to eliminate any physical problems, have you taken her to the vet and discussed this with them?  If not do this now, just in case it is a bladder/kidney problem.
At the same time, go back to the basics of toilet training, taking her outside every hour, rewarding good behaviour, I am sure you know what to do.
The only other thing I can think about is marking her territory.  It does sound a bit excessive, but if she is marking more alpha objects, like beds, couches as such, you may want to consider marking.  If it happens more on the floor, it sounds like piddles.  Teaching not to mark is similar to toilet training, you have to catch them doing it then you can tell them off.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Can I use my 'for people' organic oatmeal wash on my dog, instead of dog shampoo?



He is a chihuahua, doesn't shed almost at all but has dandruff. I figured oatmeal would be good for that, but could I use mine, or is it necessary to get his own?



</question>



<answer from>



Taboo
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 2249 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes you can.  Most pet shampoos tend to be less alkaline in nature then our shampoo.  Just asses for itchy or dry skin.  A rehydrater or creme rinse will be nessesary to lower the PH after your "human" shampoo. Rehydrater should sit on coat for at least 3-5 minutes before cool rinse.  Leave in conditioners can also be healpful and often provide SPF.



YOu may want to try Neutrogena T-Gel shampoo.  This is an effective treatment for humans and canines.  Get the one with Coal Tar and Sulfer.  This is excellent for occasional use for treatment of seborrhea, dandruff, allergy, bacteria, fungus, and dermatitis of unknown origins.



Keep shampoo out of eyes and ears.



Source(s):



Owner of large mastiff breeds over the years....also a licensed hair stylist and RN.



</answer>



<answer from>



Benedett...
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The best is that you get a dog shampoo that treats his dandruff problem as the dog might not be able to take the contents in human shampoo.



You can also get those pet medicated sprays to treat his dandruff problem. I got a medicated spray for my coming 10 months old Beagle as he has got flakes and it is working quite well and I can see that there is improvement.



</answer>



<answer from>



chistine SSS
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 6238 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs

</answer>



<answer from>



Gabrielle B
Member since: 05 November 2008

Make sure you read the labels....find out whats in the shampoo and do some research.....just because something is organic doesnt mean that it wont cause an alergic reaction.....maybe do a test patch on you dog first....I think that would be better than doing a complete wash with something that could potentially harmful to you dog.....I know my dog has very sensitive skin (as many staffordshire bull terriers do) and its taken me a lot of test patches and research to find what shampoo I cant use on him :)

<answer from>



suzie
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 1188 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Oh gosh, not a dog as a christmas present.  Sheesh the worst time of the year to purchase a pup.  I will not and have never let my dogs breed at this time of the year for this reason specifically.



Before you plunder ahead with your endeavour take a little minute well I hope a few to consider.



Have you asked your wee cuzs if she really wants a puppy.
Have you pre warned her you are looking for this puppy.
Is her home set up to accept this puppy.
If she doesn't really want this puppy are you going to take it in.
Do you know anything about the breed.
Does your cuzs know anything about the breed.
Do you know what you are getting into with this pup and does wee cuzs.



The Beagle is a hunting dog.  It's main endeavour is to hunt.  It's main aim is to escape and hunt.  It needs a fully secure fenced yard.  It requires basic training at the least and some.  It will try to dig it's way out.  It is not the best of breeds for the inexperienced.



How do I know this?  I was going to get one as my next showing dog, but changed my mind as I have just secured my yard for my breed of dog and finally kept them in.  I have chickens and don't want a Beagle using them as practice.



</answer>

<category>

Taboo

</answer from>



<answer>



He has Kyphosis (vertebral compression fractures), which if untreated is debilitating and painfull. Kyphoplasty is a treatment option, though expensive, and you may have to search for  a specialist.



"metastase" is not congruent with a kyphosis diagnosis..so i dont understand this..this is usually associated with cancer..not palliative therapy.



Im assuming that your dog is aged..  In any case, it sounds like you'll be doing your dog a favor by taking his pain away.  Just be sure that you are there to hold him during his final moments..he'll thank you one day.



</answer>

<answer>



dogs are attracted to their own smell, so when you clean up her mess put some of the paper toweling and faeces on the pad, this will encourage her to use it.

<answer from>



simpsons...
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



unless you dont have a garden i wouldnt use them. your given yourself twice as much work, because eventually you will have to train her to go outside



</answer>



<answer from>



Lindsey C
Member since: 22 May 2008
Total points: 2883 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you are home with your dog, take her to the place you want her to go every 30 minutes as well as after she sleeps, plays, and drinks water or eats (if you are planning on eventually training her to go outside, skip the pads and start training her to go outside. Using the pads will make her think it is ok to potty inside). Young puppies have a small bladder, but this gets better over time. Tell her to "go potty" and give her lots of praise and maybe a treat when she does. Be patient, though, she may be a fast learner or it may take a few months before she goes there on her own. Consistency is key. When you catch her going potty where she isn't suppose to, say "bad" in a firm voice, but ONLY if you catch her in the act. If you scold her after, she won't understand why your are mad, even if you put her nose in it like some people might tell you to. Pick her up and put her in the tray and say "go potty". Again, praise her when he does. Dogs have a very short period of time after doing something where they will associate their behavior with a consequence, so the reward or scold must be immediate.



Also, look for signs that she has to potty. Most dogs will sniff around a lot when they have to go.



If she is waking up during the night to go potty, take her to the place you want her to go. Don't give her any water after 7pm either if she is having this problem (don't worry, it isn't cruel and after a few months she should be able to hold it through the night.)



Source(s):



I work at Petco and have a 5 month old puppy that I trained using this method. It worked with my Yorkie too.



</answer>
