<answer from>



toni lovin daryl
Member since: 17 September 2007
Total points: 1803 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



have you ever heard of pets as therapy? this is an organisation where volunteers who have calm well behaved pets (cats, dogs, Guinea pigs etc) take there animals into places such as old folks homes, child homes, hospitals, children's hospitals so the patients can stroke the animals play with the animals and grow a bond with the animals.this cheers the patients up and they look forward to the next visit. Its a great idea and really gets the kids talking in the wards or in the homes.
Hope this helped



Source(s):



animal care student



</answer>



<answer from>



Dogbero
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Their presence, just being there with and for you, perhaps snuggled by your side, is very comforting.  Emotionally, you know that someone is connected to you and you are not alone.  Their love and devotion to their pet parents is really unconditional. They love you and adore you no matter what.  Psychologically, this kind of acceptance can boost our morale and confidence. You get affirmation that you are important, because somebody's life and happiness depends on you.  And you can also depend on them, they can be your friend, your guard, your sight, your assistant.  Gently stroking a dog, in slow, gentle, repetitive and caressing motion, can actually relax you.  Physiologically, this can de-stress you and bring down your blood pressure. Dogs can make you smile, they can make you laugh, they can remind you of the happier times of life.  Interaction with dogs and topics about dogs make people open up and communicate their feelings.  Owning a dog, taking care of a dog or simply being in the company of a dog, can really be very therapeutic. They teach you responsibility while you're having fun.



</answer>



<answer from>



Taboo
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 2251 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tactile Sensory
Motor function
Emotional Connectivity
Mental stimulation
Memories from better times.
Physical Presence
Dogs provide a nuetral, non-judgemental outlet, which patients can connect with physically, mentally, and emotionally encouraging increased motor function, as well as, mental and emotional stimuli.



</answer>

<question>



Small dogs...what's the best breed for children?



I have children under the age of 8 and want to adopt another dog. We have a large breed dog already (Shepherd mix) who is great, but he's too big to sit with us on the couch & cuddle, etc....we give him tons of attention though!! Does anyone have a good recommendation as to which small breeds are good with kids? A medium sized breed would be ok too, just not huge. I've been reading about different breeds and I have a headache now because of all the information!! You can't judge a live creature solely by their "general description" so I'm asking for experiences with your own dogs or those of family/friends.



I've already ruled out Yorkies, Frenchies and some of the "yappy" breeds. In order to keep this brief, I won't go into details about that. I'm still looking into Chihuahuas, as they are the easiest to find & so cute. However, I hear they can be difficult to house train & snappy w/ kids.



Any helpful advice is welcome & have a great day!! Thanks :)



</question>



<additional details>



I want to respond to a couple people, even if they don't read this! We had a Yorkie & it was too fragile & tiny. I didn't say I wanted a toy breed, there's a difference between toy & small. The Yorkie went to a loving home where the woman LOVED the breed & had experience.



Secondly, I would never adopt a dog simply to cuddle or hold. I realize it's a dog. Honeslty, I think sometimes people don't think before they answer on here...it's just a place to speak your opinions freely. Please do not assume things by taking my words out of context. Thank you!! Sorry to be so candid, but it gets kinda old.



</additional details>

<answer>



OK One thing I want to know is why you ruled out Yorkies. We got one about two months ago and she is the most loving non yapping dog you could ever meet. Yappy is just a Stereo type. That doesn't mean that most of them are. Chihuahuas are not good with more than one person. They bond to one person and one person only. Most of them are yappy and nippy( I've been bit quite a lot). Have you ever wondered why there are so many Chihuahuas in the pound??? I would at least give yorkies a chance. Mine always wants to cuddle and only yaps when she is unsure about a person(Not every stranger as you would think, only select people). <answer from>



Kate M
Member since: 04 November 2007
Total points: 4358 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Small kids and small dogs do not generally get along. Most toy breeds can be snappy and do not like the roughness of small/young children. You do better to look for a dog at least 15lbs or bigger. You probably don't want anything too delicate. Some breeds can break bones jumping off the couch or if they are put down too rough. You will also want a dog that can handle living with a bigger dog.



Some breeds to consider are miniature poodle (not toy) or Bichon Frise.



You should go to you local shelter and see if they have anything that interests you. Looking on the website can be a big help. Remember to bring you whole family and you current dog.



Remember that small dogs still need to be treated like a dog. They need to be trained, disciplined, walked, groomed, and taken care of. They should not be cuddled all the time or bought just to cuddle. They are dogs, and need to be treated like a dog. If you aren't going to do something to you big dog, don't do it to the little dog and vice versa.



</answer>

<question>



Can dogs be fed with only dried food and water?



</question>



<answer from>



Talina W
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 175 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i dont see why not



</answer>



<answer from>



Janet R
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 1260 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



No you can feed them other things. Just not HUMAN CHOCOLATE it causes blockages in the bowels & other nasty problems. My Whippets have dry dog food mixed with warm water if they are cold makes food swell & fills their little tummies better or with gravy. They also have things like weetabix (for poorly tummy or to hide medicine that they will not take willingly). My bitches drink tea with milk & if they are lucky & we have visitors sugar too.  I personally would not give either of my dogs tinned dog food it makes their tummies bad.



</answer>



<answer from>



panache
Member since: 11 February 2006
Total points: 18702 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



A good quality dry food has complete nutrition so a dog can be healthy on it only with water



</answer>



<answer from>



Dogbero
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dried dog food and water only, no problem.  That's the most basic and easiest thing to maintain.  But you can also give them treats, like doggie biscuits, and rawhide chewbones which they can chew to their hearts' delight, or tid bits of cheese and other treats.  Just be careful not to give them any of the foods in the list of harmful foods for dogs, which you can find in the following link.



http://www.ukcdogs.com/WebSite.nsf/WebPa...



Source(s):



http://www.ukcdogs.com/WebSite.nsf/WebPa...



</answer>



<answer from>



Kayleigh P
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes you can feed them with dried dog food and water but you might want to either give them a good quality dried food with loads of vitamins or give them chew sticks that are full of vitamins and they help keep the teeth healthy. (solid chews) !



Source(s):



Me ! x



</answer>



<answer from>



galliano...
Member since: 18 December 2005
Total points: 9580 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I feed all my dogs a high quality dry dog food only and provide clean cool water at all times.  I do caution against feeding or giving dogs rawhide.  There are no regulations on quality, and many rawhide treats have chemicals in them that whiten the hide.  They also tend to cause obstruction and gastritis. I do not give my dogs any rawhide.  Pig ears or hooves are better choices although in large amounts they can cause diarrhea due to the high fat content and so should be fed sparingly.



Source(s):



Owner/trainer of dogs



</answer>



<answer from>



Flick
Member since: 05 May 2008
Total points: 262 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes. It is recommmended that dogs only be fed on dry food and water. If it is a good quality dry food (not from Supermarkets) Hills euka and royal canin are three very good brands to have you dog on. They have designed some brands for specific breeds eg **** tzu is a Dental and digest as they dont have the best teeth. Labs are on a weight controled....Best to ask your vet they will recommend the right one for u



XX FLICK

Vet receptionist

<answer from>



matt matt

</answer from>



<answer>



Your question can be taken 2 ways so apply the following:
Take 1: As a puppy the dog will require soft food (water'd down with hot water and allowed to cool) purely until they can digest harder foods and have the teeth to chew it.



Once older than 3 months you can begin safely reducing the amount of water you add to their food until around 5 months when it can be totally dry food. Always leave a bowl of fresh water down for your dog, if your out for any period of time and the dog will be left alone try buying a water despencer it just keeps the water fresher for your dog.
Take 2: Dogs can eat anything except coco based products. we've fed our dog her food (Beta) since day one, around the 3 month mark we started introducing other things into her bowl, scraps of cooked meat, cheese, veg, cerial anything she looked like she fancied we put in her bowl (but only into a meal not other times as she would accociate begging with getting and thats a road you dont want to go down if you ever want to eat in peace).



Hope that helps.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Pure breed dog or Mixed breed dog?



I want to get a labrador, but can't choose between a pure labrador breed and a labrador/golden retriever mix. Somebody told me it's better to get a mixed breed dog.



</question>



<additional details>



I'm adopting a dog from a dog rescue organisation... not from a pet store!



</additional details>



<answer from>



coax_me_...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 2435 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



From my experience mixed dogs tend to have less health issues than purebred, although some illness's prone to the breed do carry through to mixed dogs. It's really a matter of which you would rather, If you know you want a lab or a lab mix find breeders in your area and talk to them and get a feel for it. You may find one breeder makes you feel more comfortable than the other, or has a better plan when dealing with issues after you bring your puppy home. Just talk it over thoroughly with the breeders and the members of your family and make whichever decision seems would work best for you.



Read the reply below mine and wanted to mention that purebreds are actually more prone to genetic disease, since you have 2 completely different sets of genes mixing together in a mix breed your pup has a 50/50 chance of missing a genetic disorder whereas if it was the same breed and they both had that gene your dog would absolutely 100% get it sicne it would be a dominate gene.



</answer>



<answer from>



KuroSagi
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 287 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pure breeds are definitely better. They have a predictable outcome as in size, weight, colour etc and they are probably less likely to get genetic disorders, which are costly to treat in the long run. Plus if you get it from a good breeder, they're not as expensive as some really outrageous 'designer pups'.



</answer>



<answer from>



Karens BCS
Member since: 24 October 2006
Total points: 6465 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It doesnt really matter
If your getting the Pure lab just make sure your going to accredited breeder, if your getting a mix try your best to adopt from a shelter.
Dont feed the BYB.



</answer>



<answer from>



aries33
Member since: 06 January 2007
Total points: 799 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would buy a pure bred dog.. but honestly it doesnt matter whether its a pure-breed or a mixed... all that really matters is the relationship that u have with each other!!! Trust me.. Breed does not matter AT ALL!!!
But if your looking for a slightly cheaper dog then u should buy a mixed breed as they are much cheaper! But as i said before u should get a dog according to its personality and not breed or quality!!



Source(s):



My own experience



</answer>



<answer from>



babycak...
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 428 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

If you go to a breeder, make sure they are legit. Most breeders wont hand over papers until you show that they have been fixed. If you get a mixed one, dont get the "designer" pups from the puppy mills, pls go to a shelter & save a life. No pet stores pls!!!!! Best of luck on your new addition!!!

<question>



Is this a rottie or a doberman?



Hi, I got this pup from dog kennels who said she is a rottie and arond 3 months old. I already have a rottie and think the pup is slightly older than 3 months. I also think she resembles a doberman. She has a long nose and is very thin (she was neglected before we got her). She was found in Ireland as a stray and got brought to Scotland as she was going to be put to sleep. Wondering if anyone could tell me if she's a rottie or a doberman. I already know u can get a test done at vets. I can email u a pic if it helps. Dont know how to add pics on this.

<answer>

by the description youve give it sounds like a doberman.....rotties have very broad heads :)



</answer>



<answer from>



coax_me_...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 2435 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Since she was a stray the age is probably just a guess. She could be mixed or she could also be poorly bred. A properly bred rottie is stalky and has a bulky head, those 2 traits which are very desirable in a rottie are also sadly one of the first things to be lost in poor breeding, which could have been what lead to her being abandoned. It takes a very long time to get a proper bloodline that produces a ideal looking dog, when people are not focused on breeding the best of the best sadly it shows greatly in the dogs, sometimes the traits lost and gained almost make the dogs look sickly or muttish. Once she's a bit older if you find she's still very thin looking you can try bulking her up with extra protine and working her muscles harder(lots of running jumping and climbing if possible).



</answer>



<answer from>



Glamour.
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)

<question>



Dogs papers for Bichon Frise?



I have two bichon frise who are both pure breed but the problem is tht the people that we bought the ***** off of werent able to give papers but the male has papers. I’m a breeder and I wish to try and provide some papers for the puppies. Is anyone able to help me by saying where I might be able to do this?



</question>



<answer from>



Gabrielle B
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Without the papers of the female you cant get papers for the pups. You may be able to get replicated papers, but you would need to get back into contact with the original owner of the dog (or whoevers name will be on the papers) so that a name transfer can be made.....but to me it sounds like they were just telling you it had papers so that you would by it....a responsible owner wouldnt let paperwork like that go missing...i know i keep my dogs papers safe all the time.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr. P's Person
Member since: 29 April 2007
Total points: 23099 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only papers worth giving with any pup are AKC. The female is not AKC registered so you won't be able to get them. I'm sure that's why her breeder was "not able to give them to you."She is no doubt badly bred by a BYB who did not care about papers health testing etc. That makes her non breeding Quality. You should have her spayed and if you really want to breed do it the right way. Find an AKC registered pup. Put her through her conformation then the health/genetic testing at 2. Then and only then if she passes everything well should you think of breeding her. The health/genetic and conformation of course applies to your male too.



</answer>



<answer from>



suzie
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 1192 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends what country you live in.  In Australia papers are given when the pups are born.  You have 3 months to register them.  Both parents have to have papers and the owner of the B and D have to have signed the papers at the mating date.



You cannot get papers for a dog after 3 months of age without extreme exception which is up to the discretion of the vca.



All breeding stock must have all genetic tests done.  You must also have a breeders prefix and pass an exam if you intend to breed.



Source(s):



www.dogsvictoria.org.au



</answer>



<answer from>



patricia...
Member since: 24 May 2007
Total points: 4231 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



If you just wants papers you can go through  CKC (Continental Kennel CLub),APR or APRI or any number  of pet registries.These are just pet registries .



Source(s):



20+ yr dog breeder(I use AKC)



</answer>

<question>



How long after my dog gives birth can i give her a bath?



also when she is done do i let her away from her babies and let her out side? when she is donw will she stop panting? it my first time i adopted her she ended up commin to us pregnant



</question>



<answer from>



biscuit
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 1758 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



just let her be she will let you know when she needs space just make sure she has plenty of food and water and space to clean her pups and let her out  side when she is ready



</answer>



<answer from>



Gabrielle B
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dont wash her straight away....residues of the shampoo may be left on the fur and the pups could end up ingesting it (not good!) The best thing to do is to prepare an area for your dog to give birth and allow her to adjust the bed as she wants (nesting) ....keep the light levels low....and when she is giving birth make sure there is at most 2 people in the room at the same time (dont let the dog get stressed). It is also important to advise you vet that your dog is about to give birth (so that they are on standby if there are any emergancies). Emerse yourself in as much info as possible so that you are ready for anything....cos anything could happen!



</answer>



<answer from>



Olliee W
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ideally leave her too it as instincts are amazing in animals... Also unless u really can't bear her smell don't bath her as the pups, if still haven't opened their eyes will rely on their mothers smell for comfort and even guidance on where she is... The mum will clean herself, the pups and the area so no  worries there ;) But is she still giving birth now? If so then the panting is expected yet if she remains in labour and not producing a pup for over an hour then get her to a vet ASAP!



</answer>



<answer from>



petunia1...
Member since: 18 September 2006
Total points: 4596 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any legitamate kennel would not've sent her to you pregnant !!!  I don't know where you got her or if you let her get pregnant & aren't admitting it. Either way, it's done now.  You do not worry about bathing her at this time for goodness sake -- she's worn out, that's why she's panting.  She should be taken to a vet as soon as she's done giving birth!  call a vet and get advise this morning.  Call PetSmart they have vet clinics in most stores which are very reasonablly priced !!!  They will tell you how to check her and when to bring her in and the pups.



Usually she will know when she's done and she will then get up and leave the pups to go pee or poop and she will need plenty of water and she may also be hungry !!!  I was starving after I had my son ! But just have food & water available and allow her free access to go to the toilet !!!!



CALL



PETSMART  this MORNING !!!!



I believe they open at 8am or 9am  and have centers in most areas !!!!  If not ask neighbors about a good vet b4 they go to work today !!!!!



Then have her spayed as soon as the doctor says it's ok as she will go into heat in about 2-months from now !!!!! And you do not want more hard to place pups that may have to be put to death on your conscience I hope !!!!

BREEDER of GERMAN SHEPHERDS



</answer>



<answer from>



coax_me_...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 2435 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If she's a good mom she'll let you know when the pups are good and it's time for her to go outside. As for the bath, She'll be pretty tired and might not want you around much, or like being touched and a bath might be too much, wash her with a cloth and warm water with a small amount of soap in it for now and give her a couple days to rest and care for the pups before trying to give her a full bath if you can. She might pant for awhile depending on how long the labour was and how tired she is after it, but yes she will stop. Try to keep her around the pups if you can, especially at night, if she's used to sleeping somewhere else she might try to move them. My moms woken up with puppies tucked into bed with her before because her dog was used to sleeping on her bed.



</answer>



<answer from>



suzie
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 1192 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can let her outside before she is done, just keep a careful eye on her and make sure she is not pushing at the time you do.  In fact they need to go outside between puppies, labour can go on for quite a few hours, she will need to relieve herself.  If you are not confident then put her on a lead, take her for a walk.



The washing, no, leave her be.  She will not want much time away from the pups, it can actually unsettle her and she may reject them.  She will clean herself up enough.



While she is in labour, give her some milk halved with warm water and some sugar dissolved in it about a teaspoon full, it will give her some extra energy and she will lap it up.  Put the bowl near her, she may not get up to go to it.  Hold it in your hand and offer it under her chin, give her a minute to realize what you are offering.



Yes when she is done she should stop panting.  But then some stop panting and they are not done.  You will only tell if she settles with the puppies to feed them.  Personally I have taken my B's to the vets after having pups for a general check up, they give an injection to expell any kept placentas and make sure she is all ok.



Wanted to add.  If you let the pups suckle inbetween her deliveries the pups produce oxytocin(hormone that causes contractions) in her and help her deliver the next puppy.  Remove the pups as she is delivering the next one, then put them back.  You can keep them warm in a box with a hot water bottle covered with a towel.  They will be fine for 15 or so minutes as she stands up pushing to deliver her puppy.



Petunia...WOW!!!  wooahh.  Regardless of the reasons for the situation, it is what it is.  Help, don't criticize at this point.
I have had kids myself.  I have also bred dogs. There is no comparison.  You breed dogs..hmmm.  Do you show them???  oh the dog won't go into heat in 2 months btw.



For the owner of this dog, yes, please spay her after this.  It is the responsible thing and best thing you can do for your dog.



</answer>



<answer from>



xx Hellen xx
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If your dog has had pups before than you can wash her bout an hour after the pups are all born, by then she'll hv them cleaned and feed.



If its your dogs first time then wait till morning and wash her then because she'll want to be with the pups and keep them safe. Also ensure that she is fully dryed to prevent the pups getting wet and caughting a cold because that could be a real danger to new pups.



yes let your dog away from her pups, she doesnt need much help from you now she knows what to do by nature, she will leav the pups for a very short time to eat or drink or go out for the toilet. If you take her out a walk she WILL pull to get home to the pups but you can take her for a walk after about 3/4 days so shes happy with the pups but dont be out longer than 20 minutes or she will worry. But dry her when you get home and when she comes in from outside to make sure she doesnt have any bugs or durt on her tets.



when shes done she'll probly pant for a wee while and clean the pups to make sure they are breathing alright.



Source(s):



breeder, 6 litters xx



</answer>



<answer from>



love my goldens
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 1166 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Congrats!
Do not give her a bath!  Yes, she will be a mess for a bit, however, one of the biggest dangers on puppies is for them to get cold.
If you bathe momma, the pups will get damp laying up against her.  You can't blow dry her, as she will not want to leave the pups alone that long.
When you are sure that she is done birthing, try to coax her to go to the bathroom.  She may not do this for a few hours though, not wanting to leave her babies.
If she is still panting hard, she probably is not done yet.  When she is finished giving birth, she should settle down for a nap.
Offer her plenty of water, even if you need to hold the bowl over to her for a few minutes.
Make sure her food and water is close to her box, so she can eat and drink without having to be far away from her pups.
She may not eat for quite awhile, even a day, if she ate the placenta's.



Source(s):



My Profile



</answer>

Shelters or rescues. Any cheap(under 500) purebred puppy has come from a mill or a backyard breeder, you will end up with a dog who probably has health problems or is not socialized properly. Hey,

<category>

</category>



<question from>



Agility ganna b a 6/7
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 86 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dog agility, the contacts. I'm really stuck! ! !?



My little dog is quite quick and powerful, ie a big stride. Everything else is OK but the contacts are terrible! Not his fault tho!



He is only toy motivated so teaching contacts is made harder, with food he doesn't bother as much!



Any methods that you can suggest that would work, running might not work as he cant be told he is doing wrong, he simply shuts down and it makes him turned off agility very easily, any ideas please help!!!



</question>



<answer from>



vegachan...
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



How are you using food incentives? When we were training our Huskies and German Shepards, we would use sliced vegan cheese for the contacts. We'd put the cheese where they would need to stop at or to go to. They'll have to pause to get it off the area, so it helps for stopping, like on the teeter-totter. I don't know what to tell you if it doesn't work. All my dogs are cheese-addicts and will do anything for a slice. lol. Good luck!



Source(s):



Seasoned breeder



</answer>



<answer from>



Linda_Do...
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 5084 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



History



Mythology & Folklore



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Back-chaining with a clicker.  I'd actually not train the contact on the DW or A-frame but start on a plank or a contract trainer.  Are you going for running contacts or 2on2off??  If you have a truly little dog - you might consider training 2o2o on the DW but having running contacts on the A-Frame.  Just taking in consideration of the strain on its' back.



Train a touch to a target plate w/clicker.  Then move the target plate to the end of the "contact zone" (plank or c-trainer).  You dog must walk over the plank and hit the zone correctly and touch the plate.  Repeat, repeat, repeat!!  I'm talking weeks if not months here!!  So, if your dog shuts down at the thought of multiple repetitions (as if he thinks that he's not doing the exercise correctly) - be sure to do just a few or go from doing 2-3 attempts and then move on to another type of agility skill.  Break it up to keep your dog excited!!



See the youtube video - it's a nice little intro



Source(s):



http://www.dogpatch.org/agility/FAQs/faq...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uYrZ6On41...



</answer>



<answer from>



Karens BCS
Member since: 24 October 2006
Total points: 6256 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ive also got a fast dog that was always flying of the contacts,she too doesnt care for food as treats.
So i put her back on the lead & took her over the contacts making her wait at the end then standing infront of her with a ball then letting her catch the ball while still on the contact,
Then we moved on to she didnt get the ball till she has waited on the contact & i gave her the release command.
Im still learning at agility but hope ive helped a little.
Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13484 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



For hitting the contacts you need to establish CONTROL.  Slow him down to start with.  Use "STEADY" a LOT.  Hold your hand in front of his nose to halt him on the contacts.



Don't ever tell him he's doing something -wrong- only effusively praise him when he's doing something -right-. The NO should only be used when he's heading in totally the wrong direction.  Some dogs do totally shut down when the think they've been told that what they are doing is wrong, the trick is to guide them in the -right- direction.



For now, just slow everything down a little, get the control, get the voice control and then speed up.



It's difficult to do, and they do so enjoy the game, but it will eventually come.



Dogs -can- see the contacts, eventually they learn the trick of flicking at least one paw on the contact in passing...



Source(s):



Competed with a Papillon for 4 years.  He adored the game!



</answer>

<question from>



Leo
Member since: 09 September 2007
Total points: 6541 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



To those who've had to put your dogs to sleep, how long did it take to have peace about your decision?



My 18yo golden lab was put to sleep at 5pm yesterday. I was so distraught crying, and soon after passed out and took a long nap. I woke up a few moments ago, and now I'm back to crying and second guessing everything. Was it the right time, decision, did I do the right thing, and so on. She had cancer, had stopped eating, and could barely walk.



I know it just happened, but with all of my might, I would at least like to have peace with the fact that I did the right thing.



My biggest comfort right now, other than my husband, is my AmStaff who has not left my side since I came back. He's so sweet. Whenever I start to cry, he's quick to come and lick my face, and sit with me as I cry.



I know grief is different for everyone, but what are some things I could do to help me though this difficult time.



</question>



<answer from>



I love my mutt
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 2395 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Aww you poor thing.
You did the right thing, your dog lived a long life. My puppy didn't make it too her first birthday. (She attacked someone, so we had to put her down since she wouldn't let anyone on the property and would growl if anyone went near her and yeah, it was the drunk guys fault! you don't do head lock things with dogs!! Idiot) I still miss my puppy and it's been like 4 years :(
Your other dog seems to be doing a good job :) and taking care of you well. You'll soon feel better and realize you made the best choice, but the pain of losing someone will never go. :(
Counseling. No kidding, talking helps. and to a complete stranger why not? You may find some other hidden emotions..



</answer>



<answer from>



Owned by Rocco the staffy.
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 4721 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



You could try taking Rescue Remedy.



Is is for grief, loss, pain etc.



It is available from health shops and pharmacies.



An acute dose would be 4 drops every 15 minutes for 1 hour, then either take as needed or 4 times a day.



What a long life your golden had! 18 years is good going.



It is never easy saying goodbye to a pet. The grief is so hard to go through that it makes you doubt your decision and think maybe there could have been more time.



But the timing was right and she is at peace. You know that.



Allow yourself to grieve. It will get a little easier, get a little harder, then get a little easier again. It will take some time.



Rocco and I send you lots of love. I bet she is smiling over you thinking what a wonderful life she had.



XXXXX



</answer>



<answer from>



emilyj85
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 556 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know what you are going through must be tough, I have been there myself, it is good to let your emotions out and cry about it, I am the opposite, I find it hard to cry, my grieving process takes a lot longer,your dog will be thankful that he is no longer in pain or discomfort, it is a hard decion to make and it almost feels like you are 'playing god' he was 18 which is a fantastic age, he had a good life also and a mommy that obviously cared for him, you have proved that by ending his suffering,take a few days off work, if sleeping is the best way your body can cope, then do it,each day will get easier, you will stop questioning your decision and start thinking of the good times instead, look at photos if it helps and talk about it, yur husband is going through the same thing so talk to him about it, grief hits us hard and affects everyone differently, there is no right or wrong way to grieve and no time limit either.  The vet would not of put him to sleep if he didnt think that you were doing the right thing.  Walk where you used to walk and smile about his life, I totally sympathise with you and i could cry for you, please dont punish yourself and take one day at a time, xxxxx



</answer>

<answer>



letting go is always hard to deal with even when it is the right time to do so..when i had to put my girl down almost 3 yrs ago i hated myself as she was only 8 yrs old but i knew in my heart that she was suffering..i chose to do it because it was cancer and i knew there wasnt anything i could really do..your dog was 18 yrs old so yes it was the best thing..cancer is a nasty thing for everyone and anything..I cryed for days, i even still now catch myself grieving over her, but the one thing i have learned was when i feel that way i think of all the joy she did bring to me and my family..i look at all the aspect of the life she had and what she did and realize that what i did was the right thing reguardless of how bad i felt..I even had to put my other dog down about 7 yrs ago, he was my dog but stayed with my mom as she was the one who bought him when i was still young..he was 15 and suffered from strokes and epalepsy..the day befor i put him down he had a really bad stroke and the vet said he will not recover from it..my mother refused to put him down as she didnt want to loose a best friend, i talked to her and made her realize that she wouldnt want to live in pain till she died, he really couldnt move and looked as if he was hurting so bad..i made the dission for her as i couldnt sit here and watch my friend lay there in so much pain..it took her a long time to forget about him but she finally realized it was for the best..
we all have to make horrible disissions once in our life but most of the time it is for the best..we all also react differently and morn differently, but the one thing we all can say is we wouldnt want to live suffering in pain untill we die..death is a horrible thing but sometimes it is for the best..your beloved pet is waiting for u at rainbow bridge and is now romping arround with no pain or suffering..dont second guess yourself, it will only hurt u more, know that what u did made him a happy dog knowing that u cared enought not to let him die in pain..



also when you other dog comforts you, comfort him as well..dogs know when we are in pain and it is a wonderfull feeling to have a dog love u that much to be there for u through this painfull time..
i hope i helped alittle.

<answer from>



hopeless...

<answer>



18 years is a long time to be together and in your heart you know you made the right decision for your dog, but it is still a hard decision to make.  There are really no words to help you through this sad time and when I have been through this with much loved pets, the strangest thing was that even though I knew they were no longer with me, I expected them to greet me when I came home and cried every time I came home from work for about 2 weeks.  It is a natural part of the grieving/healing process and please remember that you given the best gift you could to your friend - She is no longer in pain and unhappy.



This poem is always makes me cry with a mixture of sadness and hope.



RAINBOW BRIDGE



Just this side of heaven is a place called Rainbow Bridge.



When an animal dies that has been especially close to someone here, that pet goes to Rainbow Bridge. There are meadows and hills for all of our special friends so they can run and play together. There is plenty of food, water and sunshine, and our friends are warm and comfortable.



All the animals who had been ill and old are restored to health and vigor. Those who were hurt or maimed are made whole and strong again, just as we remember them in our dreams of days and times gone by. The animals are happy and content, except for one small thing; they each miss someone very special to them, who had to be left behind.



They all run and play together, but the day comes when one suddenly stops and looks into the distance. His bright eyes are intent. His eager body quivers. Suddenly he begins to run from the group, flying over the green grass, his legs carrying him faster and faster.



You have been spotted, and when you and your special friend finally meet, you cling together in joyous reunion, never to be parted again. The happy kisses rain upon your face; your hands again caress the beloved head, and you look once more into the trusting eyes of your pet, so long gone from your life but never absent from your heart.



Then you cross Rainbow Bridge together....



Source(s):



This poem is found on many websites, but here are a few.



http://www.rainbowsbridge.com/Poem.htm



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainbow_Bri...



</answer>



<answer from>



LifeHapp...
Member since: 31 May 2007
Total points: 6536 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know that we ever really get over being without a loved pet,we can only take solace in knowing we did the correct thing unselfishly for them.



My best friend closed her eyes last night,her head was in my hands.
The doctor said she was in pain,and it was hard for her to stand



The thoughts that scurried through my head as I cradled her in my arms



were of her younger puppy years and her oh so many charms.



Today there was no gentle nudge with an intense 'I love you gaze'.
Only a heart that's filled with tears,remembering our joy filled days.



But an Angel just appeared to me and he said"You should cry no more"
God loves our canine friends...He installed a doggy door.



Source(s):



Author unknown



</answer>

Answer mine pretty please with a cherry on top :)



http://uk.answers.yahoo.com/question/ind...



</answer>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13484 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



A dog will only do well at Agility if the -whole- game is fun for it.



If he has lost confidence in one or more obstacles, then you have to go back to basics until whichever element is causing the problem becomes FUN again.



Take it slowly, dredge up vast resources of patience, and soon enough you will both be charging round the courses again.



Remember praise, praise praise and occasionally offer food/toy (whatever gets his attention) as a reward. He's -brilliant-, always, no matter how he did, let him know that he's done a fantastic job.



Source(s):



Competed with a Papillon for 4 years. He adored the game!



</answer>



<answer from>



Vi...
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think dogs just loose confidence. There had to be something to cause it... Maybe you lost confidence and maybe you are less enthusiastic about agility? Or maybe you are giving him something bad to eat? There has to be something.



</answer>



<answer from>



wiz34bas...
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 607 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



As has been said there is normally a reason for this, how old is the dog, could it be its getting to much for him, is he healthy, any minor problems can effect there ability, check for any sign of discomfort during normal movement and when training, has anything happened on one piece of equipment that has scared him,  If needs be go back a step, lower the jumps make it more fun, sometimes if you get to carried away it can affect the dogs and it stops being as much fun for them.
Remember at all times Agility is fun.



Source(s):



10 years compeating
Agility trainer



</answer>

<question>



I am very sad. My pup get stolen. How can i get him back?



It had been only 5 days since i get a 9 week old male akita. He was very gentle and sweet. I went to grocery store, but forget to pull up the windows of my car.



The akita pup was laying on the seat.  I just had to pick up my prescription from the pharmacy. I returned back in 7 minutes. But to my horror, the akita pup was no longer on the seat.



Since then I have been very depressed. I feel lot of pain and hurt.  I don't even understand how to get him back.



What can I do to find him now?



</question>



<answer from>



grendagi...
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 874 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am not sure where you purchased the pup, but all dogs are not micro chipped.  If you purchased him from a pet store or breeder you should be able to go back to that person and let them know that your pup has been stolen.  They will tell you the process for getting your dog back.



Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Maarlee....
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Awww akita's are too cute.



Well mabey you could go to the police and report the dog missing and you could also pin up flyers around the area he got stolen from.



</answer>



<answer from>



sillywhi...
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 476 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to vent the windows when you leave a dog in the car, but not far enough down that they could get out.  Your pet may have jumped out, but you are right, someone probably stole him.  I'm so sorry.



Contact the local dog pound. Look in the phone book under government agencies (county or city government) animal control. Leave a report with them.



Offer a reward. Use Craig's list to post a notice.  Print up missing dog notices to post on utility poles and community bulletin boards.  Search the neighborhood where you lost him door to door. Put an ad in the local newspaper under lost and found.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mostwant...
Member since: 27 September 2007
Total points: 2128 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hey.. sorry to hear about your pup.



Have you tried to make an announcement nearby the location you lost your pup? Or have you tried to contact anyone who might had seen your pupu gone or taken by someone else?



The best is to keep looking in the area where you lost your pup. Don't give up on putting an add on newspapers or location where you lost it.



I suggest you find another pup if it doesn't succeed.



Best of luck,



Hang in there.



</answer>



<answer from>



Brady
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 1010 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Contact the animal shelter in case he jumped out of the car and got lost. Give them a description of the puppy or a photo if you have one. Tell them the color of the collar it was wearing if it had one and any tags it had on the collar. See if they give rewards to people who report stealing of dogs. The Humane Society of Utah was offering a reward for the beating of a dog whose owners' home was burgalarized and there were two teenagers who got arrested.



Also tell the police if you think he got stolen and give a description of it or show them a photo, etc. just like I mentioned. Stealing a dog is a crime.



Also see if the store has a video camera facing the area the pup was gone. If you don't see one tell a manager or supervisor of the store what happened and ask if they have a hidden video camera in the area of the parking lot it was stolen.



</answer>



<answer from>



girlnext...
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 298 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Find out if there are any camera's for the store or street. It doesn't sound like he's microchipped since you only had him for 5 days and didn't mention it. Even if he was, if whoever took him was planning on keeping him for themselves, it might not matter. I would post up signs with pictures along with the story around the area that he was stolen from (make and model of car stolen from, date, time, location, etc.) so that someone could contact you even if they just saw something. Just finding out the make and model of the car that this thief got into with the puppy is a step forward. The sooner, the better. I would offer a reward. If you don't have much to give, then don't list the amount of the reward, just that there is one in big letters at the top of the paper.
Call the police, because if you do somehow figure out where he is, you can't just take him back, you need to be able to prove that he was stolen and that he's yours.
Check the local papers for a puppy for sale that matches the description of yours. I just had a friend that bought a puppy from the front of a local grocery store and brought it home to find out that he had just purchased his neighbors stolen dog!



If you do call the police, they can check your car for fingerprints and run them through the database, you never know if they will come up with something. Or if you do find out where he is, they can check that persons prints against what was found on the car. You may think that they won't do much to help you, but this is theft and they have to try to help you. It won't cost you anything so I would try it.
Your best bet is to put up as many fliers as possible, talk to the manager of the store you went into, put something in your local paper about it as well as anything online that is for your area.



Next time you get a dog, microchip him right away. You should take any puppy you get to the vet within 24 hours of the purchase anyways to make sure it's clear of any major health issues, so you can do it then. I probably don't even have to tell you not to leave a dog in the car like that anymore.



Your story has made me think about my behavior, as I have left my puppy in the car while I run into Starbucks. All it takes is a few seconds and a bad person.



I'm really sorry that this happened to you though. I can't even imagine. I wish you the best of luck and the safe return of your puppy!



</answer>

<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 274 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are lots of medication available to battle a flea infestation but you have to consider that your battle will not be won overnight. In most cases, it will take at least three to four weeks to completely rid your dog of fleas, and you will need to stick it out if you want your treatments to be effective. Please visit the following link to a better understanding, treatment and recommendations.



http://dogtime.com/flea-control.html
http://dogtime.com/flea-control-tips-aah...



Hope it helps! Good Luck!



</answer>

It was so sad. My sister says that they never get fed, and that the workers never pay attention to them. So my brother and I grabbed a can of fishfood from the shelf, and when no one was around, we poured some in one fish tank. All the fish were going crazy, like they had never eaten before. They were almost jumping out of the tank, and fighting each other for the food. We have had fish before, and this isnt a normal reaction. So we poured some food in every tank. We wanted them to be fed. We felt really good about it. We knew that we had helped those poor fishies. Dont you think its horrible that animals in big pet stores never get fed? The young, clue-less employees dont even seem to care!

<answer from>



ozzy59
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 3854 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's not true.



They only feed the fish once daily and it's for their own welfare that they only get that.



You have to realize that fish pee and poop just like every other pet does. But they have to live in it. the more they're fed the more pee and poop they live in. The tanks would have to be cleaned too often if they fed them more which also is not healthy for the fish.



Fish sold in department stores are very young and are easily stressed so a stable environment is absolutely necessary to ensure healthy fish get sold. I know you thought you were doing a good deed but you did a bad thing feeding these fish.



</answer>

<question>



What's a good gift to give a veterinarian?



My puppy recently broke his leg :( The emergency vet that I took him to in the middle of the night was so amazing and caring. She really went the extra mile to try to re-set the leg, put a cast on and gave me a list of vets that I could go to the following day. Not to mention that she had to deal with me (in tears almost the entire time) asking tons of questions.



She was unsuccessful with re-setting his leg even though she tried for a very long time. It certainly wasn't for lack of care or effort. She clearly felt really bad about it.
I would love to send her a care package thanking her for taking such good care of my pup and I. What's some good stuff to send a vet besides a card thanking her for her services?



P.S. My puppy is doing well. After visiting many other vets, we opted out of surgery because he is so young and tiny (under 4 pounds)that risking his life with anesthesia just isn't worth it (they gave him a 25% chance of not making it) So he has a cast and pain medication which is making him feel much better. We will re-asses the situation once he is at least a year old if it doesn't heal well and is causing him discomfort in any way. I am told that the leg can be re-broken and repaired with surgery if need be.



</question>

<answer>



As a vet technician, I can vouch that any sort of food gift is never amiss within a clinic.



However, if you want to be more specific for the Vet who showed you so much care and concern go with a World's Best Vet coffee mug. Or any type of animal themed coffee mug. Most of them love things like that.



Thanks for taking time to express your gratitude! You sound like an awesome client! Glad your puppy is alright.

<answer>



I noticed that my vet had a stethescope with a short binaural on it-it bothered me for some reason to watch him have to bend over and reach so far to listen to my dogs heart...I got him a Littmann Veterinary Scope that had a little more reach to it after he was particularly helpful with one of my dogs.  Not a cheap gift, but practical!  A thank you note with homemade salsa, baked goods, etc. are always good, but remember that the best gift you can give your vet is a recommendation.  You could write a letter to the editor of your local paper (small towns will print it, bigger cities-probably not) thanking her for going above and beyond, or taking out a small ad proclaiming your gratitude.

<question from>



happyand...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Does anyone know how to make a runner for my dog help me plz plz plz ?



by the way i am from australia. plz someone help me :)



</question>



<answer from>



Aki P
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



a runner? huh?



</answer>



<answer from>



RED
Member since: 22 November 2007
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A runner is not a problem to make. First get you some line like close line. Attach it to 2 different poles or trees. huck the the lead to runner and the dog there you go you have a runner.



</answer>



<answer from>



Greyhoun...
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 3510 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Red has the basic idea - but do not use a clothesline, it will soon wear out from friction of your dog running back and forth.



Get a nice metal cable and stretch it between trees or poles, the length you want the run to be.



The you use a tear-drop shaped pulley to run along it smoothly and be sure to attach a swivel where you attach the lead to.



That way the run work smoothly and it will not twist up.



Good luck!



Most larger pet shops, or any hardware store will have the cable, pulley and and other things you need to put this together.



</answer>

<answer from>



Nekkid Bootie ♪♫
Member since: 15 June 2007
Total points: 44580 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Dogs dont earn money.



There's no money to be had in shows, you are right.



There's no money to be had in breeding, it costs money.



There's not really a high demand for things like calandars..  A group of people compliled pics of Cresteds to do a Crested calandar one year..  even with donated pics from forum members..  they did not make any profit off the calandars, as there was the start up cost of having the calandards printed!



You could put alot of money into having your dog trained for something special, like search and rescue.. but honestly, most of those are volunteers, not paid.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks love!



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Only if you can be the creative artist, and your dog be the model who you make money off of. My dog is more photogenic than lots of dogs, but the good photographers just sell pics of their own dogs. Mine modeled for a major oil-painter artist a few years ago, I thought that when the print came out I could at least make him give me one, but then he couldn't make a go of the image.
If you can get 12 great shots of your dog, you can make a calendar and sell it at pet stores and through breed-groups on the internet. It's all about an artistic eye and a good camera.

<answer>



Both of those dog breeds are well known for those forlorn looks they can have, but rest assured, it's just their sweet face and has nothing to do with their feelings.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 276 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Every dog has lazy or bored days--and friends and family may be convinced that nothing more serious than that is at issue. But you can tell when your own best friend is showing signs of a deeper problem.



Signs of depression include:



* Lethargy



* Excessive sleep



* Clinginess



* Loss of appetite



* Change in personality



* Whining



* Weight loss



Check this link to help your dog deal with depression.



http://dogtime.com/depression.html



Hope it helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



Mikel
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 246 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

http://dogtime.com/depression.html
http://dogtime.com/behavior.html
http://dogtime.com/
http://dogtime.com/dog-breeds.html



</answer>

<original file>7749.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk17501.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



brewzers dad
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How long or what age does a boxer puppy stop peeing in his crate?



My wife and i just bought a boxer puppy and we have had him for 3 months, he will lay in bed with us for up to 8 hours sometimes and never need bathroom but he is in his crate for over 30 minutes and he pees. Doesnt seem rebelious or anything. Thay say its the best way to train a dog but how does it work?



</question>



<answer from>



wishnuwe...
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 13372 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Sociology



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Bladder isn't grown until 6-months-old, they are not usually fully potty trained until 1-year-old.  Here are some tips, use what helps.
I use a crate* to potty train with, but only for potty training and then I break it down and store it.  I put blankets and a small food and water dish in the crate.  Dogs don't potty where they eat and sleep.  When they are first little, I only expect them to hold their potty for 4 hours, and then 6 hours, then 8 hours and so on.  So when they are first little, I set a timer or alarm clock to wake myself up at night to take them *out.  I only allow my puppy in the bedroom* or the living room, only one room at a time.  They have to graduate to more space.  If I allow them to have full run of the house, it will overwhelm them.  I take them out the same door each time.  I tie a dinner bell to the door handle.  Do not use a jingle bell as they could get their toe caught in it.  So when they are little, I ring the bell for them, and then open the door to go *outside to potty.  When they get bigger, I take their paw and whack the bell and open the door to go potty.  Eventually getting to the place where the puppy will ring the bell and let me know when they need to go potty.  Dogs want to please you, so it is your job to let them know what behaviors please you and what doesn't.  So when my puppy goes potty, I give her a treat*, and clap, and make a fuss and praise her.  So she learns that going potty outside makes me happy.  If she has an accident, make a disgust sound like “tsst” and take her out right away.  I never yell* or spank* my puppies.  Take them out when they first wake up, after they eat or drink, before nap, finish romping, when their activities change, or when they are sniffing around. Some puppies go pee right away, but may not go poop until 10 minutes later, so wait for the poop.  I have a little play time here, because sometimes I think they are done, and they are not.  Puppies train at their own pace.  While I may have a puppy that hasn't had an accident in several weeks, I don't let my guard down.  I don't expect my puppies to be "fully potty trained" until one-year-old.  If they have a setback, shake it off, and start over.  I only have my puppies in the crate when I am not watching them.  When I am sleeping, cooking, ironing, doing chores, basically when I am not watching her.  All other times, she is out of the crate practicing being a "big girl."  This is the time I train her how to behave in the house.  So we are practicing "no barking", 'no biting", "no jumping", and "don't eat the furniture."  I also have to practice "playing inside" so she doesn't knock over things.  You must keep the puppy in sight when they are little because they don’t know the difference between newspaper and carpet, and you don’t want them sneaking off and getting into trouble.



Some puppies can sleep through the night around 3-months-old, but their bladder is grown around 6-months-old.



REVISIONS:



*I use a CRATE to train with.  It is the method I prefer, compared to other methods I have tried.  I noticed that if they are in the crate, while I am doing chores, they are o.k., because the crate allows them to see me and be re-assured.  The crate can also be a comfort when stored in the basement for dogs who live in areas where thunderstorms and tornados are an issue. .  However, use the method that works best for you.....a laundry basket, a cardboard box, a woof-woof house, x-pen, child gates, whatever works for you.
*OUTSIDE, pee pad, litter box, whichever method you are using.



When the puppy is first little, keep the pee pad, litter box near the food and water dish, so the puppy can eat and drink, and then go potty.  You can move it away as they get older.  The pee pad has a scent that smells and initiates potty.  Sometimes a pee pad makes a sound that scares some puppies, so you might want to use a litter box if that happens.  The pee pad allows a puppy to walk around, but a litter box keeps the puppy in one place.



*BEDROOMS, I use the bedroom and living room for training, because it works for me.  Choose rooms that work for you, but watch for rooms that are damp, or drafty.  While my puppies sleep in the bedroom during training, once they are trained, I let them sleep where they want to.  They don't have to sleep in the bedroom forever.
*TREATS.  While I use treats for training, you don't have to.  I like Charlee Bears for training (a little cracker for a little mouth,) I use them for training, but once they are trained, I cut back on them.



*SOME PUPPIES will go potty in the same spot each time.  Some puppies have to be told to go potty.  A command like "go out" for pee, or "go finish" for poop, might work for you, keep saying “go finish” until the puppy poops.  This is a good thing to train if you travel with your dogs.  By using commands, the puppy won't get confused when you are visiting someone, on vacation with you, or when you get to a new home.  The command



</answer>



<answer from>



Mikel
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 246 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It actually depends on the amount and quality of training he gets. No dog is born with good manners..good thing, boxers are very trainable. I'd be glad to share some links with you to learn more about it. Have a nice time!



http://dogtime.com/
http://dogtime.com/boxer.html
http://dogtime.com/housetraining-crate-t...
http://dogtime.com/training-center.html



</answer>

<answer>



Well, there's no real way to tell, usually when the dog's testicles drop and start to grow is when it starts, usually around the time they start humping everything around them (aka 5-6 months). It's also partially a learned thing. I've got a male dog that's 5 years now that was only around females and doesn't hike his leg to pee. He squats like the dames do. So if he's around unaltered (unfixed) male dogs that hike, he most likely will too and soon.



Simple answer - between a week and never :p
Hope I helped.

Seasoned Breeder

<question>



How can i convince my parents to let me have a dog?



I will pay for the dog and everything else but how can i convince them to let it stay in our house? i only live with my mum and dad and we live in a big house with a big backyard, But we have a cat also



</question>



<additional details>



gg G ??? What are u talking about?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Eden
Member since: 08 October 2006
Total points: 4 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tell them dogs are the kind of animals that love you FOR LIFE if you treat them with love and respect. tell them it will be a really nice new family member and that you love them and will take care of the dog properly. also consider the finances, it's not cheap.



One more thing, very important: do not buy the dog if you think your parents will say one day get rid of it! it will break your dog's heart. dogs are not cats, when they get attached to the owner it's for life. i have owned dogs and cats.



gg is saying it's a HUGE responsability and it is. that's why many people give them up and dogs end up homeless and just await their end. it can be a very sad story so do not get a dog unless you are 100% sure your parents will not get rid of it.



</answer>

<question from>



Kay
Member since: 03 February 2006
Total points: 264 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Black lab baby has MAJOR fleas, too young for chemicals?



I just got a black lab puppy last night. She is three weeks old but we took her in because her mother died last night and she had nine siblings, so the owner was in a hurry to get them to good homes. We noticed that she literally had NESTS of fleas under her eyes and near her ears. So we washed her twice, and picked off  and killed fleas for a couple hours, and by my guess we killed at least 50, but they still crawl on her body and she still itches. She is way too young for chemicals, is there anything else I could use?



</question>



<answer from>



hjioyu u
Member since: 07 January 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



give her a nice long bath a scrub her fur real good flea shampoo for puppies



Source(s):



google.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 276 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try to use Earthbath shampoo. Makes soap-free, pH-balanced shampoos they guarantee won't irritate your pup's skin. Check this link for more information.



http://dogtime.com/earthbath-shampoo.htm...



Hope it helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



skl865
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 429 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've used Dawn dish soap before on a stray pup and it works very well.



Source(s):



I've used dawn before



</answer>



<answer from>



Golden gal♥
Member since: 26 January 2007
Total points: 68459 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



You need a vets help!  There is a flea product that only vets carry for pups this young.  Your vet can help you out.



50 fleas is not that many if the poor pup is infested!  Make sure it's bedding is cleaned ever day.  Get a flea comb and use it.



When giving a bath the fleas will rush to the pups head to get away from the soap & water. So get a wash cloth and makes sure you wipe them off!



They are nasty little creatures and can make a pup Anemic very quickly!



I'd get the pup vet checked very soon too.  If the pup has that many fleas then it is bound to have tape worms too! The pup need to be wormed!



Good luck!



Source(s):



Former Golden breeder and owner for over 20+ years



</answer>



<answer from>



Mikel
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 246 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just like we have baby shampoos there are also very gentle shampoos available for puppies. Make sure that you apply it thoroughly and you could also apply some anti flea powder afterward. To know more about taking care of this type, just follow the links below.



http://dogtime.com/bathing.html
http://dogtime.com/
http://dogtime.com/labrador-retriever.ht...



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



What are the responsibilities of having a dog?



I am thinking about getting a dog but don't FULLY know the responsibilities of having one, can someone PLEASE help me!!



please dont leave silly answers!



</question>



<answer from>



RED
Member since: 22 November 2007
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A pet is a big responsibility you don't only have to feed it and give it water, but you all so have to bring it to the vet to get it's shots. and for any other problems there may be. There is like all kind of things to have to do just to take care of one. They are not cheep eather.



</answer>



<answer from>



rodent lover x
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 176 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



ok
you wil need to:
walk the animal daily
feed the animal daily
wash the animal when required
take it to the vet when needed REGARDLESS of the price
provide a loving home for the animals ENTIRE life
Probably (unless u intend to breed) get  her/him neutered/spade
allow the dog to run off of the lead at LEAST every other day



Source(s):



owns a border collie and a springer spaniel



</answer>



<answer from>



ryma
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 299 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,



Owning a dog takes a lot of time, money, and commitment - over 15 years worth, in many instances. Dog ownership can be extremely gratifying, but it's also a big responsibility. Here are some things to consider:



- Can you afford a dog? The costs of caring for a dog throughout her life can be expensive. Healthcare, training classes, grooming, food, toys, treats, boarding, and other expenses add up fast.
- Are you ready to deal with the problems a dog can cause?
- Does your living situation allow for a dog?
- Do you have someone to look after your dog when you travel for work or pleasure?



Those are just some questions that you should ask yourself first before owning a dog.



You may check out this informative site that can help you decide in getting a dog:



http://dogtime.com/consider-before-getti...



Hope this one helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tid
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 396 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I got a dog before, and OMG, no one fully told me the responsibilities. Walking, at least twice a day, to prevent them going lula. Feeding, Vets, Playing, them eating EVERYTHING, and you can't just get up and go when you want, cos their effectively like a child. If I were you, I would get a cat, they're less responsible, and see how you get on. If a a dog lives til its 16, or 17, thats your life stuck. You can't move around home that easily, and unless you own your home, it could provide problems. They do give all the love in the world back, but I had to give my dog away because I didn't have enough attention to give him. It broke my heart to do it.



</answer>



<answer from>



pppbbbll...
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 2549 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. getting your dog from a proper breeder or shelter, not a pet store, not a backyard breeder who doesn't ask a million and one questions and doesn't make you jump through hoops to get one of their precious puppies.
2. Properly socializing the dog
3. Properly training the dog
4. Neutering/spaying the dog UNLESS the dog had championships, all the proper genetic testing, and certifications and is to be bred due to its high quality, NO EXCEPTIONS EXCEPT FOR REAL WORKING DOGS
5.Shots, vet care, etc every year
6. Registering your dog every year
7. Feeding everyday
8. Watering everyday
9. Walking a minimum of twice a day, one walk for at least 40 minutes, allowing the dog to go outside to go defecate/urinate at least another 2 or 3 times a day
10. housebreaking
11. Proper grooming
12. Playing with the dog
13. Being fully responsible for the dogs actions towards others, which is why#s 1-4 are so very important. Ill bred dogs, ill socialized dogs, ill trained dogs, and dogs who are not neutered/spayed can become nuisances.



</answer>

<question>



How big will my 17week old yellow Lab puppy grow?



i have a beautiful lab puppy called Harley. He's 17weeks and weighs 37pound (17kgs). He has paws the same size as my 2yr old Lab. Any ideas on how big he may be? Also he has quiet thick, somewat wavy fur on his back..is this normal?he is purebred im pretty sure..saw parents. Plz help.. =)



</question>



<additional details>



i thank u all for ur answers so far.. but is there anyone out there that knows if 38pounds is good? is he going to be a big lab? hes paws are the same size as my 2yr olds..? HELP..



</additional details>



<answer from>



Suzanne
Member since: 13 February 2007
Total points: 1206 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



38 pounds at 17 weeks? Wow! good sized boy.
The lab will probably be bigger than your two year old - because the paws do grow as the pup grows. You can only estimate for now - there is no way of knowing how big he will be until he is grown.  The parents should have given you a good idea however.  Never saw a dog that was bigger than both of the parents (but I bet it does happen occasionally)



Source(s):



Owned a lab puppy with VERY large paws - and loved him for over 14 years!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks so much, ur answer was quiet informative.=)



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Thick hair is common in Labradors.

<question>



Entertaining bored dogs?



I have 4 large dogs who are used to running round the orange groves in Spain but we have now moved back to the UK and they are getting bored when it rains and they can't go outside.
3 of them are 2 years old and are constantly ripping their beds up and barking. I know it's because they are bored so does anyone have any ideas to occupy them?
I walk them as much as I can (my mum is at work most of the day so I have to walk them all myself) and take them out into the garden (it's quite big) to run around and play when it isn't raining but the rest of the time they are bored.
We used to give them stuffed bones and stuff but now one of the dogs has a wheat allergy so any ideas on how to stuff a kong that won't cost too much? (She also has a nut allergy)
I am making some agility equipment too.



Any other ideas?
Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



sn0zb0z
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 4018 (Level 4)

<answer>

She taught her dogs what each were and trained them to retrieve them from the box using reward treats.
