<answer from>



swish_sw...
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 4165 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



you need some inside games to play with the dogs.  Some to do are:



1.  Hide a toy/treat in another room and encourage the dogs to find.  Normally you start with a toy they know the name for, like ball.  Hide the ball in a different room, then take them into the room and say find ball.  Give treats to all dogs when it is found.



2.  You can do the above but hide your keys.  this is really useful if you lose your keys, you can get your dogs to search.



3.  Play hide and seek yourself.  It is easy with another person.  She keeps them in one room while the others hide, then get the dogs to find you.



4.  Kongs can also be used with cream cheese, a little vegemite or even cat kibble, which normally does not have wheat.



5.  Teach them to retrieve a toy inside (my dog loves this one).



6.  Teach them the High Five game.
Initally a bit tricky, but when they get it they love it.  Put your hand out near their face, when they smell it give them a treat and try to encourage them to touch it.  The idea eventually is that you use both hands and quickly put them in different positions so the dog touches their nose to your hands, you can even make them jump up.  Dogs really love this and you could take turns to play with them.



</answer>



<answer from>



jessica b
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 794 (Level 2)



</answer from>

my dog always looovvveeeee a kong stuffed with peanut butter or cream cheese it keeps him happy for hours on a rainy day! i also wrestle with him a lot.



</answer>

Jenascia

<answer>



well. i would suggest leaving then in the garden with kongs and treats and toys, even if it is raining - they won't mind!



and i leave things hanging from the door frame in my dogs room, so leave s stuffed kong hanging,just her wet food, but frozen, they lOve it frozen, not only does it keep them preoccupied by waiting for it to melt, but the coolness feels nice on their gums. i usually put frozen peanut butter..however in your case, why not try frozen tripe mixed with fresh yogart, you can be create with kongs, things you may find gross they will probably love, also if you leave a few tennis balls and big balls in the garden that should keep them happy, my dog will chase a football and chew a tennis ball to death! it's good you walk them as much as you can but mental stimulation will tyier them out, that's why freezing your kongs is great because it makes them think how their going to get this great treat out!



and even certain fruits can keep them occupied, e.g my dog goes mad for magos and if i leave her say 2, will keep her going for 1 hour, because she likes to chew the seed, just see what works with your dogs, it might help to buy them some new toys with different textures, especially if you want to keep them inside, this way they will be exploring new fun toys and will associate being inside with new toys, however i do heavily suggest you just let them go outside.



hope this helps

<question>



I got a stray puppy .it is one month old,after consulting vet he told to feed ceraleac and milky water but it ?



stopped drinking milk.can u give me any  suggestion how to feed her.i also want to know wht shampoo to use to get her a thick hair and  now it got an infection too wht medicine should use

<answer from>



gg G
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 145 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

and come back u will see the plate empty



</answer>



<answer from>



Sheltieg...
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 132 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all, it was kind of you to take in this stray!



Now to answer your question. At one month, your puppy should be starting to get teeth, so I would start transitioning to dry food. Here's how.



Find a good quality, dry food that is formulated for puppies. I would get one formulated for dogs with allergies as well, just because the ingredients tend to be easier to digest.



Put some of the dry kibble in a food processor or blender and make into a powder, then soak it in some warm water or chicken broth until it is soft. Your puppy will probably eat this right up. A puppy this young will need to be fed every 4 hours of so, and be sure to have clean water for it to drink at all times.



If you have been giving the puppy snacks and people food, it will learn to hold out until it gets these treats, so don't feed anything but dog food for now.



If a young puppy gets chilled, it cannot digest food, so make sure she is warm enough, especially at night, just as you would a human baby.



I would not bathe a puppy at this age if you can avoid it. Just wipe her down with a damp cloth. At this age they can get chilled and sick easily. Wait until the puppy is 10 weeks of so, and even then be careful about it. Use a mild shampoo that is made for dogs, and rinse it out well. Most grooming shops sell quality supplies and can advise you.



As for any medicine, it needs to be given by a vet. Remember your puppy will need to be vaccinated starting at about 8 weeks and will need deworming and heartworm prevention. Keep her protected indoors until then and rush her to the vet if she acts sick - puppies that do not get mother's milk have no protection from disease



</answer>

<answer>



Well, like it or not, your parents would be the ones who'd pay for the veterinary bills and other expenses, which can run a small fortune.  They'd be taking care of the dog when you're at school, and they'd probably have to do it full-time when you go to college.



You might be able to volunteer at the local shelter, depending on their age limits (you might need an adult with you).  I'd suggest you try that.  It's very rewarding to walk and play with the animals.

<answer>



I dont think you are going to convince them to get a dog.  They offered the Ipod instead to "shut you up" basically.



Dogs cost quite a bit more..  I easily spend $100-200 a month to care for my healthy dog.  Dogs are alot of work, you may get tired of it after a month or so.



besides.. dogs live 12-17+ years.  In another 5 years or so you will be moving out and either off to college or your own place.  You cant take a dog to college, and its hard to find affordable housing when you start out, its impossible to find affordable housing that allows a dog.  Your parents dont want to be "stuck' with a dog.



ADDED



Sorry, but I dont think you will convince your parents to get you the dog instead of the ipod..  ussually when a parent offers an other item "instead of" one item..  its pretty much a final answer...



its a "you can have this, or nothing at all" kind of deal.  If you were wanting an ipod, now's your chance to get one.



</answer>

<question>



Wirey Haired Jack Russell Terrier?



Yesterday we bought a 3 year old jack russell from birmingham dogs home .. background was unknown but after seeing him we instantly bonded with the dog. picked him up yesterday and all day he was as good as gold . spent his first night and there was no problems. This morning he has urinated up the base of the stairs. After myself making sure he knew this was wrong i took him outside and he went to the "toilet" after 5 minutes of being back in the house he has gone straight to the stairs and cocked his leg up and done it again. Why is this ? and what is the best way to make sure the dog knows this is unacceptable? thanks in advance for your answers.



</question>



<answer from>



miss young
Member since: 31 January 2008

<answer>



most household cleaners will not destroy the dogs scent. try using biological washing powder 2 clean it. if he can still smell his scent he will keep going back



</answer>



<answer from>



Mazzz
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 4886 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



He is territory marking, has he been castrated? I would get him neutered if he has not already been done, clean the area where he peed with biological washing powder in warm water, you should give him lots of opportunity to toilet outside and watch him when he is indoors if you need to pop out for a moment restrict him to a dog crate, you need to have lots of patience with him if you see him about to lift his leg to pee indoors tell him no and take him outside, when you take him outside to toilet give him a command like 'be quick' when he pees give him a small treat and lots of fuss, hopefully he will then learn to toilet on command.



The following link has some tips on dog training and may be useful



http://www.apdt.co.uk/dog_training_tips....



Edit do not shout at him or frighten him as he will just learn not to do it in front of you and will sneak off or wait until you are not around to do it, this problem is easy to overcome but is frustrating initially.



Do not get angry with the dog as any form of punishment will inhibit the training.



</answer>



<answer from>



john n
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 7730 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



he is marking his spot and can smell other odors on there along with his own. wash the area down with a good cleaner and add a little vineagar to remove the smell. scold him when he cocks his leg in the house and watch for the signs when he is sniffing around.put him right out and praise him when he goes outside. if he is not altered they have more of a tendencey to put their scent on what is thiers in ur home. my little yr old poochi has this bad habit and will **** his leg on the couch when i am not there to catch him,i then show it to him and ask him "what did u do" and he runs to the door. with telling them they are bad and scolding him he will learn that he is not to pee in the house.my little guy is not neuterd yet and has a little side to him that wants to show he owns everything in the house and trys to make sure my other 2 large dogs know this.after a few days he should stop by scolding and catching him in the act and know he has to pee outside. he is new to the family and will get use to the rules and his new home in time. good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 276 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Marking is instinctual in canines and is primarily used to communicate ownership or assertiveness. The best way to curb the behavior is to ensure that your dog is properly housetrained.  Don't let him roam freely inside the house. Put him in his crate or another small, safe space when you aren't able to monitor him.  If you catch him in the act of marking, immediately interrupt him and lead him outside. Don't scold him; this will make the problem worse. Refer to this link for more information.



http://dogtime.com/marking-housesoiling....



Hope it will help.



</answer>



<answer from>



Miff Buster
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 1467 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



JRT come smooth broken or rough -coated.
What sort of coat or breed doesn't matter in housebreaking!
Yeah,it's marking *&* needs to be trained NOT too.



</answer>

Seems he has been a good boy for you so far You just need to let him know what is acceptable & what is not remember he has just come from the BDH and there are many dogs & *****'s there

<question>



How to train a beagle X spaniel puppy?

Ritchell...

<answer>



The key to rock-solid housetraining is to start the day your pup comes home and stick with the program. Using a crate is the easiest method. Check the following site for more details about housetraining your puppy.



http://dogtime.com/housetraining-for-pup...
http://dogtime.com/start-housetraining-0...
http://dogtime.com/training.html



Hope it helps! Good Luck!



Source(s):

<answer>



Well there are several good book (listed below) but I'd also highly recommend you find a good local trainer and take an obedience class with the pup, this provides skills for the dog and will give you confidence in handling the dog.



101 Dog Tricks (I love this book for teaching tricks, lots of pictures)
By Kyra Sundance



The Other End of the Leash: Why We Do What We Do Around Dogs
By Patricia B. McConnell



On Talking Terms with Dogs: Calming Signals
By Turid Rugaas



The Art of Raising a Puppy
By The Monks of New Skete

<answer>



You could try bathing it with an oatmeal stocking.



Just put one minute or rolled oats in a stocking and immerse in water. When they are all soft rub all over her stomache.



Leave the creamy solution on for 10-30 mins then rinse off.



You could also use some Paw Paw ointment on afterwards or some calendula cream or lotion.



Good Luck.

<answer from>



aj.puppy...
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 972 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When my Min-Pin obsesses over her paws and licks them raw the vet suggested using Gold Bond Powder.  The Powder has a taste she doesn't like so she's less apt to irritate the area with her licking, plus it has soothing medications to help with irritation.



You might also try Sulfadene, an anti-itch product for dogs.



Good luck.  Hope your baby feels better soon.



</answer>

john n

</answer from>



<answer>



my border collie was the same way this past june with the shaveing and surgery after finding a bladder stone.  the area became raw and itchy  and she was always digging at her belly so i washed it down with warm epsom salted water then dryed it and wiped achol over the area and put on benadryal anti itch cream on top.gold bond is good too and u can sprinkle it over top of any kind of anti itch cream to help soothe the skin. do this a few times a day and it will calm the irratation down and try not to let her chew at it. give her a treat or raw hide to knaw on so she will get her mind off the sore spot.she can take a benadryal pill to help also and it will take the itch out. they can take 1 pill per 20 lbs of their weight but since my girl is 55 lbs i gave her 1  in the am and 1 at night along with cleaning the skin when she started digging at it. it takes a few week for the fur to grow back so by keeping the area clean and using these method she healed nicely. good luck



</answer>

muddingc...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



well you should just call around and ask if they will groom her. I am 4th generation dog groomer and no matter what the breed is, I groom the dog how the owner ask me to. If they want me to shave their pomeranian I do. If you want the dog brushed out and trimmed around the feet then say that. We've had people say they want their dog trimmed down and what they meant was just cutting the feathers around the feet and what not. Be careful how you word things because trimming and cutting, words like that make us think you want the dog shaved.



</answer>



<answer from>



emilyj85
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 556 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am a dog groomer and although i am in England what I would say is well done for wanting to keep the dog original rather than shaving them like most people want! If people have made a mess of her. 1st of all, bite your tongue and get her clipped, I know it doesnt look the best but it will be the best thing for her, you can start again, it gives you time to find a decent groomer out there aswell, in the meantime, after she has been clipped, bath her and put plenty of conditioner on the dry areas of coat, the reason that people are put off grooming them is usually due to the amount of matts and knots they get,it is a long, hard and time consuming job when you get one that is matted up, if the coat is well groomed and free from bits of twig and leaf, lol, it is so much easier for the groomer.



After she has been clipped, take her to the groomer after around 4 weeks, his way they can just trim her and train the coat,maintain your daily grooming and keep taking her every 4 weeks,this way the coat gets trimmed into shape, after it has reached full length again, it will be in good condition and already shaped so it should be a lot easier to groom,if I lived by you, I would come and do her, lol  Good luck x



Source(s):



Dog groomer



</answer>

the  next time you go to a dog groomer tell them you DO NOT want  your dog clipping anywhere on the  body just a full groom,  that means tidy around feet edges With  scissors and nails clipped removing dead hair on body and combing all way through  the coat the only part that needs clipping is around the anal area

<answer from>



Bassetnu...
Member since: 28 June 2006
Total points: 68244 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



There is a reason why groomers usually shave Old English Sheepdogs.  It's because by the time the owner brings it in, it is matted and it would be cruel to brush it out.



In 20 years of dog grooming I've only had ONE OES client that was able to keep their dog well enough brushed in full coat that I didn't have to shave it.  Some were able to maintain the dog with a short (1") coat, the vast majority had to be shaved.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lady Bug
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 8785 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



No groomer should be cutting your dog if you don't request it. You need to make this very clear that your dog is not to be clipped, bath brush nails trimmed ears cleaned sanitary trim feet trim if you wish.



absolutely no hair cut.



Source(s):



Pro Groomer 21 Years
Grooming Salon Owner 12 Years
LB

<question>



6 month old puppy still urinating and pooping inside house at night time - has anyone got a solution?

i took the pads away and introduced him to outside and he has mastered that during the day, the trouble is at night.  during the day he is fine 99% of the time - he goes to the door for me to let him out to relieve himself. it just seems at night he cannot hold it?  I don't want to leave him out all night long...

<answer from>



Vet Tech
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 48234 (Level 7)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



You need to crate train this dog!  Pull up his water and food two hours before bed and make sure you walk him before bed so he has a change to eliminate!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sue J
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 447 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If he is good during the day that is great.  Withhold food and water early in the evening....If you crate him just at night....or leash him next to your bed...so he can't sneak off...it will gradually become a habit to hold it.



</answer>



<answer from>



tipsy pixie
Member since: 23 March 2007

<answer from>



Patient Paws
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 2225 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to crate him, not leave him outside.

He can only hold his urine for six hours, which means he needs to be let out every six hours. He needs his water and food removed at LEAST two hours before his scheduled time to go to sleep. Do not free feed (this means leaving food down all the time for the dog to eat as he pleases). Free feeding is one of the FIRST causes of house breaking difficulties.

http://www.inch.com/~dogs/cratetraining....



</answer>



<answer from>



Amber V
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)

<answer from>



jasmine_...

</answer from>



<answer>



After five, six or seven o'clock at night, take his food and water bowls up and take him out to go to the bathroom RIGHT before you go to bed.

<answer>



Hi,
You can't just take away the pads. You have to reduce the size of them as you introduce him to the outside. Don't forget he's a baby. Would you take a nappy off a baby because you introduced him to a potty?



</answer>



<answer from>



MSAD
Member since: 01 August 2007
Total points: 26461 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Insurance & Registration



Insurance



Law & Ethics



</answer from>



<answer>



At 6 months, his bladder may not be developed enough for him to "hold it" through the night. He may still need a few more months of growing. So, take him out right before bed. If you have to, set an alarm clock to get you up during the night and take him out again. (I never had to set a clock. I'm a light sleeper and would hear my puppies moving around in their crates and would wake up take them out).



</answer>



<answer from>



jenna
Member since: 11 May 2007
Total points: 243 (Level 1)

<answer>



Basenji's are a breed of dog that do not bark. But I've herd that they do make other noises. Actually, dogs use more then just barking to communicate. Wolves in packs hardly use their voice at all. These dogs just are adept at body language and the others are great at reading it. I learn a whole lot more from watching a dog's tail or body stance then I do from the noises they are making.

<answer>



Basenjis do not bark. Although they do make a yodeling sound. If you want to know a dog that doesn't make a sound then no dog breed is completely sound-less, yes there is completely bark-less but not sound-less. In a pack, I would think that they didn't go outside the "clan" headquarters, lol. Actually they have other ways of comunicating. Talltail is right. Dogs can smell other pack members issues, fears, enemys. friends, etc all by sniffing. Many packs also use ear, eye, and head movement to tell other packs and pack members what's going on.



</answer>



<answer from>



kaththea s
Member since: 14 July 2006
Total points: 1396 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Short answer: no.  All dogs bark, but they can be trained not to do so excessively--mostly by distraction, and by not encouraging them by joining in with yelling.  As soon as they're quiet, say your command word--like 'quiet'' or 'hush'--and reward them.  Also, ignore them when they bark, unless it is being done for a positive reason, like warning.
The basenji has more a yodel or squeak than a bark, but they have certain behavioral issues that render them a breed only for special owners.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 18 April 2007

HDB

Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Unfortunately, she will never stop having heat cycles because dogs do not go through menopause which means that, unless their uterus or ovaries have been extracted, she will keep on having her heat cycles



Source(s):



http://www.seefido.com/dog-breeding/html...



</answer>



<answer from>



Chalice
Member since: 13 March 2007
Total points: 26138 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



No. Dogs do not go through menopause.

Your dog is old, but if she's healthy I would still get her spayed. The chances of her getting mammary cancer or pyometra are HIGH, and then she'll have to have an anaesthetic anyway, while she's ill.

Even if you decide not to spay this dog, PLEASE get any future dogs you may get spayed before their first season. People always underestimate how common pyos and mammary cancer are - if more people had seen even one dog suffering from one of these conditions there would be a lot more spayed dogs around.



Chalice

EDIT: There you go - Lily H's neighbours dog died from pyometra. Many people know of a dog who's suffered from this, it really is that common!



Source(s):



vet nurse, feel free to email



</answer>

<question from>



Tess B
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 92 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do I know what is normal panting or not normal my dog just had heartworm treatment on tuesday. ?



My dog just had his first injection on tuesday of last week. Hes always panted. But how do I know if this is just normal or if its a reaction to the injection he acting completely normal. Is there a difference in the panting when it's a reaction? PLEASE if anyone has ANY advise please let me know. Thank you.



</question>



<answer from>



adoptdon...
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 614 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



After a dog's been treated for heartworm, you want to really restrict his activity.  You don't want the dog worked up so that the worms don't "break up" and travel to the lungs where they cause death.  I'd call your vet, but I'm also pretty sure that coughing is a lot worse of a sign then panting.  Try and keep him cool and comfortable and as still and relaxed as you can.  Good luck!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



very reasuring



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Rob R
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 225 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



im not a vet but i wouldnt worry to much all dogs pant! check his mouth if his gums arent bright pink get him to the vet if they are ok dont panic!



</answer>



<answer from>



Christa C
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, normally reactions to injections occur within the first 24 hours. Is he groggy? Eyes clear or glassy? How hot is it where you are? Is the breathing raspy or shallow or otherwise abnormal?



</answer>



<answer from>



harperta...
Member since: 16 April 2006
Total points: 3762 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Heartworm treatment will not cause your dog to pant.  It has no known side effects of any kind.



Source(s):



Vet assistant



</answer>

<question>



Does anyone know of good dog grooming course in Scotland?



Hi I am looking to start a dog grooming course but not sure of the best ones in Scotland. I have looked at home courses but apparantley they are not the best way to go. 
any info appreciated. 
thanks



</question>



<additional details>



I have typed in grooming schools in my area.



people dont take on apprentice or voluntary workers, tried this also.



</additional details>



<answer from>



cen5
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 5488 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



Other - Pets



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



I think there is a City & Guilds course available to show that you have some sort of official qualification, but it would also probably be useful to have some on the job training by volunterring to help or even being employed as a helping hand/ apprentice in a grooming salon.

Add: Just done a bit of 'googling' and found the city and guilds site: Here's the link and good luck in your new career.

http://www.cityandguilds.com/cps/rde/xch...

Just noticed your add- I understand that people may not be keen to take you on but they may be more willing if  they know that youar enrolled on the city and guilds course. It will reflect well  on their business if , when you qualify, they have certificates to put up on the wall to show that they have fully trained groomers working there rather than regular joe bloggs of the street who is just copying the techniques off the owner of the salon.



Source(s):



Live in Scotland and know a few groomers



s



</answer>

<answer from>



schnauzer mom
Member since: 13 January 2007

</answer from>



<answer>



no such thing as a "mini" yorkshire. that is just a name the breeder slaps on there to charge you more money. the breed is called yorkshire terrier, no mini attached. oh, to answer the question: sassy, buttons, lacy, dodger, rusty.

<answer from>



ilikesug...
Member since: 08 February 2008
Total points: 1969 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Thank goodness you haven't bought the dog yet. Don't purchase this dog. I'm giving you vital information here. What the backyard breeder who is selling you this dog is doing is taking the runts [the sickest dogs in the litter] and breeding them. This creates sick offspring. You'll have to pay a crap load in vet bills if you purchase this dog. Just get a standard Yorkie and save yourself the financial trouble. Don't support backyard breeding. It's a horrible practice by irresponsible people who just want your money. Standard Yorkshire Terriers won't exceed seven pounds anyway, or they won't fit the breed standard.



</answer>

<answer>



I have met a lot of dogs in my life. One thing that I would suggest is that if you have children it may be a good idea to get an adult dog. An adult dog is already adjusted to life and will be better able to deal with children. For a family that has children I would suggest a Corgi. I do not own one myself but I know two families that have corgi's and they are very happy with them. The corgi's are good with strange people coming into the home, but let you know when someone is coming. They are little dogs with big hearts.



Good Luck!



Source(s):



Dog judge, owner and breeder.



</answer>

<answer>



I would strongly suggest a Boxer! They are very very sweet dogs and great with children! I have 3 of them and they are great. They hardly ever bark and although they do shed they have short hair and its not that mess or that bad of a shed. Females get more attached to the male owner for some reason and vis versa witht the males. Females dont grow as big as the males. Females only get to about 65 lbs. and males get to be about 75-80 lbs. Females are shorter than males also :)



i hope i helped!



Source(s):



proud owner of 3 full blooded boxers// 2 German and 1 American boxers :)

Liz Claro

<answer>



There are special fun races for retired racer pet greyhounds.  Other sighthounds are allowed to enter, too.  There is a track which the dogs run on, chasing a plastic bag on a string.  It's lots of fun.  Try to find out more at dogchannel.com or dog fancy online.



</answer>

she had her final jab last tuesday ...the vet said i could take her out a week later ...but i was just wondering if she could go out today as we want to take her out with us...i know its only 6 days but does that matter?.... i dont want to risk it if she is in danger of catching something.....thanks

<answer from>

<answer from>



Crysis Management

<answer>

<answer from>



moshy_mo...
Member since: 17 August 2006
Total points: 166 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The excitiment of taking your dog out is high, but the way I see it, there is a risk, not HUGE if you take her out, but there is a risk.  Don't take the risk, and just be patient and wait till it's time.  Then there is ZERO to worry about!

It does matter, not nearly as much as if she had not had them at all, but it does matter.  In my opinion, don't take the risk!

Best of luck!



</answer>

Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Who breeds them? Backyard breeders. Why only backyard breeders? Because no responsible, reputable breeder would dare take two different breed purebreds and mix them. Mutts are worth nothing more than an adoption fee. Get one from a shelter. Think about it, you save money, and a life.

ADD: In response to: "People are saying that they would not be bread by reputiable breeders, well in fact they are very popular in America and some friends of mine out there have one and she is just darling therefore I am searching for one in England."



Just because someone takes a male dog and has him sire a litter, no matter what his credentials are, does not make them a reputable breeder. Especially if they are breeding mutts. These kind of breeders are frowned upon by responsible breeders. They are popular in America because a number of people in America are undereducated, and when they are educated, they choose to be ignorant about certain subjects, and this happens to be one of them. I live here, I know. :P



</answer>



<answer from>



leonard2...
Member since: 11 April 2006
Total points: 4100 (Level 4)

<answer>



People shouldn't but if no one ever does the dog will not be trained to ignore people that want to pet it and go doggy. I use people to distract my dog when I am training him so he will know to ignore distractions. We use noises, here kitty kitty, a kid on a bike, a female in heat, toys and people going "oh what a cute doggie". This way the dog can be corrected and learn that distractions are so many booby traps.



</answer>



<answer from>



The AWC Team
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 147 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Many people don't really consider the fact that its a working animal when they see one. They will register the fact ots a dog, and will suddenly get the urge to pet it, call out to it or distract it in some other way.

Whilst that may not be a problem if its an ordinary dog whom is just going for a walk, people need to understand that they can't done that sort of thing to assistant dogs. They are 'at work', and can't be distracted.



</answer>

<answer>



It sounds like you've answered your own question, you want a puppy more.
You need to demonstrate to your parents that you can take care of a dog, they are a lot of work. write out a plan for care, exercise and training and explain to them how it will work. If you get the dog take some of your money and sign up for an obedience class (make sure this is written in your plan), this give the dog some skills and builds your confidence in handling the dog. also go to the library or bookstore and pick up and read the book below. This will help you develop a well behaved/trained adult dog.



Remember to exercise, play with and love your dog!
Good luck



The Art of Raising a Puppy
By The Monks of New Skete



101 Dog Tricks



By Kyra Sundance



</answer>



<answer from>



Schnoodl...
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 9610 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



You won't be able to get and care for a puppy with only $400. What about those costly vet bills? Monthly general care fees? Heck, $400 won't even cover initial supplies PLUS initial vet care PLUS the puppy. If mom and dad say no then that's their final answer.



THEY support you. THEY pay for your room and board. THEY have to pay thousands in monthly fees for the car(s), home, your food, etc. If THEY don't want to add an extra couple hundred a month for the pup then that is their decision as they are the ones working and earning that money.



So when you get a job that can cover, say, $300 per month for the pup AND put enough away into savings for college and your future you can ask them again. I would work on your responsibilities while you're at it!



Source(s):



Owned by Mutt



</answer>

<question from>



Cup T

</question from>



<question>



Cure for eye infection in dogs?



My dogs eye has been crusty for 3 weeks now, the infection doesn't appear to be going. She's getting lots of eye-bogies, etc. Will this infection eventually clear itself, or do I need to take her to the vet? Are there any cures I can buy in the shop?



</question>



<answer from>



swish_sw...
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 4165 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Take this poor dog to the vet, if her eye has been sore for this long it must be painful, and we all know how painful eyes can be.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kittymom...
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 2289 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



hmmm i think the best bet is to take her to the vet, they should have a topical/gel you can put on her eye lids. Is the drainage greenish color? It may just be ordinary eye boogies! My kitties have them all the time =(



Source(s):



nurse



</answer>



<answer from>



jimmy
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 1438 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Take her to the vet.
This answer should be given by everyone who answer this question.
You need to find the cause of the infection, then the vet will give you a script for the cure.



You will only make it worse if you just start rubbing creams in her eye



</answer>



<answer from>



Beamer
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 666 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wipe the dog's eyes several times a day with a sterile cotton swab to remove all crusty bits. Then after each eye has been cleared of debris, get some saline water and thoroughly irrigate the dog's eyes with it. Be very careful that you work from the tear duct corner out towards the outside of the eye, or you risk washing the infection further into the tear duct.



If this continues you will need to go to the vet. If it is simple conjunctivitis the saline should work with 1 week. If it worsens or remains go to the vet as it could require antibiotic drops to avoid damage to the cornea.



</answer>



<answer from>



panache
Member since: 11 February 2006
Total points: 17226 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



She needs a vet check and antibiotic drops at the least,it may have caused a more serious ulceration by now



</answer>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13490 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to get some antibiotic/anti-inflammatory drops/ointment from your vet.



Eye infections do not clear up by themselves, the infection can spread deeper into the eye area and become a really serious condition that can lead to blindness.



Don't risk your dog's sight. Go to your vet.



</answer>



<answer from>



john n
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 7730 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



she might of got a draft or cold in her eyes along with some kind of allergy. if there is a greenish crust she needs meds to clear it up since it has been on going for a while.u could steep a tea bag in boiled water and after it cools appy the bag to her eyes to try to get any inflamation out or she might have pink eye.u can buy eye scrubs at the pet store or use human treatments or artificial tears to clean the eyes out.warm compresses will soothe them a few times a day.again if she has redness.swelling or greenish mucus call ur vet. u could give her a benadryal to see if the weepys eyes clear up since air borne pollen and dust can keep them flared up. 1 pill in the am and 1 at night. if she is small just give her 1/2.i hope there is a improvement with in a day or so and if nat take her in for a checkup. good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Nekkid Bootie ♪♫
Member since: 15 June 2007
Total points: 44591 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



the dog needs to see a vet.  Eye infections do not clear up on their own...  the longer you leave this go, the more damage it could do.. which would cost you more!



There's no cures in the shop.. the dog needs antibiotics... which you can get at the vet office.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AipIp0RKo9UlNKeqPUCHMEWxBwxc7da.html</original file>

<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



memphis_...
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 7751 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Euthanizing your dog, would you stay or go?



Until last November I have never been in the situation where I was called on to make the decision. Our vet suspected DCM or another heart problem had scanned her and was waiting for the result from a cardiologist. Becca rapidly deteriorated and was rushed to the emergency vet at 3:30 am, the day after she came home. The vet said she was in heart failure and needed to be pts, did I want to stay?

Yes I wouldn't leave her and no I wanted it not to be happening and be able to take her home.  After signing the form I carefully put her on two pieces of soft vetbed to make her comfortable, gathered her up in my arms and the vet administered the injection. It was over so quickly and very peacefully for Becca. (The two gasps of breath after she died where awful and stayed in the front of my mind for ages afterwards)



Would you choose to stay with your dog or leave?



</question>



<answer from>



Stacy
Member since: 16 March 2007
Total points: 5904 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>

Cap

Total points: 862 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am a vet tech myself, so I usually leave unless I am assisting.  I know from euthanizing animals myself that it's easier on the staff if you're not there.  Most vets are very professional and perfectly happy to have you stay, but it is not a pleasant thing for them either, and secretly most are hoping the owner leaves so they can focus on performing the procedure and not be distracted by how the owner is reacting.

On the other hand, I do think that for some animals (especially dogs), it is comforting to have their owner there so they can leave this world relaxed and comfortable.



</answer>

<answer>



I own a German Shepherd and I believe the average cost is about
$800 from a good breeder. A good breeder will give you a health
guarantee. Mine for example, if it is sick due to genetics, I will be
given a new puppy and be able to keep my original. Also a good
breeder will breed trying to keep all the German shepherd characteristics and abilities in mind. I got mine from a good breeder
and am extremely happy. Here is a site that will help you find a



good breeder in Texas. Good luck and and enjoy your puppy.

http://www.akc.org/breederinfo/breeder_s...



</answer>



<answer from>



ainawgsd
Member since: 28 March 2007
Total points: 10385 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



There are TONS of backyard breeders of german shepherds in and around Houston.  If you want a reputable breeder, then visit the German Shepherd Dog Club of America's website and ask for a breeder referral (be sure to check any potential breeder's references though, even a clever BYB can manage to get listed on a breeder referral...but it's a good place to start looking).



If you are interested in adopting a purebred german shepherd from rescue there are several active rescue organizations in Texas (Austin German Shepherd Rescue, North Texas German Shepherd Rescue, and Central Texas German Shepherd Rescue come to mind off the top of my head).



As for cash, it varies a lot depending on where you get the dog (but then again, so does quality).  You could probably find a BYB shepherd for $100-400 in the paper and a pet quality puppy from a reputable breeder will probably cost $350+.  Keep in mind that you often get what you pay for though.  Pups from reputable breeders tend to cost a little more because those breeders are doing tests (like screening for hip and elbow dysplasia, checking for pancratic insufficiency, checking eyes, and testing for STDs before breeding) and having their dog's mental and physical soundness evaluated (conformation trials, performance events like agility, tracking, schutzhund, obedience, etc, and temperament testing) and all of these things a lot more money than just throwing two dogs who happen to be german shepherds together and waiting for the resulting babies.  BYB dogs are more likely to develop crippling and expensive hereditary diseases and have severe health problems so any money you "save" by purchasing one of these "cheaper" puppies rather than going with a reputable breeder will be more than made up for with vet bills down the road.  In the end, the "expensive" puppy from a reputable breeder that tests their breeding stock before carefully choosing which dogs to breed usually ends up costing you less than a "bargain" puppy from a BYB.



Rescue dogs are an excellent way to go.  They are less expensive than a dog from a reputable breeder because the rescue can not guarantee their health as many of them come from unknown backgrounds (and many of them were originally BYB puppies that new owners got tired of when they realized dogs don't come pre-trained and do require some work).  But the adoption fee is not going towards any hopes of profit, it all goes directly back into the rescue to help feed and vet their dogs that are waiting for a new home.  Both of my german shepherds are rescues and I have never regretted the decision.



</answer>



<answer from>



bmthespi...
Member since: 03 October 2007
Total points: 18310 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



Birds



Fish



</answer from>



<answer>



You can start your search for a resonsible breeder here http://www.gsdca.org/base/classifieds_pu...



Expect to pay $800-1200 or more for a pet quality puppy from a responsible breeder.



If you find a puppy for less someone is cutting corners somewhere likely with health testing and GSD are too prone to problems to risk getting a puppy from untested parents



</answer>

<question from>



marmalad...

<question>



Help with fleas and kennel cough.?



Help with fleas and kennel cough.?
My dog has just returned from staying with a dog sitter and now has kennel cough and fleas. The lady told us to firstly treat the kennel cough with Benylin, is this ok? Are there any side effects to using Benylin.



For the fleas, even though she has just had her monthly treatment, we are going to do it again. Will this clear them up? We have so far only found 6, so I understand that she isn't infested with them, but obviously we want to stop them from further developing.

Any advise will be much appreciated.
12 hours ago - 3 days left to answer.



</question>



<answer from>



MICHAEL D
Member since: 27 November 2006
Total points: 3459 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Easy take the dog to the vets. Benylin wont do any good get the proper medication  and get some frontline for the fleas all the others are crap



Source(s):



Workng dog owner.



</answer>



<answer from>



hanerant...
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 171 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Firstly- your dog should have been vaccinated against KC before going into a boarding establishment. And the stupid women taking your money for looking after your dog should not have allow her to board without the KC vac. These sort of people really annoy me as they have no idea about running a boarding kennels or dog sitting and are just out to make money out of peoples dog's.

Don't give it Benylin. You will need to go to the vet and get a course of antibiotics and while you are there you may as well get the fleas sorted. Don't give a dose of frontline as this only acts when the fleas bite- your dog will need to be sprayed, as will your house and car now.

Then come home and report this women to the council and RSPCA. I doubt she has a license to run kennels and she obviously has no standards for taking dogs in and makes them live in grotty conditions.



Source(s):



6 years running a dog walking and pet care business.



</answer>



<answer from>



GK
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 333 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Get advise from your vet about flea treatment, my vet explained the cycle of a flea had to be broken. Lots of hoovering, sprays and powders. I became obsessed in getting rid of them. It did work in the end.



</answer>



<answer from>



spannera...
Member since: 01 October 2007
Total points: 4305 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Gosh, I'd be inclined to say don't use that dog sitter again!  Has your dog not been vaccinated against Kennel Cough?  All reputable Kennels and dog sitters should insist on seeing your dog's vaccination certificate to make sure that the dogs in their care are safe from illness.

Anyway, my advice will be like most other posters on here; i.e. never give human medication to dogs (so no Benylin please) and use a systemic flea treatment like Frontline (drops that you pop onto the dog's neck) which will stop the lifecycle of the fleas and eggs.



With regards to the Kennel Cough, you must seek vet advice immediately and also get your dog vaccinated as soon as possible against further attacks and other diseases (parvovirus etc.).



Source(s):



Dog owner for 11 years.



</answer>



<answer from>



x_firefl...
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 307 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



kennel cough can be a huge problem get her to the vet ASAP and isolate her from other dogs =]



</answer>



<answer from>



Mama
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all do not take your dog back to this place lol!!!  And indeed, it might be worth reporting her, although I'm no fan of the RSPCA

Second.  You cannot 'treat' KC.  It's a virus.  You can however treat the symptoms and actually Benylin is one of the treatments of choice.  Be advised by your vet as to dose, but using a child's dose should be okay, without knowing what breed/size your dog is.  If the symptoms are severe enough, and remember, it's puppies and the elderly who are usually affected the most, she may need antibiotics. But this may clear without the need of a vet.  You will have to judge how ill she is!



If you do go to a vet, PLEASE leave her outside in your car until the vet is ready to see you.  KC is highly contagious and you will be doing others a huge favour of you do not sit with her in the waiting room.  And did you know, this virus can still be passed on for a week or more after the symptoms have stopped.  It is rife in some areas of the country (UK) right now and if only people would keep their dogs away from others, it would help.  Puppies can, and do die from this.  Also, although jabs can help, this virus mutates and you may think your dog is protected, when it isn't!!  And there are two forms of protection too - one via jabs and the other a spray in the nose.  But that still leaves any number of variations of the virus - it's like our flu virus.  Unfortunately.

Fleas - I'd say treat again - and that includes your place, car, where she's been ...... six on her - yoiks what kind of place is this woman keeping?  I'm scratching at the mere thought.

Hope the KC clears up.



Source(s):



Owner, breeder, judge ....... since 1972



</answer>

<answer from>



schnauzer mom

</answer from>



<answer>



apparently, you didn't read the part where it says there is no such thing as a teacup poodle. the smallest poodle there is is a toy poodle.

EDIT: if you check the AKC website, it will tell you the three accepted sizes of poodles. in the non-sporting group, it's the standard size and the miniature size poodle. in the toy group, it is, well, the toy poodle. Standard: over 15 inches tall at the shoulder; Miniature: over 10 but under 15 inches; Toy: 10 inches or under.



</answer>

If you had researched them you know they come from puppymills and bad breeders out to make a buck and take advantage of people.

http://www.poodleclubofamerica.org/breed...



from the breed club themselves

"Teacup" or "Pocket" Poodles and "Royal Standard" Poodles

Responsible Poodle Breeders do not promote the sale of "teacup", "pocket" or "royal standard" Poodles. This is a marketing ploy to sell the pups for increased prices. Prospective Poodle owners interested in a small toy poodle or a large standard poodle can make their preferences known to their breeder. Most responsible breeders are familiar enough with their family of dogs to provide information about size and other attributes.



</answer>

<answer>



FYI, in this instance 'fragile' means 'sickly and defective.'  There is no such thing as a 'teacup' Poodle (or any other breed).  It's a BS term used by unscrupulous breeder to get more money for inferior dogs from gullible people such as yourself.

If you must leave it alone, start with a crate which is well padded and about twice the size of the dog.  Eventually you will find out what objects she can or can't effectively climb onto - until then, watch her carefully to prevent mishaps.

<question>



Cairn terrier barking all night



alfie is six we inherited him from friends who  had a pub and he was kept outside we cant do the same  he seems to have settled ie eating ok loves walks he seems to find it hard to settle at nights he is kept downstairs in the kitchen (nice bed ect) any tips for a quiet night coz we love the noisy git!!!!!!!!!



</question>



<answer from>



Abby K
Member since: 02 July 2008
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Get him de-barked.

I don't think it's natural, but it'll solve your problem.

Or put in some ear plugs, or take him to obideiance"(SP ERROR sorry)school.!



</answer>



<answer from>



Bozema
Member since: 14 January 2007
Total points: 50180 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Crate train him and put him in his crate at night - with the crate in your room.  He'll feel more secure being close to you and will be much less likely to bark.

Our dogs sleep in our room (they have graduated from their crates and sleep on dog beds) and they almost never bark.  Dogs feel more secure when they are part of the pack and are less likely to bark an alarm at every little noise.



Source(s):



http://www.inch.com/~dogs/cratetraining....



</answer>



<answer from>



Mairimog
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are lots of anti-bark gadgets out now 
http://www.pestcontrolshop.co.uk/acatalo...
This site might help



</answer>



<answer from>



Ankhesan amun
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 6349 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Friends of mine used to leave a radio on for their dog when he was little and restless at night.  The sound of that, even on low volume would drive me nuts, so I don't know how they managed, but the dog did settle down.  It may or may not have been the 'people sounds' from the radio though.

Do you keep him downstairs because he won't settle down, or is this the way it's been since day one and he's developed the barking routine as a result?  It could be that with everyone else upstairs, he's have a good yell at night because he's feeling lonely.  Have you considered putting his bed in the hallway outside your bedroom door, and leaving the door cracked, if not taking him right inside the room with you?

Someone else suggested obedience training, and I think that's probably your best way to go if changing his scenery doesn't do the trick. An expert can narrow down why it's happening and offer you the best options for gaining control of the situation.

He sounds like a great little dog...I hope you find out what his complaint is!



</answer>



<answer from>



Aonarach
Member since: 02 August 2006
Total points: 3518 (Level 4)

<original file>index;_ylt=AjWphObWHqI1eurphbWLxdYgBgx8dd2.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk35692.txt</current file name>



<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



Cooper C
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I get my puppy to go to the bathroom outside?



We are trying to house train him and he is doing pretty well. When I take him out he will do number 1 but not number 2. I will continue to walk him until he goes but he will drag me back to the house. Once we get inside as soon as I turn my head he goes number 2. I don't know what to do. I am trying to be patient but I am losing patience very quickly. Can someone please give me any advice you have. Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



wishnuwe...
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 7172 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



Well it is hard to give advice since you don't mention the age of the puppy.  I use a command like "go out" for pee, and "go finish" for poop, and you have to wait for the poop.  The dog can't go poop in the house if you don't let them back in the house until he goes poop.  My puppy tries to get back in the house, but I just tell her to "go finish" until she really does get it done.  Potty training gets better around week 12, but don't let your guard down that early.  Here are some tips, use what helps.
I use a crate* to potty train with, but only for potty training and then I break it down and store it.  I put blankets and a small food and water dish in the crate.  Dogs don't potty where they eat and sleep.  When they are first little, I only expect them to hold their potty for 4 hours, and then 6 hours, then 8 hours and so on.  So when they are first little, I set a timer or alarm clock to wake myself up at night to take them *out.  I only allow my puppy in the bedroom* or the living room, only one room at a time.  They have to graduate to more space.  If I allow them to have full run of the house, it will overwhelm them.  I take them out the same door each time.  I tie a dinner bell to the door handle.  Do not use a jingle bell as they could get their toe caught in it.  So when they are little, I ring the bell for them, and then open the door to go *outside to potty.  When they get bigger, I take their paw and whack the bell and open the door to go potty.  Eventually getting to the place where the puppy will ring the bell and let me know when they need to go potty.  Dogs want to please you, so it  is your job to let them know what behaviors please you and what doesn't.  So when my puppy goes potty, I give her a treat*, and clap, and make a fuss and praise her.  So she learns that going potty outside makes me happy.  If she has an accident  make a disgust sound like “tsst”  and take her out right away.  I never yell* or spank* my puppies.  Take them out when they first wake up, after they eat or drink, before nap, finish romping, when their activities change,  or when they are sniffing around. Some puppies go pee right away, but may not go poop until 10 minutes later, so wait for the poop.  I have a little play time here, because sometimes I think they are done, and they are not.  Puppies train at their own pace.  While I may have a puppy that hasn't had an accident in several weeks, I don't let my guard down.  I don't expect my puppies to be "fully potty trained" until  one-year-old.  If they have a setback, shake it off, and start over.  I only have my puppies in the crate when I am not watching them.  When I am sleeping, cooking, ironing, doing chores, basically when I am not watching her.  All other times, she is out of the crate practicing being a "big girl."  This is the time I train her how to behave in the house.  So we are practicing "no barking", 'no biting", "no jumping", and "don't eat the furniture."  I also have to practice "playing inside" so she doesn't knock over things.  You must keep the puppy in sight when they are little because they don’t know the difference between newspaper and carpet, and you don’t want them sneaking off and getting into trouble.



Some puppies can sleep through the night around 3-months-old, but their bladder is grown around 6-months-old.



REVISIONS:



*I use a crate to train with.  It is the method I prefer, compared to other methods I have tried.  While personally, the crate traumatizes me, (it looks like a doggie jail), my puppies do better in the crate.  They like it, I guess for the den like feeling, but I noticed that if they are in the crate, while I am doing chores, they are o.k., because the crate allows them to see me and be re-assured.  The crate can also be a comfort when stored in the basement for dogs who live in areas where thunderstorms and tornados are an issue.  It is a safe secure place for them.  However, use the method that works best for you.....a laundry basket, a cardboard box, a woof-woof house, child gates......whatever works for you.



*Outside, pee pad, litter box, whichever method you are using.



When the puppy is first little, keep the pee pad, litter box near the food and water dish, so the puppy can eat and drink, and then go potty.  You can move it away as they get older.  The pee pad has a scent that smells and initiates potty.  Sometimes a pee pad makes a sound that scares some puppies, so you might want to use a litter box if that happens.  The pee pad allows a puppy to walk around, but a litter box keeps the puppy in one place.



*Bedrooms, I use the bedroom and living room for training, because it works for me.  Choose rooms that work for you, but watch for rooms that are damp, or drafty.  While my puppies sleep in the bedroom during training, once they are trained, I let them sleep where they want to.  They don't have to sleep in the bedroom forever.



*Treats.  While I use treats for training, you don't have to.  I like Charlee Bears for training (a little cracker for a little mouth,) I use them for training, but once they are trained, I cut back on them.  Although I use them to give them pills too.  I used different treats for different things.  We use one bone at bedtime to let the dogs know it is time to go to bed.  We use a big rawhide for when we go on long trips, so they have a bone to amuse them, and they will be expected to hold their potty.  When they get the rawhide, they will not eat their food and water, until we get home from our trip.  (dogs are funny)  Do what works best for you.



*Some puppies will go potty in the same spot each time.  Some puppies have to be told to go potty.  A command like "go out" for pee, or "go finish" for poop, might work for you, keep saying “go finish” until the puppy poops.  This is a good thing to train if you travel with your dogs.  By using commands, the puppy won't get confused when you are visiting someone, on vacation with you, or when you get to a new home.  The command will tell them what you want them to do in an unfamiliar place.  You might also want to use a leash method, so the puppy doesn’t sneak off, or for strange places.

*Yelling.  It is not a good idea to "yell" or "spank" your puppy and then take them outside when they have an accident.  They may get confused and think that going outside is punishment.  While you want to correct them, if you are extreme, they may not want to go outside again.  Shake it off, and resume your schedule.  You have to keep it real.  Puppies train at their own pace,  but a puppy can only hold their potty for a few hours.  A guide would be 1 hour for each month of age, plus 1 hour, so a three-month-old puppy should only be expected to hold their potty for 4 hours at most.



*Sometimes it seems like you take your puppy out 5 million times a day.  You can sit on a bench, or folding chair, or a 5 gallon bucket turned upside down to stay in the shade. I use an umbrella for shade too.  You can always tape your favorite tv shows.  In the winter I microwave a gel pack heating pad, (sold at walmart in the pharmacy, made by Kaz, (I think.)  I put the heating pad under my jacket so I won't freeze to death.  In the summer, I freeze bottles of water, so we can grab one real fast on our way out the door.  I have a mini back pack by the door I can just grab with doggie treats, a flash light, a rubber band for my hair when the wind is bad, etc.  Do what works for you.



*Time lines.  Keep it real.  Puppies train at their own pace, so while your last 2 dogs may have trained faster, this puppy might take longer.  Training is all about routines, and repeating yourself.  It is about rewarding good behaviors, and correcting bad ones.  If you have a setback, shake it off, and keep going.  Good luck.
Source:  These tips, tricks, and ideas were contributed from many brilliant minds.  Thanks for your help!



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=Ak4_7KydQSOjWmM4.6EOrfIzLxVb6e4.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk35739.txt</current file name>



<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



h_schaff...
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I need to get my new bitbull a birth certificate on oline



where do i go



</question>



<answer from>



Baa_Baa_...
Member since: 24 December 2005
Total points: 4696 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Do you mean registration papers?

pit bull is not a recognized breed in the US which means that there are no papers for them.

So in your case your dog doesn't need one.

If you got a staffie and the breeder didn't give you papers then this breeder wasn't a registered breeder.

Either way...dog doesn't need one



</answer>



<asker's comment>

<answer>



If you got a purebred Pitbull, it would be registered by UKC. You should have gotten a slip to fill out from the breeder and you would need to send it in to register him. You can still register him with a limited registration

http://www.ukcdogs.com/WebSite.nsf/WebPa...

A pedigree, that is list of parents and grandparents etc and that you should get from the breeder

<answer from>



Kristin B ©
Member since: 26 December 2006
Total points: 5943 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually, a pitbull or American Pit Bull Terrier is a recognized breed in the U.S. by the UKC.

You cannot get registration papers on your pitbull unless the parents were registered as well, in which case the breeder should have given you everything you need to register your dog as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



piziesta...
Member since: 12 January 2007

<answer>



You're probably talking about registration papers.
I don't know why the breeder didn't help you with this. If the parents are registered then the papers needed to be given to you when you got your pup.
I not only make sure the papers are given at the time my pups are picked up, but in most cases I have them filled out on the spot.
I do it so I can trace my pups and make sure no one is buying them and then falsifying papers to resell them. I keep track of my babies!
I see several people whos answers on here would have made me hit the roof and I would have their dogs back here so fast their heads would swim. You buy one of my babies you darn well better take care of the paperwork too. Talk about not being responsible.
I'm not to keen on people on some board contacting me, but if you want to add me to your contact list I'll see if I can help you out. First though you need to get a hold of the breeder and ask for your paperwork. 
But feel free to get hold of me if you need help. I promise not to bash you! LOL



</answer>

<question from>



pfmonkey
Member since: 15 July 2008
Total points: 339 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Phantom dog pregnancy help....



My boyfriend has a beautiful 4 year old staff pedigree, she recently did the dirty with another staff in the park and got pregnant. She was due around now, and was getting what we thought were contractions and nesting...we took her to the vet because it had been a week and were told that he couldn't feel anything inside her and that it was a phantom pregnancy :( he's really upset because he loves Flossy more than anything and was looking forward to having more of her.

the vet also told us that she would have to be spayed as otherwise she will go loopy. Is this true? 
We really want her to have puppies and floss was so excited to have them. My boyfriend is devastated. Do you know if this is the only way around it? How the phantom pregnancy might have occurred? 
We just want her to be happy and Ok.



Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Liz Claro
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 704 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If I recall correctly, false pregnancies are caused by abnormal hormones.  The dog will cycle in and out of false pregnancies constantly, which can indeed make her kind of "loopy".  Your vet is right.  The kindest and best thing to do is to spay her.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tess Tikkels
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 817 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



mother nature is cruel sometimes dogs reabsorb puppies if the mum dog is stressed or ill or various hormonal reasons unknown, if she has milk and appears to nurse a toy, she could be an ideal surrogate mother to a litter of pups or one or two as a foster mum, if a mum dog has no milk for some reason, kindest to have her sorted so this doesn't re-occur, her hormones will make her  a bit out of sorts but when she returns  to her normal self she wont remember, dogs live for the here and now and dont feel sad/guilty emotions about pregnancy etc like a human would. it is



just her instincts.good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



anwen55
Member since: 29 November 2006
Total points: 19679 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



If she has had a phantom pregnancy this time, she is likely to have them after every season and the only way to prevent this is to have her spayed. Unless your b/f's b1tch is  something really exceptional, KC registered & has been tested clear for a number of hereditary diseases, you are really better not breeding from her. Rescue Centres are bursting at the seams with unwanted Staffies.
http://www.eastangliansbtclub.co.uk/bree...
http://staffy-bull-terrier.co.uk/HealthI...
http://www.scsbts.freeserve.co.uk/puppy_...



</answer>

<question>



Whats the best diet for a siberian husky puppy



whats the best diet for a 14 week old siberian husky pup tried numerous puppy foods but they don't agree with her asked my vet he says trial and error



</question>



<answer from>



Harumbah
Member since: 18 June 2007
Total points: 1359 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



3AP3я_T...
Member since: 04 September 2006
Total points: 5564 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



try 3 flavour dog food



</answer>



<answer from>



Rich S
Member since: 09 August 2006
Total points: 7826 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



dog food.



</answer>



<answer from>



gsdgirl
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 1101 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hills Puppy large breed until 18 months old then Hills Adult. Unless your puppy has diarrhoea and vomiting then around 18 months try Hills Sensitive Stomach but ensure you stay on puppy food until at least 12-18 months as puppies need specific nutrients. Other foods to try are Pro Plan Puppy, Advance Puppy, Nutro Choice Large Breed Puppy, Royal Canin puppy large breed. Or try Supercoat puppy as my puppy was on this one for a few months first. Ensure that you feed a complete meal though so you don't need to add anything to it. Dry food is better than wet as there are no nutrients in wet food. 
Ensure that you change over from your food your on now to a different food over 7 days otherwise you will give your puppy diarrhoea/vomiting - gut ache. Day 1 and 2 feed 3/4 old food (your on now) and 1/4 new food, days 3 and 4 feed 1/2 old food and 1/2 new food, days 5 and 6 feed 1/4 old food and 3/4 new food, day 7 feed all new food and none of the old food.



Source(s):



vet nurse



</answer>



<answer from>



girl_on_...
Member since: 23 August 2007
Total points: 6006 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



dry food w/a bit of wet food mixed into it......



</answer>

<answer>

In Uk there are suppliers who will deliver it frozen in lb bags so easily stored in freezer and handy size bags to take out and defrost amount you need.

I use www.tpms.co.uk based in Redditch UK

<answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



RIP Mutt... I LOVE YOU!!! ~♥~
Member since: 23 April 2008
Total points: 1152 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



it might be because they have long hair and long-haird dogs tend to smell a bit more than short-haired dogs (ie. your Rotty). what you can do, is buy some oatmeal shampoo. it smells great, and keeps fleas, ticks, and occasionally in soem bottles, mosquitos off your dog. after you wash all the shampoo off, rub some doggy conditione on your dog to make his long hair easily combable. after you rinse off all the conditioner, scrub him with some baking powder (Arm & Hammer, i recommend) and thoroughly rinse-through. it will get rid of the bad smell and leave your dog smelling fresh!



Source(s):



i asked a question in DogFancy magazine, and i got this same answer.



</answer>



<answer from>



piziesta...
Member since: 12 January 2007
Total points: 317 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's that longer hair.
Ask the breeder what they use or look up a breed club and get some ideas. 
The people on here are right about using a blowdryer and it's good to get them used to it now since they're babies.
If I don't blow dry my Toy Poodle he will smell to high heaven. And make sure you really rinse all of the shampoo out. It's hard to tell if you've gotten it all out with that breed, but when you think you've rinsed enough, rinse some more.
Rotties are a whole different subject. I used to be able to clean mine with a cloth. LOL ....My breed now is Cane Corso and same thing. It's those hair beasts that you have to take that extra step for. 
I love that breed by the way. They are awesome looking little puppies and beautiful when adults. I know some breeders who attend some of the rare breed shows and I love to go play with their dogs.



</answer>

<answer from>



Rick S
Member since: 26 November 2006
Total points: 3928 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



As I type this, my only-just retired greyhound is lying in the sofa, ears twitching and has just sort of 'whined' and moved his legs.
My old mongrel (breed description, not personality description!) did the same.
All dogs do it - just as we do things in our sleep. It's perfectly normal and, like a human sleep-walker, leave her alone to enjoy her rest unless she's about to go over the end of the bed/fall out of her basket!

[Ease up on candy of any sort - and chocolate is poisonous to dogs, it builds up in their bodies, so be very careful of that!'



</answer>



<answer from>



ozabelle...
Member since: 24 March 2008
Total points: 2631 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



She is dreaming: the flickering eyes indicate that she's in the middle of a REM cycle, a deep sleep in which people (and doggies) can have intense dreams.  The moving her legs is fairly normal too, just like some humans walk in their sleep, or talk, like I do. My dog does as well actually, he woofs in his sleep, it's pretty cute :D  She's not suffering at all; unless she was abused I think it's pretty unlikely that she could be having nightmares.  Dreams are our brains' way of processing information that we receive in the day.

On a side note, please don't feed her candy bars, chocolate is EXTREMELY unhealthy for dogs!  Even if she tolerates it now, the toxins in chocolate can build up and cause problems later!



</answer>
