<question>



Does your dog do this? why does mine do this so much?



My little 1 year old dog
chews her own feet, like a chew toy, in fact

i'm watching her do it right now! as i'm typing this,
i try to stop her when she does it, but just curious
does ur dog do this too? why does mine do that?



</question>



<answer from>



Madgeoly
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 247 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't really know why your dog is doing that but maybe your vet might know.



</answer>



<answer from>



smiles
Member since: 18 March 2007
Total points: 66 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



this is a very common problem with dogs, i work in a vet surgery so i see this a lot... there are a few home things you can do and make sure ur doing that may help this;
1. make sure ur dog has plenty of toys
2. spend lots of time with it
3. when you catch her doing it, growl at her and tell her to stop.
4. put some chilli/hot sauce on the ends (so long as there are no sores)
5. if it keeps happening make sure you take her to see someone cos she could really end up hurting herself and she could easily have a skin allergy



</answer>



<answer from>



Bindi §
Member since: 01 December 2006
Total points: 13319 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Its not normal.



Two things that could be going on are allergies, or a skin infection.



Time to visit the vet.



If the vet rules out both of the above, then it could be boredom. That constant licking can actually lead to sores so more exercise and mental stimulation are in order if that's the case. But have your vet rule out options 1 and 2 first.



</answer>



<answer from>



Socion
Member since: 21 July 2007
Total points: 5981 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



By trying to stop her, you are giving her attention which only reinforces the behavior.  But the chewing could turn into a harmful habit and she needs real help.



Try giving her her favorite chew toy or taking her for a walk to relieve her boredom and frustration. If that doesn't work, maybe this idea will:

A dog trainer on TV helped a dog that had obsessive behavior. Every time the dog started the behavior, the trainer would call out "enough!" and then turn away and leave the room. This broke the focus and directed the dog's attention elsewhere.  Rather than be left alone without an audience, the dog would stop the behavior and follow the owner out of the room. Over time he gave it up altogether.



</answer>

<question>



What can I do to stop my dogs agressive behaviour?



I have a 15 month old terrier.  I take him to obedience classes every week and have done since he finished his puppy jabs.  He has been socialised with other dogs from 12 weeks and is walked for between 1 and 3 hous every day - rain or shine.  In the last few weeks he has started growling at other dogs and in the last week has now moved on to more agressive behaviour and actually goes for them.  He is a medium sized dog (he doesn't come as high as the knee).  In the home he is a lovely, well behaved dog.  He hasn't been castrated and I wonder if this would be the answer.  He hasn't been attacked by another dog (as this can sometimes provoke agression).



Has anyone been able to successfully correct this behaviour in their own dog?



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 15 July 2006

<answer>

Sammy

<answer>



Let me tell you kong toys are AMAZING!! I would suggest a medium though the smalls are really small but the medium will be a perfect size up until adult hood and you could still use it than too. Ya you  can pretty much fit any type of dog treats in there but my favorite thing to use is peanut butter or wet dog food its cheap and it lasts a lot longer. The kong toys have a whole in the middle that is smaller on the top and larger on the bottom and dogs spend hours being occupied on them! But with dog treats they can get them out pretty easy, but peanut butter and wet dog food lasts a long time and you can freeze it too so it dosn't make such a mess! But you dont really have to worry about your puppy chocking on them they'll be to occupied with whats inside D



Source(s):



I work at a petstore

Lindsey C

<answer>



Yes it is fine. The only difference is that the puppy kongs are made of softer rubber that is more soothing for teething puppies. If you are talking about the large kong treats, it usually says on the box which kong toys they will fit. Otherwise you will have to compare the size of the hole in the kong toy to the size of the treats to see if they fit.



Source(s):



I work at Petco (we sell kong toys as well as other pet supplies) and I have my own dogs

Total points: 1160 (Level 3)

Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Our English bulldog has the least discriminating taste on the planet.  He loves EVERYTHING, including lettuce, goose poop, the wall (YES!  THE WALL!!  We came home to find him eating a dent into the wall one day!!), tires, feet, smelly dirty feet, paper bags, electrical cords, books, furniture, the upholstery in our car, unpeeled bananas, and even vinegar.  We thought maybe it was really a chewing issue, but really, he loves to eat the stuff he chews.  It cost us quite a bit when he had an "indestructible" rubber bone from Nylabone.  He bit off a piece as soon as we gave it to him, and by the time we got up off of the couch to grab it from him, he had eaten a huge piece of it.  About $3000 for surgery and medical bills later, we had a healthy bulldog again and a really smell piece of his bone as a souvenir.

When we got him, our house was totally turned upside down as we worked on his training to get him to stop eating things.  He still has a taste for it all, but luckily, we didn't have a real hard time training him to stop doing this stuff.

My husband has yet to fix the hole in the wall, so we have that little reminder of how silly our bully used to be.  I'm thinking about putting a little frame around it and having our bully sign it with his paw print.  We thought we were getting a bulldog.  We had no idea we were getting an interior decorator.



Source(s):



Oh, that nasty old broad, Experience.



</answer>

<question from>



lalabear

</question from>



<question>



Information about Alaskan Malamutes?



Hey guys, I am considering getting a Malamute and I would really appreciate any tips/advice from people who have experience of owning this particular breed please. I am trying to assess if my lifestyle would be compatible with owning a Malamute.



I have no children or other pets (at the moment) and I am very active (walking/hill walking/jogging). Also, it would be possible for me to take a dog to work with me (I know, I'm lucky). Also, I have worked with many other breeds of dog (8 years experience) in various capacities, that said I have NO experience of Malamutes.



Thanks everyone :)



</question>



<answer from>



Captain Obvious
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 3744 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi lalabear!

I'd love to be able to give you a concrete answer to your question, but unfortunately, it's just not that easy.



What i *can* recommend is that you start meeting some breeders and their dogs.  Ask them questions about the needs of a malamute and if your lifestyle sounds suitable.



The other things to consider are what life is like at work and if that job is going to be the same for the next 15 years.



http://www.alaskanmalamute.org/amca/inde... is a great place to start to get to know the breed better, and to get referrals to experts.



Gl to you and I hope that I was at least a little helpful.  :)



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 05 January 2008
Total points: 1629 (Level 3)

<answer from>



QueenBee
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 2849 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are great dog...for the most part.....lol

They need a firm hand (not physically) in training..they tend to be stubborn and not want to listen. If you would rather be a dogs friend all the time then a stubborn dog isn't for you. You have to be the boss and a friend

They do shed....mainly twice a year and get very warm in the summer. Luckily their hair like to come out in clums when they shed which makes it easy to brush/pull out and clean up.

They need to be socialized at a young age....they protect their families and homes and can be cranky towards other dogs if they are not exposed to them.

They need a job...they were bred to pull sleds and if they are left alone to do nothing all the time they may become distructive (not always just a possibility)

They can "howl" like they are in pain if you touch them and they don't feel like being touched. There was a puppy at the dog park that did this if someone tried to pick him up while he was playing. Just putting that out there.....I found it funny more then anything else.

Again these are just generializations and everything varies between dogs. Make sure you research the breed...don't just listen to one website because everyone has thier own opinion. Spend some time with the breeder and puppy and parents before you choose one. Make sure you choose a breeder that raises faily pets and not just breeds dogs for the sake of it. If you would treat your puppy the way the breeder does...move on to the next breeder.

Good luck and bonus points to you for asking first and not asking after you purchase.



</answer>



<answer from>



shelter puppies rule♥
Member since: 13 May 2006
Total points: 11008 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



my friend has 2 female malamutes. they do not tolerate warm weather good at all and can't be taken out for walks during the heat of the day.



</answer>



<answer from>



Whiteout Alaskan Malamutes
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 1908 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there
Have a look at this website

http://www.Icebaymals.co.uk/forums

Mals are a very special breed. For the right person they are the most wonderful breed.
The adult dog requires a good 2 1/2 hours of daily exercise. They are a very dominant breed which means you should read up on dog training and dog behaviour BEFORE getting a Mal.
From the moment you get the dog they need daily socialization with other dogs, big and small. Also very important socialisation with humans, again big and small. If you do not have any children go to friends or invite friends over with children, so the dog can get used to them as well.
Mals are a very intelligent breed and get bored easily. When bored they become destroyers and howl the house down. So they are not really a breed that should be left for 8hours or more while the owners work.The the past I had to take my dogs out from 4.30 - 6.30 h in the morning to make sure the dogs got enough exercise, after all they gonna be lazy all day again. Then take them out again after work for another our of exercise (and I do not mean a slow shuffel around the block) Daily dogtraining --for the dog to use their brains-- is important. They are a working breed and want to keep busy. They do not do so well in hot summers (being originally from Alaska) so walking and exercise has to be done either early in the morning (5am) or late at night.
When fully gron you can train the animal to pull you on a scooter (like the big version of a kids scooter, but with better breakes lol), but you need proper equipment for that, be pulled on a rig, go back packing and lots of other stuff.
I do not know if you are in the US or UK but that website is really useful for newbies to the breed and to get info on it. Try to find breeders and go to rallies (sled dog racing rallies) to meet people with Mals and to find out what living with them is like.

WARNING: It is most important to find a good breeder if you decide on the breed. BYB and puppy farmers are in every country.

I could write you an essay on what to look out for and what health test documentation to ask for, but all that you can find out on the Icebay forum too.

Good luck



Source(s):



15 yrs of Alaskan Malamute ownership.



</answer>



<answer from>



laraine
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i have a 14 week old siberian husky pup , no matter how many books you read and web sites you study from breeders etc, its still a shock when you actually own one in the flesh, they are alot like malautes all i can say is i hope you have alot of patience and you dont mind everything being chewed, they are very stubbon. i have been a expericened dog owner for 30 years i have had labradors, staffy, german shepard, the husky is our new addition i can honestly say she is the most stubbonest animal i have ever come accross but this in mind she is so full of love and i would not swap her for the world , all i can say is that you adapt your lifestyle around the pup  good luck



</answer>

<question from>



Curious

</question from>



<question>



Cartrophen Injections for joints - Are There Side-Effects



My soon to be 14 year old Cairn, is on Cartrophen (2nd injection coming this week).  I haven't read about any side effects and the vet hasn't mentioned any.  I just wondered if there are any



</question>



<additional details>



Monica P - thanks, I give my two 'Canine Veterinary Tab' (Mobility Support). I'm not sure if I see a change yet...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Monica P ♥'s Boxers
Member since: 02 April 2008
Total points: 1015 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



As with any medication there will always be possible side effects.
If your vet is using this product, than he/she feels good enough that there will be noticeable change and that the risk for side effects is low enough to try it.
I have heard good reviews on this injection.  Have you also thought about glucosomine and chondroitin tabs for your dog as well.  It would just be an added incentive to promote healthier joints.
At the age of 14, aritritis is pretty much inevitable so I commend you for thinking of your dog and wanting him/her to be as pain free as possible.



Here is a link offering more info on this medication
http://www.kvh.com.au/Cartrophen%20Vet.h...

Good luck!

ADD:
I forgot to ask...have you noticed any change yet?



Source(s):



Mama to 2 Boxers



</answer>



<answer from>



Barbara
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any medication will have possible side effects.



</answer>



<answer from>



H.O.T. Dog
Member since: 23 December 2006
Total points: 20312 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



Entertaining



</answer from>



<answer>



CARTROPHEN VET® (pentosan polysulphate) is a new treatment for osteoarthritis, that provides pain relief by acting on the pathology within the joint that causes the pain. It also protects and supports the recovery of joint cartilage that is damaged by the arthritic process. CARTROPHEN VET has therefore been classified as a disease modifying anti-osteoarthritic drug and represents a new and rational approach to the medical treatment of osteoarthritis in dogs.

I would say that since the drug is also used to alievate the pain of arthritis that it would not induce pain while your dog is undergoing the treatment.

This is such good news for many of us

Good Luck,
H.O.T. Dog
Handler Owner Trainer of GSD's
Member U.S.A & A.W.D.F.
http://360.yahoo.com/sewwoodyou



Source(s):



yahoo search vehichle
http://www.arthritis.au.com/htm/vet_01.h...



</answer>



<answer from>



smartypa...
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 3632 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



My collie had them and the affect was amazing.
She could walk miles across the fields after a few months of the last injection.That was 2 years ago and she has never needed a booster as she has never been lame or struggled to get up since.

She dislocated her hip and after a year she was showing signs of pain.
The vet didn't mention any side affects.
Although she has cancer of the lymph nodes now.
I don't think there is a link to the injections as I have had 2 other dogs in the past with the same form of cancer.

She has had 2 quality years after cartrophen and I wouldn't swap that for the world.



</answer>

<answer from>



Madgeoly

<answer>



When we were getting our puppy we looked everywhere for a wide pet gate to block off our kitchen and living room as well.  We also wanted something that we didn't have to mount into the wall.  We ended up going with the Ritchell wood freestanding pet gate. I HIGHLY recommend this gate. <question>



How can I get my dog to eat?



I have a year old 3lb teacup poodle, and I didn't get her until she was 10 mos old. We started her off with Pedigree because that's what we were feeding our other dog, after learning about dog nutrition we switched to EVO Chicken & Turkey canned food and the same flavor dry food.  My dog liked this for a while, until just recently and I don't know why. She will not eat the wet food, but she will eat the dry food which is fine, but now she won't eat according to our routine. We feed the dogs once in the morning and once in the evening. I've stopped giving her treats throughout the day, but she will only eat when she feels like it. Sometimes she'll eat when it's time to eat, sometimes she'll have her breakfast in the afternoon, and sometimes she'll only eat dinner. There's nothing wrong with her health, she just had a checkup and she's fine, so she's just being picky. There's another dog here, so I don't understand why she doesn't feel compelled to 'compete' for her food especially when our other dog tries to get her food anyway. I've tried feeding her alone in my room and sometimes that works, but sometimes she won't eat unless I hand feed her, and other times she'll just eat on her own. I'm worried about what will happen when I start school in the fall and there's no one around to give her food 'when she feels like it.' I need to get her to eat when it's time to eat. What can I do to get her to eat on time, and on her own?



</question>



<answer from>



MrsBossy
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 89 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Do you leave her food out even if she hasnt eaten at the scheduled time? If you stay consistant with your times then she should adjust unless she is sick and thats why she wont eat. I had to allow my dog 30 minutes to eat and if she didnt eat during that time I would take the food away then by the time her second meal came around she would eat it all and soon she adjusted to the time she was set for her routine.
Dont listen to the post where they suggested to "shove her face in it" she is a moron!

<answer>



Sometimes you can help a picky eater along, by putting food down for a 15-20 minute period, then taking the bowl up.  Whether she's eaten or not, she'll learn that food is available at the times you pick, and only then.  She won't let herself starve.  After being picky at the first meal, she'll be hungry by the 2nd one.



Try feeding her separately (different rooms) from the other dog.



Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fetch! Malibu
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 13884 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



~ The most important thing to rule out first is if you are overfeeding her.  For a small dog on a grain free diet, they do not eat much.  Are you feeding her per her weight according to the dog food bag?  I have a 5lb Chihuahua that eats Orijen which is also grain free.  He only eats 1/4 cup in the am and 1/4 in the pm.  Small dogs on a high quality diet eat very little.  Also, I have poodles and poodles are known for not being big eaters.  I do have one that is a pig, but my other two and others I have met, are light eaters.  As long as your dog is not losing weight or looking sick, she is fine.  She is eating what she needs, you may just be giving her to much of a good thing.  Monitor her weight and if there are no changes or the next several months then you can rest knowing she is eating properly.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Small dogs do not require a lot of food and it's possible that you're feeding her more than she wants.  I'd leave dry food available all the time and give her the wet food (just a couple of tablespoons) in the evening.  She will not starve herself.  It's better that she just eat when she is hungry not when you want her to.  She won't have a weight issue because she is listening to her own cues on eating.

murderou...

</answer from>



<answer>



This isn't really that big of a problem - a lot of dogs tend to be picky, even if they ARE hungry (sigh, dogs). Do you leave the food out so the dogs can eat whenever they like? Stop that. Lay out the food for about 15 minutes in the morning (or at night, if you prefer), and even if she doesn't eat it, once that 15 minutes is up, take it away. Repeat this for a couple of days, and she'll get the message: eat or starve.

Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



Jennifer H
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I currently have a 5lb pomeranian. She did the same thing about that age, about that weight. I was really scared because she refused to eat and she was such a tiny thing!  I tried Iams select bites, pedigree, science diet, etc.

At first, I would cook chicken and rice for her. She would never refuse that!  The vet said that is a healthy diet for a dog, and provides the necessary vitamins. I'd cook a bunch of chicken at the beginning of the week, separate it into baggies, and freeze it. I would give her a baggie each day.  My vet also said that most human food that is healthy for humans is healthy for dogs (most veggies, for example). Just don't give her human food that dogs are allergic to!

Finally I found Ceasar, which is a brand you can only really find in the grocery store.  It's a wet food, so it's not as good for healthy teeth as dry food.  But that brand adds extra smell to the food to make it appetizing, and my dog would eat that.  Smaller dogs don't have as developed a palate as big dogs, so that's why they are pickier: they can't taste the food as well.  The Ceasar makes the food smell stronger to make it appetizing for little dogs.  Try that.

Also, my dog will eat Royal Canin for small dogs, which you can find in most pet stores, but not grocery stores. It's a dry food, and better for her teeth, but she won't eat as much as the ceasar. I leave it out and she picks at it throughout the day.  I also leave the wet food out, because my dog is also picky about only eating when she is in a good mood. I hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



Cheryl C
Member since: 18 October 2007
Total points: 1188 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



offer her food when it is feeding time give her 15 mins and if she eats great if she doesnt take it up and throw it away. Do the same at the next feeding and so on. She will eat when hungry, i mean she is only 3 lbs maybe her metabolizem is changing and she just is not as hungry anymore.

i would suggest keep offering her the can and dry but keep them seperate, they can be in the same dish just dont combine them and she may choose to eat what she wants. You can also offer her some cottage cheese or 1/2 a FRESH  raw egg, great for dogs and high in protein other dogs will love it too. She really may just be sick of that particular flavor. I know  dogs at my work that are seriously this picky, so try a different flavor. different amino acids are in different proteins so a variety is actually more beneficial to your dog. i really hope this helps just remember dont give in. dogs need water to survive wayyyyy longer before they need food (im not trying to sound cruel), just a fact



i hope some of these tips help  good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Rachel
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am sorry to hear this. But the best thing to do is just to let her eat on her own when ever she wants. Most small dogs don't eat all their food at once. They eat when they are hungry. Try putting something special like cheese or her favorite treats on top of her food. Don't worry because putting pressure on your dog's eating habits can just stress them out.



Small dogs do not have large stomaches so don't get stressed if she isn't eating enough. Slowly praise hair after eating small portions. Sooner or later she will get hungry.



Your problem could be that she is sick  of the food or doesn't like it. But don't keep switching her food types because it can lead to becoming very sick! Ask your vet for food type suggestions.



Hope this helped!



</answer>

<question from>



trudy w
Member since: 11 March 2007
Total points: 437 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Boston Terrier has become agressive. What can I do?



I have a one year old Boston Terrier that I have had to let go and live with a very nice lady that has had several and hers passed away and she needed a companion. I have 2 new grandbabies and Sassy was just too hyper around them. She was never aggressive just hyper. Now the lady says that Sassy has become aggressive. There are 2 bigger dogs that are barking and she can hear them. I do not know if that is a factor. I know the lady and it is nothing she is doing. She says Sassy has nipped her a couple of times. Please help and please no judgement on the fact that I had to let her go. I talk to the lady every day. I did what was best for her and our family. She has a wonderful home with space to run and someone that is home with her every day. She gets to ride in the car with her and lives a good life. Please help. Thanks. Also this is not an elderly lady. She is 51 years old.



</question>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13490 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds as if Sassy hasn't yet accepted her new Owner as "boss", she's being dominant and not accepting the roles; sort of like a step-child saying "you're not -my- mother, you can't tell me what to do!"



You might suggest that the Lady take Sassy to "puppy" classes as this will help establish the correct relationship between the two.



Many trainers do allow older dogs in as long as they are consulted before joining.



Read up on the breed characteristics, this will go a long way to explaining the problem



Source(s):



http://www.nextdaypets.com/directory/bre...



</answer>



<answer from>



frankie1...
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there!
There are several reasons that might explain why your Boston Terrier has become aggressive.
1) Sassy may be experiencing some anxiety now that she has moved home, and a common outlet for anxiety is aggression.
2) You say Sassy can hear other dogs, how much socialisation has Sassy had with other dogs in her life? If she is unfamiliar around other dogs, she may feel aprehensive and threatened by their presence, which can lead to fear-biting.
3) Is her new owner strict enough with her? Sassy may need reminding that she is no more the Alpha dog in her new home than she was in yours. Explain to her new owner that with some firm training, (not punishment!) she may calm down and stop nipping.



My advice is, regardless of the reason, Sassy may just need a firm but gentle training regime to help her comprehend that her new owner is Alpha - with this realisation, Sassy will relax in the knowledge that she has a kind and fair owner and should cease nipping :)
I would advise buying a training book that covers basic troubleshooting - it should have a section on dealing with an aggressive or anxious dog.



Source(s):



Years of experience in the animal care sector.



</answer>

ilikesug...
Member since: 08 February 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



Who breeds them? Backyard breeders. Why only backyard breeders? Because no responsible, reputable breeder would dare take two different breed purebreds and mix them. Mutts are worth nothing more than an adoption fee. Get one from a shelter. Think about it, you save money, and a life.

ADD: In response to: "People are saying that they would not be bread by reputiable breeders, well in fact they are very popular in America and some friends of mine out there have one and she is just darling therefore I am searching for one in England."



Just because someone takes a male dog and has him sire a litter, no matter what his credentials are, does not make them a reputable breeder. Especially if they are breeding mutts. These kind of breeders are frowned upon by responsible breeders. They are popular in America because a number of people in America are undereducated, and when they are educated, they choose to be ignorant about certain subjects, and this happens to be one of them. I live here, I know. :P



</answer>

<answer from>



spannera...
Member since: 01 October 2007
Total points: 4295 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You won't find a Yorkshire Terrier crossed with a poodle from a reputable breeder so WHY would you want one from a breeder which you already know is not reputable?



I'm sorry because I expect this is the last thing you want to hear, but if you're going to buy a puppy it should only ever be from a Kennel Club registered breeder.  This doesn't necessarily mean a huge breeder with lots of dogs in kennels; a lot of KC registered breeders are home breeders, but what you will get is a responsibly bred pedigree puppy which has been wormed and hip scored, KC registered, and you'll be able to see its parents and usually grandparents as well.

You already know that if you want a crossbreed the best place to go is a shelter but whether or not they are popular in America is immaterial.  The fact is that if you knowingly buy one of these crossbreeds from a "breeder" you are encouraging irresponsible breeding and will possibly end up with an unhealthy little pup.



Source(s):



Dog owner for 11 years



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

<answer from>



beyondth...
Member since: 17 April 2006
Total points: 232 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



What kind is going to fit into your lifestyle? No dog is a perfect breed for all people. everyone is going to have different wants and needs. I have an 8 month old golden retriever and couldnt ask for a better dog, but then again some people dont like dogs that are big and shed so maybe thats not your cup of tea either. Do some research or go to the pound. Dont get one and then put it up for adoption once you realize it wasnt a good idea.



</answer>



<answer from>



Apricot Lover
Member since: 30 April 2007
Total points: 34715 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Never leave a dog outside, unsupervised.  Someone should be with the dog when it's outside.  The dog also needs to socialize with other dogs, so dog parks are a good place for that.



Let your parents decide what dog to get, since the dog will be spending most of it's life with them.  You'll be moving out in a few years, and the dog will have about another 10 years of life after that.



Get from shelters or rescues.  http://petfinder.com  They'll have shelters and rescues listed in your area.



Never from a pet store or off the internet.  Here's why..http://stoppuppymills.org, http://saynotopetstorepuppies.com, http://millbusters.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Meg
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 70 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<question>



How offten should i give my dog a bath



I usually bathe my dog every to week she stay in the house and my mom like her clean she is a pitbull terrier is this to much bathing



</question>



<answer from>



gsdgirl
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 1101 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you bathe her every week this is not good. Once a month-or once every 3 months is fine. If you do this any sooner you are stripping all the natural oils from the dogs coat and can be doing the coat more harm than good. If she smells spray a per cologne on her to freshen her up inbetween baths.



</answer>



<answer from>



Monica P ♥'s Boxers
Member since: 02 April 2008
Total points: 1015 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



That is too much.  They don't need baths regularly especially if she is an indoor dog.
The most important thing is to make sure ears stay clean, and this is for any breed.  Just use a cotton ball to clean the ears out.
If odor is an issue, the anal glands may need to be expelled.
If it is just because your mom worries, than check into som pet wipes to rub over the coat in between baths.
Too much bathing can strip your dog of natural oils needed for healthy skin and coat.

ADD:  Cotton balls should not be dripping wet because you don't want to get excess water in her ears.



Source(s):



Mama to 2 Boxers



</answer>



<answer from>



Soph
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 304 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question from>



αυτυмиιο...

Total points: 722 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How can I train my dog to come?



My dog is a miniature australian shepherd but he can be very stubborn at times. he knows how to come because when were in the house or the back yard we will say to come and he will.
But he always finds ways to escape into the front by just like slipping through the door or whatever and we will say to come but he just doesnt listen and whenever he sees us running towards him trying to catch him he runs faster. He just loves to bark at other dogs so when he escapes he will just run along through the neighborhood barking at every dog through their fence and just won't listen to us. idk what to do because there will be a car driving down the street and he will just be running right in front of it so im afraid hes going to get run over one day or escape when someones not there to catch him and he wont come back. 
i just dont know how to get him to come when he doesnt want to.



</question>



<additional details>



we already do try to get him to come with treats but running around is more important to him



i think the problem is that he knows that if he comes when were in the front. he knows hes going back inside but he wants to keep running around.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Brandy L
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Calling your dog to you should always be a pleasurable (happy) experience. Always use your dog's name, and reward him generously (lots of hugs, kisses, treats) when he gets to you. You are his favorite person!



When you teach your dog a command, it's important that he hears the same word over and over so he can learn what it means. You can use 'come' or 'come here'. It doesn't matter which word you choose. But always use the same word so that your dog is not confused.
When you say your dog's name and 'come here', he should stop what he's doing, look at you, and come running. He should do it the first time you say it and he should be happy about it.



When your dog responds and comes to you, always reward him. Make him happy that he stopped what he was doing and ran to you. There are many ways to reward your dog. You can feed him treats, give hugs and kisses, go for a walk, play with a toy, or feed him a meal. The point is that your dog is happy to come when you call because something good is going to happen.



Reward your dog when he comes. You are basically going to have to retrain him because he is now set in his ways and thinks in his head that when he escapes, he does not have to listen. There is no extreme punishment so he doesn't worry about it. I am not saying to punish him when he does not listen. He just won't get the praises when he comes back. eventually after working on it, he is going to come to you no matter what once he hears that word cause he gets what he loves in return.



That's really all you need to do. from now on whenever you use that word to come, you praise him like he is a god for doing it. Every time. After a couple of weeks he will always come to you no matter where he is.



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<answer from>



Toller Gal ! * ~
Member since: 12 February 2008
Total points: 1346 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you want the dog to listen and come to ou when called, you might want to also start training it Sit, Down and Stay. Not to forget, come as well. Here's how.



Sit :



Get your dog started off in a quiet area, where there is little to no distraction. You will need patience, treats or toys. First, you want to go up to your dog and push it's bum down lightly, follow up by saying " Sit " and praise + treats. Repeat again and again. It doesn't happen overnight...nothing does. So really, have patience. Soon enough, it will start to do it on its own. [:

Down:



Get you dog into a sit postion, don't praise or treat (this also teaches the dog that not all commands will come with a treat). Then take the treat and put it in front of the dog's nose and " pull " downwards towards the floor, encourage the dog to lie down as well. Once he achieved this step, immediatly say " Down " and treat + praise. Again, repeat until the dog understands. This will take patience as well.

Stay:



Get your dog in any position you would like (preferably, Sit or Down) and show the dog your treat. Then walk away, chances are, your dog will follow, so when it does, go back and get it to sit, walk away and say " stay " if it comes, get it to go back and reward it. Do it again and again, gradually, increase the distance. :)



Come:

Get your dog to either sit or lie down. Then tell it to stay. Say " come " and wave a treat. If your dog insist to stay, then put a leash on it and tug it ever so lightly, so that it knows it is suppose to come. When it does, reward and praise. Repeat again and again. :)

You might want to train these tricks in the order that I have listed, as they do kind of fit in together. There is no " proper " way of training each tricks, as there are many methods and techniques out there. This just happens to be mine [:



I hope I helped, and Good Luck ! :D



</answer>



<answer from>

<question>



Are there breed specific docile dogs?



I asked a question earlier asking for a definition of a docile dog.  I was wondering if there are breeds that are docile or whether it depends on specific dogs' nature or even how they're 'brought up' so to speak.



</question>



<answer from>



rjn529
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 6948 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



All breeds have docile dogs and ones that are more feisty.  The dog's breeding and early socialization will have a major affect on the dog's later life.

However, the larger breeds are typically more laid back.  Dogs like Great Danes, Irish Wolfhounds, St. Bernards, these dogs are all typically very slow moving, loveable dogs.



</answer>



<answer from>



GoldenPatrol &lt;3's tobster
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 1121 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



doc·ile



Audio Help



/ˈdɒsəl; Brit. ˈdoʊsaɪl/ Pronunciation Key - Show Spelled Pronunciation[dos-uhl; Brit. doh-sahyl] Pronunciation Key - Show IPA Pronunciation 
–adjective 1. easily managed or handled; tractable: a docile horse.



2. readily trained or taught; teachable.



--------------------------------------...

[Origin: 1475–85; &lt; L docilis readily taught, equiv. to doc(ére) to teach + -ilis -ile]



—Related forms
doc·ile·ly, adverb 
do·cil·i·ty



Audio Help



/dɒˈsɪlɪti, doʊ-/ Pronunciation Key - Show Spelled Pronunciation[do-sil-i-tee, doh-] Pronunciation Key - Show IPA Pronunciation, noun



—Synonyms 1. manageable, malleable; obedient.

[dictionary.com]

any dog can be docile, it doesnt matter what breed. it depends on the dog's personality itself.



Source(s):



golden breeder for 9 yrs



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



Kitbitir...

</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with SouthernLady. English Bulldogs are very docile compared with any of let's say the Terrier breeds, English Setters. They are big, sweet lugs.  One thing to remember though is that just because a dog is docile does not also mean that it is low maintenance dog. English Bulls are very high maintenance.  My opinion is that many purebred dogs are overall more high maintenance than say a mutt.  If you want a dog you don't have to walk day and night (even though they love to do so) a Bulldog is a good choice. Also when you decide on your breed consider the life span, health issues, grooming, etc. so that you can get a dog that suits you the most. Good luck & have fun!



</answer>

<question>

From the questions below can you guess the breed of dog??

1: A popular dog the world over. Bred for retrieving game which has a medium length coat.

2: A small dog than the first though from the same group. Again medium length coat and come in either English or American. Very scent orientated.

3: Medium size dog who doesn't bark, yodels instead

4: A herding breed, that was bred and is native in one country, yet named after another.

5: A terrier breed which looks somewhat similar to that of the Min Pin

6:Toy breed which is said to be that of a small lion

7: The dog which has a blue/black toungue

8: The most popular of all the Swiss mountain dogs

10: The 2 breeds which are often used alongside the Hunts/

<question>



How do I get my dog back if it runs off to play with another?



I know that if my Ozzy (staff cross) was off a lead, and saw another dog, it would ignore me altogether and go to play.  Because of this, I only take him off lead when I know there isn't any dogs, but one day, a dog will be there.  How on earth do I get him back or train him for this.  I've bought a tracking lead, one of those really long ones.

I know I can't get him back because when he's been with my parents dog, or once a jack russell came into our garden, and I phoned his owners and had to spend an hour trying to get ozzy - the russell was trying to hump Ozzy and he'd only got back from having the snip the day before.

Help please x

He's good, he'll come back if there is no distraction, loves toys and thought I could usse that, but doesn't work, neither does petting or treats.  I've trained him to do sit, lie down, paw, high five etc, but finding this difficult.  One day he'll be off a lead, and run to play with a dog who is not dog friendly !



</question>

<answer from>



Righteous James

Total points: 3268 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I recommend joining an obedience class with other dogs. Unknowingly, I taught my dog to ignore other dogs after I joined an obedience class. When looking for a good dog trainer, you want a person who not only uses positive methods but also some amount of corrections and distractions. Some trainers can also bring their trained dogs as a distraction and so no group classes are necessary.



</answer>



<answer from>



jams
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 2253 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



my suggestion is follow these steps:
1 - find 2 -3 well behaved dogs with willing owners (friends, family, etc) to help train with you.  i would practice the following scenario once a day for at least 2 weeks, alternating dogs.

2- have his tracking lead on.  set up to meet one of the other dogs in a safe place.  before allowing ozzy to play, ask him to sit and stay next to you for a few moments, then give him the release "OK go play!" .  follow at the other end of the tracking lead (hold the handle) and let him start to play (the other dog should be on lead is possible, as well, so that it doesnt come to you when you call ozzy).

3 - after ozzy has been playing for 3 mins, very excitedly call "Ozzy Here!"and start running the other way while gently reeling in the lead.  when he gets to you, give tons of praise, have him sit, and stay.  wait a few moments, and then release him with "OK go play!"  (since his goal is playing with that dog, that is his ultimate reward).  repeat this activity every 3 mins.  when you are ready to go, NEVER call him to come to leave.  instead say "All Done!"  , then reel him up and walk away from the other dog.  (we dont want him to think come when called means play time is done, otherwise he will ignore you)

4 - after about 2 weeks of repeating this scenario daily, you will then 'test' it out.  do the usual meet, up, have him wait, and release him.  then, when you are ready to call him, do NOT run, do NOT pull the lead.  instead , squat down, and excitedly call him "Ozzy Here!".



see what response you get.  if he comes running back, TONNNSS of praise, then, sit, stay, then release to play.  if his head doesn't even flinch, continue the run/reel the lead scenario for another 2 weeks.



if you get a head turn, stare, and then he returns to playing, follow on to the next step

5-  if when you call him , he looks at you and the goes back to playing, calmly walk i towards him while gathering up the lead, say "All Done" and instantly walk him away.  since his playing with dog is contingent upon coming to you, and he didnt, then play time is done.  no need for harsh corrections, or getting upset.  just too bad for ozzy.  wait about 3 -4 mins, have him sit , stay, and then release to play again.  repeat this again.  if he comes back, then TONNNSS of praise and a release back to play.  if he looks again without coming, then again, gather him in, say "All Done", wait 3 -4 mins, and start again.



6 -  make sure to be consistent, upbeat, positive, and have fun.  you want ozzy to see you as your leader AND team mate, so he enjoys responding to you and sees a purpose to it as well.



Source(s):



trainer, owner, volunteer



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AsQ7nwY0CAE969eCNwhX9jIGBgx4ccc.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk40643.txt</current file name>



<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



LISA M
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 517 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How to heal a dogs tail?



My dog wags her tail so much that she managed to cut the tip and it wont heal as everytime she wags it and hits something with it the wound starts bleeding again. Vet says if it does not heal they will have to amputate the end of her tail!!!! I thought that was a bit drastic. I am going to try bandaging it for a while to see if that helps and put alot of padding under the bandage to help against future bangs tot he wound area. WAs just wondering if anyone else has had this problem and what did they do? The wound is at the very tip of her tail and it is not a very big wound and not at all deep just superficial really but my ceiling is now polkadot red!!



</question>



<answer from>



Julien Poublon, vet
Member since: 30 July 2007



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This is both a common and very frustrating problem.

Most commonly affected breeds include the working dogs with long (and waggy) tails such as the springer spaniels. This is the reason why many of them had their tail "docked".

While there is now a ban on the systematic docking of the tail in new born dogs, this is sometimes the only alternative when everything else fails.

The cause of the problem is the frequent trauma inflicted to the tip of the tail. Treatment is to avoid such trauma through bandaging of the tail. This is difficult and such dressings tend to slip easily. When healed the lesions do seem to recur quickly.

I recommend to give the tail protection a good go but not to waste too much time if you see that it does not work and get that tail amputated.

Best wishes, julien



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thankyou. We have bandaged the tail and used tape to keep it on. I know it will probably pull the hair off but hair grows back, Tails dont!!! If it does not work we will have her tail amputated and yes she is a chessie!!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Pam J
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 546 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can wrap it with a breathable wrap, make sure to use a gauze under the wrap so as the wound can breath.



Good luck, I had a lab that used to clear tables with her tail and she was always getting abrasions on her tail.



Eventually she outgrew the table clearing behavior and all was well.



</answer>



<answer from>



SiD
Member since: 09 April 2007
Total points: 1960 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a fairly common problem and sadly it does sometimes end up with amputation as the only way of solving the problem. Bandages can help but you need to be very careful that they are not too tight so as not interfere with the blood flow. If the dressing is too tight it will make things much worse. 
I usually use a plastic syringe case in the dressing for the tail tip to act as 'armour plating' and this often works quite well.
If you are not happy with the advice your vet has given you either discuss it with him/her further or seek a second opinion. You might however get the same advice!
Good luck this is a tricky problem but with perseverance and a little luck you may well save your dog's tail



Source(s):



I'm a vet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Vet Tech
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 47543 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Poor thing has what we call "happy tail" in the vet world!!  Dear God, growing up I knew a Labrador who would "paint" the walls and ceiling red with blood splatter paint!  What a nightmare!!



Listen, there is NO need to amputate the end of her tail.  Let's think about this logically for one second.  If your vet were to amputate the tip of her tail what would then stop her from banging that part on the wall????  You would have the same problem, once again!  How would the area heal from the surgery??

Here is what you *should* do: laser her tail.  Ask your veterinarian (or call around to local vet offices) if they have (or have access to) a laser machine.



When you laser a wound it cauterizes the area and promotes new skin growth!  Our hospital is lucky enough to have a laser and we have used it successfully for dogs who suffer from "happy tail".



The first laser treatment will be under anesthesia, but the treatments following the initial treatment will be done without any sedation at all since she will not feel the lasering.



Most "happy tail" dogs take about 4-6 weeks of treatments (3 treatments a week).  She will wear a pretty funky medal splint at the end of her tail until treatment is done.

I wish you the best of luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



doggonec...

<question from>



abbievc

</question from>



<question>



Is my dog pregnant?Help?!?!



she is a little over 1 year old and her tittys are swollen, if you sqeeze them a dot of milk comes out, she was around a male for a week, she sleeps all the time, she doesnt eat much, her tittys are sagging,she doesnt like to be alone, she really likes her belly rubed lately, she is not spayed. help if have answer



</question>



<answer from>



gsdgirl
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 1101 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes I would say she is take her to your vet as the gestation period for a female dog is around 2-3 mths. If you did not want a litter you should have got her spayed as so many dogs end up euthunased in shelters due to accidental matings.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mona Lisa
Member since: 12 February 2007
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have an unspayed female dog, you should anticipate the possibility that she is pregnant. However, it is only possible if she was on heat during the period when she was around the male. A dog on heat has blood stains coming out from her vulva. 
Unfortunately, there is no clear visual way to tell if your dog is pregnant, unless you are very experienced...especially early on in the pregnancy. Thus, it's best to take your dog to a vet if there is any question.
You mentioned that the dog doesn't eat much, pregnant dogs usually eat 2 to 3 times their usual portion. Dogs often have false pregnancies where they put on weight, produce milk, get pudgy, enlarged nipples. 
The only reasonable thing to do in my opinion is to go to your vet and take it for tests.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fields of Gold
Member since: 15 April 2007
Total points: 7088 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



She shouldn't have been 'around a male' when she was in season.  That is totally irresponsible.  She is far too young to have puppies.

Now the damage has probably been done.  If you remember the exact date she frst mated with the dog then she should have her puppies 63 days from then.

You can take her to the Vet and have an ultrasound if she is between 4 and 5 weeks pregnant.  This will tell you if she is definitely in whelp.  The Vet will be able to give you a rough idea of how many she is carrying but will not be able to give you an exact number as sometimes a few of the puppies are hiding behind the rib cage and cannot be detected by the xray.

If she has gone past her sixth week then you need to start giving her an extra meal per day to give her the nourishment she needs to feed her puppies.  When she has her puppies she will need about 5 meals a day depending on the size of her litter plus access to water day and night.  This will help with her milk production.

I hope all goes well for you.



Source(s):



Golden Retriever Breeder 30 yrs
Had dogs all my life
Own 8 Goldens & 1 Springer



</answer>



<answer from>



Maize
Member since: 11 April 2007
Total points: 232 (Level 1)

<question>



What is the best way to introduce a new dog to my other dog? please help!!



i need to know how what is the best way to introduce a new dog...
i have already introduced the new dog to my other dog yesterday. and i am planning to have the new dog for the night tomorrow, but i am a bit worried about some things like if they will fight. my other dog is a male and the new one is a female.



</question>



<answer from>



DaveSFV
Member since: 26 April 2007
Total points: 3921 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Obviously your "other" dog is not socialized or you would not have this concern.  Socialized dogs are friendly, confident, and do not fear new encounters.  Not possible to socialize a dog in one day.



Source(s):



50 years of owning, raising, and training dogs.



</answer>



<answer from>



meggiesu...
Member since: 04 January 2007
Total points: 341 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is always a good idea to introduce animals in an area where neither owns the territory.  Do not use your home. Maybe a park or something along those lines.



</answer>



<answer from>



djfkdjkl...
Member since: 03 February 2008

<answer>



its good that one is male and one is female because normally, with this combination, they wnt be aggressive towards each other. 
here are good sites that tells you what to do:
http://www.gomestic.com/Pets/How-to-Intr...
http://leerburg.com/introducingdogs.htm
http://www.rescueamaltese.com/intro.htm



good luck! :]
xooxo
questions?email me!
(read the notice on my profile for reply informations)
--------------------------------------...
i got your message :)
youre very welcome! im glad that i cn help. im very sorry about your dog's past owner, i just cant understand why people treat their dogs like that when all the dogs cn trust is their owner!!
here is a good site that tells you how to give time and dedication to the dog, so she has positive experiences with you and learn to trust people again :]
http://www.healthypets.com/socializing.h...

here are also some bits-by-bits tips that may help:

When socializing with people, very calm, no sudden moves, no loud noises. Very controlled enviroments for now. Only bring over people you know well and are good with dogs. When socializing with other dogs, again, you must go out of your way to know that the dog shes playing with is reliable and wont attack her because yours may be aggressive or whatever other reason there is. Bottom line, take it slow. All happy memories. Lots of treats for behaving like a good girl!
*Let the dog come to you especially in the first couple of weeks. She has likely been forced into situations with no regard as to his feelings. Let her approach you - let her decide if he wants a cuddle, etc.
Keep a journal of what works & what doesn't that way you will be able to see the progress all your hard work has accomplished.

good luck
xooox



</answer>

<question from>



sus
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What do we do now that our yorkie puppy died? We purchased it 3 weeks ago? help pls?



We bought our yorkie puppy 3 weeks ago (today would have been 3 weeks), he passed away thursday night. He never ate by himself  I had to force feed him everyday all day, untill he just got really bad...we didnt have any money (because we were broke from buying him) so we could not take him to the vet, he was a gift for my 6 yr old daughter that worked really hard to get him. He got really bad, I tried everything the breeder told me to feed him, he had 2 sets of shots, he was vomiting and severe diahera, my husband took him to the vet after hours, the vet told him the puppy was in real bad shape that he didnt think he was guna make it even with treatment. We did not have th 800 dlls to try to hospitalize him, we had to bring him home and pray to save him, he died an hour later. The vet said he thought it was parvo but we did not test him. Now the breeder is saying he will not replace him, my daughter and I are heartbroken. I want to get her another one (of course not untill 6 mo) what should we do? The breeder says that because an actual test wasnt done it could have been anything. Pls help I am desprate????? Thank you



</question>



<answer from>



chancely...
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 504 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First of all, please let me extend my sympathies about the loss of your little puppy.  A death of any kind is never easy.

We know what kind of person that breeder is, anyways.  I would say please report them to AKC as well as perhaps the Better Business Bureau.  Any breeder who doesn't care about the cause of a young puppy's death THAT THEY BRED should not be in the business, period.  Please report them with an extensive detail list of the sickness of the puppy and the breeder's attitude.

Now, I'm not saying the breeder is a bad breeder because he didn't give you a new puppy at no cost.  I'm more concerned about the breeder's seemingly uncaring attitude.  If anything, they should check on the rest of that litter and the health of the parents to make sure there isn't some genetic problem.

I understand having no money to save your pet.  Veterinarians are doctors and should be paid accordingly, but boy, it sure does add up for the average pet owner.

I would say, after you've taken care of the details surrounding your puppy's death, to perhaps contact a Yorkshire terrier rescue.  As cute as puppies are, they are nearly as much work as a child, and rescuing a dog is saving that dog's life, in the kindest way possible.  Rescues usually have adolescents who weren't right for their previous owner and middle age to older dogs who lost their home due to moves or a death in the family.

You can contact Barbara Meskan of the Yorkshire Terrier Club of America at yorkrescue@aol.com, or visit http://www.petfinder.org for a huge listing of Yorkies awaiting their forever home.

If you decide that you'd still like to raise a puppy, be sure to visit this webpage of essential questions to ask the breeder:

http://www.petpeoplesplace.com/resources...

A good breeder will never be hesitant or unsure of anything you ask them; they will truthfully answer your questions and have plenty for YOU, as well.  After all, these people barely make their money back breeding their dogs; they don't breed to make money, but to improve the breed, because they love it so.

Again, I am so sorry for your loss.  Hopefully you can find a friend to fill the void in your heart!

Best of luck to you!



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<answer>



You couldn't afford your first dog, you should not get another, sorry, that may sound cruel, but please think about it.

Parvo also is very persistent in the environment and difficult to kill, if your puppy that passed away did indeed have parvo and you bring a new undervaccinated puppy into that environment you are putting it at a dramatic risk of also getting parvo, which again you won't be able to afford to treat. Bleach and a chemical viricide called parvosol are the only things I know that will kill the virus in your home, and I assume you aren't going to soak your carpets in bleach.

Wait a few years when you can afford a dog, adopt one from a shelter at a much lower cost, and have a backup fund for emergencies, because they do happen.



Source(s):



vet tech



</answer>

<question from>



maxx-MAX
Member since: 07 June 2008
Total points: 1304 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What is flyball and how is it done?



</question>



<answer from>



moonshoo...
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 994 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Flyball is a relay race with 4 dogs on a team. The course consists of a starting line, 4 hurdles spaced 10 feet apart and a box. The hurdle height is dependent on the height of the dogs in the team -- 4" below the shoulder height of the shortest dog. 7" is the minimum height and 14" is the maximum height. The first hurdle is 6 feet from the start line and the box is 15 feet from the last hurdle making for a 51 foot overall length. The dogs jump the hurdles and step on a spring-loaded box that releases a tennis ball. The dog catches the tennis ball and then runs back over the 4 hurdles. When the dog crosses the starting line the next dog goes. Teams race against each other at the same time and the first team to have all 4 dogs run without faults wins the heat.



</answer>



<answer from>



gsdgirl
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 1101 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Flyball is generally sen with border collies and involves the dogs one at a time run over around 4 hurdles and then push a plunger on the fly ball machine to retrieve a ball and then race back over the herdles and the next dog goes. It is kind of like a tag relay.



</answer>



<answer from>



Liz Claro
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 704 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Flyball is a team sport.  The dogs have to run and jump over a series of hurdles, grab a ball that pops up rom a machine then run back, jumping over the hurdles again without dropping the ball, returning to the owner.  Then the next dog and owner on the team go.  You compete against other teams, all at the same time, for speed and accuracy.  The hurdle heights are set according what best suits the smallest dog on each team, so teams always welcome small dogs as members.



</answer>

<question>



Do dog owners mind when my dog runs up to theirs in a park? Your opinion*?



I have a little pomeranian that's super friendly. He just loves to run up to dog to initiate play. I was wondering if in general, others find this irritating? (I wouldn't if somebodys dog ran up to my puppy)
Yes I do have a leash and collar, but since he comes back on command after a few minutes, I find no need to restrain him. Am I wrong?

Your thoughts please!



</question>



<answer from>



Jamie D
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



no way! if it is a park where dogs are allowed to run free without a lesh then no one cares!



Source(s):



me



</answer>



<answer from>



insaneee...
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 979 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Well the whole point of a dog park is for dogs to socialize and run around with each other.



If your Pomeranian gets to the point where he is irritating other dogs and people, then it is your responsibility to remove him, mostly for his own safety.



</answer>



<answer from>



wanda w
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i dont mind at all
my female husky is  young and VERY playful
and she loves playing keep away with other dogs



</answer>



<answer from>



abbyful
Member since: 10 April 2007
Total points: 26465 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Unless it's a dog park where the dogs are *supposed* to be off-leash, I wouldn't be happy about another dog running up to my dog. How am I supposed to know your dog is friendly?

Here's a situation to consider: What if *my* dog was aggressive? What if my dog attacked your dog when it ran up?

For the safety of you dog, and also in general dog-owner etiquette, keep your dog on-leash and ask the owner if it's okay before your dog approaches another dog.
.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lexie
Member since: 05 March 2008
Total points: 492 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i dont mind, i have a sheltie and i think that when a dog runs up to him it is good for him, he makes a new friend and gets better socilied at the same time, and my guy just love other animals..
and i rarely have my dog on a leash too, because he is so well behaved and he also comes back on command.



Source(s):



Proud Owner



</answer>



<answer from>



Ashley B
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



No. It's just to dogs just having fun. I think it healthy for dogs to be social with other dog. I wouldn't mind if your puppy did that.

<answer from>



proud walker
Member since: 19 August 2006
Total points: 19301 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's lovely when dogs play together, but I think people will always worry that maybe their dog will take an irrational dislike to yours give him nip, and then they'd be faced with claims for damages and vet bills. Some dogs can be very 'funny' and attack when they're on a lead and another dog runs up to them. Also, their dog might not be properly socialised, or it might be badly trained and run off with your dog and not come back. So no, I don't think you are wrong, just maybe a little unwise.



Source(s):



being an old cynic.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bethany
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 280 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If your dog is on a leash this should be fine...as long as you are reading the other dogs actions.  If he is reacting in a negative or defensive way, I would restrain your dog and walk away.  If the other dog shows this behavior and you didn't restrain your pooch, they could be irritated.  If you guys aren't in an off-leash dog park, then your dog should never be off-leash no matter how good its recall skills are.  What control do you have if another dog says no and gets defensive?

Either way...I wouldn't be irritated if someone came up to me on leash to play with my dog.  We love meeting new dogs!



</answer>



<answer from>



Bonzie12
Member since: 06 April 2007
Total points: 18644 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



You are asking for trouble allowing your dog to do this.  Even though your dog is super friendly that doesn't mean the dog he is approaching or running up to is, especially with your dog being on the small side.  You never know what reaction another dog is going to have with a strange animal running up to it, friendly or not.  You should keep the dog on leash, and if and when approaching another dog find out first if the dog is friendly and then let them get to know each other.  If some dog would grab your dog and hurt it, the owner of the dog would not be responsible since your dog was off leash.  Not a good idea at all.



</answer>

<question from>



GAVIN ROSSDALE FAN
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why do dogs always......?



stick there heads out of a moving car? i see it all them time and was just curious as to why?? when i do it i can never catch my breath and end up putting my head back in



</question>



<answer from>



Aluka
Member since: 12 February 2008
Total points: 2057 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think it's probably because of all the smells. Fast food, people, other animals, foliage, and anything else that's in the air. That's really the only thing I can think of.

Also, the reason they can do it and you can't, is the way our respiratory systems are set up. Theirs are designed in a way that they can handle the rush of all the air in their faces, where ours isn't. I mean look at the size of a dog's nose and chest. They have larger nasal passages and larger lungs.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



very informative



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



MamaCass
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 292 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



To cool off



</answer>



<answer from>



dmondman
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Could it be that, like people on a motorcycle, they enjoy the feeling of the breeze blowing in their face, the freedom of "going fast"? They probably start out by putting their heads out to smell what's around, and then end up loving the feeling as well as the smells.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr. Ici
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 1729 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dogs can only sweat through their feet, that's why they tend to pant quite a lot.
They stick their head out of a car to cool down.

Did you hear Noel Gallagher talking about this the other week? Very funny!!



</answer>



<answer from>



louisa xx
Member since: 07 July 2007
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My dogs do it, i think they are taking in all the different smells



</answer>

<question from>



Dominique M
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 157 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How long will my dog stay on heat?



My dog just came on heat today and i want to put another dog to her, how long will she still want to mate for?



and also she is a toy poodle and i want to put her to a minature who is a bit smaller then her, will she squat for him or will they just not work together...



</question>



<answer from>



Rayven Wolf - Back In Action
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 473 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Keep her away from ANY intact males. You obviously don't know what you are doing if you want to breed a mini to toy.



Do you know what any of this means in references to your dog and her particular size?
Optigen Testing Results for progressive retinal atrophy
OFA Certification of Hips and Patellas
Yearly Eye Exam for CERF

There are enough poorly bred animals in the world right now. If you aren't going to spend years, yes YEARS learning how to do it right don't do it at all. Breeding is more than male dog and female dog. You need to know about genetics, rates of inheritance her bloodlines his bloodlines.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chihuahua Addict R.I.P. Gigi!
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 11570 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dogs go into heat, usually every 6 months and they stay in heat for 3 weeks! You obviously don't know anything about breeding, and you need to get your dogs fixed. You have no business breeding your dogs. What happens when your dog has complications during whelping (delivery) and you don't know how to handle the complications. I'll tell you! Your female can die, if you don't know what you are doing, which you don't. Is that really a chance you want to take with your dog? Be responsible, and leave breeding to the professionals, who know exactly what they are doing and who are breeding for the right reasons. Again, if you love you dogs at all, you will get them both fixed!



Source(s):



Former Chihuahua Breeder



</answer>

<question from>



Sonia S
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Advice on raising two husky pups from different litters?



]we bought a husky dog puppy at 8 weeks he is now 14 weeks 3 days ago we bought a husky ***** puppy she is 19/20 weeks to keep each other company. They do get get along really well most of the time she seems to know her place but does test him at times, when they play fight some times it gets really noisy growling and such like is this normal? is there anything i can do to strengthen  their friendship any tips or advice would be great thankyou



</question>



<answer from>



Amanda
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 7985 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



It's normal for her to challenge him, and very healthy. Just because he was the first one to join your family does not necessarily mean he will end up being ranked higher than her in the end. Some dogs just aren't interested in, or right for, the #1 spot (or I guess I should say #2, since you should be #1!), and will gladly and happily give it up to another dog. They need to let them work their pecking order out for themselves. The only time you should step in is if they become violent, which is more unlikely than likely.

Play fighting is noisy at my house too. If someone didn't know my dogs, they would probably think they were trying to kill each other just based on the sound alone! Unless your dogs and my dogs are different from the norm, yes, vocal play fights are normal.



They'll naturally grow closer in time. It sounds like they're off to a great start!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jason E
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



dogs always play fight as a way of working out social structure this is normal you may need to get involved if it gets to rough.



</answer>

<question from>
