<question>



Help cane.... collare elettrico...?



CIAO A TUTTI, io ho un cane bastardino di media taglia, ormai sono costretto a tenerlo continuamente legato ad una corda che è collegata ad una passatoia a casa mia (che in ogni caso lo lascia abb libero di muoversi, xò sempre in quei 10 metri) x' se provo a slegrlo lui parte a razzo (non gli sto dietro in scooter a 70 km/h) e si mette a rincorrere tutti (macchine, moto, ciclisti, ecc... una volta ne ha fatto cadere uno) quindi a me dispiace tantissimo lasciarlo legato sempre, ma non posso neanche lasciarlo libero. PERCIO' SE QUALCUNO DI VOI SA INDICARMI DOVE COMPRARE UNO DI QUEI COLLARI CHE RILASCIANO PICCOLI IMPULSI ELETTRICI.
PS: non consigliatemi corsi di addestramento (spesi + di 500€ risultati 0= ha imparato a sedersi a comando quando è legato)



</question>



<additional details>



X TSEFANO: il tipo che ha fatto il corso è uno dimantova che si occupa dell'addestramento dei cani che vengono utilizzati in tv ed è uno dei migliori in italia è il mio cane che è un po troppo anarchico



x malapea: si fa dai 4 a i 6 chilometri di corsa al giorno con me, ma quando torno a casa se non lo lego subito scappa di nuovo



per tutti quelli che mi dicono che sono da denuncia, io la denuncia l'hgo gia presa perche il cane ha fatto cadere un ciclista che si è spaccato il polso...



comunque allìinizio avevo casa che sembrava un campo di cincentramento, tra fili in accia e recinzioni che recintavano tutta casa ma lui scappava lo stesso.



per EMILIANO sul lungo tiene i 40/45 km/h mentre in scatto mi sta dietro fino a 65/70 km/h sul motorino, xò dopo si ferma subito x' è stanco morto.



con il collare a strozzo, mi ha trainato in bici ed ad un certo ritmo x piu di 2 km. nn serve a niente



ULTIMA COSA CHE AGGIUNGO: MOLTI DI VOI MI DICONO PORTALO FUORI DI PIU, INSEGNALI A RIPORTARE GLI OGGETTI (PENSO SIA L'UNICA COSA CHE HA IMPARATO FINORA), DEDICAGLI PIU ATTENZIONI ECC...ECC... MA QUESTE SONO COSE GIA TUTTE PROVATE, IL COLLARE E' VERAMENTE UNA SOLUZIONE ESTREMA XHE DISPIACE UTILIZZARE ANCHE A ME.

PS: IL CANE è LEGATO AD UNA CORDA A SCORRIMENTO CHE GLI PERMETTE DI GIRARE IN QUASI TUTTO IL GIARDINO, MA DI SPAZIO X FARE UN RECINTO NON NE HO!



INFO: IL CANE ESCE REGOLARMENTE OGNI SERA A CORRERE CON ME UN'ORETTA, MA COME GIA DETTO ANCHE APPENA FINITO DI CORRERE, SE NON LO LEGO SUBITO BEVE UN GOCIO D'ACQUA E RIPARTE



X MATTIA: il mio crede di essere il capo branco, infatti appena esce dai luochi che conosce non si muove e mi sta sempre vicino anche se è slegato, ma dove conosce la zona fa quello che vuole: un mio vicino da casa ha un'alano, che tra l'altro quello è il cane piu buono del mondo, ma il mio a forza di entrargli nel giardino a rompegli le palle è riuscito a farsi attaccare anche da lui, rimanendo non poco ferito.



</additional details>



<answer from>



baumail
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 164 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Se posso esprimere una mia opinione, ti dico intanto che il collare elettrico non serve a nulla. Primo, perchè è una cosa tristissima e secondo perchè non è così che il cane capisce come deve comportarsi e cosa non deve fare.
Io credo che tu debba solo dedicargli più tempo e tanta tanta pazienza.
Intanto, prendi un collare a strozzo che vada bene per la sua misura, e portalo in giro al guinzaglio con quello. Ci vuole tempo.. ma imparerà sicuramente come ci si comporta, anche perchè è davvero fastidioso provare a "tirare" con quel collare.
E poi, per abituarlo (o almeno provare) a non scappare, cerca qualche area dog nella tua zona.
Sono "parchi" recintati, dedicati solo esclusivamente ai nostri amici a quattrozampe; puoi sentirti libera di slegarlo e iniziare a provare con lui qualche esercizio di richiamo e obbedienza.
Se hai bisogno di altre info.. contattami. Se siamo in una zona vicina possiamo vederci e vediamo di risolvere qualcosa insieme.

Ciao
Mariaelena 
mariaelena@sosbau.it

**************************************...
Scusa ma non basta certo mettergli su il collare a strozzo e salire in bicicletta per fargli imparare a stare al passo.
Prima di tutto, stare al passo, significa camminare (padrone e cane); non ha senso portarselo dietro in bici se non è capace di andare al guinzaglio. Questa è una cosa che viene dopo!!!!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



GRAZIE

<answer>



Io penso che se supera i 70, non  è un cane ma un ghepardo camuffato.
Detto ciò, il collare elettrico lascialo sullo scaffale del negozio. E' assurda come cosa. Se necessiti di un collare per portarlo in giro allora usa quello a strangolo.
Il fatto che deve per forza stare legato mi pare una stronxata perchè se fai le cose come si deve e vuoi bene al cane come dici, ti applichi di più, voglio dire che se scappa perchè passa o scavalca reti, chiudi i passaggi; se scappa quando apri il cancello, lo leghi, tiri fuori la macchina e quello che è , chiudi il cancello, LO SLEGHI e te ne vai senza che scappi. Più lo lasci legato, più avrà voglia di scappare. Non gode di bella vita il tuo cane, permettimi...



</answer>

<answer from>



geppo
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 2655 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



ciao, da quello che hai scritto si presume tu abbia un pezzetto di terra dove tieni legato il cane.
Il mio consiglio è , visto che hai già speso 500 euro, di spenderne qualcun altro per costruire un'apposito e solido recinto in cui il tuo cane possa muoversi liberamente.
Anche se lo spazio è poco lui se lo farà bastare.
Il collare elettrico è un'inutile violenza, in quanto tu stesso hai detto che se "provi a slegarlo lui parte a razzo" e quindi dovrai utilizzarlo praticamente sempre.
Inoltre non puoi sapere che reazione può provocare a lungo andare un collare elettrico a livello fisico e soprattutto a livello comportamentale.
Inoltre ti faccio presente che i collari elettrici sono "antiabbaio" e non per paralizzare un cane in movimento.
Inoltre dal 2006 c'è un espresso divieto di uso di questi congegni che fanno violenza sui cani, sia con sentenza del tar del lazio sia con apposito divieto , e quindi andresti incontro a sanzioni.
Infine ti faccio presente che il tachimetro del tuo scooter va rivisto in quanto la velocità massima che può raggiungere un cane (in particolare il levriero, che com'è noto è il cane + veloce del mondo) è di circa 60-65 km/h.
Ciao.



</answer>



<answer from>



saddrum
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 1703 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Una domanda forse banale: non hai la possibilità di recintare il giardino o comunque il luogo in cui si trova il cane? In questo modo non dovrà stare attaccato ad una corda di 10 metri, che probabilmente lo rende ancora più nervoso, e non avrà modo di scappare e creare subbuglio per strada...;)



AGGIUNGO, VISTO LA TUA RISPOSTA: esistono sistemi di recinzione a prova di denti! E poi fissala a terra con il cemento, in modo che non possa scappare da sotto. Io ho fatto così!



</answer>

<answer>



guarda che il collare elettrico bisogna saperlo usare sai, oltre al fatto che è proibito...se con 500 euro e un addestratore "bravo" non sei riuscito a trovare un metodo per calmare il tuo cane, allora stai andando incontro allo sfacelo più totale con un collare elettrico. devi solo dare più attenzione al cane...se lo porti fuori e poi lo lasci legato lui troverà dei passatempi. non ti considera come il suo capobranco! ti suggerirei intanto di costruire un bel recinto, che non gli lasci vie di fuga, e abbastanza grande, dove tenerlo. poi, visto che gli piace correre ed a quanto dici ha un forte istinto alla predazione, fallo giocare, tiragli la pallina e insegnali a riportartela (ci sono molti libri di addestramento x cani e il riporto è facile e divertente), poi insegnagli a tornare, ovviamente senza stressarlo più di quello che è già! insomma distrailo! se è un cane vivace non dovrebbe trascurare troppo le possibilità di correre e muoversi! se poi, mentre provi a lasciarlo libero, usi una lunga corda attaccata al collare e lasciata x terra, più lunga a seconda di quanto corre ed è veloce il cane, che ti permetta di riprenderlo, insieme a dei bocconcini, che sono più convincenti del collare elettrico, (che in più costituisce un rinforzo negativo se usato male), sarà più facile convincerlo a tornare! se ti sei preso un cane, si presuppone che tu abbia del tempo da dedicargli, quindi mettiti sotto e fagli vedere che è meglio se sta a casa, e non a correre dietro alla gente! in bocca al lupo e ricordati che il collare elettrico non serve a NIENTE! auguri! ^.^

se hai bisogno di consigli: claudia_wgoku@yahoo.it



</answer>



<answer from>



paoletta
Member since: 05 December 2007
Total points: 3488 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



ho cominciato su answer proprio chiedendo come potevo fare collla mia meticciona "frascona"; a causa di fastidiosi vicini oltre all'indole, abbaiava e saltava addosso alle persone, soprattutto in bici, in moto o sui pattini (pensa che passeggiate tranquille mi facevo...)
c'è voluto un anno intero, ma le cose vanno molto meglio...
ora io non so che origine abbia il tuo rapporto col cane, o come tu lo viva, ma per me il fattore scatenante è stato attirare prima continuamente la sua attenzione, poi in modi e appuntamenti ben precisi; e farle ignorare ciò che accade al di fuori di "noi due" e del recinto; la coinvolgo continuamente, nel correre in giardino fino alla stanchezza, passeggiare utilizzando guinzaglio lungo 5 mt. e collare a strozzo che le da' l'idea di libertà di movimento ma posso sempre "strizzarlo" a dovere quando non bastano i comandi vocali; quando sono a casa entra con me, ha il suo "divano"che condividiamo soprattutto la sera per le coccole, il suo angolino in cucina, la cesta dei suoi giochi che usa a piacimento con una pezza che usa a mo' di "ciuccio"e il divieto di entrare in camera salvo comando.



è diventata talmente dipendente da questi momenti di convivenza affettuosa che non conosceva e non voleva conoscere, al punto che mi aspetta davanti la porta al mattino in attesa di fare i bisogni in giardino e poi partire in passeggiata! iniziamo a ricevere gente con lei ancora legata ma fintamente ad una lampada (che potrebbe portar via se solo volesse) e sta lì che aspetta paziente il suo turno di attenzioni.
ancora a volte ha quegli scatti di "matto" che punta i motorini o le persone, ma posso riuscire a prevederla.
in inverno cominceremo ad uscire fra la gente (che gira di meno) così per l'estate spero saremo pronte a partire per le vacanze assieme...
una cosa è certa: il collare ad impulsi non avrebbe effetto; quando sono così sensibili (ché non sono affatto atteggiamenti da stupidi!) imparano presto la differenza fra l'indossarlo e non, la soluzione sarebbe lasciarlo "sempre", e non va bene...
il cane deve imparare che la sua libertà è "con te" e non lontano da te.



</answer>

<answer>



Animal shelters in Melbourne area



Australian Animal Protection Society
Corner Chapel & Homeleigh Roads, Keysborough
Telephone (03) 9798 8044 / (03) 9798 8415



Blue Cross Animal Society
Lot 9 Homestead Road, Wonga Park
Telephone (03) 9722 1265



Cat Protection Society
200 Elder Street, Greensborough
Telephone (03) 9434 7155 / (03) 9434 7255



Geelong Animal Welfare Society
Drysdale Road, Moolap
Telephone (03) 5248 2091
Emergency ambulance, phone (03) 5221 5122
Website: www.gaws.org.au



Lord Smith Animal Hospital
24 Villiers Street, North Melbourne
Telephone (03) 9328 3021 / (03) 9328 3128 / (03) 9328 3589
Fax (03) 9329 5347



Lost Dogs Home & Cat Shelter
2 Gracie Street, North Melbourne
Telephone (03) 9329 2755
Lost & Found - 24 hour service (03) 9329 9493
After-hours emergency ambulance  (03) 9625 5000 Pager #35945
Fax: (03) 9326 5293
Website:  www.lostdogs.com.au - You can check for lost or found animals, and submit your lost or found animals. There is also a Free Pet Registration ID tag service to help you get your pooch or moggie back.



Peninsula Animal Aid
Corner Smiths Road & Robinson Lane, Pearcedale
Telephone (03) 5978 6706 / (03) 5978 6811



Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA)
Corner Burwood Highway & Middleborough Road, East Burwood
Telephone (03) 9224 2222. After-hours emergency, (03) 9888 9822.  Website:  www.rspcavic.org



Save A Dog Scheme (SADS)
Save-A-Dog is an entirely non-profit Organisation, which exists to save dogs of good temperament from being killed when their time has expired at dog pounds and animal shelters.
293 Tooronga Road, Malvern (Melways Ref 59:E5)
Telphone: (03) 9885 1188 or Mobile: 0418 389 810
Website:  www.saveadog.org.au



Victorian Animal Aid Trust (VAAT)
35 Killara Rd, Coldstream 3770
Telephone (03) 9739 0300



</answer>

<question from>



dorothy s
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 9183 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</question from>



<question>



Do any of the "askers" do "health checks" on a regular basis?



I know that there are hundreds of “answerers” who are keen on dog training. I have always trained my dogs; I think that it’s vital and kind to be able to communicate with them.

Can you imagine adopting a child from a foreign country who does not understand your language? that’s what its like for a puppy who is not trained. Nevertheless I understand that that there are owner who don’t train their dogs who still love and care for them. (I hate saying owners; it makes it sound like our dogs are our slaves).

I have read a number of questions from people whose dogs are injured or they have a problem. The owner then becomes concerned that their dog will not allow them to touch them. The vet also has a hell of a problem because the dog has to be muzzled before it can be examined.

Please, will those of you who do not want to train your dogs, start doing a “health check”. Look into your dogs ears, under its tail, touch its feet and feel it all over for lumps and bumps. Do this on a regular basis and your dog will not object when this becomes vital.

My question is. Why do kind and caring owners wait until there dog has a problem and then wonder why their dog objects to being touched? Do they also wonder why their sick dog has to be muzzled at the vets?



</question>



<additional details>



Mama, you would need less preparation for the unexpected if you anticipated your dogs problems.



W, If you don't understand the question, don't answer.



Lilley H, our dogs don't need trainers, they just need us. Everyone should learn how to comminicate and help their dog. I think that you are doing this.



Those of you who have answered, care for your dogs. Lets hope that there are people out there who have not answered my question,  will look at my question and  consider regular "heath checks" and that they can cope with their dogs when the need arises without having to use restraint and muzzles.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Mama
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 6471 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't really understand what you're saying. A kind and loving owner would train their dog. Period.

And my dog is as sweet as any animal I've ever met, but **I** have requested he be muzzled on occasion, just in case. For example: when the vet clips his nails.

He's never tried to bite, but in the off chance he should, I want to know he can't. I also don't like to take him into the vet's office unless any kids in the waiting room are sitting down because he gets so nervous when he goes there (he doesn't like shots).

It's our responsibility as pet-owners to train to the best of our and the dog's ability and then to be prepared for the unexpected. No matter what.



</answer>



<answer from>



Marina
Member since: 28 October 2007
Total points: 29665 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think this is necessarily fair. I touch my dog all over and do routine physical exams on him...he is a show dog and he gets handled by judges as well. When he has an ear infection however, and it comes time to go to the Vet, he needs a muzzle. When a dog is in pain, it may not react the way it typically would when mom is giving him a friendly check up exam at home. My Mastiff is really sweet with a great temperament, but he currently has an ear infection and is in a lot of pain. He needed to be muzzled as a precaution at the Vet because he was NOT having his ear touched.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ms. Presley
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 2706 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Women's Health



</answer from>



<answer>



My dogs love going to the vet they run right in get excited and never yelp bite or struggle. My english has been through some pain and surgery and never has shown any aggression.



I do health checks everyday with my pups.
I constantly play with my dogs ears and clean them out and also play with their paws by separating them and moving the nail up and down and yes i give my dogs mini massages so they pretty much are used to being touched every where and have absolutely no problems when going to the vet or simply having their nails clipped.

I always am aware when something looks weird or feels different on my dogs.
Not sure why all dog owners don't take a little time out of the day to do this.

A good way to get your dog to not fear the vet is just to drive him/her there when they have no appointment and nothing is wrong and bring them in the vet with treats...treat them in there and then leave and treat them when you leave. It will put a good vibe in the dogs head that the vet is not all pain and misery. You can call your vet ahead of time and they can come out and greet the dog and make them feel comfy.
My mom had to do this with her american bulldog for a month and now he's fine.



</answer>



<answer from>



Greyhoun...

Total points: 3190 (Level 4)

<answer>



These are the people who don't train their dogs --- they don't socialize them with people or other animals.  Some of them want "one owner dogs" - they don't want their dogs to like other people.

Most also do not take them to the groomers or vet on a regular basis.



The dogs aren't used to being handled.



It's sad to see dogs like this - if they ever end up in a shelter - they will be put down if the owners don't claim them, or if they surrender them.

It is a death sentence for the dog.

<answer>



These are also the people who "can't" brush their dogs, or cut their nails, or clean their ears, because "he won't let me".  Sometimes they're afraid if they do their dogs will hate them (yes, they've told me that)!  Or they're afraid of being bitten, or they just hate to see little Fifi upset.

All of my dogs are accustomed to being handled, everywhere, by me and by other people.  I can hold their feet, look in their ears, open their mouths etc.  I'm like the Borg - resistance is futile!

EDIT: I don't think Dorothy is asking about dogs that are seriously in pain but rather dogs that in normal circumstances won't allow an examination by the vet, won't allow you to give medicine etc.

FWIW, I've brought dogs in to the vet that WERE in pain, and they still trusted me enough not to bite.  As I said in an earlier question, one of my dogs lay quietly on the table while the vet stitched her up without anesthetic or freezing - because I told her to.

Some dogs are just jumpy around other dogs, my Ellie is 5 now, and I love her to bits and around people she is lovely.

<answer from>
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 4565 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi Dorothy

I agree with you training is vital to a happy dog it also increases the bond you have with your dog, and you both get to know each other well. Well we are dog owners, (to differentiate between dog keepers, who keep dogs but do not put in the care and effort to be called an owner), but I see my relationship with my dogs as a partnership, I am the pack leader and they are my very important but junior partners, absolutely not slaves they get paid with reward based training.



All my dogs get a routine vet health check every six months. Every day they are groomed and have their eyes, ears and teeth cleaned. They also have lots of stroking and cuddles. They also have lots of cuddles when they go to the vet.

I have seen dogs having to be muzzled at the vets and I have heard owners say they cannot do ear drops or give tablets etc because the dog will not allow them too. I suspect these are the people you were thinking of.



As usual you are giving another good piece of advice to ensure dogs will allow handling of all areas of their bodies before the need arises, it is better to introduce handling to a healthy dog than attempt to handle a sick dog who is not used to handling.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



My neighbours dog is ruining my life?



hi just wondering if i could get some help. my neighbour has 2 staff bull terriers, about 2-3 months ago the 2 dogs chewed part of my fence panel and got into my garden and killed my kitten (in front of my 3 year old son and 1 year old son) my father in law came round to collect the kitten to bury it as my wife and i were very upset about what had happened. When caring the cat out he saw my neighbour to which he didn't seem to bothered about his dogs had done. A few days later my wife tried to talk to my neighbour about his dogs to which he gave my wife some verbal abuse, i phoned my local council and spoke to the dog warden who said that there wasn't much that they could do. So i replaced some of the old fence panels with new ones and then stapled some dog fencing to the fence to stop them getting through , then yesterday they have bitten another part of my fence and it wont be long until they brake a bigger hole to gain access to my garden. Also i should mention that every time my boys go out to play the dogs bark at my kids. So i have been round to try and talk to my neighbours about whats happened to get them to do something but no joy as yet either there not in or they don't want to answer the door. I don't mind replacing the broken fence but im scared that one day they will try to attack my family, Please help if possible what can i do



</question>



<answer from>



taxed till i die,
Member since: 27 June 2006

<answer>

Then, get photos of the dogs chewing the fence.  This may take a little time, but it will be worth it.



Also, document the incident with the cat.

Then talk with your authorities again, and bring copies of everything you have.  Every time there is an incident, report it, both to the police and to the animal control folks.

It may take a while, but there should be some resolution.



</answer>

<answer>



Yet more idiotic Staffie owners giving the breed a bad name, honestly, most Staffies when trained right are very good dogs.

To answer your question, refer everything to your local police.
From now on, gather as much evidence as you can, including photographs, dates + times.



Be very careful with your children playing outside as well, it isn't fair you have to live in fear. 
Also, if you live in a council house, or more specifically, your neighbour does, the council can actually evict a tenant for having an "unruly" dog.



Keep ringing authorities - council + police. Unfortunately, in England you have to keep nagging them for them to actually do something.

<answer from>



Jojo
Member since: 11 July 2007
Total points: 610 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is nothing wrong in taking a pup of 7 weeks from its mother especially if it has been weaned properly. I had both my gsd`s at 6 weeks old and NO problems. In fact between 6-7 weeks old they settle into a new environment faster than at 8 weeks. But Breeders are now not supposed to sell pups under 8 weeks old. A lot of pups decline to eat much for the first few days at their new home and often get the runs. At least he is eating something and minced chicken is good. Try a little boiled rice mixed in with the chicken. If he still has the runs after 24 hours it would be wise to have him checked over by a vet as it may be something more serious than just a change of environment. Good Luck.



</answer>

Sasha Woo Woo♫♪

<question from>



A For Adorable
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 380 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How can I make my puppy sleep on her basket?



My dog Blossom is roughly 7 months now (she was born on the 2nd of January) And she has always slept on my bed or my mums and I now want her to sleep on her basket. Now I know I should have started that a long time ago, but there is no point telling me that now. So just tell me how I can get her to sleep on her basket-cushion. No point telling me what I SHOULD have done because it'll be no help now. Should I put her on lead and tie it to the banisters for the first few nights so she'll get used to it and won't just run into a room in the night? The hall light is on and its all ways warm and her cushion-basket is very comfy.

So... how should I get her to sleep on her basket?



</question>



<additional details>



Ok, just a few things to make it more clear. My kitchen doesn't have a door, my mums door is easily pushed open and my mum has to  get up at 6:00 am so if i was to not let her in it would have to be in a seperate room with her lead on earlier to bed then everyone else as she can open doors easily and whinges for quite a while.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Lead her into her basket a lot and give her a treat when she does that way she'll learn that its a good thing. Then put a sock of yours in her basket so she does have that scent of you. Give her anything that will make her comfy like something really soft to lay on and water access.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



You just have to shut the doors, put up with some whinging, and She'll soon learn what's what.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I am not sure about the basket part, but PLEASE don't attach her lead to the banisters. Dogs hang themselves that way (if she slips through the railings or slips down the stairs.) Best of luck on training her!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yoiks, do not tie this baby to the banisters.  Dogs have been known to hang themselves this way!!!  Suggest, if she's to stay on the landing, you baby-gate the top of the stairs, (or any other room that can't have the door shut for that matter) put her basket outside one of the doors (but don't fall over it in the night!!), shut the doors, all of them, and turn off the light.  She doesn't need the light.  She needs a familiar warm place and if the one she's now unfortunately used to is to be denied her, you need to make her as comfortable as possible in another.  Good luck because you have unwittingly created a MONSTER.  I know, I did it with my first, and second Basset, and that's where they stayed - for life!!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

<answer>



If she's used to sleeping with you, the basket is a pretty poor substitute in her little mind, she must feel like she's being punished!  (Feel guilty yet?)  Try putting something that smells like you in the basket with her, that way she won't feel quite so alone.  Get her a stuffed animal - yes, dogs can have them, just make sure it doesn't have a plastic nose or eyes that can be chewed off and swallowed.  Play with the dog and the stuffed toy so that the toy smells like you, too - this is comforting to the pup and may make her more willing to stay in her own bed.



</answer>

<answer from>



Tulip
Member since: 11 February 2008
Total points: 3400 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Amendments to Tail Docking Laws in Victoria

RSPCA Victoria welcomes legislative amendments currently before the Victorian parliament to tighten existing laws around the cruel and unnecessary practice of docking a dog's tail.

The existing laws have been in place since 2004, however the amendments further protects dogs from this cruel practice.

After many years of submissions and pleadings by the RSPCA and Australian Veterinary Association, the government agreed to ban the cosmetic tail docking of dogs from April 2004. In a national campaign launched in December 2000, the RSPCA described dogs with docked tails as ‘fashion victims’.

The new legislation is called the Animals Legislation Amendment [Animal Care] Bill 2007 and inserts a new section into the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act 1986.

The new section will make it an offence for a person in charge of an animal to allow a prohibited procedure [tail docking and debarking] to be carried out on the animal.

It will also make it an offence to show or exhibit or allow another person to show or exhibit an animal on which a prohibited procedure has been carried out.

Tail docking is not a written requirement for any breed and was only done as a matter of tradition and fashion.

Dogs being shown or exhibited will all have their tails intact. As more dogs of docked breeds will be shown or exhibited with tails, the community and show judges acceptance of tails will improve with time. 
http://www.rspcavic.org/campaigns_news/c...

National ban on cosmetic tail docking of dogs!

The RSPCA believes that cosmetic tail docking is a painful and totally unnecessary tradition and had long campaigned for ban on this cruel practice. In October 2003 the RSPCA’s call was heeded when the Primary Industries Ministerial Council agreed to implement a nationally coordinated ban on routine tail docking for non-therapeutic (cosmetic) reasons. The ban came into force nationally on 1 April 2004. Since that date it is illegal to dock dogs’ tails anywhere in Australia unless there is a medical reason behind the operation. Only a qualified veterinarian is permitted to carry out the surgery, in accordance with state and territory legislation.

Why is the RSPCA opposed to the cosmetic tail docking of dogs?

Puppies' tails are docked at around 2-5 days of age using a pair of scissors or a very tight rubber band. Until the national ban was implemented in April 2004 there were many areas in Australia tail docking did not have to be carried out by a veterinary surgeon - anyone classed as an 'experienced breeder' could cut off their puppies' tails themselves. No anaesthetic was usually used even though the cut goes through highly sensitive nerves. Many veterinarians oppose the procedure on the grounds that it is 'cruel, painful and unnecessary’.

Tail docking is painful

Advocates of tail docking claim that it does not cause pain or discomfort, as the nervous system of puppies is not fully developed. This is not the case. The basic nervous system of a dog is fully developed at birth and the available evidence indicates that puppies have similar, if not increased, sensitivity to pain as adult dogs. Docking a puppy's tail involves cutting through muscles, tendons, up to seven pairs of highly sensitive nerves and severing bone and cartilage connections. Tail docking is usually carried out without any anaesthesia. Puppies give repeated intense shrieking vocalisations the moment the tail is cut off and during stitching of the wound, indicating that they experience substantial pain. Inflammation and damage to the tissues also cause ongoing pain while the wound heals.

Is it legal in other countries?

Cosmetic tail docking has also been banned in a number of countries including Sweden, Norway, the Netherlands, Finland, Germany and Denmark. Several other European countries including Cyprus, Greece, Luxembourg, Switzerland, and Austria have also ratified a European Convention that prohibits the cosmetic docking of tails. In the United Kingdom tail docking can only be carried out by a registered veterinary surgeon. The practice is opposed by the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons which describes it as an 'unacceptable mutilation'.

A tradition of pain

There are over 70 breeds of dog that traditionally have their tails cut off a few days after birth. Many people think that dogs of docked breeds, which include Dobermans, Rottweilers, most terriers, spaniels, pointers and other gun dogs, are born with short tails - this is not true! The reason some breeds and not others are docked is simply because of the fashion set for that particular breed.

There are a rare few dogs of specific breed that may be born with a naturally short tail; some examples may be the Stumpy-tailed Cattledog, Boston Terrier or French Bulldog.

Furthermore, each breed had an arbitrary standard for where the tail should be cut off. These absurd rules include 'just



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



It's only illegal in the UK.

People think it's cruel, and unnecessary. Maybe now--with so many working dogs living in suburban or city enviornments.

However, docking is done at an age where the puppy can feel very little pain, and remembers it not at all. And it's necessary on working dogs where their tail may get caught or injured in their line of work.

Having no tail is far better than having a broken tail, believe me.

Owner of a docked Aussie.

<answer>



In countries which respect the welfare of animals it has been recognised that tail docking and ear cropping are being carried out purely for cosmetic reasons - i.e. to alter the way a dog looks, which is considered to be inhumane.

Tail docking may still be carried out by a Vet for medical reasons.  Most Vets are against tail docking and ear cropping as they recognise that it benefits the owner, not the dog and is therefore compromising the animal's welfare.

I applaud the foreward thinking in these countries.

Ainawgsd:  There may be a case for a few dogs to be docked but you have to admit that the majority of dogs in the docked breeds are pets and not working dogs and have no danger of injuring their tails.  I don't see why we should dock all the pups for the sake of a few.  In the past, many pups have had their tails docked in the backyard by their breeder and not under sterile conditions, not using anaesthetic, all to save some money.  This is an undeniable fact.  In addition, working dogs hurt their feet, legs, etc.  Should we start removing these too in advance in case of injuries?

As for circumcision - just because this was done in the past does not make it a good and necessary procedure.  I am against circumcision, in fact when my son was born my obstetrician told me in no uncertain terms that he would not carry out that procedure and if I and my husband wanted it done we would have to find another doctor to do it.  It wasn't an issue for me.  There are less and less doctors willing to carry out this invasive procedure as well.

Just because it is legal in America does not make tail docking a justifiable practice.  America is not the conscience of the world, thank God because if it was this world would really be screwed.

Also, just because a puppy heals from the operation does not make a necessary operation in the first place.



We should all respect animal welfare and learn to love our animals the way they were born.  Human beings are so warped in their efforts to adapt nature to their idea of perfection.



</answer>



<answer from>



ainawgsd
Member since: 28 March 2007
Total points: 10083 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Because people who have never owned working dogs doing jobs that really do put a dog's tail in severe danger of being broken deemed it an "unnecessary" and cruel aesthetic procedure.  Sadly, in areas where tail docking has been banned many working dogs must then undergo the pain of breaking a tail, the pain of waiting and waiting for the tail to heal (and being re-injured), and the eventual pain of having the tail amputated.  Done properly it is not cruel and is FAR less traumatic for the dog than a broken tail and amputation done later in life.  I don't doubt that it is somewhat painful for the puppies, but there is no evidence that it is painful for a prolonged period of time (most puppies seem to have totally forgotten it within minutes).  It's like a circumcision (they do that without any kind of anesthesia either)...and I don't know any circumcised men who were horribly and irreversibly scarred by that procedure.



</answer>



<answer from>



larryyin...
Member since: 20 February 2006
Total points: 1438 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's perfectly legal (in the US) and doesn't hurt the dog.  It's about the equivalent of a baby boy's circumcision as it is done before there are even developed nerves in the tail.  Fellas, how many of you remember that excruciating pain from your first days on Earth?  There are two forms of docking.  One is to basically just cut it off.  The other, is a technique called banding which restricts blood flow and the tail dies and falls off.  The banding is said to create a more "muffin" type and is usually regarded to be better looking.

As a proud doberman owner, we have both of ours docked.  Doberman (the man who is the namesake of the dogs) wanted a sleek look for the dog.  However, this actually does serve a purpose in this breed.  Doberman tails are extremely slender and prone to fracture.



When they get excited they wag them very fast and all over the place.  If that tail were to strike a fixed object such as a table leg or even a couch, the tail could essentially break.  Which do you think is more painful for a dog?

There isn't much that gets under my skin more than people who complain about tail docking as they are usually people who don't take the time to research the Pros and Cons of the procedure.



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 4565 (Level 4)

<answer from>



chygyrl2
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



As a 8 time Boxer owner I can tell you the reasons for cropping and docking.
Boxers have very strong necks and very thin ears. When they shake their heads, the force they use causes the blood vessels in the ears to rupture causing painful and expensive to fix hematomas. If the ears are not cropped, the only way to fix the hematoma is to put shunts and drains in the dogs ears. Other breeds known for their powerful necks are Pit bull terriers, Mastiffs, Great Danes. I have had both cropped and uncropped dogs, and the uncropped dogs almost always ruptured the blood vessels in their ears, resulting in long, expensive recuperation. As for the docking, most boxers are born with "rat tails", no hair at the end of their tails. This is from hundreds of generations of breeding. Thus, instead of keeping the hairless rat tails, they are usually cut or "docked". Also Boxers, Pit bulls, Mastiffs and Great Danes were once fighting breeds. Docking and cropping cut down on body parts available for injury. 
Most people think this is a purely aesthetic issue. But, as an owner of one of the breeds that is regularly docked and cropped, I can tell you, it does serve a purpose.



</answer>



<answer from>



dumbo
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 14157 (Level 6)



</answer from>

I think it is a good thing it has stopped. After all the tail is part of the spine and it is there for balance, wagging and flicking insects in some cases.

</answer>



<answer from>



Orange
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 555 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can still legally dock working dogs if you find a vet that will do it and you can prove that the pups will be used for working. It definitely has it's benefits for working dogs. The dogs that go scrambling through brambles having their tails sliced to shreads would tell you if they could.

For pets and show dogs it's illegal now and a good thing too, it's completely cosmetic and unnecessary for these dogs.

For those who think it is painless, I was a vet nurse for years and had to hold pups being docked at just a few days old (when it was still legal) and believe me when I say they feel it. They wriggle wildly and yelp out in pain and squeal for a bit too. They do very often go to sleep afterwards but I have to say that I might pass out with the pain of it, if that was me. Cutting through a tail where the nerves ARE fully developed is not the same as circumcision, which is just a flap of skin as opposed to bone, cartilage etc thats about as similar as chopping your finger off and piercing your ears.



Source(s):



Qualified vet nurse



</answer>

<question from>



KATE P

Total points: 118 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Puppy barking at the cat!! ?



My 8 wk old GSD puppy keeps barking at my cat! Any tips on how to stop this??
The cat does tell him off if he gets too close, but just gives him 'evils' when he barks!



</question>



<answer from>

<answer>



Time is pretty much the best solution. They will eventually get to know one another. The cat is protecting his turf, and the dog will learn not to mess with him. Just make sure you don't isolate out your cat for the new puppy, he will feel sad and possibly act out.



</answer>

<answer>



You do understand that dogs & cats don't usually get along. Unless they have been together living in the same house, since they were BOTH born. It's normal for your puppy to get defensive. They are both a little weirded out especially your cat - having a new pet in the house. Give it time, keep them away from eachother when your not around, and when you are let them play... but watch out don't let them fight. Sooner or later they will get along i'm sure.

:]



</answer>

<answer>



I have dealt with this before...

Use a spray bottle every time the puppy barks at the cat.

Or eventually get a citronella bark collar.  It simply sprays citronella at the dog every time it barks.  Perfectly harmless...dogs just can't stand the smell of citronella.

You can get one at Petco or Amazon.

Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



He's excited and wants to play. We have a dog, who was once a puppy, and he barked at all three cats. If he got too close, he got a swat on the nose. He doesn't bark at them anymore (except for one that keeps hidden and he barks at her just like he did a year ago).  He will learn where he is in the pecking order, even when he outweighs the cat in a few months. Dont try to stop it....let him outgrow it.



</answer>

<answer>



I had this exact problem when I first got my dog (I had my cat first).
First it started with the dog bullying the cat, and once the cat got sick of it, he started bullying the dog.

Time will heal it, whether or not they ever get along... they will eventually get to know and learn to live with each other.

The way I got around it was just giving each a little telling off if they start with each other (no punishments or anything) just a small telling off to let them know you're not going to allow it.  Just remember to make sure your cat gets plenty of attention so it doesn't start getting jealous of the puppy (I know it's stating the obvious) the last thing you need is the cat getting jealous lol)



</answer>



<answer from>



LittleMi...
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 134 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to establish yourself as the pack leader, and owner of the cat.  If the puppy is paying attention to the cat (even before he barks), you need to correct him.  Do this by jabbing him and making a sound.  Choose a sound that you can use consistently , and eventually you wont need to jab him, only make the sound.  It is really important that you correct him at the same level as he offends.  So, if he just looks at the cat, a small correction, but if he barks, a much larger correction.
It is really important that you take care of this problem now, before the puppy becomes a much larger/louder problem.
If you get the national geographic channel, you should tune in for The Dog Whisperer.  Is sounds corny, but it really is an informative and helpful show.



</answer>



<answer from>



pierced_...
Member since: 13 October 2007
Total points: 15121 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Barking is a very normal way for puppies and dogs to communicate.



To deal with the issue you first need to figure out why he barks at the cat. Is it for attention, is it territorial, or could it be threat?



Here are a few sites with training tips to help you stop this behaviour..figure out which one will work best for you.

http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pag...

http://www.veterinarypartner.com/Content...



</answer>



<answer from>



kaththea s
Member since: 14 July 2006
Total points: 2454 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Puppies bark, just like children yell.  That's nature.  Your only realiable option would be to silence train him, which ain't all that easy with pups, although young is the best time to teach it.

He would also probably like to assert his dominance, which is mostly problematic in sharing a house with a cat.  So long as the pup doesn't do damage to the cat, you should just live with it.  They'll find an arrangement that works for them, given time. Particularly if the feline is mature, the pup won't get hurt, but he will find his place in your family hierarchy, which is essential to his mental health and happiness, anyway..



</answer>

<question>



Cocker spaniels help?



do you think a 3 year old cocker spaniel will be friendly to another cocker spaniel. because we have a three year old cocker and my daughter would like another cocker pup for xmas?



</question>



<additional details>



the new pup will be male as the cocker we have now.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Natasha T
Member since: 24 January 2008
Total points: 279 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



if it friendly towards other dogs then their is no reason y it wont get on with another cocker, but if they r both uncut males u could have a problem on ur hands, also like people not everyone can get on with everyone all of the time, but i think it should be fine. good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Sarah S
Member since: 05 May 2008
Total points: 414 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'd say it depends a lot on how often the dog has been socialized.  If he rarely gets to see other dogs, it might be a problem.  If, however, he frequently goes for romps in the park or gets to run around an off-leash dog park, you'll probably be fine!

Basically I'd test his reaction to other dogs before investing in a new dog.  and keep in mind they tend to act differently on a leash than they would off their leash!  Our cocker sometimes growls at other dogs on walks, but is super-friendly in the dog park with no leash.



Source(s):



fellow Cocker Spaniel owner!



</answer>

<answer>



The answer is in socialization, any dog needs both human and dog socialization. If you have not done this, do it before you introduce another dog. You can introduce the baby slowly and with supervision always.  If your 3 yr old has not had interaction you need to be so careful. If your 3 yr old does not accept the pup then make sure the breeder will take the baby back.

<question>



Fur Shedding on a Cavalier King Charles Spaniel?



My Cavalier King Charles Spaniel sheds a lot of fur. We brush him every day but were advised that they shouldn't have their fur cut ideally.
How can I stop him shedding as much?



</question>



<answer from>



xxrsm
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 322 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi

I've grown up around dogs and there is nothing you can do



It depends on the weather and what time of year and stuff like that actually if you stop brushing him every day that might help they don't need to be brushed every day I have 18 German Shepard's some are long coats and I never brush them because they don't need it oh and I have a American cocker and I brush her once a week and none of them shed there fur much



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



kristend...
Member since: 10 June 2006
Total points: 1368 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's the time of year for them to be shedding. However, sometimes excess shedding is a sign of poor nutrition. Try feeding a better quality food, and not the grocery store brands(IAMS, Purina, Eukanuba,etc).



</answer>



<answer from>



Jean O
Member since: 28 January 2007
Total points: 2827 (Level 4)

<answer>



I had three dogs at one time and they seemed to produce less hair than my current cavalier.  When he has his summer cut there is less on the carpet.  His ears and paws are trimmed on a regular basis but his body is trimmedd only in May.



</answer>

I worked at a vet's office for 5 years and these tools came out towards the end of my employment and were literally flying off the shelves!  They are used in vet's office, grooming shops, etc.  Every person I talked to ranted and raved about this product..and several people that I worked with took one home and were amazed how well it really does work. I think it would be worth if for you to check it out and watch the video.

http://www.furminator.com/

<question from>



littlelo...
Member since: 19 June 2008

</question from>



<question>



My dog won't pee any suggestions?



ok here is the situation.  i live in an apartment and have to walk our dogs for them to pee (leaving them outside is not an option). the last time my dog went to the bathroom was a little over 8 hours ago at 5:30 PM (it is now almost 1:30 AM).  since then i have taken them out 3 times (one dog went potty the other did not).  we have had 2 walks that were over an hour long.  i have even gone to sleep for a while and set the alarm to wake up and take her for a walk which was just now that lasted for over an hour with no luck.  i can't stay up all night but if she goes until morning without peeing it could be bad for her.  i have to get up to go to work in the morning...i can't call in because of this but if i get no sleep then i won't be any good at work much less to be driving on the road.  any suggestions on making her pee without stressing her and me out?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Is this a puppy? Puppies generally cannot go 8 hours without peeing which means there's probably a more serious problem going on and you may need to contact the vet. It could be a bladder problem. If it's an older dog, it could hold its bladder throughout the night and should be ok until morning. If not, and she has an accident, you'll just have to think of it as that...an accident.

Just make sure she hasn't forgotten the routine to insure the accidents don't happen all the time. She could just be going through a rough patch. Just make sure she doesn't have any access to water right now, and maybe crate her...and she probably shouldn't drink after 8 or 9 in the future, if it's not like that already.



</answer>

<question>



At what point does an animal have a "personality"?



For instance, many say their dogs have personality, because they have very unique behaviors.

My guess is animals tend to have "more" personality if they have a high capacity of responding to their environment or surroundings.

ie: rodents may have "less personality" because they cannot respond to as many cues as dogs can, such as in the case of training them. Some animals respond to presence of food. They sleep, eat, relieve themselves, and produce young--thats it.

Though I may be wrong. This thought just came to mind. What do you think?

Thanks for your answers!



</question>



<additional details>



"chillama" good answer :) I'm curious though...what about ants? lol.



"tassa3" I personally believe humans are no "better" than animals too. Just makes me wonder, what constitutes "personality"...especially in animals? :) thank u for answering!



</additional details>



<answer from>



chillama...
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 720 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, everything has personality, even my old grandfather clock.  It's how MUCH personality that draws attention.

The old family dog in the corner doesn't draw attention because his personality may be drab and snappy, curled up in a ball asleep 3/4ths of the day.  The puppy would have 'more' personality because, well, look at it!  It's cute, it jumps around, wants to be played with, and is all around obnoxious to get you to look at it.

By the by, a fun fact about rodent persona.  Rats are ticklish!  They did some animal testing on behavior and personality a while back (nothing abusive) and found that rats with play time and regular interaction were quite similar to dogs in their responses.  They talked, played, chased balls, ate communally, and even LAUGHED when the scientist tickled them.  It was cute!

ADD:  Ants are capable of learning, and their behaviors will vary from ant to ant.  They also communicate though touching and scent.  Little buggers BITE too!  Never said they had a complicated personality or a good one though.  :P



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



Forest Basenji
Member since: 10 October 2007
Total points: 7176 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Certain animals, like dogs and cats, are naturally more social and will engage with humans on a more complex level than other animals.



I think you're right, the more capacity an animal has to respond to people and surroundings, the more humans percieve that the animal has a "personality".  Dogs are social creatures to begin with, and will seek out human interaction.  Plus they have been selectively bred to serve all sorts of functions, from companion to working partner.  When an animal is an integral and useful part of a humans' life, we are more likely to relate to them on "our" level (to a point) and recognize distinct personality traits in them.



Other animals commonly kept as pets, perhaps didn't originate from social animals.  Or, they were never originally domesticated as a companion or working partner, but rather as a source of food.  Rabbits, chickens, cows, pigs, sheep, etc.  Someone who keeps these animals as a "pet" and who actually spends time observing their behaviors and their nuances WILL see a set of particular and unique behavior patterns in that animal.  No two animals are totally alike in behavior, preferences and reactions to stimulus.  However, with these less "social" animals, or perhaps in less "developed" animals, it takes a bit more attention to detail to "see" the personality.  Whereas with dogs and cats, it's infinitely more obvious.



All animals, even humans are driven by a set of primitive, basic survival instincts at the base of their psyche.  In human psychology it's referred to as the "id"....the most basic and unrefined part of the human brain.  The part that drives us to seek food, shelter, comfort and sex.  Generally, all animals are pure "id" as it's generally accepted they don't have a sense of "self" or identity in the way humans do (a dog doesn't see himself in a mirror and think "That's me!"- he tries to play with the other dog!).  Wolves (and likewise, dogs) are driven by the same basic survival needs as any animal, and they have developed a social structure that helps them meet those needs more readily in the wild.  It's that social structure that transfers over into the social behaviors humans enjoy in their pet dogs :).



</answer>



<answer from>



celtic.p...
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 2213 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My snake had a personality. She was as dopey as hell, clever, but daft lol.



Spend enough time with any type of animal, and you'll find that they all have their own personalities.



Personality is just what makes them different to others of their species. What makes them 'them' instead of 'bob'.

Dogs, it's easy, we can see their differences, They're everywhere, so we have lots of comparisons. Some like to be indoors, some outdoors, some are lazy, active, easy going, hughly strung etc.



Ants, can be tricky. We don't know them well enough to tell them apart. But they know. So they have personality.



</answer>

<question>



What is the average Age for a Toy Yorkie?



I have a 14 Years old Toy Yorkie, who is already blind on both Eyes. What is the Average Life Expectancy of a Toy Yorkie?



</question>



<answer from>



Alex K
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Toy breeds tend to have shorter life spans than larger breed dogs. I have had 4 chihuahuas, all of which died before hitting 10. This is due to the fact that toy dogs have weaker immune systems and more skeletal problems than other dogs. There are small dogs who live to be in their 20's, but I believe the average is somewhere around 10-15 years.



</answer>



<answer from>



amy~
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 423 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I seen on one site that they have a Life Span of 15 years

But you can always beat the Odds!!



Source(s):



Dog lover, Proud Owner of a Black Lab Mix and a Pure Bred Akita



</answer>



<answer from>



Hermiony
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Usually from 14 to 20 years. Small dogs live longer than larger breeds. I know because I have 2 giant breeds and volunteer at a animal hospital.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What breed could I be? Owners unsure.?



My owners bought me home from the pound at six weeks old, I'm now 10 weeks old. But I'm wondering what breed I could possibly be. I was dropped off at the pound by a lady who got me off the street.

I have brindle markings on my sides and white on my back feet and white lines on my legs.

The pound said I was a cocker spaniel mix
The pet shop said I was a Border Collie Lab mix (same with the vet)
And my owners dad says there could be staffy in me.
And my owner really hopes I have pit bull, but knows I most likely don't.
Does anyone else have any guesses?

This is my album on flickr.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/30596662@N0...

(and does anyone know what this has to do with zoology?? It came up when choosing a category lol)



</question>



<additional details>



http://www.flickr.com/photos/30596662@N0...
Will this work?



kiwi mutt actually.
:) I do hope when she's older she looks more like a pit bull, they're cute! And mixed with Lab and Border Collie, even cuter!!



Yeah, I thought Jack Russel, but you never know, she could have nearly every breed in her. (very unlikely lol)



She'd been dumped on the street, then got picked up.

<question>



My dog is 8 yrs old and just started to pant like Crazy?



she is a little over weight and we are working on that taking her for walks and changing her diet and she has joint problems and is on Rimadyl for the pain what else could be causing this should I be worried or just give it time with the walking and the change of diet



</question>

</answer>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13490 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



When does she pant?



Is it during/after exercise, or all the time, when she's at rest?



If at rest, and the ambient temperature isn't too hot, then a visit to the vet is in order to rule out something like pneumonia or heart disease/congestive heart failure.



</answer>



<answer from>



panache
Member since: 11 February 2006
Total points: 17226 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Any stress can cause panting.Exercise,pain or changes in their routine can all stress a dog,I'd have a vet check to make sure the pain control is adequate



</answer>



<answer from>



Lee P
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 702 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dogs pant because they do not have sweat glands and this is how they cool down their bodies. Water with ice cubes should help. Changing the diet and losing the weight should help also. If she has joint problems, make sure your walks are too long or too much for her. Start with short distances and gradually increase the distance, but make sure she gets use to each change first before moving on. Your Vet would provide you with the best answers, considering her age and condition.



</answer>



<answer from>



Terry G
Member since: 01 May 2007
Total points: 678 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are lots of issues with Rimadyl, I've listed a few of the side effects but search the web for more details. I would try a different vet, look for a holistic vet or one that does acupuncture, I've had many old dogs and natural path treatments seem to work much better overall with less risk.



Some Rimadyl side effects
- loss of appetite
- change in drinking habits (refusal to drink or increased water consumption)
- unusual pattern of urination, blood in the urine, sweet-smelling urine, an overabundance of urine, urine accidents in the house
- vomiting
- diarrhea
- black, tarry stools or flecks of blood in the vomit
- lethargy, drowsiness, hyperactivity, restlessness, aggressiveness
- staggering, stumbling, weakness or partial paralysis, full paralysis, seizures, dizziness, loss of balance
- jaundice (yellowing of the skin, mucus membranes and whites of the eyes)



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 7730 (Level 5)

panting can be a sign of pain along with the meds she is on that might be giveing her cramps. changing her diet can also cause a stomach flareup until she is use to it.try to take her for short walks so there will be less pressure on her joints and don't let her run or jump.call ur vet and get the side effects of the rimadyl since she might be haveing problems with it. she can take asperin a few times a day and u can add 1/2 to 1 teaspoon of olive oil or give her a fish capsule and a garlic pill to keep her blood flowing nicely. press her stomach and she if she stiffens up or it is hard and then u might be able to tell if this is bothering her. a teaspoon of pepto bismal will calm it down when it acts up. like us any kind of antimflamatory drug is hard on the stomach and have many side effects. when she is laying down apply warm moist towels and put them on her hips and back and leave them for a little while then try gently massaging with little circle motions on the sore spots and she will feel better and love the attention.extra stress and the drugs are hard on her system so u might want to call the vet for more info and something else to help her feel better.

<question from>



Ashley
Member since: 15 September 2008

</question from>



<question>



How do you train a dog?



How do you  train a two year old dachshund/Chihuahua mix to stop doing its bathroom in the house? Also, how do you train it to lay down or sit?



</question>



<answer from>



Pomerani...
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 540 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Below are House Training, and Crate Training Tips.

Crate Training
__________________

Try locking her in a kennel or crate, or "doggie safe area" for a few minutes, while you go do something. Make sure to do the "Crate Process every time she goes in her crate.



"Crate Process"
1. Put Dog in kennel, crate or "doggie safe area" 
2. Give treats and a toy
3. Leave
4. When you come back, give her lots of praise, and treats. (Also, use the clicker if you are clicker training)

Leave her out, of her kennel "doggie safe area"or crate for an hour, then put her in for 30 minutes, Repeating the "Crate Process.(steps 1-3)" Then again, when you come back do step 4.



Repeat slowly extending the time, and make sure you leave time between kennel times, to spend with your puppy. Never expect your puppy to stay in his kennel longer than the age he is in months plus one. (example, if your puppy is 5 months old, only leave it in there for 6 hours. No dog/puppy should stay in it's kennel longer than 7-8 hours.

This is what i mean by "doggie safe area".

If you are going to be gone longer than a few hours, either have a dog sitter come to your house mid-day to walk him, or block off your bathroom, kitchen, hall, or other place with tile or wood floors for her to stay in while you are away. Leave food, water, toys, his kennel or crate, and puppy pads or newspapers(unless you want potty on the floor)

Let the puppy sleep in his/her crate at night, unless you want an adult large dog sleeping in your bed at night. Even if your dog whimpers in the crate, just ignore her/him until he stops. Do not remove the puppy from the crate when he whimpers, or he will learn that this is how to get out.

I Really Hope this helped.



House Training
_____________

First and foremost, do not make the dog smell his mess, strike him or lock him ouside. This will just confuse the pup, and it might be afraid of you.



I have just got a puppy recently. The way I trained him was crate training. Here's a few tips on crate training and house training:

1.Try to teach them that their crate is a good place. Reward them when you place them in the crate. This is teaching them, that a treat comes with good crate behavior. Always keep your dog in the crate, unless you can keep a good eye on him. 
2. Another option, if you do not want to place your dog in the kennel all of the time, hook his leash to your belt loop, this way he can not go off and use the restroom somewhere, and you don't know about it. 
3.Always take him outside after;
+ rough play 
+after he eats or drinks 
+after being let out of his crate
+ after he wakes up after a night
+ or if he shows signs of having to use the restroom,(below are those signs)
*sniffing 
*staring at you
*whining
4.Don't ever hit your dog, or rub his nose in his mess. This will just teach the dog to be afraid of you. 
5.Don't feed him or give him to much water, before you plan to put him in his cage.
6.Don't expect your dog to hold it's restroom, more than the age of the dog in months, plus one. But no dog should have to hold it's bladder more than a 7-8 hours.
7.Be patient!! That is the key, to housetraining. Of course if you get too overwelmed, you can always buy a book, or ask a professional trainer!
8.Always, when he goes to the bathroom ouside, give lots of praise and treats!!
9. If you expect your puppy to go outside, and dont use puppy pads when he gets older, starting out with puppy pads, is not a good idea, because this trains them that it's ok to go inside, and then before they know it, they cant, it is to confusing for them.
10. Make sure to have a schedule.
11.When you go outside, stay outside until he uses the restroom. 
Good Luck!



Training (the only part not written by me, it was written by another answerer, on another topic)

Sit- have treats. Say sit. If he doesn't, push his bum gently until he sits. Then say sit and give him a treat. Do this a couple of times until he can do it on his own. Remember to reward him when he does well.

Lay- He needs to know this trick before roll over. Make him sit. Then, a treat in your hand, move your hand from his nose, down to the ground, sort of away from him a little bit. Say lay, or lay down, and he might do it, and if he does, give him the treat, and say lay, or lay down.(I think you should say lay down rather than lay, because he could get confused with lay and stay. But It's just my opinion so, yeah.)

Stay- This trick was really hard for my dog. I make my dog sit, then put your hand out as if to say stop, but say stay. Say stay in a firm voice and keep reinforcing to stay. And if he does, reward him with the treat. Just keep trying this.



Come- This trick was also hard for my dog. Make sure your dog knows stay first. Make him sit, stay, and then say, his name (I'll just say rocky) So say, Rocky, come. and if he comes, reward him. But, if he doesn't come, move the treat around in the air and keep saying come. Keep trying this.

Roll Over- I'm still in the process of trying to teach my old dog a new trick such as this one, It's very hard for her. What I'm doing is Telling her to sit, lay down and then, I have a treat in my hand, put it by her nose (I'm going to call her by her name, Cocoa) But I put it by Cocoas nose and then I pretty much draw a circle in the air, a very large one, it's hard to explain in writing. And if she doesn't get it, I try pushing her so she rolls over. If this works for you, GENTLY push him over and then say, roll over, try it again, give him a treat. Sorry, It's very hard to explain.

Down- If he jumps up on you, say "EH EH" And cross your arms and turn your back to him. It's the same thing with biting. Or, instead of saying eh eh, make a high pitch ouch, or something like a yelp or a loud noise, or just say no.

Jump- Hold treat over his head, He'll probably jump, while he's jumping, say jump, and let him have the treat. This trick can be dangerous if you hold it too far above his head, he may fall backward or brake a bone, so take it easy.

Shake- Make him sit. Grab his paw, and say shake and shake his paw. Then give him a treat. He might do this on his own if you just say shake.

Speak- All you can do for this one is, say speak, then act like your barking, and hope that he'll bark. Give him a treat if he does.

Hope I have helped you and your pup! BTW, Don't try to do all of these tricks in a day or week, it's going to take some time. Go in order how you listed them. Teach sit, and practice for two or three days and then move on to lay down, and keep going. Take it easy on him. Never yell at him if he did something wrong.
Practice practice practice!



Good Luck with your new puppy!



</answer>



<answer from>



MiZZ GSD Show girl

<answer>



All you need to know from me is -



LEERBURG.COM



Because I'm not gonna write it all out when its all on that site, better than I could put it.



PomeranianLuver, if thats all the work you did with your dog for, sit, stay, etc, he's not trained.



I don't reccommend obedience classes unless you're a complete idiot when it comes to training. You can't begin training a dog with that level of distraction, well, I wouldn't anyway. For most dogs its not ideal, for the learning stage. If its just for socialisation purposes after the dog knows basic commands then its fine. Watch out for idiot "trainers" running obedience classes, choose carefully.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



Annie C
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 186 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



For bathroom-
Stay with your dog till he/she needs to go. When she does, and you see that she is not peeing or pooping in the right place, quickly pick her/him up and put him/her in the right place & say 'bathroom' & point to where it's supposed to be. Repeat it everytime he ends up going to other places till he understands.

For Sit-
Always have a treat with you. How I trained my pup was kind of 'force' her to sit. (It sounds much better than it seems hah). Say 'sit' and push her back down and let her know the sit position. Or if you ever see her sitting, you can say 'GOOD SIT' and maybe a 'good girl/boy' for encouragement :)

For laydown-
Get the dog in the sit position and put the treat on the floor right below his/her nose. If she tries to grab it w/o doing it lay down position, quickly move the treat. Repeat it till she knows how to lie down.
Or you can point your index finger to the floor and say 'DOWN'.

Hopefully that'll help, but good luck ! :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Ann M
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>

<question from>



Peachy

</question from>



<question>



How do you prove ownership of a dog?



When we were on a vacation we had our dog staying with my friend. My friend got put into the hospital and the local animal control took my dog. We got home right away and found out where the dog was and immediatly went to visit her,  but were told we couldn't take her home as it was a hospital matter and the "legal owner" is the only one who can rescue her. Apparently since the dog was not on our property at the time she was taken this means she is not ours?  We were not allowed to visit my MY dog for a month because it will upset her when she doesn't come home with us. We explained she is our dog and they will not give her back because I have no way of proving she is mine. The dog was being fosterd for her whole time at that shelter and that foster parent promised us that once they figure out the legal issues with the hospital matter she will tell us immediatly when she will be put up for adoption. We called her weekly looking for updates on our dog, and everyweek were rejected to even look at her, blocked in the doorway or my dog was take out the back door! We complied with complete trust in the woman, that we would be able to have out dog back soon. The week my dog went up for adoption the lady fostering the dog said she would call us on a Thursday if the dog was ready for adoption, she didn't call us back till Monday and told us that we could give an application form, but they already have found a home on the weekend so there was no point. Yesterday they adopted her out to another family who didn't even want her (they wanted another dog but it was too jumpy so they got pointed in the direction of mine). I am not sure what to do about this now. I'm going to put ads in the local papers and on telephone poles hoping to find the owners but I am in complete shock. What would you suggest I do from here?



</question>



<answer from>



W.
Member since: 15 January 2007
Total points: 22154 (Level 6)



Contributing In:

</answer from>

You either need to produce registration papers or vet records.



</answer>

<answer>



Do you not have ANY vet papers?



If you have EVER taken your dog to a vet, get a hold of that vet and ask for a copy of your dogs records, and a statement FROM THE VET that saw your dog, stating he/she saw your dog, and that you paid for the services.



problem solved. 
i don't understand what the deal is here. is your friend in the hospital in some way unable to verbally tell the shelter that they were just watching the dog for you?
i would file a police report w/your local department. stating that the animal control is in reality stealing your dog. if you do this with documentation in your hand from a vet stating the dog is yours, they HAVE to give the dog back, or you could sue them.



Source(s):



owned by 4 dogs, ASPCA member, SPCA volunteer and foster home.



</answer>

<answer>



Photos and vet records are generally considered proof of ownership as are



AKC registration papers, a microchip and even a collar and tag with your information on it.



Was your friend so incapacitated that they weren't able to say the dog belong to you.  The shelter did not have the right to adopt out your dog under these circumstances.  I would recommend going to court and providing your proof of ownership and trying to have claim and delivery papers issued which would force the shelter to turn the dog over to you



</answer>

Vet records, microchip registration information, kennel club registrations papers, licensing with your city or county, (hopefully you did that) will all help in proving ownership.
