<answer>



There are only 2 ways animal control can have taken the animal (unless it was running astray in the street), and that's either because your friend signed it over to them or they had a court order to take it.

According to the law in many places the person caring for an animal is the legal owner, therefore according to the law your friend may have been the legal owner at the time the dog was taken.

A lawyer might be able to help you, but only if you can prove your posession of the animal with things like a chip number (the animal is chipped, is it?).
Vet bills might help as well, as will the posession of a pedigree for the dog.
But depending on the law those might still not get you your dog back if the law says the people caring for the dog are its legal owners.



</answer>



<answer from>



Shih Tzu Mom
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 455 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If it swims like a fish, and smells like a fish, then it must be a fish.  I'm sorry, but this whole entire story sounds fishy to me!

First off, why could the person in the hospital not tell the animal control people  that the dog was indeed yours?



Also, why did you not have vet records or pictures to prove this was your dog?

If you have any of these records of proof of prior ownership, then there is no way Animal Control could just take your dog and give it away to someone else.

If you have these records, then by all means go to court to get your dog returned.  And, if for some reason that is no longer possible (due to those people giving the dog to someone else already), then Animal Control is still responsible and as such, should be made to pay you for loss and suffering and also to buy a new dog, if that is your choice.



</answer>

<answer>



If your dog was wearing a rabies tag registered with the county, then the county will have YOU registered as the legal owner of the dog.  If she had some very distinctive marking then your vet may be able to speak on your behalf that the dog in question is definitely yours.  The only other permanent forms of identification would be a microchip (which would prove 100% that the dog was yours) or a tattoo.  Otherwise, you may be out of luck here.  If I were you I would get a lawyer, like yesterday, and consult them about your legal options.



</answer>



<answer from>



cheryls_...

<answer>



You need to act very quickly. You need to understand first of all that the shelter has guidelines and they are just following those. Because of that, you need to remain perfectly polite throughout and this will help people in wanting to help you get your dog back. You need to compile a file with absolutley anything you have that will prove beyond reasonable doubt that the dog is yours. Get everyone in your family, your friends, your neighbours to sign a petition that has a picture of the dog on it to say that they can vouch for your ownership. You need to get in touch with any vet that you have been to since you had the dog, they will have a record of your visits and can give you copies. If you have ever used a groomer, trainer or know of any professional person like a lawyer, doctor, dentist, teacher etc get in touch with them now and ask them to act as a witness that the dog is yours.

If this was happening to me, I would be talking to everyone I know that can say the dog is mine, I would get every photo I have ever had taken of the dog with my family. I would be on the phone to all the animal agencies, police, lawyers etc asking for advice, so all I can really say to you is don't give up. Fight for your dog and get her back.

Also, note the times and dates that you have mentioned above regarding the promises that were made and then broken and I would also get in touch with your friend. If she is well enough, ask her to call them and explain and if she's not, ask her neighbours, family and friends.....ANYONE who can help you!



</answer>

<answer>



if you bough this dog as a show quality dog:go back to the breeder:its inherited.Cutting the tendon will hurt the dog and also leave a scar!
I shown my dogs, and a lot of the judges check the tail for lumps and bumps!The puppies would still inherit the sickle tail:don't breed this dog.
If you are a hunter, the tail will not stop the dogs pointing or retrieving correctly.



Source(s):



do you check the hips or eyes of your setters?
never mind the tail, there are other serious health issues in purebred dogs.



</answer>

<answer>



Nope a dog born with a sickle tail stays a sickle tail i.e. a husky will always have a sickle tail they don't "outgrow" it.  It isn't life threatening or harmful, i'm sure it looks actually very interesting though. Enjoy your one of a kind dog!

<question>



My dog has Black spots on his Testicles, He had feas, there gone now, what could the back spots be?



My dog had feas, there gone now, what could the back spots be? hes a yorkey please help



</question>



<answer from>



bobsaget...
Member since: 20 December 2007
Total points: 1527 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Do these spots look like dirt?  If you put the spots on a paper towel, and put some water on it, and the spots turn red... its flea dirt.  Which means... its flea "poop".  Because fleas ingest blood.  Which means... the fleas aren't COMPLETELY gone.  Sometimes it takes a few months to break the cycle and get rid of them completely.  If the spots are like a coloring on his skin... that's all it is.  (And just a side note:  Why does he still have his testicles?  Spay and neuter!)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks, lLL let him keep his balls tho!! its my mums dog lol



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Mama
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 6471 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



flea dirt, probably (dried blood and flea poop).

A good scrubbing will take care of it.

<question>



Dog barking problem ( please help ) thank you?



My dog is barking when he dosent see anybody , but when he see's us he stop barking ,, So please help I need 2 go 2 sleep :(



</question>

<answer from>



chillama...
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 720 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This isn't an overnight type of thing.  You need to train your dog.

Be sure to make sure that you being out of the room really IS the reason he is barking.  Once you're sure, you can know that you need to stop coming in.

He is barking because every time he barks you come back.  By coming back and comforting him you are reinforcing to him that barking is just way to magically make daddy appear!

Unfortunately, you need to ignore it and let him just bark himself out.  If he barks too long you need to start over with crate training.



</answer>



<answer from>



hausie08
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 576 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think your dog is barking for your attention. I think it is better to ignore that behaviour. Give him something to play. I was told to give a toy at a time by trainer. Praise when he is quiet. Give a raw bone which is appropriate for your dog to chew. Have quality time with dog such as training or fetching balls etc.
If you need to stop him straight away, command him to sit down and ask him to wait few seconds, and treat him. regular exercise helps as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



MamaB
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 1729 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



How old is this dog?  Has he always done this?



If he is elderly, it could be that he's losing his hearing, or perhaps his sight is failing.  He's asking for reassurance.  Perhaps.

If this is just a traning thing, maybe a puppy?, yes, you do need to not react when he does this.  However, for the sake of any neighbours who may also need sleep, you have to address this problem (see another thread about barking dogs!).  Suggest maybe you need to crate this dog and maybe have the crate in with you, at least for a time, until he realises he's safe, and that you are not going anywhere, even if he can't actually see you.  This could be classic separation anxiety, and needs to be dealt with as such?

More information would be helpful please.



</answer>

<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,

Teach him that leaving him alone actually means good things--the goal is for him to associate your departure with something positive. Here are some effective techniques:



•



Leave Kongs stuffed with peanut butter or cottage cheese ready for him to dig into as soon as you leave.



•



Hide small treats around the house or in his crate. Make sure his favorite toys are tucked safely in places he knows to search. This gives him something to do while you're gone and helps eliminate boredom.



•



Tire him out. See that he receives plenty of physical and mental exercise and that he gets lots of time with you. When you do leave, he'll be more content to sleep or just take it easy.



Please visit the following link below for more details.

http://dogtime.com/barking-aspca.html
http://dogtime.com/separation-anxiety.ht...



Source(s):



http://dogtime.com



</answer>



<answer from>



air_born...
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 341 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



the next time your dog barks, take a two large pan covers and slam them into each other, do this for a while, he will get distracted as soon as he barks, he'll catch on knowing that if he barks he'll hear the horrible sound again.
also make sure that he gets at least an hour of exercise in the day time.
also don't feed him too close to bedtime, there should be about a 3-4 hour time gap between his last meal and bedtime and make sure he has supply of fresh clean water all through the night.
it could just be a phase.:)



Source(s):



Dog Owner



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, it's absolutely normal. Dogs do that because some kind of gland in that area bothers them, which happens from time to time. It's not a disorder or a disease, it's a natural cycle. I think it's something to do with the gland producing some kind of secretion.

Well, I'm no expert, but I'm pretty sure I got it just about right. Any which way, she's not crazy. :D



Source(s):



I've grew up with dogs in the house, and they all did it now and then, for short periods of time.

<question>



German shepherd puppy please help!!?



i have recentley got a black german shepherd puppy (*****) 8 weeks old. my problem is she chews everything!! i cant even walk round the house without her draggin along chewing on my trouser leg or chewing my shoes/ slippers! at 1st it was cute now its getting annoying i keep telling her no she will let go then as soon as i take another step she does it again. i seem to be spending the whole day saying no. any advise would be great. Thankyou



</question>



<additional details>



i cant believe they have blanked that word out in a dog question! ok so she is FEMALE!



she has LOADS of toys!! about 15 but find chewing me more fun



as 4 helm comment, yes she was only 6 and a half weeks when i got her but it was as her mother had a larger litter and it was wearing her out. so the breeder decided to let the puppys go early. they were all weaned and are very chuncky strudy puppies! and as for rehoming her there wouldnt be any1 out there that could give her a better home. she is spoilt rotten its only the chewing me that im trying to get advice on, which i feel is sometimes better than going it alone!!



</additional details>



<answer from>



hazel103...
Member since: 12 May 2007
Total points: 499 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



hiya ive grown up around dogs family having them etc, ive now taken in my brother 2 year old german shepherd due to divorce etc and my mums got a long coated shepherd whos a year old. so hope i can help.

with your puppy only being 8 weeks old she will be getting her teeth through if not already. there are plenty of produces now you can buy for "teething" i know you can get teething rings for dogs teething keys etc.

she will chew things that are there as she doesnt know what she can and cant chew. if you let her carry on doing it she will do it for the rest of her life, you need to nip it in the bud now.which you obviously want as your asking how on here.

you will have to continue with telling her no. shes only 8 weeks so dont expect her to get it straight away though.
keep saying no, but not softly, have a really dont mess with me effect and say NO loudly. she will gradually get the hang of it... believe me we had the same with my mums pup.



also when you go out she might get a bit distressed, my mums puppy chewed the new wooden dinning table chairs, door, door frame mats. also kitchen sink bowls, draining boards any thing that she could get hold of.. 
so when you go out put her in a room you dont mind if she chews up, if she does chew and you dont like it get a cage for her while you go out, long as the cage is big enough for her to move about and isnt squashed into and not left for hours and in direct sunlight she should be ok.

we found that doggy kongs where you fill them up with meat etc is great to distract the dog from realising you have actually gone out which could cut down the chances of your house being chewed.

oh and hard bones are great when shes older, she will chew the bone as its tasty and wont have any chew left for your trousers.

just keep doing what your doing hunny x

also theres a book which is great about german shepherds
called " THE GERMAN SHEPHERD DOG, (TERRA NOVA BOOK) i advise this one



</answer>

Get her some toys, play with her, and perhaps you might consider a crate, initially, so she has a time out place, you can do your own thing too!

wel, my pup did the same thing. she is now 4 and half month old and never does it. not sure that i had something do to with it, but my neighbors dog did.she actually teached my puppy during play how to control her bite.and even when my pup is exited and plays, she never bites too hard, always stops.dont know if that has to do with her leaving my pants alone, but she just stopped.

<answer>



Puppy chewing is an important part of the teething process. Some often chew for fun, or to relieve boredom. German shepherds like to chew, and their powerful jaws can destroy most materials. Save your puppy, and your belongings, by giving her safe chew toys and bones so she can entertain himself when you're not playing with her.

Kindly refer to the following link on how to prevent destructive chewing.

http://dogtime.com/chewing-and-destructi...
http://dogtime.com/prevent-chewing-bitin...

Hope it helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



dorothy s
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 9196 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Forget the advise to spray her or smack her all puppies chew.You must keep her amused, toys don't do this. German Shepherds are highly Intelligent with a huge amount of energy. At present you cannot take her for long walks, however you can play with her in the garden/yard or in the house.

I start training my GSD's as soon as they settle in. Soak some of her dried food to make it soft and use bits of this as training treats. Lure her into a sit or a down and give her a treat and loads of praise. Mental stimulation is more tiring than physical exercise and a few  five minute sessions of play training will tire her and she will be less likely to chew.

You could try hiding bits of dried food (not soaked) around the house and this will teach her to seek, this is another form of mental stimulation. Carry a tuggy rope in your pocket and when she chews your trouser leg distract her with the tuggy and praise her when she pulls and tugs.

I have always found that GSD's respond to praise.If they do something naughty its much better to ignore this  behaviour. Absence of praise is then taken as a rebuke, however she must do something to earn your praise. I think that one of the answerer's suggest sending her to a trainer, never do this, take her to classes when she is older and train her yourself. A weekly class is a waste of time if you fail to practise what you are taught every day.



Source(s):



Dorothy S



</answer>



<answer from>



air_born...
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 341 (Level 2)

<question from>



lithium2...
Member since: 14 August 2008

</question from>



<question>



Why does my chihuahua puppy whine when excited?



I come back from school or just a walk and when i go home, He's standing there shivering and spinning around and jumping, which is normal, but he whines intermittently, like a baby who's been crying. Are they supposed to do that?



</question>



<answer from>



Return of the Mick
Member since: 23 August 2008
Total points: 1149 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would do that as well if I was choking for a pish and I had no other way of telling you.



</answer>



<answer from>



Amanda
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 7985 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think you need to worry. It's just her way of being excited.  Dogs all show their excitement a little bit differently, and some are vocal about it.

The lab next door to us does these strange "half-howls" when the grandparents come to visit. He loves them to death. I have Dachshunds, which as a breed tend to be very vocal in general. One of my dogs has these funny sounding "excited barks" that are completely different from her ordinary barks or play barks. My other dog will sometimes whine a bit when exceptionally excited, but again, they sound nothing like her ordinary whines. They'll stand there wagging their tails and doing their excited "tap dance" with their front feet, and one will be doing these bizarre sounding barks, and one will be whining in a weird way. I'm sure it would seem pretty strange to someone who didn't know them!



</answer>



<answer from>



John Boy
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 160 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Does he/she bark yet?
I know that with other young creatures ( and don't laugh ) like ducks  need to develope the sound. The ducklings on my nature reserve don't quack until they are a few months old.



</answer>

<question from>



Sarah ♪Rock the casbah♪
Member since: 02 August 2007
Total points: 2827 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Taking photos of your dog?



Do any of you have problems taking a photo of your dog!? I see people posting perfect photos all the time and have to wonder, how do you do it??

Dom turns his head away at the last second EVERY TIME I try to snap a pic of him. He's never been subject to a flash close to his face from a camera before and I never use one when I'm taking one of him, so that can't be the problem. The only time he's not interested in treats (doggy biscuits, chicken, cheese...) is when I have some in the same hand as a camera as an attempt to make him look at it! And a lab not interested in treats...that's saying something. I've tried using my phone to fool him (maybe he just doesn't like the look of the camera?) but still no taking.

http://i144.photobucket.com/albums/r169/...
http://i144.photobucket.com/albums/r169/...
http://i144.photobucket.com/albums/r169/...

Okay, a legit question - how often do you clip your dog's dew claws? Dom needs his doing every month, the daft thing. He's used to it now, although he gives me the "not this AGAIN!?" eyes :)



</question>



<additional details>



Just to clarify - it would be nice if he looked but he's a handsome boy to me whether he's looking or not.



And he drooled on the keyboard while I was typing that...



You've got some good advice. I actually have 167 pics on my PC of him, and he's turned awayon most of them! He's 14 so he must be used to the camera, and he's doesn't have an agressive stance when I take them - on the contrary, he often rubs against my legs or the camera itself. I find it easier to take a pic of my boyfriend's cat than my dog!



Mutt - I never use a flash when I take photos of him.

Aww, these pics you're linking are lovely! :-D



I've just realised, that last one does look like he's snarling! He wasn't, trust me. He's a friendly chap.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Amanda G
Member since: 13 February 2008
Total points: 1967 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Teach him a "watch me" or "focus" command.  Once he has it down, you can start taking pictures of him while he is doing it.



</answer>

<answer>



i clip them once a week. and for your other question he probably doesnt like the way the camera is facing him (imitating staring at him) Dogs dont like to be stared at it makes them feel intimidated and it is like challenging them. i use treats i hold them behind and under my camera so it gives the illusion that she is staring at the camera

<answer>



All you need to do is take a ton of pictures.  For every good pic you see of other peples pets, i'm sure 10 more didn't turn out as well.  Cats are even harder, lol... every time i put the camera down towards the cat, he gets up and rubs on it!  Try teaching a cat "stay"... it's a no deal :)

Tips include:  sit stay or down stay (these are a must), and then chuck a toy or a treat, watch for him to perk up, take photo.



Make a funny noise.  Do a weird movement.  Take photo.



Also some dogs are uncomfortable making sustained eye contact, as it can be seen as an aggressive part of body language.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mama
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 6471 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It takes a long time with some dogs to get them to sit for a good picture. When I photograph dogs, I usually bring out the camera first. Let them smell it. Let them realize it's not a toy. I might sit by them and take a few pictures of something else- like a tree or whatever- so they get used to me taking pictures and stop caring. Then I'll give them a toy to play with or a treat to eat.



Click your tongue or say their name right before you take the picture so they'll look your direction.

Also, you can try to get some of them when they aren't paying any attention at all. Some of my best dog shots are with the dog playing with the kids or splashing in the water at the lake.



</answer>

<answer>



I have tons of pretty good pictures. The key is to stay focused and keep snapping pictures. Out of dozens, there may only be a couple I like, but it's better than taking a few and having none.

My dog is constipated........help please.?

</question>



<answer from>

<answer>



when my dogs are constipated i give 2 tbsp of canned pumpkin (NOT pie filling, but canned pumkin)

you can also give pepto bismol, look on google for dosage for your dogs weight.



If he hasnt gone at all for a total of two days, get him into the vet it could be a blockage which has the possibility of being fatal.



</answer>



<answer from>



Farina
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 3611 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Perhaps give him some warm water to help his bowel movement. That's what I did when my pup gobbled up all the dry dogfood (I'd rather avoid feeding him anything else or any "special" food)....he was fine the next day....If this "constipation" persists, see the vet. I usually check for dry nose, change in sleeping patterns/behavior and those are signs to go to vet.



</answer>



<answer from>



mark
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 1067 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Worm him with a roundworm and tapeworm (standard worming) treatment you can but from any pet shop.
Wormers act as drain cleaners and usually 'clean' the system out.
If it continues to happen you need to look at his diet but chances are it is just a one off.
It doesnt matter if he has been wormed recently, it wont harm to treat again and it may well be worms that caused it in the first place.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jason E
Member since: 17 September 2008

<answer from>



JessicaL...
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 2093 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If he eats dry food, you might want to give him canned food because canned food softens their bowels, if he's already eating canned food, you might want to change the brand. But it's important anytime you change a dog's food to MIX the two different brands at first to accustom your dog's stomach to it, otherwise it could make him sick.

If that's not the problem, has your dog been dewormed recently? Worms cause constipation or diarrhea amond other more serious problems.

If this is also not the cause, and it's just a simple case of constipation, your best bet is to give him a couple tsb of prune juice or steam some veggies. Both of those work wonders on dogs and are actually healthy tips to practice on a regular basis, especially if your dog develops a history of constipation.

Be sure to only use a very small amount of prune juice, depending on the dogs weight, since dogs dehydrate easier than humans. But prune juice is healthy for him if used correctly.

Hope this helped.



Source(s):



pet groomer
trained vet tech
owner



</answer>

<question from>



PlasticT...

Total points: 1482 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



My dog keeps itching and biting her skin, what can I do since the vet's advice isn't working?



Is there an at home remedy? She has dry skin and it was recommended by the vet that I put medicine in her food before she eats (it's in a squirt bottle and just saturates the top layer of food).



*How long would it take for fish oil to start working?



</question>



<answer from>



b.w.
Member since: 17 May 2006
Total points: 19085 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



First, I would see adifferent vet. Second, look at what you are feeding her. Our pets need quality pet food. Read the ingredients list and learn what the stuff on there is and what it does (or does not do) to/for our pets. A quick pet food 101. If the pet food contains corn/corn products or by products it is a poor quality food. Corn is a filler that can trigger skin problems. (allergies, skin problems, itching and excessive shedding) By products is anything from an animal not fit for human consumption, including cancerous tissue. Do not pay attention to advertising, they all say there food is great. "Vet approved" means they have a vet on staff to approve their product. In other words, someone paid to approve it. Same with foods most vets recommend. Salesmen "gift" vets then the vet recommends the food. Most vets are not nutritionists! Quality foods have meat as the first ingredient. California Natural, Solid Gold, Innova and Merrick are a few of the best brands available. If you want to learn more check out: http://www.sagekeep.com/petfood.htm



www.api4animals.org/facts?p=359& more=1



http://animalark.eapps.com/animal/PetFoo...

Third, fish oil will probably help some but it takes weeks...



s



</answer>

<question from>



Ajy A
Member since: 08 July 2008

</question from>



<question>



How often should i give my dog a bath?



all i can say is that she is a mutt, small, and has kinda soft fur. but she always stinks!!! if we give her a bath, she smells good for about 1 day, then slowly goes back to her stinky self. we usually give her a bath every 1 or 2 months, and we know this isnt ok, so please tell me how often i should give her a bath.



thx



</question>



<answer from>



neboptic...
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 400 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I don't think every one or two month is so terrible. I mean, I only bathe my dog once a month. It's a judgment call, really. But I will say that once a week is too often and would probably dry your dog's coat out. If you want to go ahead and give her a bath twice a month, I would recommend an oatmeal shampoo to help the coat from drying out.



To help with the smell, there's also bath wipes, doggy cologne and other things that are sold at pet stores that you can use in between baths. But I'm wondering if she smells because of the food she's eating. When my dog use to eat Proplan, it made his coat oily and smelly from all the oil. Now that I've changed him onto the raw diet, he has no doggy smell. I'm not suggesting you also switch to the raw diet, but a change of dog food might help a lot. It's something definitely you might consider looking in to.

Hope this helps. Best of luck!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thx, you answered my question and also gave me advice!! i'll check out the diet thing. she is on a half dry diet, half cooked vegetables and chicken. she eats pedigree. wat do u mean by raw diet? please email me with the answer, i would be happy to know.  thx to the person who said lemon detergent!!



</asker's comment>

you should only wash your dog once a quarter.

but changing his diet could reduce skin odor as well.

<question>



Help i lost my dog in america?

<answer from>



eagles07
Member since: 22 March 2007

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If you go online and search the area where you were staying for local dog shelters you should find their phone numbers call them ASAP and give them a description and photo if possible. Most shelters are kill shelters so they have 5 days for an owner to come before they are put down... You can try this website

http://www.nycacc.org/lostandfound.htm

or



http://www.lostfoundpets.us/index.php?si...

Good luck!

Kiki B

</answer from>



<answer>



I never advocate neutering a young dog, so I'm one of the few who know better...whatever... It is not a good idea to breed any dogs unless they have been checked for inherited diseases (OFA certs on heart, hips and elbows, done at 24 months of age) as well as showing or having a person who KNOWS what the heck they are looking at tell you if your dog is conformationally correct for it's breed standard and whether it's temperment is what it is supposed to be. The do should have no disqualifiying faults if being bred, regardless as to whether you are showing or not. You are responsible to breed a sound dog with good temperment.  If you really want to breed your dog, invest in a dog with papers (AKC) from a reputable breeder who will show  you the ropes. It's not always a good idea to breed just for yourself to get a puppy.  A lot of time and effort go into  breeding quality healthy dogs, not to mention money.  Good luck and just enjoy your dog. By the way, it wouldn't hurt to invest in a furminator de shedding too,  your breed blows it's coat twice a year and a furminator will help you alot...



</answer>



<answer from>



Reena
Member since: 04 September 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



since a male doesn't actually do anything other than contribute the sperm to fertilize the eggs of the female I don't think you will
ruin him by letting him breed when he is able to do so.

But the owner of the female might not want to agree to this until he can judge the attributes of your male dog.
And for that a puppy isn't very impressive.

So present him when he is in his "prime" and at least 2 years old.
That way he can be judged. A breeder might want to be able to inspect anything from teeth to gait and overall appearance to his bone structure.
Especially when you have no papers that would allow to inspect his lineage.



</answer>

<answer>



No papers, no breeding.

It really IS that simple.

Actually, a dog needs to be (or at least SHOULD be) more than just "papered" before he's used for breeding.  He should also be titled.

And ... you don't care what breed your dog is bred to?  You're fine with creating more mutts, just so you can have a pup?

You want a mutt, visit a pound or shelter.  There are PLENTY there to choose from!

ADDED:  You HAVE no bloodline.  Your dog's bloodline is only valid if he's from a registered litter, meaning both his parents (and farther back) were registered, papered AND titled.  You've got an unregistered dog.  Your vet's "paper" stating that he's purebred (he may be, or may not be) means NOTHING.  Your dog's future puppies are worth NOTHING in terms of bloodline and perpetuation of the breed.

Please cut your losses.  You bought an unpapered pup.  He may be a wonderful dog, and I'm not disputing that.  But that does NOT mean he should breed!

If you DO choose to allow him to breed, you are doing so for your own selfish reasons.  You will not be doing so to better the breed.



</answer>

<answer>



What is the early time you can breed your male dog?
(Not meaning i am going to do it straight away i just like to know)

- Two years of age after the proper health clearances OFA CERF BAER PennHip Brucellosis CHV etc

What is the perfect time to breed a male dog?

- When he has proven himself in either the show or work ring and earned a CH and all the above is done and you as stud owner have invested years into learning about the breed his particular bloodline etc

How do i go about finding a female dog?
(Large dog's does not have to be Japanese Akita)

- If you aren't going to breed to the same breed DON'T BREED

I do not want to charge for the breeding i only want a puppy from the litter is that a good idea?

- Stud fee or pick of the litter is how it normally goes

He is pedigree but has no pedigree papers (The vet said he is pedigree and gave me a a paper to prove it was)

- No registration papers no breeding.

If you are not going to get him fixed FINE but do not breed him. nothing you have mentioned here shows he is even worth adding to ANY breed bloodline let alone Akitas.

ADD: Irresponsible breeders/owner like you are the reason for the overpopulation of animals right up there with BYBs and puppymills. Secondly WHAT bloodline? You do is unregistered with no pedigree. He has no freaking bloodline. Any responsible dog owner loves their pets and would get hurt for them.



Yeah breeders aren't born with the knowledge but they also don't go to YA looking for answers. They find a breeder in their breed club if the not the breeder they get their PAPERED dog from and have them mentor them. Don't talk down to anyone when you don't even want to go about this the right way. So a ***** can have two litters a year. A male can sire 20x as many in that same year.

ADD2: ALL dogs are unique, doesn't mean they should be bred.



ADD3: The average LEGIT kennel club will only give you LIMITED registration and that requires a certain surgery you refuse to do.



Source(s):



Do it right or don't do it at all

<answer>



It's actually very easy to define a bad breeder, and "loving your dog" is NOT enough to make you a good breeder. That's possibly one of the most idiotic claims I've ever heard anyone make. There are plenty of absolutely TERRIBLE breeders who "love their dogs." That doesn't mean they aren't irresponsible morons who have no ethics and are breeding dogs that are not of breeding quality.



Just so we're on the same page...

-You will breed him with any large breed female, intentionally and knowingly creating mutt puppies. 
-He has no papers, and the pups can't be registered with any reputable registry.
-You have no clue about his bloodline's genetic history or health problems, and don't mind risking passing a potentially crippling or deadly health problem along to his pups.
-You have not had his hips, eyes, etc. certified and have done no other health testing other than having your vet look at him.
-He has no titles and you have no clue about how well he fits his breed standard or of his overall breeding quality.



So you're just another scum BYB. Don't breed. If you want a puppy, buy one from a reputable breeder or adopt one of the millions of homeless dogs waiting for a home. Wanting one of your dog's puppies is an extremely poor reason to go ahead with this plan.

We can't control overpopulation? You're right, we can't. There are too many people like you out there to even make that remotely possible. The only way to prevent overpopulation is to stop people from breeding just because they "can," and altering all non-breeding/showing dogs.



Questions like this frustrate me to no end!



</answer>

<answer>



1.  A dog with no papers cannot be pedigreed.  He may be purebred but he is not pedigreed.

2.  Just because you selfishly want 1 puppy you are prepared to bring how many other puppies into the world to take their chances.  The dog population is already at saturation point for good forever homes.

3.  A bad breeder is anyone who breeds a dog for any reason other than for the betterment of the breed.

They do not get their dogs tested against all the genetic / hereditary diseases prevalent in their breed.

They do not show their dog to prove that it is an excellent specimen of the breed.

They will allow their male to service any bit*ch that presents itself and that haven't been tested against all the genetic / hereditary diseases prevalent in the breed and putting the male at risk of contracting a canine STD (sexually transmitted disease).

They do not assume responsibility for the pups produced for the pup's entire lives.

They are not as informed on their breed as they should be.

They are unable to identify their dogs / bit*ches faults so they can find a suitable mate to complement the bit*ch / dog and thereby improve the breed.

I'm sure that others could list so many more but I will leave it there.

As for desexing your dog, that is a personal choice, however it is your responsibility to ensure that your entire male does not contribute further to the over-population of dogs already in this world sitting in shelters waiting to be put to death.



</answer>

<answer from>



Cleoppa
Member since: 27 July 2007
Total points: 8801 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



As a general rule, large dogs bark less and are better with kids than small dogs. Of course, small dogs have much more to fear from children--they could get hurt a lot more easily by children.



I think any of the breeds below would be good with kids (although I wouldn't recommend a Black Russian Terrier for a first-time owner). Of course, there are plenty of breeds that are good with kids, but these shed minimally. To research these and other breeds, go to http://www.akc.org/breeds/complete_breed...  From there you can go to each breed's national club. This will help you find a responsible breeder and/or a breed-specific rescue.

I just answered a question for someone else about dog breeds that don't shed as much. Here:

Curly-coated dogs shed little. Large dogs of these include the Poodle, Portuguese Water Dog, Irish Water Spaniel, Kerry Blue Terrier and Soft-Coated Wheaten Terrier.

You can also check out wirehaired dog, which generally shed less as well. These include German Wirehaired Pointer, Airedale Terrier, Black Russian Terrier, Wirehaired Pointing Griffon, Giant Schnauzer, Bouvier des Flandres.

The Poodle (curly hair) and Xoloitzcuintle (hairless) come in many sizes, including larger.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 27 June 2006

<answer>



I think that your best bet is to start attending dog shows in your area.  That way you can see the dogs (albeit well-groomed and trained ones) in person and talk to people that actually own them.  You will see breeds you never even knew existed and just may find your perfect breed.  Or you may find that a dog is not for you at this time (due to the young age of your kids), or at all.

Buying a dog should not be done in a hurry.  Take your time, do your research and carefully select a breeder.  It will pay off over the next 10-15 years.

Marna O

</answer from>



<answer>



Although you obviously will get many suggestions here, make your own decision!  I agree, find a dog show (www.akc.org search for events...you should be able to find one in your area)  See the breeds in person before you decide.

And..as you honestly state you are not that knowledgeable when it comes to dogs...be sure you research dog care and training more than research the actual breed. After all, dogs are all basically dogs!!!!

And...dogs shed and dogs bark.

Also, I would seriously consider the age of your children..a 2 year old toddler might be a bit young. Puppies have sharp little teeth they use in play, tend to jump up a lot...you might want to wait a bit. But spend the time while you wait doing your research!

I would not be demanding on the 50 lb or over weight criteria. Weight is not the big factor as it can vary so greatly depending on the body type of the dog. Just say to yourself, a medium to large breed of dog. My Border Collie (not recommending one, mind you) stands just above my knee height and weighs only about 37 pounds. She is a great size. Big enough, but easily manageable... won't knock me over, I can pick her up in case of emergency, does not take up the entire back seat of the car,  but is active, athletic, can jump in the Suburban...

For a first time dog owner, I would GREATLY consider the "trainability" of the breed you choose.



I have been around dogs my entire life, training and competing in obedience since Jr High. Have been training agility students for about 13 years. I see many first time dog owners, 2nd dog owners who have very little knowledge of dogs nor how to train them. Several have erroneously chosen a very difficult breed....known for independence and such.

Some breeds have a history of wanting to work with, for their person. Search for top list of competitive obedience dogs...there is a reason these breeds are chosen by their humans.

My suggestions:

Golden Retriever
Australian Shepherd
Collie 
Labrador Retriever
English Shepherd
Shiloh Shepherd
Shetland Sheepdog (smaller, but bright and ez to train)

then....LOTS of research finding a reputable breeder to guide you and has your family's best interests in mind. Do not buy sight unseen!



</answer>



<answer from>



DP
Member since: 15 October 2006

<answer>



You should avoid these new so called Designer breeds.. 2 legitimate breeds, bred together to produce what is supposed to be cute. They are often sold as non shedding, and alot of other lies.. They are not at all bred for health or temperament.. The people breeding these dogs are breeding only for cute.. They aren't taking into consideration that the 2 breeds should never be bred together.. People that suggest dogs like Labradoodles and others... They are only helping to support backyard breeders, puppymills and people who are not breeding for the dogs and their quality of life, they are breeding to make a profit off of people who think that they are getting something they aren't.. It's like the new scam in the dog world... Selling mutts and pretending that they are bred to be something special.. best of both worlds.. WHat you end up with is the worst characteristics and health problems of both breeds...



</answer>

<question>



do you think a dog need a lot of walking?



</question>



<answer from>



Sassy
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 478 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It is necessary for a dog of any age and breed to be on a daily excercise program.  Some breeds, like labs, require more excercise than lets say a Yorkie, so build your daily excercise ritual according to your particualar breed needs.  You can go on line to get some helpful ideas on how much excercise your pets should be getting.



</answer>

<answer from>



MamaB
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 1729 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on the breed.



What do you mean by 'a lot'?  The average adult probably can do with 40 minutes twice a day?  But this is really a how long is a piece of string question.



What I truly don't like, and was very concerned to see the 'sainted' Cesar Millan doing, is running a dog with a bike.  This is, in my opinion, verging on the cruel.  A dog needs a certainly amount of free off-lead exercise where it can browse, or gallop, depending on how he feels.  Dogs will keep going way beyond their comfort level, and on the end of a lead attached to a bike is asking for trouble.  Jogging is just about okay, provided breaks are taken (what about peeing and poohing when being expected to run like crazy with a bike?)  They do, of course, benefit from some onlead road work (not all breeds!) also.  But please, stay off the bikes if you want to exercise your dog!



Source(s):



Years with Bassets - who do NOT like organized exercise - although they are also not the couch potatoes many think they are.



</answer>



<answer from>



carrie
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, your dog needs walking not only to stay fit and healthy but it also helps your dog's behavior too.  Even "couch potato" breeds require regular activity to stay fit, and a daily walk is a minimum requirement for any dog. Active breeds need multiple chances to exercise each day. Not giving your dog enough exercise almost guarantees a pet who's destructive and unhappy.

I think this could help you more:
http://dogtime.com/health.html



Source(s):



http://dogtime.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Pitbull lover♥
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 2409 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Every dog needs exersise, some breeds more than others.
It depends what "group" the breed of dog you have is in.
For example, the "Herding Group" needs the most exersise as most of those dogs were bred to live on farms and round up cattle and go skitzo, smaller dogs tend to still need a daily walk, but not for as far or as long. Giant Breeds such as the Saint Bernard need alot of exersise, they need at least 3 walks a day to keep them healthy.
Labradors however, need heaps on exersise because they are notorious for the ease in which they put on weight.
Anyways, ALL dogs need exersise, no matter what breed, just some dogs need more exersise than others.



</answer>

Lyn B

<answer>



Both are great. Border Collies will be somewhat smaller and they are very, very smart and learn quickly. They are independent because they were bred to think for themselves.

Goldens are great family dogs and will be larger but are full of fun and love. They are good family watch dogs without being aggressive. They are a little spastic and like to test the boundaries of the rules. A little nuts if you ask me.

When you are looking, check for temperament. If you want a family dog you want one that is a follower not a leader.



</answer>

<answer>



Neither breed is better, really. It all depends on your lifestyle and what type of dog you're suited for. Border Collies tend to be more high-strung and vibrant, and need lots of exercise. <answer from>



goto
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 351 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have had both dogs...

Border Collie = highly energetic, these dogs are best outside; they can be aggressive bc they are meant to heard, possessive dogs (mine would growl at other dogs if they got near me), very loving dogs, extremely smart, not many health problems, shedding minimal

Golden Retriever = energetic the first few years of life, but calm down especially if "fixed", great family dog, good with other animals, very high maintenance bc they shed horribly and can get stinky if not well groomed, extremely easily trainable, prone to seizures later in life, beautiful animals



</answer>



<answer from>

<question>



Puppy housebreaking question?



ok so ive had my puppy for 3 weeks now he is 9 weeks going on 10 he sleeps at night in his crate and when im not home hes in there. when i let him out i use to carry him outside right away. now i let him out he makes his way to the top of the stairs( i live in a basement) and i go and open the door for him. if i ever dont go and open the door he eventualy comes down and i eventualy find a mess. i wondering if theres any tricks to make him understand not to pee inside. i realy want to be able to leave him home and now put him in his crte all the time.

ps. is it just an age thing where he cangt hold it i to long? he does well in his crate



</question>



<additional details>



my dog understands he needs to go outside like when im home hes not in his crate at all because wwhen he need to go he goes to the door and i let him out. i just dont want him to pee inside when im not home



</additional details>



<answer from>



Annie C
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 186 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hah, the same thing with my dog. I keep my dog in the kitchen, and once I let her out to play, she ends up peeing on the carpets...

My advice is, whenever you see him pooping/peeing on the carpet, quickly pick him up & put him back into the crate. Point to the floor and tell him 'NO'. Do it a few times any hopefully he'll understand.
I think it's because he doesn't know he's not allowed to pee/poop there, cus you've only trained him to use the crate, once he gets out, it's like freedom basically. There's so much things he can see and adventure basically- so he might forget.

The key thing is for you to see him doing it, if you don't, it's less likely he'll learn.

Good luck!!! :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Pomerani...
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 540 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Until he is potty training, it is best to keep him in his crate.

Below are House Training, and Crate Training Tips.

Crate Training
__________________

Try locking her in a kennel or crate, or "doggie safe area" for a few minutes, while you go do something. Make sure to do the "Crate Process every time she goes in her crate.



"Crate Process"
1. Put Dog in kennel, crate or "doggie safe area" 
2. Give treats and a toy
3. Leave
4. When you come back, give her lots of praise, and treats. (Also, use the clicker if you are clicker training)

Leave her out, of her kennel "doggie safe area"or crate for an hour, then put her in for 30 minutes, Repeating the "Crate Process.(steps 1-3)" Then again, when you come back do step 4.



Repeat slowly extending the time, and make sure you leave time between kennel times, to spend with your puppy. Never expect your puppy to stay in his kennel longer than the age he is in months plus one. (example, if your puppy is 5 months old, only leave it in there for 6 hours. No dog/puppy should stay in it's kennel longer than 7-8 hours.

This is what i mean by "doggie safe area".

If you are going to be gone longer than a few hours, either have a dog sitter come to your house mid-day to walk him, or block off your bathroom, kitchen, hall, or other place with tile or wood floors for her to stay in while you are away. Leave food, water, toys, his kennel or crate, and puppy pads or newspapers(unless you want potty on the floor)

Let the puppy sleep in his/her crate at night, unless you want an adult large dog sleeping in your bed at night. Even if your dog whimpers in the crate, just ignore her/him until he stops. Do not remove the puppy from the crate when he whimpers, or he will learn that this is how to get out.

I Really Hope this helped.



House Training
_____________

First and foremost, do not make the dog smell his mess, strike him or lock him ouside. This will just confuse the pup, and it might be afraid of you.



I have just got a puppy recently. The way I trained him was crate training. Here's a few tips on crate training and house training:

1.Try to teach them that their crate is a good place. Reward them when you place them in the crate. This is teaching them, that a treat comes with good crate behavior. Always keep your dog in the crate, unless you can keep a good eye on him. 
2. Another option, if you do not want to place your dog in the kennel all of the time, hook his leash to your belt loop, this way he can not go off and use the restroom somewhere, and you don't know about it. 
3.Always take him outside after;
+ rough play 
+after he eats or drinks 
+after being let out of his crate
+ after he wakes up after a night
+ or if he shows signs of having to use the restroom,(below are those signs)
*sniffing 
*staring at you
*whining
4.Don't ever hit your dog, or rub his nose in his mess. This will just teach the dog to be afraid of you. 
5.Don't feed him or give him to much water, before you plan to put him in his cage.
6.Don't expect your dog to hold it's restroom, more than the age of the dog in months, plus one. But no dog should have to hold it's bladder more than a 7-8 hours.
7.Be patient!! That is the key, to housetraining. Of course if you get too overwelmed, you can always buy a book, or ask a professional trainer!
8.Always, when he goes to the bathroom ouside, give lots of praise and treats!!
9. If you expect your puppy to go outside, and dont use puppy pads when he gets older, starting out with puppy pads, is not a good idea, because this trains them that it's ok to go inside, and then before they know it, they cant, it is to confusing for them.
10. Make sure to have a schedule.
11.When you go outside, stay outside until he uses the restroom. 
Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Amanda
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 7987 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



They have very little bladder control at this age and need to be let out at least once every hour or two. Before bed, sometimes once during the night, first thing in the morning, IMMEDIATELY after being let out of their crate, after eating or drinking, after playing...he should be let out many, many times a day at this age, or there are going to be a lot of accidents. In his crate is one thing, but when he's out and about, he will need to go out a lot.



There aren't really any "tricks" to make him understand this faster. It'll likely be several weeks Or even months before you can completely trust him not to go in the house. Just consistently reward and praise him when he goes outside, and be extremely patient. He'll get it in time.



</answer>

<question>



How can I get my dog's confidence back?



My lovely gentle Flat-coat retreiver x collie was viciously attacked by a staffie in our woods the other day, and was wounded quite badly.
He was then sitting in our garden yesterday, when our neighbour's daughter turned up with her dog. We share a communal path, so don't have a fence, but as there are no other dogs in the neighbourhood within close proximity, I assumed he was safe from attack on his own garden, but this dog was not on a lead, and charged up the path, and my poor boy was attacked AGAIN.  Twice in 24 hours, and YES, it was another STAFFIE!!!!
 My dog is now in a state of shock, and is frightened to go out, even in the garden, and I'm worried about his mental state, as he appears depressed. He heard the neighbours (visitirs) dog barking, and hid under the bed, shaking with fear. He's off his food, and he's totally depressed. 
I know he's in pain from his injuries, but his depression seems to go deeper, and he won't even go outside the door now.
I intend to sue both owners, and as my dog was on a lead when the first attack happened, and on his own property when the 2nd attack happened, a solicitor I have spoken to believes I have a good case. 
I know both irresponsible owners, one of which has paid the vet bills for the attack in the woods, and as a single person, on benefits, with 3 kids, I hope it has hit her hard in the pocket, and taught her a lesson.
I have no concern for her, but how do I get my lovely dog back???



</question>



<answer from>



Susan B
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 2367 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is a very hard thing for a dog or any person to get over.  I suggest you sue and use the money to put up a fence so your dog can go out in your garden and be safe from passerby staffies!



http://www.seefido.com/html/the_fearful_...

ADD:  I would also learn clicker training, as this is a positive method of training and will set your dog up for many successes.  With success will come confidence.  Your dog may always fear other dogs though.  I hope you will work with this poor soul.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jared K
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Yogi and Me

<answer>



I agree with you..My dog was attack by a dog when the dog owner left him walking with a leash on but he was not hold it. I assume that he was harmless since the owner was causally talking with his back turned. The dog got a hold of my dog's side after she sniffed him. I think he's a pit mix and won't let go. The dumb owner pull his dog which make him clam down even more. That dog tore a muscle and my dog was in pain for over 6 months. Occasionally she still yelp if I rub her too hard (she gets massages) Funny thing is the next time she saw a dog, she was back to her old self, happy and wanting to greet and meet. I didn't let her. NO WAY. 
I'm sorry that happened to your dog. I would ask those owners to pay your medical bills to the least (i made a dumb mistake of not getting info from the owner, he denied the whole incident and claim that his dog was never out that day. what a jerk and an irresponsible owner?!) Anyway, I would really concentrate on building your dog's health first then self esteem. If he's in pain, he will not be willing to learn. I would try to ignore it when he is scare but praise him when he is being more confident. Like when he hides, ignore him then when he starts to move forward, away from hiding...Praise him. There's a book call Loved Dog that shows a lot of technique on how to build a dog's self-esteem. Also I would consider talking to a trainer to help with the esteem issue. 
Give him lots of time and praises when he's coming out of his shell. Only time will heal both mentally and physically. I really from the bottom of my heart wish your dog well. I've been there and I know how you feel. Good luck.
Link to the book and the author
http://www.theloveddog.com/



</answer>

Peter P

<answer>



We had a 3 y/o when we got our 2 new pups, so I was worried about that also... What I did.. well do. My oldest dog knows all her tricks and obedience but when I'm working with the 2 pups she still wants a snack to, so she's right in there with the little ones, sitting, standing...



Some say it's important to give each one their own separate food dish too, I don't know about this one, because my pups won't eat out of separate bowls. However my big dog does have his own bowl and it's up on a stand so the pups won't try to take over her dish too.

I hope that's what you meant... if not then just make sure all your four legged friends are present and accounted for before shutting the door :-)

<answer from>



Amanda
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 7990 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



As already mentioned, onions are toxic to dogs. Boiling it in salt is also not a good idea if you'll be giving it to your puppy. Before you give your dog ANY "human food," make sure it's something he can safely eat.

Please don't listen to the people suggesting you give her milk. Dogs naturally lack the enzymes needed to properly process cow milk. They are essentially lactose intolerant. Any more than a tiny amount will cause tummy upsets and diarrhea. At 7 weeks your dog has been fully weaned for a while now anyway, so I don't know here people get the idea that milk, cow milk no less, would be somehow beneficial to her.



</answer>



<answer from>



jazalici...
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 204 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



OMG don't do that you dog will get very sick!

Call Dr Phill



</answer>

<answer>



No, its not really good for him, coz of the soy sauce and onion and other spices in the soup, boiling some chicken in some water (without salt) is fine for the dog if you wanna introduce poultry or protein in their diet, but make sure that you shred the chicken off the bones, coz chicken bones splinter after you cook/boil them, also make sure you remove all connective tissue from the bones, since he is just 7 weeks you wouldn't want to choke him.

what I don't understand is why you wont give him boiled chicken, is it coz you eat it, is that a problem, coz it shouldn't be.

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



My dog has a real problem with overgroomong. ?



She licks and scratches herself all the time. We have varied her diet, we comb and brush her every day and she has been treated for mange. To no avail. Any ideas?



</question>



<answer from>



JessicaL...
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 2111 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Does she do this more during a certain season? It sounds very much like an allergy of some kind, whether it's seasonal or something in your house. My dog has allergies and has the same problem. It's something you probably want to talk to the vet about because they can give her meds and/or shots to help her feel more comfortable.



</answer>



<answer from>



Amazingw...
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 8614 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



My cat does this - we were so concerned we asked the vet about it and he said that some cats (and dogs) just get a bit OCD about the grooming thing or they can be quite senstive to things in the house, like the washing powder or other cleaning detergents or airfresheners we use can aggrivate them or there can be dust mites (every house has them) and those mites don't harm us, but to the animal it makes them have to lick and bite their fur like crazy.

My cat has bald patches on her belly where she grooms to excess.



</answer>



<answer from>



Alex K
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be an anxiety problem. Have there been any changes in her home setting recently? Have you been away a lot?



</answer>



<answer from>



Amanda
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 7990 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



I know you said you varied her diet, but do you mind telling me what foods you tried? 99% of pet foods you can buy at a grocery store, your vet's office, and Wal-Mart, have a lot of corn, soy, and wheat in them, which many dogs have bad skin reactions to. This is also true for at least 70% of the foods at pet supplies stores. So if you've just been trying different foods that all have these same ingredients in them, you won't see any change in her condition.

Some dogs aren't affected at all by these ingredients, and some just have a mild case of itching, but some dogs have their skin dried out and irritated to such an extent that they will constantly itch and lick themselves. Would you mind listing the brands you've tried? You're welcome to e-mail me with them if you'd rather not post here. I think her food could definitely be the culprit, but I'd need to know what you've tried feeding her to be sure, and to advise you further on which foods will get rid of her problem.



</answer>



<answer from>



hausie08
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 576 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It can be due to boredom or allergies or as someone suggested anxiety.  For allergy you will need to see a vet. For others you need to spend quality time with your pooch. When you leave and arrive home from outing or work, try to ignore the dog for at least 5 minutes. Give her regular walk. and carry out basic trainings at home. While you are out, give her a bone to chew and a toy so that she can spend time by herself.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kallan
Member since: 07 September 2008
Total points: 321 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A full workup for an itchy dog can take weeks if not months.

What was the treatment given for mange?  Was she treated for fleas also?  Ectoparasities are the main cause of itchy dogs seen by vets.

Next step once ectoparasites are ruled out is to do a food trial.  This could be quite difficult in your dog as you've changed her diet a lot.  To do it properly you need to speak to your vet, but basically you find a new protein source she hasn't been on before (e.g. venison, rabbit, duck - you can buy these allergen trial diets from the vet) and keep her on it for six weeks, with absolutely no other food at all - no tit bits, no chews - as doing so voids the test.  If she stops scratching at six weeks, you'll know she was reacting to something she was eating.  You can then gradually reintroduce her normal food, one type at a time, and when she starts scratching again you'll know what is is that's causing it.

If the food trial doesn't work, we move on to the intradermal allergy test.  Common things that cause allergies are injected into the skin under sedation and from that we can identify allergies to things like plants,  dust mites, or pollens.



If we can't find the source of her itchiness and have ruled out as many allergies as we can, the only diagnosis left is atopy, a problem with the immune system.  Unfortunately it is becoming increasingly common in dogs.

Coincidently, what breed is your dog?



</answer>

</answer>

<question>



Kennel Cough - how long will my dog have to be kept in?



Kennel Cough - how long will my pup be contagious?
My 17 week old pup developed Kennel Cough five days ago and has been on antibiotics ever since. How long do I have to keep her away from other dogs? She is very sociable and not mixing with other dogs is driving her mad. She is hardly coughing at all now, eating well, and as active as ever.



</question>



<answer from>

Deb mashed potato

</question from>



<question>



I have a very timid 5month bull arab, who even though she sees my grown sons regularly, feels threatened. Help?



We have only had her for three weeks and she was scared of everything but learning to be braver each day. Lots of socializing to aid this, however seems not to remember my sons even though she sees them regularly. Can anyone help us help her please?



</question>



<answer from>



emilyj85
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 558 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Let her settle, 3 weeks is nothing, it took my husky 2 years to accept my friend, she would hide when he came in, ask your sons to sit on the floor, make no eye contact or attempt to touch her, let her go to them, if she doesnt try again another day, she doesnt know or trust them, she is unsure of their ranking within the pack as she doesnt see them consistently ( all day, every day) so it will take her longer to know and recogise them, dont worry, just persevere with it, it will come, xxxx



</answer>



<answer from>



canineco...
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 247 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not sure what a bull arab is, but a professional trainer can help yu with socialization and desensitizing her to the things she's afraid of. In the meantime, don't let your sons pursue her if she's moving away- all contact has to be on her terms. Get treats she can't resist- start by you treating her for calm behavior, then your sons tossing treats to her(tossing closer to themselves as she gains confidence), until she can take them out of their open hands. They should avoid standing over her, eye contact and petting until she is ready. You want her to be asking for petting from them before they try.



</answer>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13490 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



What's a "bull arab", sorry I've never heard of that breed, is it a cross?



Unless your "grown" sons live with you they are not "family" they are "strange men" to your dog.



Many puppies can be very timid, and "strange" people don't tend to be trusted. If you think about it, it's very sensible when you are that small and defenseless.



Don't worry too much, as she gets older and better socialized, then she will begin to remember them and welcome them as family. If you allow your sons to make a fuss of her (she should approach them, not the other way round) using a LOT of bribery (toys, play, food), she will definitely remember them quicker as a source of nice things.



</answer>



<answer from>



Konstantinos A
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 663 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



you should euthanize it before something bad happens to your son

<question>



How long a walk is needed?



How long per day should i have my dog out for, she is a 3 year old springer spaniel ( how long on the lead & how long off the lead)



</question>



<answer from>
Member since: 22 November 2007
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



most people say to walk you dog for about 45 min a day. Most of the time it depends on the bread and the age and how much they do in the first place.

<answer from>



X],,*aNiiMaL cRaZii3,,*[X]

<answer>

<answer from>



ryma

</answer from>



<answer>

http://dogtime.com/exercise-needs.html

<answer from>



sazziiee...
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

Off Lead ~ 10 minutes.



</answer>



<answer from>



Stan Man
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 587 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



As an owner of a very active springer spaniel, I can tell you that my own dog needs at least 3 hours of walking/jogging in order for him to be bearable at home.  dogs may need more or less.  Usually 1 hour is spent just walking around the neighborhood, the other 2 hours are him running around an open field while still on a long retractable lead.  I'd recommend at least 2 hours of daily walking for this active breed of dog and you can take away or add on more exercise depending on what your dog needs.  The walking shouldn't be the only form of exercise for a springer.  Ball fetching, going for hikes, and agility are also things I do with my dog to keep him healthy physically and mentally.



</answer>

<question from>



alaska_a...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do I treat dog wounds?



I have a year and a half old maltese who has a superficial wound just above his paw on the left back leg and could really use some advice on how to treat it.



</question>



<answer from>
Member since: 22 November 2007
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



bring it to the vet if its that bad a vet should take care of it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tid
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 396 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's 'surgical' water in most first aid boxes, wash it with this, and stroking only in one direction, and using clean cotton wool each time per stroke. If you don't have the water in the box, boil water and leave it cool and do as above. Dogs have enzymes in their tongues to help cure superficial wounds, hence we're not running down to the vet every minute.
Hope your dog is ok!



</answer>

<question from>



Artydude
Member since: 12 January 2007
Total points: 284 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



My Yorkshire keeps going potty inside..?



I have two dogs, a yorkshire silk terrier, and a "chorky", or Chihuahua/Yorky mix.
The smaller younger dog, the Chorky, she is great. She does not bark or potty in the house.



But her father, the 3 1/2 year old York, he is fixed, yet every once in a while, anything from a printer on the floor, to a garbage bag.. anything new or that smells like food im guessing, he will pee on. And he also poops in corners or by the carpet.



Every single time, I put his nose up to it, yell at him, smack his nose, and toss him outside, and when he comes back in I give him time out in the Kennel.



I Just don't know what to do any more. It has been months, and it does not matter how loud I yell, how hard I smack him, how long I keep him outside or in the Kennel... he just does not get it!



What do I do?



Also just to clarify, these dogs are very well taken care of. I am young and don't have kids, and they get treated as though they were my kids. There are loved, pampered, and I make sure they are let out frequently, walked often, and fed properly, as well as groomed and bathed.
I am not neglectful of my animals. I have a cat, two dogs, and a 100gal fish tank. They all get taken care of!



</question>



<answer from>



frankie1...
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there!
Firstly, I would advise putting an end to the punishment you are giving your dog for his mistakes. So many owners use the nose-in-the-muck strategy, and it can feel frustrating that it doesn't work. This is because your dog does not understand why he is being told off.



Secondly, your dog may have an underlying physiological problem. Have you taken him to the vet and explained your problem?



Thirdly, the best course of action is to crate train him, just like you would a young puppy. This fantastic method of training is neither cruel nor unfair and is the fastest way to stop your dog from using your house as his toilet.



All the best, and good luck!



Source(s):



Zoology BSc & Dog training experience



</answer>



<answer from>



missinhi...
Member since: 17 May 2008
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



For starter punishing your dog with yelling and smacking him is not the answer! When you scold you dog like that he feels he has to "hide" his business i.e. the corners. the fact that he is peeing on anything new means he not feeling comfortable in his environment, and he needs to mark his territory. I had a basset/corgi mix that was the same way! he may be feeling threatened by the other dog or cat. it will take time and lots of supervision. When the dog uses the restroom take it directly outside and praise it when it does its business.. A lot..I mean get super excited and try treats...when he goes in the house try putting him outside with whatever he has "messed" on. Watch for any signs of needing to potty, and if your not sure take him out anyways. Its all about praise..your dog wants to feel important. when you get excited he gets excited...using a stern no is okay if you miss the signs, but do not , put his nose in it, yell, or smack him, hopefully this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



irishbal...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i also have a yorkie and he also pooped and peed in the house all you haft to do is let him out every hour if he poops and pees give him a treat if not kennel for a hour after about a week he'll start to get it and he'll go to the door when he needs to go



goto www.housebreakingmypuppy.com/yorkie



</answer>
