<question>



Is it dangerous to have a protection trained dog with kids at home?



is it dangerous to have a protection trained dog with kids at home?



</question>



<answer from>



Miff Buster
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 1469 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



PROFESSIONALLY trained? Nope.
Some amateur fooled with thing? YES!



</answer>



<answer from>



emilyj85
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 558 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



How old are the kids??  Who is it protecting?? Do you know the specific commands that the dog relates to when protecting??  How old is the dog?? Where did it live, in or out? Has it ever been domesticated before?  Lots of questions before this can be answered honestly



</answer>



<answer from>



ainawgsd
Member since: 28 March 2007
Total points: 10385 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



If you ask the insurance companies, it is dangerous to have a protection trained dog period.  Personally, if the dog is mentally sound and stable and PROPERLY trained I think a trained dog is less likely to bite than one who isn't because they have been taught under what circumstances it is appropriate to bite.  However, if you are at all concerned about your kids (or don't have a lot of money to spend on insurance...because most insurance companies won't insure you or will charge through the nose with a dog trained to bitework) then don't get one.  Few people actually *need* a protection trained dog and most dogs are naturally protective of their pack and territory.



</answer>



<answer from>



Owned by Rocco the staffy.
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 4721 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with Miff's answer.



If the dog is trained professionally he will protect the whole family and be great with the kids.



</answer>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13490 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends.  Is this, for example, a police/army trained dog living with the family?  If so, then there should be no problem. Police dog handlers have their dogs with them 24 hours a day, with, and without, the family.



If this is an amateur trained dog, trained to enhance aggressive tendencies rather than a well rounded obedient dog that just happens to have been trained to guard as well, then, No, definitely not.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ring of Uranus
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 6101 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on who trained it and what it thinks it's protecting.



If it's a pro trained dog and it thinks the kids are the clients they will be safer than they would be if left with their parents



</answer>



<answer from>



Schnoodl...
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 9610 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree - the only dangerous protection dogs are the ones home trained by people who want a guard dog but don't want to spend the money on professional training.



A protection dog with professional training behind it will be perfectly fine in a family environment - much like the police K9s who are brought home at the end of a shift.

<answer>



A professionaly trained protection will be fine as long as it has been socalized around children.  Dogs properly trained in bitework are actually less likely to bite (inappropriatly) than the average household pet.



Trying to train your own dog with out knowing what you are doing or using a less than reputable trained is another story and a dog trained imporperly could be a danger not only to children but to everyone.

Ang
Member since: 23 October 2007

<answer>



The person above me is correct, a dog that is CORRECTLY and RESPONSIBLY trained in protection is less likely to have an accidental bite happen.  This doesn't mean that this dog can be left alone with young children ( no dog should be)... any dog should be accompanied by an adult when there are young children in the room, accidents can happen at any time.  If the dog is correctly trained and has the nerves that it takes to actually get titled in a protection sport he/she should be fine around children... provided the dog has been socialized around children.  You know who could answer this question to a T.... Greek Man.... ashame he's no longer with us isn't it.

<answer>



Have his thyroid checked and have the skin biopsied for autoimmune.  Does he have draining tracts around the anal opening? Sounds like this guy needs a full work up including blood, urine, feces and skin.  Even a bad veterinarian can do some of this stuff.

<question>



What should i name my new dog?

its a male



</question>



<answer from>



Trixie L
Member since: 08 September 2008

<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 276 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are lots of medication available to battle a flea infestation but you have to consider that your battle will not be won overnight. In most cases, it will take at least three to four weeks to completely rid your dog of fleas, and you will need to stick it out if you want your treatments to be effective. Please visit the following link for more information.



http://dogtime.com/flea-control.html
http://dogtime.com/flea-control-tips-aah...



Hope it will help.



</answer>

<question from>



lolli&po...

</question from>



<question>



Why do some Jack Russell Terrier's ears stick up?



You know how Jack Russell Terriers are supposed to have floppy ears, like this:
http://www.new-pup.com/images/jack-russe...



And the  some Jack Russell Terriors ears stick up, like this:
http://www.dogbreedinfo.com/images8/Jack...



Why?



And no bullying please, thats not what Yahoo answers is for.



</question>



<answer from>



PomMom♥...
Member since: 24 July 2006
Total points: 42488 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Prick ears are a fault and a disqualification.  Prick ears are a poorly bred dog.  They are called Parson Russell Terrier, by the way. Not Jack Russell Terrier.
http://www.akc.org/breeds/parson_russell...



Source(s):



de



</answer>

<original file>16560.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk7292.txt</current file name>




<category>

<question from>



Dear Abby
Member since: 15 March 2007
Total points: 1060 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How long will this last?! (kennel training)?



My husband and i recently got a puppy, yay! We decided to put in the work for crate training her, but I'm curious: we put her to "bed" tell her "good bed" and leave without emotion or any attention after that. It's been shocking to find how loud she can get and how long she can go on with crying. I do let her out every couple of hours to go outside and play for a bit. Her bed is comfy with her own blankie and there's plenty of room. She goes on for SO long and it is really hurting our ears. She has done this for over two weeks and had *seemed* to be crying for shorter periods of time until a couple days ago (i swear nothing changed) and she seemed to learn how to get louder and go on for even longer. It sounds like she's in immense amounts of pain (there's no way she can be, nothing in there is painful!) and she also throws herself against the sides sometimes.



I want to do what's best for my Annabelle, but it just seems to have no end. We've had her for almost 3 weeks now and she is 2 months old. and she's a min pin/mexican hairless mix. Do we keep doing what we're doing or WHAT?!



Thanks for all help and advice!



</question>



<additional details>



sorry for the confusion-we got her at 6 weeks. I said *almost* 3 weeks.



</additional details>



<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13490 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



She's 8 weeks old, and you've had her for 3 weeks?  You got her at 5 weeks old?  No wonder you are having problems!  The tiny breeds do best when they stay with the mother/siblings for at least 10 weeks.  But it's too late for that now.



Sounds like you have a VERY stubborn puppy.  Keep hold of the thought that she will -eventually- settle down and accept the crate.



Buy all the family ear plugs and persist with the training.  The more attention you pay her while she's in the crate, the more she will go on yelling.



At the moment -she- is training -you-.



Try a -very- well wrapped hot water bottle and/or a ticking clock.  With warmth and a heart to sleep against she may (only may) settle down quicker.  A big blanket that she can snuggle right under is necessary as well..



</answer>



<answer from>



Jasmine
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 6771 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do you ever take her out while she's crying?  Can't give in to the crying.  What kind of crate is it, big enough, plenty of ventilation?  Make sure the crate is not in an isolated place.  Don't put her in there too much.  Only bed time and when you can't supervise her.  Might want to treat her when you put her in.  Put a couple of her toys in there too.



</answer>



<answer from>



kazzyb37
Member since: 02 February 2008
Total points: 2202 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I feel that you have had your puppy too young.  Puppies should be a minimum of 8 weeks before they leave the litter.  Have you actually read up on crate training?



</answer>



<answer from>



the_char...
Member since: 05 December 2007
Total points: 1116 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



lol she doesnt want to sleep in there obviously, she wants love affection and attention.



</answer>



<answer from>



Acheron Hades
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 238 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all , you are definitely doing the right thing for your dog. Crate training is healthy and important for any dog, as it makes housebreaking easier, reduces separation anxiety, and keeps a puppy away from dangerous objects in your house. A crate is good for traveling in, and can be moved around your house if need be.



If you train your dog at a young age they will grow up to appreciate their crate. I have three dogs, and when they are resting they all like to go "in their house" to take a nap or lie down (Especially my elderly lab)



Here are a couple of things you can do to make this a positive experience for you and your dog:
1)  Every once in a while (when your dog is not in the crate) drop little pieces of food or treats in the crate. This will help your dog associate the crate with something positive.
2) Feed your dog in the crate. I cannot emphasize this enough.
3) Praise your dog when she enters the crate! Don't force them into the crate bodily. Treats are always very helpful! I have very food motivated dogs, so this works best for me. Try and find something that really motivates your dog; do they love pleasing you? Do they love a particular squeeky toy, or a certain kind of treat? One of my dogs will do ANYTHING for a little piece of cheese.
4) Start out crating your dog for short periods of time while you are home with her! Put the crate in a living room or other area, and crate them while you are watching TV. If she is resting and not whining then reward with treats and praise. If she crying just ignore her. Don't even make eye contact until it stops. Crate training is best done when you are there with your dog. This way they don't associate the crate with always being lonely.



Make sure you take off a dog's collar when you crate them (it could be dangerous! I had a lab puppy who got her collar stuck in the bars of her crate...she was one unhappy little doggie!



Also try and make sure your dog has bathroomed before.



Hope that helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



Anni D
Member since: 14 November 2006
Total points: 195 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When we got our dog she did this too, but i had many cherished stuffed toys around so we decided to give her one as a "bed buddy" ... she chose a pink elephant.



also puppies can be full of energy ( as you're probably finding out) i say run her ragged so that she curls up n falls asleep on the floor.



when you let her out to play, are you playing with her or are you detached from that as well? ....you need to nurture your animals.



i hope this has helped.



-Anni



Source(s):



Trial and Error



</answer>



<answer from>



slickmic...
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 5654 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



is she in the same room as you?  if not, she might be freaking out since she's alone.  we made that mistake with our springer - we left the crate in the kitchen.  didnt know they could howl that long that loudly.  we had to give in because we had gone 3 days without any sleep and the neighbors were complaining - it was THAT loud.  after that, bedtime was in my mom's room, and she was fine, and the crate was just for when we had to leave her alone, which she didnt mind at all.  it was just when she knew we were home and she couldnt get to us.  our newer dog is the same way.  we had to stop crate trainning with her too because she ripped a dewclaw off and broke a tooth on the bars, but she stays in the basement and howls and screams like a banchie if she knows we're still home, but if we're gone, she's fine and will just go lay down.  its craziness



so i guess what i'm saying is that if the crate isnt in the same room with you, try moving it to your bedroom so she's near you.  you can also try getting a clock that ticks and putting that in the crate with a "dirty" shirt of yours so that she can keep smelling you (and the clock acts like a heartbeat)



good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



JEANNE C
Member since: 11 November 2006
Total points: 2802 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Achron Hades pretty much said it all.  Great suggestions and advice.  Although I wouldn't actually put her food in and let her eat her meal in a crate, just snacks and treats, but that is my opinion.



I can only add make sure your dog is well exercised.  This will tire her.  Lots of praise, and positive reinforcement when she is good.



Good dog and treats, not so good dog...ignore.  She sounds a little stubborn and is tryng to "train you", but be firm and be the "Alpha" and don't give in and she will learn.



</answer>

<answer>



Poodles or poodle mixes are very good with children.  German Shepherds can go either way.  I've seen a German Shepherd attack a boy.  I grew up with a Peek-a-poo.  He was amazing with us kids.  My parents currently have a tiny toy poodle.  He is great with kids and cats.  My parents don't have a cat but when they take him to places with cats he always does well.  Also, poodle mixes are good for people with allergies and they do not shed.  Good luck!

<answer>



Almost any dog could be good with cats and children as long as you get it when it is a puppy and it grows up with other animals/children. I would only stay away from small "yippy" breeds and really energetic dogs. Such as greyhounds, maltese, rat terriers, chihuahuas, etc. Good luck!

I have a mutt that is GREAT with children and any other animals.

<answer>



Boxers that have been with their mother for at least 60 days.

<answer>



If you get it as a puppy, keep the puppy and the cat close together for a little bit every day. Dogs usually get used to them and pay them no attention as they get older, they are simply a part of the environment.



I know they get a bad reputation, but boxers and pitbulls are the kindest, sweetest dogs you will ever have. The stories you hear about are the owners mistreatment of them (raising them to be mean). I worked at a pet store for years, and I never once met a pitbull or boxer that didn't wag it's tail and act like a big baby. And when properly trained, they are very obedient.



</answer>

<question from>



Nathan Loves Maverick
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Im A Junior Handler With My Dog.?



And before we got him into shows he was trained on level 4 obedience and every time i stop he sits he cant sit in a show how can i get him to stand any answer accepted thank you. Btw He Is A Australian Terrier.



</question>



<answer from>



Alisha S
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 1030 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



With a level four obedience, he should know the "wait" and "stay" commands.  I like to use wait, just as a technicality.  Wait means there is another command to come, while stay is the end of the command.



Tell him to wait BEFORE he gets a chance to sit, stepping in front of him may help.



It will just take time and practice.  You need to somehow differentiate between show time and obedience time.  Different collars and leads, treats, etc.



Most of all, have fun!



Source(s):



Owner and trainer of many pedigree dogs:
Cocker Spaniel
Labrador Retriever
Siberian Husky
Miniature Schnauzer (2)
Shih Tzu
Australian Shepherd



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you bery much its alot of help



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Nancy M
Member since: 09 June 2007
Total points: 13834 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



I am not sure what you concept of 'level four' obedience is, but it is novice level for a dog to learn a stand for exam and in such, to be told to stand and have his legs positioned and allow himself to be examined.  Simply use your obedience stand command and if you want him to adjust his feet in the breed ring (good thing to train as well) you can give him commands for that as well.  My dogs are trained obedience as well as conformation and have no issue at all discerning the difference as well as utilizing the commands from obedience to show in differing ways.  It is all simply training, repetitive, consistent, motivated training.



</answer>



<answer from>



Divapom
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 1232 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



When I was young I had an Irish setter that I showed in both Jr Handling and Obedience.  When working him always use a different leash and collar for obedience & Conformation.  When you stop him immediately move to the front, face him and bait and stack for conformation.  When you do obedience you stop square and look ahead.  The way you move in conformation vs obedience will also give him a clue as to what you want. If you are consistant he will soon learn the difference of what you want in a very short time.



Source(s):



Used to show obedience & conformation



</answer>



<answer from>



Nekkid Bootie ♪♫
Member since: 15 June 2007
Total points: 44533 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



You will have to work with him to correct that.  When he sits tell him "no, stand" and put him in a standing position.  This may take some time and practice to get him to do this.



Try using a different type of collar and leash for obedience work and showing to help him differenciate between show time and work time.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 270 (Level 2)

<category>



Pets

</category>



<question from>



doglover
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



My 12 week old jack russell puppy has a bloated tummy..!?



she seems happy and healthy in every other aspect apart from her tummy.. I took her vets and they gave her worming treatment and the worms passed through, she went back again for a second treatment but nomore worms. she seems to have a bit of trouble with her hind legs almost like she is to heavy for them to carry her, I have another dog that is well n healthy so i kinda know a bit about dogs and i know i am not over feeding her. she has vets on thursday for her jab but any ideas you can give me to put forward to him would be most helpful.
Also, my friend has her sister and she is alot bigger then my one. the breeder said my one was the runt..!!



many thanks



</question>



<additional details>



many thanks for all replies.. she has been treated for fleas and so has my other dog.. this was done about 2 weeks ago..



</additional details>



<answer from>



Julien Poublon, vet
Member since: 30 July 2007



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



Worm infestation is, by far, the most common cause of bloating in young puppies.



I understand that he passed worms following treatment which shows that he has been in contact with worms.



I recommend that you carry on with regular worming until resolution of the bloating. Also check the puppy (or in contact pet) for fleas as they can be the source of tapeworms.



Best wishes, Julien



s



</answer>

<answer>



We feed 2 different brands of dog food. We buy a premium brand for our show/companion and working Great Pyrenees and usually buy 4-6 bags at a time. One 37 lb bag (they are getting smaller!) lasts 6 Pyrs and 1 Whippet (my wife's traveling partner) about 3-4 days.



Purina donates dog food for our rescue program and we get about 250-300 lbs at a time if I remember right (don't quote me on that weight). It is hard to track that food because the number of rescues varies and also their eating habits but I think that a 25lb bag lasts 1 Great Pyrenees about 10 days or so



Source(s):



http://www.WhiteFirePyrs.com
http://www.GPRNC.org



</answer>

<category>

<question from>



there_sh...
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 349 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What breeds do you think my dog is?



He's around 7 months old, 50 pounds and a shelter dog so I don't have any clear idea as to what he could be. Guesses?



http://www.flickr.com/photos/there_she_g...



http://www.flickr.com/photos/there_she_g...



http://www.flickr.com/photos/there_she_g...



</question>

<question>



How much to feed Chihuahua/Jack Russell mix?



Hi,



I just got a chihuahua/jack russell mix from the shelter. She is 12 lbs. and I started feeding her Cesar Cuisine's, how much should I give her in order to maintain a healthy weight? All help is appreciated.



</question>



<answer from>



there_sh...
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 349 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most pet foods have feeding guidelines on them by age and weight. It's best to follow those.



</answer>



<answer from>



Linda S
Member since: 24 October 2006
Total points: 782 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A chihuahua/jack does not have a very big stomach so you would feed it about a cup of food a day at twice a day intervals. You may wish to check out this link, toward the bottom of the page shows the scale for feeding a dog of your size. I hope this helps out.



http://www.dogbreedinfo.com/feeding.htm



Source(s):



http://www.jackrussell.net/faq/faq/feed2...



The Intellegence of Dogs by Stanley Coren
How to Speak Dog by Stanley Coren
Be a Pack Leader by Cesar Millan
Scared Poopless by Chic Lett A Dog
Living over 40 years with dogs and puppies as well as numerous other animals for roommates and friends. Oh, and living with my fiance too.



</answer>



<answer from>



sparrow_...
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have found that the feeding guidelines on pet food are only good advice when the food in question is good quality (not the standard supermarket varieties).  The general rule is this: 1 cup of dry food per 30 lbs of animal, per day.  In a wet food, this would translate to about 156g a day per 30 lbs. If your pet is more active, give him/her a little more.  If they are less active, give them a little less.  If you have an overweight animal, or your pet gains too much weight, don't just assume you need to put them on a low fat diet. More often than not, they are overweight because of how much they are being fed.



Source(s):



Working in a holistic pet supply store.



</answer>

<question from>



Puppy Advice
Member since: 15 October 2008

</question from>



<question>



HELP! What is the best way to stop puppy biting, FAST??!!!?



Okay, so i have a shih tzu 3 month old puppy, and he constantly bites me when he sees skin. And its not just me, its like anybody. Its like when he sees skin its like "biting time!" to him. Whats the best way to do it without doing any of these?
-hitting/slapping
-kicking
-hurting in anyway
-yelling
-yelping a puppy-tone



PLEASE HELP ME! THOSE ALL DONT WORK! but, i dont do the harmful things, thats cruel, just the yelping and saying 'no' doesnt work.
Got any ideas how to stop my pup, Nick?



Oh, and if this helps, he's teething, but he bites me not because of that, because of playing.



Please Help! Thanks! Best Answer is ten points!



</question>



<additional details>



I DONT WANNA BE MEAN AND I AM NOT BEING MEAN TO MY PUPPY!!
thanks!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Mimi999
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 216 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Young dogs like yours will bite to 'play', but you have to show him early on that it's not allowed.



If he's teething, buy him Pedigree Denta Stix, to keep him from chewing other things.



My friend also has a 3 month old shih tzu that is also prone to biting, however it doesn't hurt and it's because he's teething.



If you have a cage for him, this is the time to use it. (If you don't, go and buy him one)



What you should do, is once he bites, say no, pick him up and put him in his cage. Leave him there for the rest of the day, no matter how early it is. He will eventually learn that it's his biting that's doing that, and he'll most likely stop.



Hope this helps!!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks! I think this is a good idea! And its worth giving a try, i bet! :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Stephanie V
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 219 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I forget who it was that told me this, but I heard it a long time ago. Puppies, ESPECIALLY, love to bite hands the most, mainly because thats what's usually always closest to them. Whenever one of my puppies bit my hand, I used my thumb and pressed gently down on their tongue. It causes them to open their mouth, PLUS they don't like that the thing their biting is doing something to their mouth either! It works, That along with a vocal command would work I would imagine!



</answer>

<answer from>



missy101...
Member since: 04 April 2007
Total points: 1965 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Puppies bite. This is normal behavior and it is important for puppies to experiment with biting so that they can learn not to bite too hard and then not to bite at all. They need to learn how to control their jaws and develop bite inhibition so that if they are in a stressful situation and they bite before thinking about it, they will be able to control the bite and hopefully not bite hard by mistake later in life.



Puppies learn about not biting too hard from their mother and litter mates. If one puppy bites too hard and another one squeals, all the fun stops. If a puppy bites Mom too hard, the lesson may be a bit harsher.



Watch this video that shows how roughly puppies play. You do not want your puppy to play this way with your or with your children. Notice that when the Newfoundland puppy squeals the other puppy lets go immediately. Also note that when the Newfie loses his patience and shows his teeth, the other puppy runs off and bites the child off camera. This is a redirected bite: she doesn't dare bite the Newf again because he is getting angry, but she wants to bite so she runs over and bites the closest child. This is a young puppy and cannot do much damage to an older child, but a baby or toddler could be injured quite severely by sharp puppy teeth. It is a good idea to keep babies and young children out of the way of a wound up puppy and to keep stuffed toys handy so that the puppy always has something appropriate to bite.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chalice
Member since: 13 March 2007
Total points: 28051 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



There IS no quick fix. There are methods that work, but you gotta give it weeks.



It's normal for puppies to bite and mouth. This is how they explore things. So don't punish him for it because it's just normal behaviour,  he's not being naughty.



He'll grow out of it. You can assist this by saying NO loudly when he does it, or OUCH or whatever and just taking your hands away. Put them behind your back if necessary, anything so he can't get hold of them. Then shove a toy in his mouth so he learns what's acceptable to bite and what not. Have plenty of chew toys from him to play with, and persevere.



Consistency and TIME are the only things that get puppies over this, you're not going to solve it just like that.



Chalice



EDIT: It is NOT OK to hold him down when he does this. This is something you do with aggressive dogs, you don't do it with a puppy exhibiting normal behaviour, you'll just encourage aggression!



If you want to modify a dog's behaviour you have to first understand why he's doing it, and clearly most of the other answerers have no clue. Don't squirt him with anything either - DON'T punish normal behaviour! In fact, punishment is pretty much an obsolete training method in general.



Source(s):



vet nurse, feel free to email



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Who does spaying refer to dogs or cats?



I want to know if spaying refers to dogs and if neutering refers to cats.



</question>



<answer from>



Ista
Member since: 26 October 2007
Total points: 17374 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Spaying is for female animals. Neutering for males. Cats and dogs alike.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bassetnu...
Member since: 28 June 2006
Total points: 68292 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Spaying refers to de-sexing a female dog or cat.



Neutering technically refers to either sex, but is commonly used for the male. The more correct term is castration.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kris M
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 2011 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



spaying refers to any female animals surgery to prevent pregnancy



at work we spay cats dogs rabbits rats and guinea pigs



males are neutered



Source(s):



vet tech



</answer>



<answer from>



IS YOUR NEWF GELLIN'
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 40508 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Spay...females
Castration...males



neuter....either



</answer>



<answer from>



lt;3_Gizm...
Member since: 04 July 2006
Total points: 11698 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



spaying is for females, dogs or cats, and neutering is for males, dogs or cats. its not a animal thing its a gender thing.



</answer>



<answer from>



Single Worker 1230
Member since: 23 July 2006
Total points: 10227 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Spaying typically refers to desexing females and neutering to desexing males.  It doesn't matter if it's dogs or cats.  The terminology refers to the sex of the animal.

Lady Bug
Member since: 14 February 2008

<category>

<question from>



Jackie.
Member since: 01 May 2007
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Help with my now nervous dog.?



My dog has always liked people. She was always a little shy around men and other dogs but quickly warmed up to them. Recently, the neighbors dog tried to bite her face. The neighbor thought they were playing and laughed it off. Luckily she missed and we haven't been around that dog since. But now shes scared of everyone and everything, except for us and our cats. Shes fine around children, but only the ones that are not scared around her and are excited to see her. She is a Staffordshire Bull Terrier aka The Nanny Dogs.



Is she going to be nervous around people and other dogs forever now? We socialize her a lot with our friends and other neighbors and anyone she meets at the beach. I just hate seeing my Marley scared.
any help?



</question>



<additional details>



http://i36.tinypic.com/1zwothc.jpg



added a pic just cause i like showing her to people.



i have a ton of friends that have nice dogs that she can socialize with.



i am never bringing her near that other dog. i dont even talk to the neighbors. they are the definition of bad neighbors. loud, rude, they haven even brought drug dealers to the complex. i dont think they would be to fond with our dogs bond. unfortunately, i think they want their dog to be like that. poor doggie.



</additional details>



<answer from>



David L
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 3215 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hire a dog trainer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweetpea Pom
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 496 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I love Staffies.  Little dogs with big friendly personalities.  I'm sorry she has had this experience.  I am no expert on dog psychology but I think that you need, if at all possible, to take her to socialisation classes so that she mixes with other, controlled, dogs that she does not know and with people that she does not know and who can help you and Marley recover.  Marley may well be picking up on your nervousness around strange dogs too which you can work on.



I would talk to your vet, see what clubs are around you.  Or if like me you live in the middle of nowhere, talk to friendly owners of other dogs to ask for their help in resocialising your precious girl.  Life is too short to spend it afraid.  Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Miguel G
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 93 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



its fine, all you have to do is keep on socializing it with that same dog that tried to bite her, and eventually she'll know that theres nothing to worry about. however u have to be alert and have both dogs on leash incase of a fight.



my puppy almost got bit in the face from another dog, and at first he was terrified with his tail between his legs, and whining, but with staying with him and the other dog on leashes he realized that the other dog wasnt going to do anything else, and eventually wagged his tail. and started playing with the other. this will most likely work.



if not ur dog is traumatized.

<question>



Maybe I'm a little behind the doggy times...?



Ok, I have to know, what is a troll?  I keep reading about it here on Answers and I want to be in the loop!
I just read the answers to this question, which made me laugh my a** off, and troll was mentioned frequently, along with maltishihpuggadoodlepoms.



:)



http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;...



</question>



<additional details>



now I feel so much more informed!  I just started using Answers a couple weeks ago and was really stunned by some of the qQ's I saw asked, now I know why.  I especially enjoy the rating system and names you have given the different types of trolls, Heather.



And Forest, you sparked my memory! My dad drove trucks for years and I do remember now he told me about people doing stuff like that on the CB and how irritating it was.
thanks all!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Bonzie12
Member since: 06 April 2007
Total points: 25852 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



An Internet troll, or simply troll in Internet slang, is someone who posts controversial and irrelevant or off-topic messages in an online community, such as an online discussion forum or chat room, with the intention of provoking other users into an emotional response or to generally disrupt normal on-topic discussion.



</answer>



<answer from>



Forest Basenji
Member since: 10 October 2007
Total points: 8471 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Someone who posts stuff (here, or anywhere on any Internet forum) that's designed to stir the pot and get a reaction.



An example would be, "What can I feed my Pit Bull to get him ready for a fight?"  Chances are, NOBODY is fighting their dog, it's just a bored kid wanting to rile people up.



Back before the Internet, when CB radios were all the rage in the 70s, there were (and still are) people who do the same stuff.  They're called "agitators" on the CB.  I drive a truck & you still have them pretty much all over the place.  Most are bored truckers sitting in truck stops talking about controversial subjects (politics, race) trying to get people mad.  The saddest cases are the grown men sitting at home with base stations, spending entire days doing nothing but "agitating" on the CB.  These sad sacks evidently haven't found the Internet yet, or they'd surely be "trolls" on any given message board!!



LOL...just goes to show, I think "trolling" behavior is probably part of human nature- there are always small-minded class clown types who get a kick out of disrupting things.



</answer>



<answer from>



Heather R
Member since: 15 May 2007
Total points: 7411 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



a troll is someone who posts something to get people upset or disrupt the normal use of the site.  they exist to make the other users miserable.  there are actually several breeds.



thumbs down troll: gives everyone thumbs down to annoy them
points troll: answers questions with i don't know just to get the points
attention seeking troll: puts outrageous responses or questions to get people upset



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweetpea Pom
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 496 (Level 2)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer>



LOL



Someone who purposely makes up Q's and A's to invoke personal responses-- just to get a reaction.



I had to look it up when I first came here too. :)



It's like if someone asks "Hi, my dog just licked up my cocaine, and I want it back! How can I get it out, it was expensive!?" When it's not true-- they just want people to get angry so they can have a laugh.



http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;...

<original file>826.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk83172.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



Kayla L
Member since: 09 April 2008
Total points: 89 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dealing with male dog "marking"?



I adopted a 3 yr old neutered male dog. But he marks everywhere, he has gotten a lot better; however I want to bring him in as an inside dog. Has anyone had any success with stopping this habit? I have a spayed female  as well...



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



This is entirely normal.  Your pup has a new home which he is claiming as his and things should settle down as he becomes adjusted to his new home.



When bringing him inside, I highly recommend that you tether him to you as much as possible.  When he cannot be tethered to you, tether him to a piece of furniture (or other like object).  This way, the dog is never unsupervised, he'll become more bonded to you and he will not have the opportunity to mark.  Then, when you take him out for potty time, have an absolute party with lots of treats when he does his business outside.



Good luck and congratulations on adopting a new dog!



Source(s):



vet tech 15 years



</answer>

<question from>



Deirdre M

<question>



How often should I brush my dog's teeth? ?



He's a 1 1/2 year old Yorkie. His teeth are pretty white except I can see some plaque that's green. Also, why do cats have shiny, white, clean teeth and no bad breath, but dogs don't?



</question>



<answer from>



dyllis
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 813 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ah cats do have dirty teeth and bad breath too!



brush at least once every 2 days. everyday is best of course



</answer>



<answer from>



buick
Member since: 27 June 2007
Total points: 1142 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



teeth and breath differ from dog to dog and cat to cat.  I've got a dog right now with perfect teeth and sweet breath and I brush the teeth rarely, but the dog I had before him had horrid teeth and terrible breath.  I was brushing him twice a day and giving him special tablets to help out the breath.



Same goes with cats - I've seen some filthy mouths and some sweet ones.



Point is, you can brush as much as you feel necessary.  Just be careful on the pressure.  His gums are gonna be more delicate.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jen J
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 2430 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



The answer is: as much as you possibly can.  Small dogs, and especially dogs like Yorkies, have a very tight teeth conformation which makes plaque and tartar formation very easy and frequent.  Brushing is a great idea, but I would also feed your dog LOTS and lots of healthy chew treats such as beef tendons, buffalo achilles, fish skins and things of that nature.  They do a phenomenal job at keeping the teeth naturally clean and these items are extremely safe too.  I purchase all of mine at www.k9rawdiet.com and with a dog as small as a Yorkie, you should be able to feed a wide variety of tendons since you have an economical dog in that regard &lt;grins&gt;.



Good luck!



Source(s):



vet tech 15 years
canine nutritionist



</answer>

<original file>899.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk83252.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pets



Dogs



</category>



<question from>



babycake...
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 322 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



HELP HELP HELP I NEED HELP!!!?



one of my pekingese eyes are really really red i have no idea with it could be maybe she hit her self or something got in it what can i do to help she isn't acting like it hurts or anything whats going on?!!?!?!?!



</question>



<answer from>



Mary c
Member since: 11 May 2007
Total points: 5159 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I grew up with a Pekingese, from the time I was a little girl until after I left home.  Because their nose is smooshed against their faces (and so there is a little ridge between the eyes where goop and matter collect) and their eyes bulge, they can get stuff in their eyes, scratch their eyes, or the matter that collects in that ridge can marinate a little infection.



Everybody else's responses are correct.  The best thing you can do is get your dog to the vet -- not because she is in any danger, but because it will happen again, and you need to find out how to handle it.  But there are some things you can do to help your dog a little.



Get some artificial tears or -- if you wear contacts -- some isotonic saline solution, take her on your lap, draw the lower eyelid down and  spritz a couple of drops in the ridge that opens.  Then take a warm, moist  washcloth, and clean the ridge her nose creates between her eyes.  In some dogs it is more pushed up than in others, but clean it by gently and repeatedly dabbing the area.  Matter from the corners of her eyes can drain out onto this spot, and then it collects bacteria.



Once you have done these things, you can take a clean, warm but not hot washcloth and just apply it as a compress over her eyes for a moment.  She should find this soothing, and it may help relieve any discomfort she might be feeling.



Particularly since she is not showing any signs of discomfort, this is not an emergency.  But it is a problem to which this breed is susceptible, and you need to consult with the vet so you know how to handle it when it crops up again.  Also, there is a chance that it could be the beginning of a serious infection, and that being the case, you need to nip it in the bud.



Hope this helps.  Good luck.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I didn't find a 24 hr vet but i did take her a showers and she loves that also i cleaned her eyes and made sure i put some eye solution in it. she's fine but we  still made an appointment for the vet tomorrow. Thanks this really helped i wanted to at lest do something now befor i took her to the vet



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ic14u
Member since: 08 March 2008
Total points: 499 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There should be an emergency vet.
They will need to clean and flush it immediately otherwise you may cause blindness to the Peke,
Whatever went in her hit it hard since they are flat face.
Please dont risk it and google a 24 hr vet in your area.



</answer>



<answer from>



Banks

</category>



<question from>



Reece
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 93 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How heavy will my pitbull get?



hay i have an 11 month old rednose pitbull. hes very lean. i walk him everyday. i would like to know when they start ther filling out stage and how heavy they recon hell get. hes 55 pounds at the moment. thanx



</question>



<answer from>



Bonzie12
Member since: 06 April 2007
Total points: 25850 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



The APBT ranges in size from 22 pounds to 110 pounds (rare), with the most common being between 35 - 55 pounds (16-25 kg.), in fact the original APBT's were between 20 - 40 pounds (9-18 kg.) and were bred small for their main purpose, fighting, These dogs are varying from small to extra large.  A very common misconception is that APBT's are muscle bound (viscous) hulks that weigh in around 85 pounds (39 kg.) and this is generally not the majority, Most of the APBT's that Are that large have been crossed with another breeds.



</answer>



<answer from>



there_sh...
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 347 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



First year they grow up, second year they grow out. He'll probably top out at about 70 pounds, he's already quite heavy for a pit bull. By the way, red nose means nothing (neither does blue nose) it's not a special breed of pitbull it's just their color.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kev
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 938 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



a purebreed pit bull should be 65 lbs standard max although its not uncommon to be heavier. 55 lbs is a good weight, he will probably gain about 10 more depending how you feed him. Keep him lean and ripped like a real pit bull and not bulky like american bullies.



</answer>



<answer from>



Giovanna R
Member since: 10 March 2007
Total points: 4618 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should put a picture up. I love Pit bulls. If he is already 11months maybe about 60 or 65 pounds



</answer>



<answer from>



The Sh*t
Member since: 16 July 2007
Total points: 16438 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Male pitbulls usually get to be around 65lbs with ranges typically between 50 and 80lbs.



At 11months your dog should be just about full grown he may make it up to about 60lbs but I wouldn't put him at much more than that.



</answer>

<question from>



Malorie2...
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 60 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Should I get my dog a play mate?



I am a huge dog person.  I have a 1 year old male Maltese/Shi-tzu puppy and I am wanting to get another puppy.  My dog loves to play with other dogs and though he doesn't get left at home a lot by himself I still think he would do really well with a playmate.  My dog is housetrained, but lately when I leave him alone in a room, he will use the bathroom in the floor and eat his poop, but only when I leave him by himself, so I was thinking maybe if he had a playmate he wouldn't do that.  I really want another dog, but I don't want my dog to feel like I'm taking the attention away from him cause he's a very special little guy to me.  Can someone please give me some advice.



</question>



<answer from>



Lolli_ro...
Member since: 02 September 2007
Total points: 255 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A playmate is REALLY good for a lonely dog. It helps the dog develop social skills and often times good behavior. It sounds like your dog needs one. Go to your local dog park and take him out for a stroll. I wouldn't let him run around just yet, let him get to know the environment first and if he crosses ways with a few dogs, let them sniff each other.



I hope that helps! Good luck!



Source(s):



Me! ^_^



</answer>



<answer from>



oregano1...
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 27048 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



Other - Pets



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have the time and $ to care for a second dog, go for it.  Just make sure you truly have the time to give attention to both and the $ for two times the vet bills, two times the emergency fund, two times the food, toys, chews, and so on.  Adding a second dog to my home was the best thing I ever did, she's wonderful, my existing dog loves her, and they can self-entertain for a while while I actually get things done around the house instead of being the sole entertainment source.  Be sure to choose your new companion wisely.  Badly bred dogs tend to have temperament issues and you will want to avoid that, so look for an adult of known temperament from a shelter or rescue or a well-bred purebred from reputable breeders who health-test their dogs prior to breeding (ask to see OFA, BAER, and CERF certificates on the parents.  if they don't have them, leave.).



As far as the poo eating, there's a couple things you can look at to stop that.  First, check the ingredients in his dog food.  Does it contain wheat, corn, or soy products, or non-specific byproducts of any sort?  If so, that may well be your problem.  Foods with lots of indigestible fillers such as those I named will taste pretty much the same going out one end as it did when it went in the other end.  Plus dogs fed on lower-quality foods may eat their stool to compensate for nutrients they are not getting out of their food.  Should a food change not help, it may be that it's already a firmly established habit for him.  Try feeding something like Deter with his meals that will make his poo taste bad, or giving him fresh pineapple at each meal (which will do the same).



</answer>



<answer from>



Giovanna R
Member since: 10 March 2007
Total points: 4618 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Every dog needs friend. If you have the money and attention for another dog, then go head and get another one.



</answer>

<question>



Best way to remove eye discharge from my dog's eye?



My dog has facial paralysis on the left side of his face which has left him unable to blink his eye and excess eye discharge has been building up. The vet prescribed him medication to produce tears and fight off infections but she didn't explain how to remove the excess discharge off his eyes and I don't wanna leave it there to build up because I'm sure that wouldn't be good for him.



I've been using a paper towel moistened with warm water, is that ok? Should I be using something else?



</question>



<additional details>



I don't really know what Alegre_123 is talking about. My dog's discharge is due to his inability to blink so its become irritated. My dog has issues blinking so the vet gave us medication to give him to replace the tears and fight off infection. So i'm not looking for anything else just a way to clean off the discharge safely.



I understand discharge is healthy but the discharge my dog is having isn't. It is green and it stays in his eye it doesn't actually go to the corners of his eye because he cant blink but he can still see. The vet said he can't even feel it because of his facial paralysis so it doesn't cause him discomfort.



Any ways to help clean discharge still floating in my dog's eye? I don't wanna injure his eye even more than it already is.



And he is 10 year old poodle-lhasa mix so its kind of difficult to anticipate what ailments they will or won't get.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Shih Tzu Mom
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 2468 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A soft piece of gauze or bandage  wet with warm water would be idea to clean the corner of his eye.  If you use a cotton ball, you might inadvertently get a tiny piece of the cotton 'string' in his eye and irritate it more.  Anything around the eye you must be extra careful, and what might be ok to use elsewhere on the body would not be good for eye useage.



Good luck with your dear 'baby'



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks so much!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Gina G
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 2177 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A cotton ball with warm water or  Saline Solution.  You can call the vet to check with him.  But usually it is a cotton ball with warm water or  saline solution.  I think the pet store may have saline solution for dogs.  Cotton balls are gentler.



Source(s):



myvetonline.com

<answer from>



Alegre_1...
Member since: 18 October 2008
Total points: 262 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pet owners want the best for the pets and that includes keeping their pets healthy by trying to prevent diseases and illnesses and treating them when they occur. Unfortunately eye infections are fairly common in pets. They can crop up on their own or occur when something lodges in the eye. They can also occur when the surface of the eye, called the cornea, gets scratched.
The common warning signs to look out for that your pet has an eye infection are: eye discharge, squinting, redness, cloudiness, and trying to rub and scratch the eye. Rubbing or scratching of the eye can make things worse for your pet. One of those cone shaped instruments that covers the head will prevent your pet from rubbing their eyes and further irritating the condition.



Eye discharge may be ugly, but it's a valuable warning sign that something is wrong. This is important because infections can progress very quickly and even in some cases cause permanent eye damage. Discharge is a telltale sign of infection and will often be thick, yellow, gray, or green. Any off-colored eye discharge that persists for longer than 48 hours without improvement should be seen by a vet.



Infections of the eye and surrounding structures are common in pets and usually involve the conjunctiva, leading to conjunctivitis or "pink eye."



PNP Healthy Eyes Eye Wash for dogs is a veterinarian formulated sterile ophthalmic eye washing solution that gently and effectively washes and cleanses the eyes. Our veterinarian formulated dog eye cleanser wash is designed to prevent canine eye infections and be a gentle yet effective general purpose cleaning solution.



PNP Healthy Eyes Eye Wash for dogs relieves irritation and discomfort caused by debris and other irritants including pollen and is specially formulated for sensitive eyes. A great product to have on hand for emergencies and general maintenance. Provide you dog with a gentle yet effective dog eye cleanser wash from Pet Nutrition Products.



PNP products are manufactured under Federal cGMP guidelines to ensure Quality, Purity and Potency.



For use on dogs



Nature's Herbs for Pets Clear Vision for Dogs - $ 22.99
Natural herbal formula for dogs and cats that benefits many eye conditions including infections, dryness and conjunctivitis



Causes of infections include various bacteria, viruses like the Herpes virus, foreign material or irritants in the eye and even Lyme disease. Eye infections may become chronic if not treated and can cause permanent damage such as blindness if neglected.



Some dog breeds are more likely to get eye infections than others. Before you get a dog, research its breed to see if they are more prone to eye infections.



</answer>

xoxbeaut...

<question>



Whats wrong with my puppy? He only eats one kind of the mixed food?



My puppy almost all the time eats only one kind of the food in the puppy mixed food. Whats up with that??



By one kind, i mean there is like small amounts of square pieces of food in it and larger amounts of the circled peices. He only eats the square amounts like most of the time. The circled pieces he just wont eat.



Should i change puppy foods? If so, whats a good kind to change to?



(i think i give my puppy the brand 'puppy' or 'puppy chow'



Oh, and what brands should i NOT give my puppy?



thanks! and ten points for best answer!!!



HELP!!!!

<answer from>



sugar_pi...
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 595 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think the mixed kibbles are usually crappy brands. I'd talk to your vet about some healthier kinds of food.



If you really want your dog to eat that food, I'd just leave it out. He'll eventually get hungry enough and eat it. If not, you can try mixing it with warm water or some wet dog food to make it more appetizing for him.



Kibbles N Bits is a really bad brand of food - I definitely wouldn't recommend that brand! Dogs love it, but only because it's like junk food for them, yuck! Good luck! :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>

it's okay to change your pup's food if you don't think it's right for him, though right now, he's just being a bit picky.he'll eat when he's hungry whatever it is.
just don't change foods often. i've been told it isn't good for their digestion.

<answer>



This should get him to eat it. Get his favorite people food like, say... cheese. Take the cheese and melt it in the micro and immediately mix in the dogfood. Make it so that the dog can't pick it out. My dogs LOVE cheese and have been known to eat cardboard pizza boxes to get the cheese. This works well with wet or dry. You could also put some people-food gravy. Try that and consult with a vet. You don't have to go in or anything, just call in to a vet's office that's nearby and tell them what's going on. They're usually really helpful for these types of problems. Good luck!

Seasoned breeder.

<answer from>



LetBlues...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 180 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm a dog trainer, I have had this problem with many dogs. They are just not use to it. They won't start off on regular hard dog food. Get the brand Cesar dog food, its in small cans but it has a meaty texture to it. It's soft. And then as time progresses mix in hard dog food with the soft food and make the switch slowly but surely. Any type of soft dog food closely related to meat will please his appetite.  If he doesn't take the soft food, put it on a plate and pretend you are eating it, maybe its just a mental thing. Hopefully he doesn't have any type of dog flu, but sounds like he has a healty appetite, just not used to dog food, best of luck!



Source(s):



DOG TRAINER



</answer>



<answer from>



emilyj85

<answer>



My friends staffy did this, put a bowl of dog food down, leave it there for half hour, if he doest eat, remove  it, do the same the next day, leave it for 25 mins, remove it, next day, 20 mins, then 15 and so on, dont make a big deal out of it, dont look at him or speak, just do it, it took my friends dog 5 days, dont treat it in between or let it get away with anything human, you will just have to start over again if you do this as the dog will think it is getting its own way again, I guarantee it starts eating dog food in no time, a dog will not starve itself, they are natural scroungers, (unless it is ill of course) he may drop a little weight, not much but dont worry, he will soon put it back on when he realises that unless he eats this food, its either gonna be taken away, or he is gonna starve, good luck x



</answer>

<answer from>



jalford1...
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 13482 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds like a thoroughly spoilt, fussy dog - been there, done that, got the t-shirt.



Now, it is absolutely true that a dog will never allow itself to starve if food is available. You need to start with the tough love regime.



Choose a tasty dog food, one of the "Complete" dry foods.  Smell it, if it smells good to you, it will smell good to the dog.  Before you feed the dog, boil your kettle, add enough hot water to the biscuits to make "gravy", leave the bowl to cool down to "warm".  Give the dog the bowl. Leave the bowl down for about 20 minutes.  After that time, pick the bowl up.  Do this, if you can and are at home, breakfast, lunch and supper, at least until he starts eating (you have to give them a chance to get hungry).  Once they start eating, change this to 2 meals a day [divide the day's ration up into two].



Throw out any uneaten food after 24hours (don't think of this as a waste, you wouldn't have it if the dog had eaten it, anyway!), you can warm up the morning/lunch time food for the other meals if he doesn't touch it.



The trick is, is to find a food that (at a pinch) you would eat yourself (it smells good enough, rather than actually eating it).  Most "dog" foods are totally bland, have hardly any smell and is boring as anything to eat.



The other half of this regime is NO TITBITS ever, from anyone - if your household has more people in it than just you - drum this rule into EVERYONE. No handouts from the table, no cleaning up plates, no "snacks", no scrounging from dustbins, no wolfing down "nasties" on walks. NOTHING apart from the food offered in his bowl



</answer>



<answer from>



SDB
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



He's probably just being stubborn, try him with different doggy food - dried and tinned.  Put his food down for an hour or so, then take it away from him - show him who's boss in that he eats when you tell him to not when he chooses.  If he's a healthy pup, it wont matter if he misses a few meals, once he starts getting hungry he's sure to start eating.  Please don't watch him eat just leave him to it.  Whatever you do stop giving him human food unless its very plain (ie boiled white meat, unsalted pasta/rice, boiled unsalted veggies etc).  If all else fails, and he still isn't eating after a few days, take him to the vets to make sure there's nothing physically wrong with him.  I'm sure its just the trauma of changing homes though, and he'll be fine once he gets used to the new surroundings and routine.



Source(s):



Doggy owner



</answer>



<answer from>



Ritchell...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 270 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



These days, home cooking for dogs is back. After the spring 2007 scandal about contaminated pet food, which led to the deaths of hundreds of dogs and cats, many people decided that the only way to trust the food they give their pets is to make it themselves. But keep in mind that dogs with certain health conditions have different nutritional needs, get guidance first from a vet.



http://dogtime.com/giving-people-food-to...



Check this link for the dog food recipes.



http://dogtime.com/dog-food-recipes.html



Hope it will help.



</answer>

Helping people to get a dog neutered?

<additional details>

What are the eligibility criteria?



To be eligible, pet owners need to live within the defined catchment area of a PDSA PetAid hospital or PetAid practice and must be receiving financial help with their housing costs through either Housing Benefit or Council Tax Benefit. This means that one in five UK households is eligible for help by PDSA.



i think you must be working with the wrong PDSA if you don't  even know the scheme!



</additional details>

<answer>

<answer from>



IS YOUR NEWF GELLIN'
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 40508 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



The problems is that it seems people can afford to BUY a purebred dog, but then it gets time for vet care and they suddenly can't afford it.  I work at a low cost spay/neuter clinic, and I see people DAILY that paid for a dog breed of their choice, and then want help spaying it.  I also see them with their nice cars, and the whole family dressed in name brend clothes, and it just seems they can afford what they want, but are looking for help with other things.
Personally, I think if you are on benefits, you probably do not need to have a pet, but anyone who gets a pet has to budget for the costs.  If you get a puppy and save $20 a month, you can get the dog spayed pretty much on time.



</answer>

<question>



Hey my dog is 8 years old. How much is that in dog years?



she's getting grey hairs O.O

<answer from>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



its usuerally 7 human yrs to 1 in dogs.so he is 56. my husky will be 8 next month and other than sleeping a little more he is just as active and wants to play like he use to, but is a little slower.big dogs have shorther life spans where as small breeds can live up to 16 to 18 yrs. with good food and excersize along with lots of love ur dog could see another 8 yrs and be full of grey hairs.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Aprilayd...
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 1942 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't just multiply by 7, it's more complicated than that. A 3 week old pup can be more less advanced than a 7 year old child and a 3 year old dog could be more advanced than a 21 year old human.



This website does a conversion thing for you. However, it still really depends upon the size/breed of dog etc.



http://www.onlineconversion.com/dogyears...



Incidentally... I've had grey hairs since I was 11!



</answer>



<answer from>



hellonle...
Member since: 17 May 2008
Total points: 10678 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



1st year a dog apparently ages by 9 yrs ( so I have read ) so if that is true, you would work it out as :



1 X 9 = 09+
7 X 7 = 49



----



58



if it's not true then the age is 8 X 7 = 56



</answer>



<answer from>



Anti- Barbie
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 1976 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Media & Journalism



</answer from>



<answer>



The general rule of thumb is one human year is 7 dog years but this has to be adjusted for the size of dog as generally larger dogs don't live as long as smaller ones.



</answer>

<question>



Suggested Breeds of Dogs?



I currently have a 2 year old male Pit Bull, who I want to get a playmate for. I want a different breed and a bit smaller but I don't want something so small that my Pit can't play with it so I was wondering if anyone had any breeds in mind.



My boy stands at 21" tall and weighs about 65 lbs so I want a dog that will be at least 15" tall. Also I do not want a long haired dog. I was thinking of a Boston Terrier or a Lemon Beagle but I heard Beagles bark alot and I cannot stand a dog that barks all the time.



Does anyone have any suggestions??



</question>



<additional details>



I would also like to add that I am looking for a dog that is a good family dog (good with kids) as I have a 5 year old sister and my fiance has young cousins/nieces and nephews that the dog would be around.



My dog has been around all sorts of other dogs, male and female. My brother has a male mastiff/rotti/pit mix and my dog does try to hump him when I bring him over but I just pull him off and tell him no and he stops. He's not an aggressive dog, he's very much a wimp when it comes to that.



I don't have a fear about how he will be with another dog because he absolutely loves anything he can play with. He loves cats, he's played with Chihuahas, Yorkies, Shepards, other Pits, kittens etc.



I'm really grateful to have such an awesome dog, and he sets such a good example of how Pit Bulls are such loving and silly dogs that don't deserve the rep they've got.



</additional details>

<answer>



Well, you could get a bulldog. They are about 40-50 pounds and would be a good playmate for your pit. Below are two links, the first is specifically about bulldogs. <answer from>



puplovet...
Member since: 27 August 2007
Total points: 2919 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



With a male pit you'll want to get a female (spayed of course) as male pits, like many terriers and other male dogs, tend to be same sex aggressive. Some Pits, and other terriers are dog aggressive in general so be sure to closely supervise the pair once you get the 2nd dog until you are absolutely 150% sure this won't be a problem.



I would visit your local shelter and find a submissive female. Once you have your choice/s take your Pit and introduce him to the possible new pack member/s and see how it goes.



Much will depend on your ability as a strong pack leader but some will depend on the two dogs' natures.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 28 June 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)

<answer>



What about a bull terrier or miniature bull terrier?
Bulls stand up to 20 inches while mini's stand up to 15 inches. They are sturdy and could hold up to a pits rough play. I would get a female, just because males usually allow the female to be dominant and it can cut down on squables. They have a clownish personality and get along with just about any human big or small. They are one of the most entertaining dogs there are. They have minimal exercise and grooming requierments  They can be dog aggressive but if socialized properly and raised from a young puppy with your pit should be managable. Since your pit turned out so well I'm sure you can handle it ^_^



</answer>

<question>



Bichon peeing in bed..?



I have a six month old Bichon. She has slept in bed with my boyfriend and I since we got her about 3 months ago. Lately, she has been peeing in our bed..at the foot (thank god). We take her out right before bedtime  - 1030pm - & cut her off from drinking water at 8pm. What do you think the problem could be?



</question>



<additional details>



she is in her crate 8+ hours a day while we are working..what makes you think that we are cruel enough to make her sleep in a crate for another 8 hours? we enjoy her sleeping with us & believe she enjoys it too! :o)



</additional details>



<answer from>



cougarde...
Member since: 15 April 2008
Total points: 1418 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



problem is she is in your bed and not a crate



</answer>



<answer from>



john n
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 7743 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



sometimes pups get in such a deep sleep that they don't know when they are peeing and the warmth and softness of ur bed is sootheing. she is coming into the heat stage and her hormones are changeing also. have her spayed and if she continues have her urine checked for infections. sometimes its just a bad habit and u will have to take her out through out the night before she gets to the time her bladder is to full and she can't hold her urine. u could place a baby diaper with the tail cut out for a few nights and see if it is wet in the am then try to make her go a little later before bedtime. as she gets older she might have better control and the cozy bed won't cause her to have any more accidents. good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Yumi Kikimoto
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Seriouly, It would be best to take her out of her crate in the morning. If you walk her enough, she'll get aroung fine. Since you let her sleep IN the bed, she probably thinks the bed is her terriory, and shall mark it whenever she pleases. Don't let her sleep in your bed anymore. If you really would like to be with her at night, get one of those portable fences, and keep her in the room, but AWAY from the bed.



</answer>



<answer from>



JEANNE C
Member since: 11 November 2006
Total points: 2802 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, now that she has peed in your bed, you will have to clean it to get "her" scent out"  She smells her scent, she thinks she can keep going there.  Or you may even have to get a new mattress.  Try Nature's Miracle to see if that will get it out.  You will probably have to use it quite a few times before you get the mattress thoroughly cleaned.  And you may never get it all out, which is why I said a new mattress may be needed.



Secondly, it is not cruel to crate a dog.  If done properly, they see their crate as "theirs'  and a safe place, and like to be in it.



Just because she seems to hold her urine during the 8 hours she is in the crate during the day, it may be harder for her to hold it while sleeping.  Taking her out late, and taking her water up early certainly is doing the right thing, but you may have to take her out later or sometime in the middle of the night until she gets older and old enough for her bladder to be able to hold if longer.



But she has marked her territory (not just a male thing),  and she thinks it is ok to go where she is going.



If none of that works-cleaning, replacing, crating or walking, I would then take her to a vet to make sure there are no health issues or problems.



Source(s):



Do rescue work for a dog rescue and have 2 Tzu's



</answer>

<question from>



[&lt;3Punk]

<question>



How do you know if you Cat/Dog really loves you?

This is what my dog's foster mother wrote in response to another question similar to yours last night:



They always forgive you even if you make the mistake and yell at them.



When you are sad and they come to love on you and make you feel better.  They never judge you and accept you for who you are.  You love them unconditionally and them you.  They never argue with you and what ever you say or want to do they will go along with it.  WHY?  Because they love you.

<answer from>



jennifer w
Member since: 19 March 2007
Total points: 2154 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've always heard that if given the chance to run away and they don't then they love you and are happy.



I also recently read a story written by a vet,  One of her patients was a 5 year old Irish Wolfhound.  Apparently the dog was in the final stages of cancer, and she volunteered to put the dog down in the comfort of its home with its family.  The parents opted to allow their 8 year old son to watch.  After the procedure the son was the only one not upset.  He was sad, but was doing really well.  Everyone started talking about why dogs have such short lives, especially compared to humans. The son spoke up with the answer.  He said that humans try their whole lives to learn how to love.  Dogs are born with that ability, so they don't have to live long without love.



The story brought tears to my eyes.  Dogs love unconditionally.  We need to make sure we are deserving of it.



</answer>
