<question>



Any puppy commands please?



Im am teaching my 10 week old puppy to be "good" and have had some helpful tips off here when i asked about his agression the other day.He is doing pretty well toilet training and had him on his first walk yesturday and done well tho cryed to be carried most of the time.He knows his name and is getting used to the word NO.I am using the noise teqhinque at min where i have put stones in an old gravey tin and shake it whenever he is naughty or being aggressive . It seems to be working as hes been much well behaved past few days. He is sittng to command and rewarded with treats. Do any of you have any good techniques that have worked for you? As i am worried in time the shaker may loose its effect.



</question>



<answer from>



vegachan...
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some good commands would be stay and lay down and fetch. They're really energetic and usually love chasing things. Cats, their tails, etc. Just simple things. The whole 'roll over' and 'beg' are a bit too complex for a 10 week old puppy and would probably be easier to teach at 4-ish to 5 months. The noise technique works well. Usually a quick clap will startle them if the shaker doesn't work or isn't handy.



Source(s):



Seasoned breeder



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 270 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Got my 13 week year old puppy 2 weeks ago. =]
So far he knows sit,and he knows when hes doing someting wrong!
What about a different type of stones - like smaller to make a more tinny noise? or bigger to make a deep noise. Some people say no and avoid eye contact for a couple of minutes.



This is a detailed website with Information on lots of aspects on trainig...
http://www.asah.net/behavior_topics_33.h...



</answer>

Linda_Do...

Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



I love clicker training -- it is positive and you reward the good behaviors and basically ignore the bad ones.



Yes - you definitely run the risk of the "shaker bottle" becoming too normal and the dog losing it's fear of it.  But then again - why do you want to scare your dog?



Bad behavior should not be quelled by shouting or tossing a shaker bottle - unless it is a dangerous behavior for your dog or towards another dog or person.  You need to re-direct his behavior into something positive.  I could enroll in a dog obedience class -- hopefully clicker-based if there is one in your local area.



I have encosed a clicker training link.  Good Luck with your new puppy!!



Source(s):



http://www.clickertraining.com/dogtraini...



</answer>



<answer from>



Newcastle 4 lyf
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Woof Woof !



</answer>



<answer from>



ryma
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,



Teach him some basics every dog should know:



Sit
Down
Stay
Come
Walking on leash



Here are some guidelines that will make training easier for you and your dog:
1. Be consistent.



2. Start simple and gradually make it harder.
3. Don't repeat the command.
4. Use food treats as lures and rewards.
5. Time it right.
6. Make rewards sporadic, then phase them out.



Just make sure to make your training fun! :)



Check out these links that can help you train your puppy:
http://dogtime.com/training.html
http://dogtime.com/basic-commands-obedie...
http://dogtime.com/get-dog-to-enjoy-trai...



Hope this one helps.



Enjoy!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweetpea Pom
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 277 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



People do look at me strangely but I growl at my puppies when they are doing something I don't want them to do - ranging from a quick soft growl to a full on throaty growl when I am really cross.  I did this with my Rottie and it worked a treat and now with two Lab puppies and they really take notice.  It must be instinctive.  I also use a really loud hand clap to immediately take their attention away from something when they are nearer.  The only form of physical training I use is a push if they are nipping (just enough to push them away from me) or if they have done something like bite rather than nip and I can do so straight away, I will hold them in a submissive position.  Any physical training is only ever enough to get a result and is only what pack leaders would do in a group or in the wild.  It is far far gentler than the rough and tumble they get up to together!  It is firm, quick and as soon as they 'realise' what they have done wrong they are welcomed back with a quick bit of positive attention and then I turn away and start the training again.  Never hit, raise a hand or let them do something one minute and then tell them off for it the next.  Firm, consistent and with kindness.



Source(s):



I live too far away from civilisation for puppy training or socialisation classes so I have had to do it myself this time around.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mutia A
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 345 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, when my german shepherd was still a puppy, he loved to playbite. So, whenever he playbit, I would start making a loud growling sound at him and he would be startled. After a few weeks of doing this, he stopped. Another thing about my other puppy, who is a dobermann, was that he liked to bark essecively. So whenever he barked without reason, I would dump a bucket of water over him. After that, he never dared to bark too much again.



Well, here are the basics a dog should know-
1. Sit
2. Down
3. Come Here
4. Heel
5. Stay



Here are some things that would be fun for your dog to do-
1. Give me your Paw
2. Beg
3. Jump
4. Speak
5. Roll Over



And there are about a thousand more tricks that dogs could do.



</answer>

<question>



Dog attacking and don't know why...?



One of my dogs has been attacking the other for no reason lately.  He's a Jack Russell/Chihuahua mix, and the other is a Rat Terrier.  They've gotten along very well for the last year and a half.  All of a sudden, he started attacking the Rat Terrier.  I've racked my brain trying to figure out why he's doing this and can't think of anything except for the fact that he's not fixed and the other is.  They're both males.  Can anyone help me? I'm getting a little frustrated coming up with ways to keep the separated.



</question>



<answer from>



hdwildon...
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 1023 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



He needs to be fixed,he wants to be pack leader that's why hes fighting.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sybil C
Member since: 08 August 2008
Total points: 3573 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Get your aggressive dog neutered. Also every time he attacks your other dog, make a loud noise to distract him and crate him or place him in another room. He will learn it isn't acceptable behavior.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chiko
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



he might be trying to become the alpha dog
make sure you give both of them the same amount of attention
they're just like kids
they get jealous very easily
like when you come home instead of greeting one first greet both of them at the same time
or play with them together instead of individually



</answer>



<answer from>



Krissii
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 737 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most likely they're fighting for dominance. Is the Jack Russell the younger dog? I have the same situation- My labrador/Border Collie will attack my Jack Russell/Miniature Pinscher.



Dog's do fight, it's a natural thing for them. As long as one dog isn't killing the other, and the dominance behavior isn't transfering to you or other people, there isn't much to worry about. Your dog's will sort things out themselves.



If you're really worried, you can get him spayed. To help them figure out exactly where they belong in their pack, give the dog who you think is more dominant(more often than not the larger, or, if they're the same size, the older dog) more attention than the submissive one. It might sound harsh, but that's the way it is in the dog world.



Most likely the Jack Russell has gotten to an age where he wants to put himself above your other dog, and the other dog isn't taking it.



Best of luck with your situation.



</answer>

<question>



Dog question (for coursework)?



Care seeking behaviour on the part of a puppy ensures that his mother (and perhaps other members of his group, including people) take care of him. One such behaviour is vocalising.



In what other ways might a puppy engage in care seeking behaviour?



</question>



<answer from>



coax_me_...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 2451 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Jumping up on you for attention
Chewing on your pants/shoe/sleve of your shirt
Laying next to you and putting thier head in your lap while looking up at you
Jumping or pouncing on you
Licking your hand/face
Rolling on thier backs and kicking thier feet in the air



</answer>



<answer from>



Mizzle
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 198 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



All of the above....
Also in the wild, with wolves etc the pup will constantly lick at the mothers mouth and get her to regurgitate food for it!



</answer>

<question>



How can I tell whether our dog is in fact a Cavalier King Charles/Terrier X or something else?



We rescued this dog from the pound and were told she was a cavalier king charles & terrier cross, however looking at cavalier king charles spaniels they are much smaller & have shorter noses!  How can I tell for sure?  She is 9 kg, brown eyes, white/blonde fur with a few brown speckles.  I wish I could post a photo of her on here which wld be easier.  She has a very loving & quiet nature, hardly ever barks & is very loyal & gentle.



</question>



<answer from>



coax_me_...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 2451 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sadly the way shelters normally breed a dog who's orgin is unknown is by getting all their employees to look at it and take their best guess. Look up the breed standards for a Cavalier and see if anything seems to fit your dog, and ask your vet what they think. If her mom was bred with a larger dog with a long nose she could very well be a cavalier mix.



</answer>



<answer from>



Pamela D(midget12_
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 4933 (Level 4)

</answer>

<question from>



dancingl...
Member since: 27 March 2006
Total points: 424 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Some advice regarding my dog please?



I have 2 dogs who love each other dearly (ben and Gizmo) but unfortunately Gizmo doesn't like other dogs too much.  He doesn't attack them as in bite but he will snap at them.
my mum also has 2 dogs who are lovely and get on fine with any dogs.
We want to try to mix our dogs as it will make things a lot easier when either of us want to go away anywhere (so the other can look after all the dogs at their house)
Does anyone have any advice as to how I can bring all our dogs together without Gizmo snapping at my mums 2 dogs every 5 minutes?
Thanks



</question>



<additional details>



Gizmo is 6 and has been with ben since he was 9 months old.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Jenna S
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



walk them on the leash. Get your mom to walk her dogs and you walk yours and keep enough distance that yours cant go for the other one, get him used to walking with it then over time walk closer and closer eventually so they walk side by side, dogs are pack animals and success is in the walking. Then time to let them both off in the garden and leaev them to it to sort out their differences, no doubt your dog wants to be the alpha, this is something once they are aquainted with walking they must sort out between them



</answer>



<answer from>



Krissii
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 737 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



As slowly as possible. Introduce the snapper to the pack on a leash, or even through a screen or glass door if possible. Eventually, Gizmo will accept the other dogs as part of his pack. Obviously, he is the boss of Ben, and maybe even slightly protective of his buddy, so he is wary of others taking away from his time with Ben, and challenging his dominant role.



I gather Ben and Gizmo have been alone together for most if not all of their lives? Generally, dogs who live with one other dog aren't really socialised with other dogs, even though they live with another dog. Because of that, sometimes people are a little suprised when their dog isn't overly friendly to other dogs- especially older dogs, who really don't like change very much.



Best of luck with your dogs!!



</answer>

<question from>



♥Dr. Holly Girlfriend™♥

</question from>



<question>



GEtting Akita to back off while eating.?



I've finally got my 5 month old Akita to pee on her paper or ask to go out, to stop pulling on walks, and almost stopped knawing.



I knew this was going to be an issue when her owner said "oh she eats anything. She cleans my kids plates off". Now she thinks she is entitled to anything and everything we eat. I have told her no sent her away put her in another room... She ignores every command and comes back. She'll do ANYTHING to get at the food. She tries to sit nicely as if she should get a treat for this.



I was feeding her 3x a day because when I got her she was very skinny. You could not only feel her bones but see them threw her fur. I'm guessing her previous owners couldn't afford to feed her properly. Since then she's put on about 5lbs and her bones are no longer jutting out. I stopped feeding her 3x and went down to 2x because she wasn't coming close to finishing her food.



I basically went down to working part time just to have the time to fully train her so she is getting 3 20-30 minute walks a day along with going to a tennis court and running after the ball.



I'm not sure what to do about the food issue. I've never had a dog that didn't get the point, and believe me I fostered about 60 dogs. Even my husband who she obeys completely she will not leave him alone.



</question>
